Challenges and constraints of restructuring

\r\n

The most difficult task concerned the merging of two companies

column114: with different cultures and technologies. The merger involved all business units of the two companies. The two sales teams had to sit together in one room
column115: and share experiences and secrets. In the service field it took some time for them to acknowledge each other

AMSY had to make people believe that there is no redundancy

column120: and most people who left the company caused some damage – either financially or to company reputation. One colleague had to move from service to sales and did not work at all. It was obvious that personal ambitions separated workers

Implementing a strategic action plan

Sándor and Gergely identified three priorities for future development:

  • Introduction of ISO-approved quality policy and practice in two years’ time.
  • ISO-approved safe working conditions and healthy environment in six years’ time.
  • Sándor plans to write a non-compulsory ‘founding deed’ about the principles of a company that can grow
column197:
establish new business branches and survive the challenges of times.

Commentary

This case shows that establishing and building a company is a complicated process. Managers can undervalue difficulties and time pressure
column198:
which forces them to change several areas very quickly. The case has some general implications:

  • It is necessary to have professional advice and support from someone who has directed several mergers or acquisitions;
  • The organisational structure must be changed and flexible in order to receive new employees;
  • The company must be well prepared in order to avoid losing too many clients;
  • It must handle cultural difference as top priority
column199:
and make employees believe in the future;\r\n

The restructuring process was carefully planned

column83: a competencies model and systematic and targeted training. The empowerment process involved a lot of preparation
column84: as well as delegating certain functions
column85: negotiating
column86: and coordination with people. It followed the classic steps of ‘plan
column87: do
column88: check
column89:
act’. This is not a quick process since empowerment cannot be forced through; it has to be agreed. About half the employees were directly involved in the process of restructuring. About ten people who were already managers now got more authority.

\r\n

The first step in the process of empowerment was to assign and discuss new responsibilities and authority with chosen team leaders and their teams. The process intensified in 2008
column90: but the financial crisis changed the company’s orientation
column91:
since growth was not now a problem and resources had to be focused on solving the sales decline. Jakulin said:

\r\n

“Restructuring on the basis of empowerment is a process that demands a lot of contemplation. People want to feel they helped in the success of the company and that others appreciate their cooperation and skills. A lot of employees want to be able to make decisions
column92: look for solutions for problems at the workplace
column93:
take initiatives and be responsible for the results. Empowerment is a mash of procedures and behaviour that supports and encourages people in the whole organisation for these trends to come true.”

\r\n

 

\r\n

During the restructuring process
column94: paid for by the company
column95: some employees were promoted; others were moved to other workplaces. Some technicians went on to work in manufacturing. Inter-departmental borders were blurred and teamwork was established
column96: since the success of the entire company
column97: not just one department
column98: was considered as the goal. There was only one compulsory redundancy because of the crisis
column99: and there were no salary reductions or delays in pay; indeed
column100:
average salaries increased. The purpose of restructuring was to retain as many people as possible – individuals that didn’t agree with the changes left the company voluntarily. Most changes occurred among administrative and technical employees where numbers declined from 46 to 34. Manufacturing employment increased. Some technicians became sales staff.

\r\n

In April 2010
column101: Massimo Makovac was appointed as quality control manager on the understanding that
column102: should he prove to be equal to the task
column103:
he would become company director. Bringing a quality expert into ATech proved extremely beneficial. Massimo Makovac said:

\r\n

It wasn’t an innovation unless
column104: of course
column105: we call a different type of communication between employees an innovation. The key problem wasn’t of technical nature
column106:
rather mostly the problem of connections and communication in the company.

\r\n

In January 2011
column107: Massimo Makovac took over as director and within a year took over all responsibilities as Jakulin ceased daily management of the company. A more flexible organisation structure was introduced
column108: capable of dealing with constant change. The process of establishing efficient business functions
column109: especially logistics and manufacturing on which cash flow is dependent
column110: took place throughout 2010 and up to June 2011. From June to the end of 2011
column111:
a more strategic approach to selling processes and development was adopted.

\r\n

Jakulin and Makovac meet once a week
column112: mostly outside the company
column113: to discuss planning. They still need to organise more effective communication with the public
column114:
and clearly demarcate the director’s and entrepreneur’s roles in public relations.

\r\n

Challenges and constraints of restructuring

\r\n

The main challenge in restructuring was the effect of the crisis
column115: which meant that the process of empowerment did not succeed fully; nor was it implemented on time. Jakulin
column116: who had planned to head the restructuring had instead to focus on providing necessary leadership for daily running of the business. As not all assigned managers had necessary competences for running their departments the process of restructuring was stopped. If the 2009 crisis had been less severe
column117: this process could have gone through
column118:
more or less normally. Jakulin remembers:

\r\n

In March 2009 I was very close to the decision to lower the number of employees by 60%. I went to a bank and asked them what they wanted to see: a positive cash-flow or profit. We agreed for positive cash-flow which we achieved also by selling stock
column119: cancelling a contract with a certain buyer where there were high costs of material and a low profit margin. We took many different measures; for example with the Slovenian Technology Agency
column120: we started some projects that weren’t completely in the focus of our activity
column121: but they did employ some of our R&D resources. Mostly
column122:
they allowed us to keep our key experts employed.

\r\n

In ATech
column123: ensuring survival got entangled with the process of empowerment and transfer of managerial responsibilities. As Jakulin became preoccupied with ensuring survival
column124:
responsibility for restructuring fell to the newly appointed director Makovac. The process of saving the company actually ran counter to the process of restructuring and destroyed some of the already established empowerment relations.

\r\n

Employees were informed about the empowerment from the beginning at the workers’ assembly. Reactions differed as some did not agree with their newly assigned roles. Brigita Tomažič
column125: who began at the company in 2008 as a sales clerk is now manager of sales and logistics. She thinks employee reactions during the first phase of restructuring were negative and that better information would have improved them. But
column126: instead
column127:
certain responsibilities were assigned and then were not implemented. Jakulin remarks that:

\r\n

Empowerment is like the Pandora’s box – once you open it
column128: all arguments
column129:
problems and questions that were suffocated by the organisational structure and leadership methods come pouring out. Life of middle management staff becomes complicated and is quickly tempted to close the lid and make your life easier.

\r\n

Restructuring advice and support

\r\n

An outside consultant was hired to moderate team meetings and to provide technical support for the empowerment process. No other advice or support was needed. On certain issues
column130:
Jakulin consulted his network of business partners and colleagues. The company did not receive any public funds for restructuring.

\r\n

Outcomes of restructuring

\r\n

After 20 years of heading the company
column131: Davor Jakulin stepped down as director and handed over to Massimo Makovac. Now he focuses on development issues
column132: strategic sales and monitoring company performance. Makovac established the new organisational structure fully in 2011. It is now a more flexible organisation capable of dealing with constant changes. The process of establishing new operational methods
column133: especially in logistics and manufacturing
column134: on which cash flow is dependant
column135: took a year
column136: finishing in June 2011. When the second wave of crisis hit in the last months of 2011
column137:
this new structure was able to cope.

\r\n

Due to restructuring
column138: the negative trends were reversed and employment grew in 2010. Gradual growth continued in 2011
column139: with 73 people working for the company in December 2011. Gradual
column140: controlled growth is planned for the future. The company considers training very important
column141: with ATech employees participating in almost 1
column142:
800 hours of professional training every year.

\r\n

After a record high year in 2008 when company made €7
column144: 331 in sales
column145: their income plummeted because of the economic crisis and in 2009 sales dropped to 56%
column146: to only €4
column149: sales improved to €5
column151: 418. According to Jakulin
column152: growth continued in 2011. Further income and profit growth is planned
column153: as well as employing more people
column154: as they have invested a lot in development
column155: have a sound infrastructure
column156: good enterprise resource planning (ERP)information system
column157: and micro plan their manufacturing. They have also reduced the throughput time from an average of 19 days to three. Today
column158: 35% of sales go to export customers. They developed a module for collecting data in manufacturing and
column159: together with their ERP system provider
column160:
made a Manufacturing Execution System (MES) module in which the data automatically enters the system.

\r\n

One of the important outcomes of restructuring is also a clear corporate strategy up until 2020. It concentrates on the marketing strategy focused on services and products
column161:
and is based on three key competences:

  • application know-how;
  • development and production of motor controllers with connectivity functions;
  • electronics value chain integration.

They also underline their skills in producing mass customised products
column162:
design and manufacturing and electronic manufacturing services.

\r\n

Goals are constantly measured by key performance indicators and when needed
column163: the strategy and plans are refined. New products are created from market research based on understanding their customers’ needs. The company’s motto is ‘Our products solve our customers’ problems
column164:
’ and the general orientation is that:

\r\n

‘Innovations in electronic systems should contribute to the development in energy conservation
column165:
automation and individual wellbeing’.

\r\n

A good example of such orientation is the ATech’s FUMIS OXY controller for the biomass renewable heat energy sector. This received the national silver acknowledgement for innovation in 2009
column166: awarded by the Slovenian Chamber of Commerce. However the company say they were a little surprised by the positive global reaction to the FUMIS; they are now selling their products to New Zealand
column167: Chile and North America. Two years ago
column168: at a fair in Hannover
column169:
they met a client who had flown to the fair all the way from New Zealand just because of them. Jakulin says: ‘Such cases show that we are a company that sets trends. It is a good feeling’.

\r\n

Commentary

\r\n

The ATech experience of restructuring showed that it is difficult in small companies to find a critical mass of potential leaders who have the vision
column170: ability and willingness to participate in a developing company. Jakulin said that if planning restructuring today
column171: he would act differently. He would rely less on individuals
column172:
plan better and select his new managers more carefully. He said he was surprised to find how little people were prepared to change and do something for their own career growth.

\r\n

The biggest support that could be established by policymakers would be appropriate entrepreneurial education to increase awareness that companies need nurturing and that appropriate measures need to be put in place before a company encounters problems. The realisation that changes in an organisation are a constant and that a firm’s context changes a lot
column173: should be accepted as a normal way of understanding how companies function; when the context changes
column174:
everything else changes as well.

\r\n

The media should focus more on companies that restructure successfully and less on those that are in trouble
column175:
which is where most of the interest of the public and policy makers lies.

Automation company, Germany~"Automation company"~"

This German provider of automation processes and switchboards offers systems
column2: components and software for the logistical chain. Founded in the 1970s
column3: the business (60 workers) was taken over in 1983 by the founder’s son
column4: who also owned a second firm (35 workers) in the transportation field. The latter business had to file for insolvency in the early 2000s due to high investments and the difficult economy. This led to both companies being taken over by a holding company

"~"

Organisational profile

\r\n

This case study deals with a German provider of automation and switchboards. The company offers systems
column6: components and software for the complete logistical chain
column7: aiming to support a quick and efficient linkage of all processes within the chain to store raw materials and manufactured products. The firm’s services include documenting the client’s electrical devices
column8: constructing and assembling equipment
column9:
constructing switchboards or providing programmes/software according to the client’s requirements.

\r\n

The company was founded in the late 1970s and initially focused exclusively on switchboard construction. However
column10: in the late 1980s and early 1990s the firm expanded into information technology and communication technology. In 2000
column11: the founder’s son who had been working in the company since 1983
column12: took over the business as planned. At this point
column13: the company had about 60 employees
column14:
and further plans concerning growth and improvement of quality were implemented.

\r\n

The new head also owned another firm
column15:
with 35 workers. This second company was responsible for the construction or modification of vans to protect main company from any law suits for compensation in case of transport problems.

\r\n

In the early 2000s
column16: the company had to file for insolvency because of high investments and the difficult economic situation in Germany. A comprehensive restructuring was initiated
column17:
which led to both companies being taken over by a holding.

\r\n

Background to restructuring event

\r\n

About three years before the insolvency was filed for
column18: the company was asked to equip a client’s trucks with devices and control panels
column19: in order to support the client’s own new technique of transporting . The contract gave the client the right to contract a competitor instead
column20:
if the production capacities of the company were not sufficient.

\r\n

The first order was fulfilled without problems
column21: but the second order was delayed because of the larger order volume. With the third order it became obvious that the production capacities were not sufficient. At this point the company had only one production site which was remodelled in order to fulfill the orders. However
column22: with increasing order volumes and a positive outlook in the overall market – this measure was not enough. The entrepreneur therefore decided to invest about € 700
column23:
000 on new land and the construction of a new production hall. Production processes were also overhauled; new machinery was bought and equipment constructed. This was funded from within the company.

\r\n

However
column24: shortly afterwards
column25: the number and volume of orders from the main client began to drop. The client’s own new technology was not meeting market expectations
column26: and the client stopped the project without giving any notice to the company. This meant that the extended production capacities were redundant
column27:
and also that the company couldn’t raise the funding required for the construction of the new production hall.

\r\n

At about the same time
column28: the company founder retired. He received a pay-off
column29: and although this amount was much too low to compensate the work of his lifetime
column30: it damaged the company’s already weak liquidity
column31:
although neither father nor son realised this at the time.

\r\n

The situation only became obvious when the general economic situation in Germany deteriorated and orders for the company’s core business dropped. This stifled any possibility of financing the additional costs caused by the business expansion. The company was still making sales
column32: but it was obvious they were not enough to cover future expenditure
column33:
and that the company’s debts would increase.

\r\n

Consequently
column34:
the company filed for insolvency and a comprehensive restructuring started.

\r\n

Restructuring processes

\r\n

The restructuring process started with filing the insolvency which was done by filling a simple form in the insolvency court. From this point on
column35: the entrepreneur still was the owner of the company but was no longer managing it. Within few hours an insolvency administrator took over all the rights and obligations of managing the business. This meant
column36: for example
column37: that the entrepreneur had to get authorisation for any entrepreneurial activities and to point out
column38: in all negotiations with clients
column39: that any deals were conditional on getting the administrator’s go-ahead. At a personal level this caused the entrepreneur some doubt about his role in the company
column40: especially regarding clients or suppliers. However
column41:
his relations with the administrator were generally comfortable as the administrator recognised his expertise and accepted his suggestions.

\r\n

The employees
column42: according to the entrepreneur
column43: had already known the company was in difficulties
column44: having experienced a delay
column45: of a couple of days
column46: in their wage payments. They had been informed of this by the company
column47:
and accepted the situation. There were no non-payments nor wage reductions.

\r\n

On the day of filing for insolvency
column48: the entrepreneur on his own initiative released a press statement about the situation. He wanted to avoid the spread of rumours and half-truths
column49: so that he could get the company back on its feet and continue running it. Even in the difficult situation of the company crisis
column50: he was still interested in being an entrepreneur and facing the related challenges. Furthermore
column51: after investigating the causes
column52: he was convinced that the company in general offered high qualitative and competitive products and services
column53: had good clients
column54: and that the insolvency was not caused by a continuous deterioration of the business situation. Rather
column55: he identified the high investment for the new production hall and the withdrawal of capital as the cause of the crisis. Accordingly
column56: the entrepreneur together with his authorised commercial officer and the insolvency administrator developed a restructuring plan by
column57: for example
column58:
rating the enterprise and establishing a liquidity and finance plan.

\r\n

To do this he talked to his main clients and suppliers. These
column59: due to their longstanding business relationship
column60: were convinced of the quality of the company’s services and wanted to continue dealing with the company. To maintain their trust
column61:
the company then supplied its main clients with the its monthly balance sheet to keep them informed about the development of the restructuring.

\r\n

The banks were also approached and kept informed. Immediately after filing for insolvency the private accounts of the entrepreneur’s family had been frozen but
column62: relatively quickly
column63:
the banks were willing to negotiate. They saw the entrepreneur as a diligent businessman and agreed – after tough negotiations – to restructure the financial funds under consideration.

\r\n

The professional crisis management proved to be successful: Potential investors quite soon approached the insolvency administrator as it became public that the company had a sound basis and good prospects if additional capital could be secured. Two months after filing for insolvency
column64: a new company was founded and few months later took over all activities of the insolvent company. The entrepreneur kept 20% of the shares of the new company
column65: with three new partners buying the rest. These were local investors known to the entrepreneur by name
column66:
but with whom he not previously had any business contact. Together they agreed on a plan for the new business.

\r\n

The cash injection
column67: plus the concentration on the firm’s core competences meant the firm could regain its secure market position. About three years after the insolvency
column68: the company profits were at the level before the crisis
column69:
and the number of employees was back to about 60 after the redundancies caused by the insolvency (see below).

\r\n

About five to six years after the insolvency
column70:
a holding took over 80% of the shares of the company by buying out the new partners. This enabled the company to expand its range of services. At about the same time also the last administrative steps of the insolvency were completed.. The entrepreneur still owned 20% of the company.

\r\n

About one year later
column71: the holding also bought the entrepreneur’s shares. He decided to do this because of plans to integrate the holding with the company. If he had not sold up
column72: his share in the new company would have dropped from 20% to 8% with
column73: to his dismay
column74: his level of security collateral remaining the same
column75:
increasing his risk while at the same time reducing his possibilities to influence company decisions.

\r\n

At the same time there were plans to expand the activities of the second company which had not been affected by the insolvency procedure. The plans included transferring selected employees and assets from the holding
column76: but banks demanded the entrepreneur’s private assets
column77: including his home and life insurance
column78: as collateral to finance the plan. As this was not feasible for him
column79:
he also sold the second company to the holding. The entrepreneur now acts as a chief executive officer of one of the firms of the holding.

\r\n

Challenges and constraints of restructuring

\r\n

The main challenge was dealing with the banks. Immediately after filing for insolvency
column80: not only were the entrepreneur’s business accounts closed
column81: but also his private one. He had to apply to the banks before he could even cover private expenses. The bank employee who had been his longstanding contact was no longer responsible for him
column82:
so a new relationship of trust had to be fostered during intensive negotiations necessary as the suggested conditions partly were not feasible.

\r\n

It was not possible to restructure without additional finance from banks or new partners
column83: because of the firm’s great need for capital
column84:
which therefore demanded the entrepreneur’s private assets as collateral..

\r\n

Restructuring advice and support

\r\n

The entrepreneur and his tax consultant considered various possible solutions to the problem of falling revenue and increasing debt
column85:
but filing for insolvency was thought to be the most realistic. Later he was supported by the nominated insolvency administrator in the planning and implementation of the new strategies.

\r\n

However
column86: he received the most important support on restructuring from within his company
column87:
namely from his authorised commercial officer who supported him with business expertise and advice. He also received important personal support from his family.

\r\n

The entrepreneur does not feel the company had any further need for support from public authorities or private consultants in the restructuring. However he mentions that
column88: in general
column89:
a continuous system of support for medium-sized enterprises would be welcome – not only helping with the annual drafting of the balance sheet but also in cases of crisis whereby business consultants familiar with the enterprise might be able to pinpoint alternative courses of action.

\r\n

Outcomes of restructuring

\r\n

The restructuring process has led to two rebranded companies
column90: now part of a group
column91: which were previously run by an owner-manager. However
column92: their profiles remain almost unchanged. The original owner is now chief executive officer and
column93: in the third business year after starting the restructuring
column94:
the profits and the number of employees were the same as they were before the company crisis.

\r\n

At the point of filing for insolvency the company had 60 employees
column95: none of whom was dismissed at this time. The reason for this was that the company wanted to maintain sufficient resources for the hoped for upswing
column96: as well as the loyalty of the family-led company towards long-standing employees. The workers also did not have to accept a reduction of working time or wages
column97:
although there sometimes was a couple of days delay in the payment.

\r\n

In the medium term there only were minor personnel changes. The insolvency led to two staff members being dismissed
column98:
with about five others volunteering to leave the company in order to prevent further job losses if the company closed. Some of these workers have now returned to the company.

\r\n

About eight years after the restructuring
column99:
about 80% of the workers employed by the two companies before the insolvency were still working in the new firms. The loss of the remaining 20% can be considered as a natural fluctuation.

\r\n

From the entrepreneur’s personal perspective
column100: the company insolvency is an experience he does not want to repeat. Nevertheless
column101: it did have a benefit
column102: in that he has a new perspective on banks
column103: brought about positive learning effects. He now sees himself and his company
column104:
more as customers than as applicants; increasingly comparing the quality and prices of offers and negotiating more.

\r\n

The integration of the initially owner-managed companies into the holding structure introduced administrative changes for the company’s management. There are more restrictions on investment planning or staff decisions which partly result in less flexibility and a more limited scope for action. However the holding’s strong financial backing means that larger orders can be fulfilled without problems
column105:
and better deals can be had from suppliers or providers of services (such as insurance).

\r\n

Commentary

\r\n

The entrepreneur says an important factor for success in entrepreneurial activity is expertise in the economic/commercial field
column106: next to technical know-how. He feels that there is a lack of public support for making available business education and advice on business management. Many entrepreneurs become self-employed because of their strengths in the technical field. Even if they are good at administration they may need expert support because of their work load and the complexity of identifying
column107: for example
column108: appropriate financial instruments or strategies for development. A medium-sized company often cannot afford to employ a specialised worker for this area
column109: instead hiring temporary external consultants who lack continuity of knowledge about the company as well as familiarity with the long-term aims and working methods of the entrepreneur. Often only the current status of the company is assessed
column110:
but no courses of action for the future are pinpointed as soon as a first sign of deterioration of the situation is seen. This results in a lack of an early warning system early pinpointing potential drawbacks.

\r\n

He is convinced that company insolvency is not caused by a single
column111: isolated aspect
column112: but by a combination of various elements which can be internal or external to the firm. Internal aspects can include entrepreneurial mistakes such as keeping employees on for too long
column113: partly in order to be ready for the hoped for upswing
column114:
and party due to a feeling of social responsibility of a family-led company towards the employees.

\r\n

He also feels that there should be two people that a company can turn to in time of insolvency: someone that can give social or psychological support
column115:
as well as an economic/business expert within the company in order to internally discuss strategic decisions.

\r\n

Above all
column116: he recommends that companies experiencing such a crisis should carefully evaluate the causes and approach relevant stakeholders such as banks
column117: employees
column118: clients and suppliers
column119: communicating with them openly
column120: telling them of the situation and of plans for the future. Furthermore
column121: one’s own initiative and creativity is also necessary to develop and implement strategies. In negotiations with banks or other finance providers he recommends being confident
column122: having the courage to negotiate
column123:
while being open to the perspectives and requirements of the negotiation partner.

\r\n

Author

\r\n

Much more important factors

quality control and new product development (laboratory) managers.

\r\n

The next step was to develop and test the products in the market. Involving the management team in decision-making was unusual in the cultural framework of the company. As the ownership of new product idea was shared among all team members
column52: those were the fastest new product development results in the history of the company. Within the period of three months
column53: a new product was agreed
column54: developed and distributed to the market. Market response was positive
column55:
so this was a first victory and an inspiring example of the capabilities of new team to the rest of employees.

\r\n

To begin with
column56: the restructuring was quite informal
column57: focusing on changes in management
column58: planning
column59: and encouraging team work with the discussion of targets
column60: sharing of ideas and getting positive results from this. A formal restructuring plan was neither approved nor announced
column61:
there were more structural changes targeting at business expansion and later o turned into a real restructuring process.

\r\n

The new owners
column62: now on the board
column63: were very active in planning and reviewing performance measures. They and the managing director set an ambitious target of 10% growth in turnover and profitability
column64: based on the development of new products.  This was also a new toll in company’s management culture. The new targets were defined during the normal planning process
column65: bottom up
column66: in different way from the previous experience. This led to a shift in the company’s culture
column67: from an attitude of ‘this is not possible’ to ‘we know what we have to achieve
column68:
but is this realistic?’

\r\n

After the first success with new products
column69:
a new planning system led to further changes. These were focused on:

  • branding
  • clients
  • logistics
column70:
• more outsourcing.

    • This involved the whole management team working in supermarkets as product presenters
column71: while the new branding efforts strengthened the company’s position in the market. The whole team developed a clear understanding of their products’ competitive advantages
column72:
and what they should do to facilitate further development.

\r\n

The restructuring process
column73: which began in 2005
column74: was reactive rather than planned and the results of this from 2007 should be considered as arising from a company development strategy rather than from a separate and prepared restructuring plan. However
column75: although the changes were informal
column76: they were based on naturally taken actions and steps
column77: which were results of proper and adequate management and the right choice of development strategy
column78:
leading to business expansion.

\r\n

There was also no specific written strategy for personnel. New management
column79: appointed by the new owners
column80: occupied the most important positions
column81: and had their own ideas on selection
column82: motivation
column83: aspiration
column84: and conveying the vision of company to every employee. Middle management changed organically; although no manager or employee was dismissed
column85:
a sales manager and a production manager left the company a few months after restructuring started.

\r\n

By 2009
column86: when the initial restructuring was over
column87:
the total number of managers (top and medium-level) was seven and the average of employees per manager was six.

\r\n

No employees were hired during the restructuring process
column88: only a natural turnover of personnel has taken place. The share of new employees averaged about 20.5% per year
column89: which indicates the company’s moderate growth
column90: while the share of employees who left the company in 2009 was 18%
column91: which indicates a moderate level of satisfaction with job and working conditions in the company. People
column92: who left the company voluntarily
column93: could not expect state help or company support. However
column94: they did not need this
column95: or any re-training
column96: as they were highly qualified
column97: and their skills were in demand on the labour market. About 66% of the company’s employees have university education
column98: and the average age is about 36
column99: which implies that employees are ambitious. Two thirds of employees are women
column100: which gives some stability to the company’s turnover of personnel. However
column101: such a personnel structure also means that salaries are quite high compared with the average national wage. Indeed
column102: salaries rose steadily
column103: at a rate of about 1.2%
column104:
despite the global economic crisis.

\r\n

During the restructuring process
column105: the system of motivating individuals was sustained; every person is rewarded on overall performance
column106: with work load being adjusted to individual needs. Together with other structural
column107: management and working culture changes
column108: this motivation system enabled the company to see an increase in profits
column109: sales and added value. In 2009 the profit per employee was close to LTL 33
column110: 000 (about €9

column113: 000) of costs for one employee

column116: 000) of sales per employee and over LTL 236

column119:
added value creation and sales exceed 50% and indicates the quite high job productivity and profitability of company.

Challenges and constraints of restructuring

The main challenge in terms of restructuring in the BIOK case was to release internal potential.

The first task was to improve the overall atmosphere in the company after the takeover. The new management team acted more flexibly and freely in terms of personnel policy. As has been mentioned
column120:
there were no drastic changes in the management structure or in the general organisational structure affecting ordinary employees. There were only minor changes in payment or motivation system. All these actions enabled to reduce the resistance to change and created trust in the new management team.

\r\n

The next task was to break the prevailing clichéd way of thinking. The company was short of new ideas and confidence. However
column121: the involvement of management and the sharing of new ideas proved the way to success. Open information about achievements
column122: no matter how positive or negative
column123:
also added confidence and helped build team spirit.

\r\n

Following this
column124: it was important to kick-start the product development process
column125:
with the key words being speed to the market and flexibility. The successful development of new products at the first attempt served as a good example of the potential of the company.

\r\n

Another challenge was for the management team
column126: especially in the sense of product development
column127:
to be always be a few years ahead of the market.

\r\n

A common ailment of growing businesses is to demarcate functions
column128: so that employees are involved only in operations outlined in their job description. Such a strict functional distribution is not healthy for SMEs. From the start
column129: the new management team gave a good example of taking on different roles such as packaging products
column130: and talking to potential customers in supermarkets. The team also introduced work rotation
column131:
with employees moving from department to department.

\r\n

This changed the company’s culture to a more ‘family’ style atmosphere
column132: with people working in teams
column133: sharing responsibilities
column134:
and feeling part of the company.

Restructuring advice and support

The new management team received no external advice or support during the takeover. However
column135:
they successfully implemented changes by using their previous experience and tuning their relationship with rest of the management team.

\r\n

An important role was played by board members
column136: especially at the first steps of restructuring. They asked the right questions
column137: encouraged the planning process and set ambitious targets. After the first year the have taken a back seat
column138:
now following up on the most important performance measures.

\r\n

Linas Čereška feels there is no need
column139: in the case of restructuring for a business expansion
column140:
for any external support or financial resources. The company should use its own internal resources and go through changes on their own with all the attendant ups and downs.

Outcomes of restructuring

BIOK was a growing and profitable business before the takeover and restructuring
column141:
with problems more related to a lack of confidence and ideas. Management has developed the company using its existing potential.

The overall outcome of restructuring is positive:

  • constant growth of the company value
column142:
despite the national financial crisis;
  • export growth;
  • portfolio diversification.

    • Restructuring made a minor impact on employees. There were no significant changes in the payment system
column143:
and no significant impact on the number of employees.

There are two outcomes worth mentioning:

  • Due to the diversification of the firm’s portfolio
column144: \r\nplus the development of exports and spreading internal functions
column145:
the company is\r\nmore risk-resistant;\r\n
  • After restructuring
column146: the company can make a bigger impact\r\non the local economy as it can now buy some materials from local suppliers
column147:
rather than importing them.

Commentary

There are some important differences in the restructuring of SMEs compared with that of large organisations. In an SME
column148: it is difficult to distinguish restructuring processes from everyday activities. For example
column149:
the restructuring process in BIOK started in 2005 but it is not clear if it has yet finished.

\r\n

Another issue is a clear split of responsibilities. Linas Čereška says that
column150: for SMEs it is crucial to have a more ‘family’ type of organisation
column151: where people are interested in more than just their activities. It is not clear if such a set up would become an obstacle to growth in the future
column152:
but it was important for BIOK development.

\r\n

In large organisations changes could be facilitated or even implemented by the use of external resources
column153: mainly management consultants. In an SME
column154: however
column155: a company could rely on itself and make changes without external support. Employees
column156: not able to cope with such changes
column157:
should leave.

Linas Čereška has identified certain major factors vital to the success of restructuring:

  • clear vision and new ideas for further development at the takeover stage;
  • quick-wins and outcomes are of crucial importance in gaining trust and strengthening confidence among employees;
  • setting realistic
column158:
but ambitions plans;
  • no compromises on product quality.

Blažič robni trakovi is a leading provider of edge-bandings in Europe and a distributor of material for the furniture industry. The company is also the exclusive sales agent in Slovenia and the Balkans for a number of well-known trademarks.

Background to restructuring event

Blažič have experienced various types of restructuring during the last ten years - mostly business expansion. The first expansion refers to Blažič rubne trake d.o.o. in Croatia
column86: where a retail store was opened in Zagreb in September 2003. Since then
column87: the company undertook intensive internationalisation
column88: setting up subsidiaries in the Balkans. Simultaneously
column89: the company focused on Western European markets
column90: looking for business opportunities
column91:
but the process of business expansion in this part of Europe was not planned.

\r\n

The focus of this case study is the acquisition of German supplier Furwa
column92:
Furnierkanten GmbH. The management described the three most important drivers for this restructuring event.

\r\n

The first was opportunity. Furwa got to a breaking point when the owner was unable to transfer the business to members of his family and
column93: due to age and ill health
column94: decided to sell up. Furwa was founded by Armin Wiblishauser in 1974. His family had been in the woodworking business for generations and he invented veneer edges in continuous rolls. Furwa is nowadays the world’s third biggest company in the niche production of veneer edges
column95:
employing 35 people and generating €6 million sales income.

\r\n

The second motive was that Blažič had just lost its major supplier at that time
column96: the world’s second largest company in this niche market
column97:
due to a takeover by a global manufacturer.

\r\n

The third motive concerns technology. Blažič wanted to produce Furwa’s basic product themselves. It is a highly complex process that requires a large and expensive production line. Blažič was then considering either investing in its own new technology (which they tested with a potential supplier while negotiating the purchase of Furwa) or buying a company that already had it all. By purchasing Furwa
column98:
the company also gained much from the transfer of know-how as well as the expansion of sales markets.

\r\n

The decision to acquire Furwa was led by the desire to speed the firm’s internationalisation. Blažič believe the acquisition to be an appropriate investment due to Furwa technology
column99: complementary to Blažič. In this way
column100: Blažič covered the entire segment offering veneer edge bandings. Another aspect
column101: of course
column102: is the expansion of the distribution network by taking control of Furwa channels: 80% of Furwa’s production is exported. Blažič has
column103: therefore
column104: acquired many new markets in North and South America
column105:
and Africa. Furwa has a strong market reputation derived from its knowledge and technology developed in a narrow market niche – a reputation Blažič has now gained through acquisition. In this specialised niche market experience and tacit knowledge are critical to creating a competitive advantage.

Restructuring processes

Blažič first considered acquiring Furwa in mid-2010. Basic interviews with the owner
column106: management and other experts in branches were maintained for about three months. They also consulted legal and tax advisors. The process of selling the company was held up because the owner felt his business was worth much more than he ultimately got. Furwa was acquired in March 2011
column107:
after four months of intense negotiation.

\r\n

Before the purchase
column108: Blažič management prepared a detailed three-year business plan
column109:
examining the effects that the purchase of Furwa would have on Blažič.

\r\n

Our correspondent has pointed that the family business philosophy common to both companies contributed to the success of the acquisition. Their intention was to change as little as possible. The main reason for this was the company’s family tradition and their sensitiveness to change. Alignment of business was done with the introduction of a new communication protocol. They discussed targets with the Furwa management and employees and aligned products and market appearance. All this was done gradually; step by step. The cultural compatibility of the two companies supported the situation. Post-acquisition integration took place relatively easily because of this compatibility.

\r\n

The purchase of Furwa was a leveraged buyout
column110: Blažič financing the acquisition through German banks
column111: with 15% of the deal coming from its own resources. As part of the loan agreement
column112:
German banks stipulated that Furwa’s management would not be replaced.

Challenges and constraints of restructuring

Workers at Blažič did not accept the acquisition of the German supplier without hesitation. They felt quite a lot of frustration and fear that the acquisition would cause unwanted change. However
column113: management attempted to calm these fears by clearly communicating their plans
column114: preparing a written notification
column115: so that all employees were informed about acquisition objectives. Reactions to this were mixed
column116: although managers and some employees accepted the decision very positively. In general
column117:
workers are less afraid about their own future at the company.

\r\n

Interestingly
column118: some customers in Slovenia reacted to the move quite negatively. The reason for this may lie in the fact they were not informed directly by Blažič side
column119: but from magazines or newspapers. Anyway
column120: they did not take any specific action
column121:
but just let it go.

\r\n

At Furwa
column122: the lengthy acquisition process meant that the employees were prepared for changes. They feared that production would be relocated to the Balkans
column123: but with appropriate information at joint meetings
column124: Blažič fostered a basic level of trust. It took a year after the takeover for employees to recognise the aspirations and vision of the new owner
column125:
and become confident about the future. Blažič is aware that the establishment of mutual trust requires time and that there are no shortcuts.

Restructuring advice and support

The acquisition of a foreign company is a demanding undertaking
column126: and to facilitate this in terms of handling and knowledge of formal procedures
column127: Blažič made extensive use of Slovenian and German experts and consultants. The acquisition process was led by Luka Novak
column128: a Blažič manager at the time and now also responsible for managing the operations at Furwa. During the acquisition process
column129: he had legal
column130: tax and financial advisory assistance from local German consultants and from one external adviser on remaining issues such as finding good practices in the local environment. The advisor had been involved in a number of previous takeovers or mergers of similar sized companies. They discussed potential mistakes and threats
column131:
and also the advantages of such connections.

\r\n

All support providers were from the private sector
column132: and the company says that everyone
column133: especially the local German specialists
column134: were highly satisfactory. However Luka Novak was more critical of the support they received from the Slovenian side. He admitted they didn’t undertake any in-depth research regarding government support for their activities due to time constraints. He feels that
column135: in Slovenia
column136: the business support structure is simply too weak. Even if it exists
column137:
it is lost in bad communications between government and entrepreneurs.

Outcomes of restructuring

No workers left because of the acquisition and Furwa’s employees and organisation structure remain the same. This was clearly the vertical integration; no bigger synergies in HR were developed.

Luka Novak
column138: says he learned many valuable lessons from the process including an insight into the functioning of acquisition processes abroad
column139:
and a thorough knowledge of the German business environment and customs. A key challenge for him was to ensure that the decision to purchase the company wouldn’t be regretted later and that Furwa achieves positive performance in the next business year.

\r\n

The current economic situation has caused market contraction for Furwa products. At the same time
column140: it is also necessary to finance the costs of acquisition and to avoid Furwa’s development processes being negatively affected. Consequently
column141: Blažič decided to use Furwa’s profits to finance the acquisition. All other issues in the acquired company are running smoothly
column142: with no loss of staff or reduction in pay. Blažič is well aware how vital this is to building the necessary mutual trust and cooperation
column143:
in order to maximise production.

\r\n

Furwa has clear plans for the future
column144: with six projects outlined. They particularly want to attract new
column145: large
column146: customers
column147: such as IKEA
column148: with the hope that they will bring in for example
column149:
20% of total sales in future. Operating results will largely depend on the success or failure of these projects.

\r\n

Furwa’s principal business objective (if they have sufficient equity) is to develop a distribution network in Germany. They are aware that this is a very demanding project in terms of capital
column150: since a good salesperson in Germany is paid at least €60
column151: 000 per year. Profits generated will be primarily aimed at developing a sales network in Germany. Furwa is currently focused entirely on the B2B segment (selling to large factories or distributors)
column152: while Blažič wants
column153: because of Germany’s enormous market size
column154: to target the B2C segment (selling to small cabinet makers
column155:
not to the final customer).

\r\n

Blažič is already planning to extend operations into other European markets. In 2011
column156:
they employed a salesperson in Budapest. He is in charge of searching for potential new partners in agreed foreign markets such as Poland and the Czech Republic.

\r\n

Synergies created between the two companies relate largely to the acquisition of new skills. Blažič has gained new production knowledge as well as knowledge of new markets. They have gathered many new contacts and forged new business ties. They organise regular visits by German technologists to Slovenia and vice versa. Many positive effects cannot be directly assessed; however the experience of both parties is enriched.

\r\n

Blažič heavily invests in the development of new edge-banding tapes
column157: as new trends continue to emerge at an increasing pace in the particleboard industry. New boards also call for new types of edge-banding tape.  They strive to offer customers products that meet even the most demanding trends in product development
column158: in terms of quality and affordable prices. In order to achieve these goals
column159: they need to stimulate all employees to participate in development processes. For this reason
column160: an intensive system of encouraging and rewarding employees for innovative pursuits is in preparation. There are fewer opportunities for manufacturing improvements
column161: as only 10% of revenue derives from their own production; everything else is brokerage/trade. At the same time
column162:
great opportunities for improvements remain in administrative processes.

Commentary

Blažič now has the title of the fastest growing company in Slovenia (‘Gazelle’ award). According to our interviewee
column163: a key advantage of a gazelle is its flexibility. The company is happy with its decision to acquire Furwa
column164: and feels that they learned a great deal from the process
column165: although it agrees it might have been better if some things had been done differently. The company’s management is not in favour of state aid for restructuring
column166: as they feel that it is too great a problem to identify those who really need help. They believe that it would make more sense to help those SMEs which want to restructure in areas such as expert knowledge. Restructuring can be very demanding
column167: especially for small businesses
column168:
representing a disproportionately large burden in terms of acquiring knowledge and skills for successful implementation.

Organisational profile

Boris 45 was founded in 1985 in Barcelona. Its new plant in the city of Reus (which forms the basis of this case study) was opened in August 2010.

The main economic sector or activity in which the company operates corresponds to the NACE Rev2 code 56.2: ‘event catering and other food service activities’

The company is a family business

column5: originally from Barcelona. The company is registered as a Public Limited Company
column6: and its shares are all distributed among family members. One member of the family is the manager
column7:
in charge of running the daily organisation and in control of the business. The administrative board of Boris 45 comprises eight members (including the manager) with a total of six family members.

\r\n

The main production plant (the firm’s headquarters) is in Barcelona
column8: with 70 employees (as at November 2011). The business unit in Reus has 20 employees. A new production plant (a central kitchen) was expected to be opened in 2012

employing 10–15 people.

\r\n

The company’s market is limited largely to the region of Catalonia (mainly Barcelona and its surroundings) which is considered an urban area.

\r\n

Company growth in 2011 was expected to remain stable. The main business aims were to grow and to reach new clients and distribute food to more institutions such as hospitals
column11: old people’s homes
column12:
and schools

\r\n

Boris 45 has a works council of five people
column13: representing the interests of all employees
column14: (any Spanish company with more than 50 workers has
column15: by law
column16:
to have a works council). Two people on the council represent the General Union of Workers (UGT) and three represent The Trade Union Confederation of Workers’ Commissions (CCOO) the main Spanish trade unions.

Background to restructuring event

Boris 45 is an example of an extension of business activities in order to serve a new client in a different location.

The main impetus for this has been the identification of a new business opportunity
column17: based on a public tender for the new hospital of Sant Joan in Reus. This required the winning bidder to build a ‘hospital satellite unit’ in the Hospital of Sant Joan (intended for the reception and distribution of food in the hospital)
column18:
and also a new production plant or ‘central kitchen’ in the industrial park of Reus.

\r\n

After being awarded the contract to manage the hospital catering services
column19: in November 2011
column20: Boris 45 became responsible for the ‘hospital satellite unit’. This serves as a centre point from where the food is plated and distributed to patients. However
column21: the ‘central kitchen’ is still under construction. Hence
column22: Boris 45 buys in cooked food from another firm
column23: which Boris 45 arranges and distributes at its ‘hospital satellite unit’. Once the new ‘central kitchen’ is ready
column24: the company will cook its own food to serve the hospital satellite unit
column25:
as well as other new potential clients such as other hospitals and schools.

Boris 45 has been in charge of the new Sant Joan hospital catering services since August 2010. Reus hospital was transferred to a recently constructed building opened in December 2010. At this time Boris 45 started to work in the new ‘hospital satellite unit’. The ‘central kitchen’ was expected to open in May–June 2012.

Restructuring processes

All decisions concerning the planning and management of the restructuring process were taken by the company’s management board at the Barcelona headquarters
column26:
led by the general manager. The works council was not involved in the decision-making process.

\r\n

After winning the public tender
column27: Boris 45 became responsible for managing the hospital catering services. It took over employment of the 17 staff already working in the ‘hospital satellite unit’ under another employer. Once the contract was publicly announced
column28: workers attended a meeting where they were informed of the new company and the transfer of employees' rights and employers' obligations. Known as ‘subrogation’
column29:
this is an increasingly common phenomenon in Spain.

\r\n

As established by law
column30: subrogation implies that all workers’ terms and conditions of employment such as salaries
column31:
length of contracts and working hours must continue as under the previous company.

\r\n

However
column32: Boris 45 has introduced a small change in working time
column33: with employees working an additional one and a half hours every day
column34: so that they can have two days off per week (instead of only one). It has been possible to introduce this change only because employees approved it. In fact
column35: the vast majority of employees wanted this change
column36: so it was implemented from the very beginning
column37:
without discussions or negotiations.

\r\n

When Boris 45 began work at the new hospital satellite unit
column38: three extra employees were hired
column39: bringing the total number there to 20. They were hired under the same conditions as the other 17
column40: that is
column41:
following the collective agreement for catering trade.

The central kitchen under construction at Reus industrial park is expected to create 10–15 new jobs.

Challenges and constraints of restructuring

Generally speaking
column42: the expansion process has been trouble-free. Getting used to the new building and new production processes has required an adaptation period both for employees and managers. Moreover
column43: the company has had to adapt to client requirements. One of the main challenges of opening a new plant or working with new employees is to learn about the new environment and clients. In this particular case
column44: the business specialised in particular products for a new client
column45: and production processes included the latest technologies
column46:
which were new to managers and employees.

\r\n

For this reason
column47: Boris 45 made a great effort to train staff in depth
column48: so that they could learn about the new processes and techniques. First
column49: the person in charge of each unit/department was trained externally in specialised centres
column50:
then passing on their new knowledge to other employees at in-company training sessions organised by the Human Resources Department.

\r\n

According to managers at Boris 45
column51: lifelong learning is essential for a good catering service. Employees receive training on four main topics: hygiene
column52: food handling
column53: gastronomy and safety. Working processes for the original 17 employees in the hospital satellite unit’ are now very different. The previous company carried out ‘hot line’ processes
column54: whereas Boris 45 has installed new equipment for ‘cold line’ processes. Employees were initially doubtful about the implementation of the new processes and afraid that difficulties would arise. Some had worked in the hospital for nearly 20 years
column55: following more or less the same processes
column56:
so learning new methods was a big change.

\r\n

However
column57: after an adaptation and learning period
column58: employees thought the new processes were faster and easier
column59: and less likely to cause musculoskeletal problems. All employees have liked the company training plan
column60:
calling it thorough and wide-ranging.

\r\n

The new business activity in Sant Joan hospital required a huge investment for the company (both in the ‘hospital satellite unit’ and the ‘central kitchen’). Winning the public tender required the company to comply with conditions established by the public authority
column61:
including opening two units equipped with the latest technology.

\r\n

However
column62: the company says there have been some problems with regard to the public tender
column63: with initial projections varying slightly in comparison to what was finally established. This meant plans for business/growth prospects had to be modified. There were also administrative problems caused by too much red tape
column64:
and excessive administrative costs.

Restructuring advice and support

Boris 45 has not received any kind of support
column65: financial or otherwise for restructuring. All investments came from internal resources. In fact
column66:
managers complain that the Public Administration has not really supported them; and in fact has demanded a lot of money for taxes and administrative processes.

Outcomes of restructuring

Boris 45 has hired 17 employees who were already working at the hospital (subrogation)
column67:
plus three new employees. This means an increment of 20 employees in the total staff of Boris 45.

\r\n

The future perspective seems quite gloomy. When Boris 45 won the hospital contract in August 2010
column68: prospects were much more optimistic. However
column69: one year later
column70: the Regional Government of Catalonia started to cut the public health budget because of the economic crisis. Therefore
column71: the company’s initial investments might now appear high in relation to future prospects. Cost reductions in Sant Joan hospital directly affect Boris 45 (for example
column72: there will be fewer sick people admitted to the hospital and they will stay in hospital for a shorter period). For this reason
column73:
managers are considering dismissing one or two employees.

\r\n

On the other hand
column74: Boris 45 is currently building a new central kitchen as part of the contract. In order to make this production plant viable
column75: Boris 45 will have to win new clients
column76: a key business objective. If they do not
column77:
the huge investment in the new building will not be recovered.

Commentary

Boris 45 managers consider that current growth prospects are not as optimistic as they were when they won the contract
column78:
especially due to public health budget cuts. Initial investments in technical equipment were relatively cautious in case things turned out to be worse than expected.

\r\n

However managers feel they risked more on personnel and hired more employees than needed. They regret not acting more cautiously on this issue as well.

\r\n

On the other hand
column79: the interviewees think that Boris 45
column80: as an SME
column81: has more flexibility than larger companies. This characteristic allows them to adapt to new situations and take decisions much more quickly. They also consider that they have closer personal relations with other business providers
column82: than large companies. This means that relations are stronger and more stable. Interestingly
column83:
these advantages are in line with small and large enterprise differences reported in the Spanish National Report.

column1:
Construction company, Slovakia~"Construction Company"~"

The economic crisis led this producer of glass blocks for the construction industry to insolvency. Slovakian legislation permits restructuring: a process whereby creditors write off part of the debt owed to them
column2: and the debtor continues to operate in the hope of recovery. This can save a company from bankruptcy
column3: enabling the changes required to become competitive. The company decided on this option and was able to repay its debts within one year. Bringing an external business consultancy on board was crucial for the business
column4:
helping the company assess its financial situation and the possibility of restructuring.

"~"

Organisational profile

This limited liability company was founded in 2001. It is located in the south-west of Slovakia
column5: near the capital Bratislava
column6: the most economically prosperous region in the country. The company has two owners having equal ownership shares. One of the co-owners
column7: who has an educational background in construction and economics
column8:
is the founder and managing director of the company.

\r\n

The company started its activities in Slovakia specialising in the production of building glass and glass blocks for the construction industry. Glass bricks and glass profiles became attractive for specific architectonic constructions when technological development enhanced their technical and aesthetic characteristics. Glass block
column9: also known as glass brick
column10: is an architectural element made from glass and is used in areas where privacy or visual obscuration is desired while admitting light
column11: such as underground parking garages
column12: washrooms and staircases. It has a wide range of uses and applications in interiors and exteriors. Glass block was originally developed in the early 1900s to provide natural light in industrial factories. Currently
column13: glass block represents an innovative technology that reduces the thermal transmittance of the classic glass block
column14:
making it possible to create architectural façades made entirely of glass blocks that promote the conservation of energy and safeguard the environment. Texture and colour variations are challenging for architectural applications.

\r\n

The company is among the most important importers and distributors of glass bricks and builders of glass profiles in the Slovakian market. It undertakes construction work for individual customers as well as large building companies. To be able to compete
column15:
the company has developed technologies and skills for laying and connecting glass bricks and glass profiles. These activities led the way for new wall installation methods and new special mortars for laying and finishing. The company also provides all necessary construction components and materials.

\r\n

Providing good customer service is important for the company and a precondition for success. This is because the general knowledge and skills surrounding the use of glass bricks and glass profiles is not yet common.

\r\n

The company imports building glass products from Italy (Vetroarredo)
column16: Germany
column17: the Czech Republic (Vitrablok) and Poland. It distributes these products and provides services and construction works in Slovakia
column18: the Czech Republic
column19: Austria
column20: Hungary and Poland. It also distributes these products to large retail chains such as BauMax and Hornbach. It has a partner company in the Czech Republic
column21:
which is registered as an independent company.

The company does not have any relationships with trade unions nor an existing works council.

Background to restructuring event

The company developed steadily over the past decade and its performance peaked in 2008. As a reaction to the boom in the construction sector
column22: the company expanded its activities. This was due to the positive economic development in the country
column23: where the economic growth in 2008 reached 10%. In 2007
column24: as its markets matured
column25:
the company increased its number of employees from 6 to 14.

\r\n

Very soon
column26: the managing director foresaw negative trends in the construction industry. The first signs of global crisis forced the company to reconsider its strategy and change its business model. The company decided to outsource as a way of lowering personnel and operational costs more widely. This decision was made by the managing director. In 2009
column27: the company decreased its number of permanent employees from 14 to 3 in order to be more flexible. Eleven employees were made redundant. The company followed standard procedures: the employees were given a notice period of two months and redundancy payments. According to the managing director
column28: the employees received the news reasonably well. At the time
column29: it was still relatively easy to find work
column30:
and new vacancies were more frequent in the labour market. The company provided references to the employees who requested them. Some of the employees established their own businesses.

\r\n

Subsequently
column31:
the focus of the company has changed towards close cooperation with other construction companies. The company started to develop a network of cooperating companies specialising in specific tasks and activities which were performed previously by the company itself. These companies provided know-how and materials to serve their customers. Some of them were established by the former employees. This is a common practice in Slovakia in order to eliminate the very high administrative and financial burden related to employment.

\r\n

In 2009
column32: there was a substantial break in the market
column33: and ever since the company has been stagnating. The current crisis caused a severe decline in the construction industry and affected some of its important cooperating companies and clients
column34:
who have not been able to pay for deliveries and services. This eventually led to the company becoming insolvent in 2010.

Restructuring processes

When the management became aware of the company’s financial situation
column35: it contacted a company that specialises in financing and restructuring of companies in financial difficulties. Based on the consultancies
column36: the management decided that restructuring was a realistic option. ‘Restructuring’ (reštrukturalizácia) is a legal process whereby creditors
column37: in their own interest
column38: can write off part of their claims
column39:
and the debtor will continue operations in the hope that it recovers. This process is supervised by the court under the Act on bankruptcy and restructuring.

\r\n

During the analysis
column40: it appeared that there was a possibility that the company could continue in operation
column41: mainly because of existing market demands as well as good relations with suppliers and customers. The company had the option to apply for restructuring in order to avoid bankruptcy. The management started to communicate with its creditors. It was necessary to convince the main creditors that the restructuring plan was realistic and that the operating company could pay back more of its debts than yields from forced selling of company assets in bankruptcy. According to the managing director
column42: the company had several meetings with its main creditors to explain that this option would be the most beneficial for both parties. The negotiations themselves were not difficult but
column43: initially
column44: there was a degree of distrust because the option of restructuring
column45: as a legal process
column46: was unknown to the creditors. The Act on bankruptcy and restructuring only came into effect relatively recently
column47: in January 2006. The creditors
column48: not familiar with this option
column49:
thought at first that they might lose all their money.

\r\n

As with bankruptcy
column50: both creditors and debtors can apply for restructuring
column51:
and the debtor can appoint a bankruptcy trustee (správca konkurznej podstaty) to assess whether restructuring is possible. The trustee is a physical or a legal person listed under the Register of Bankruptcy Trustees of the Ministry of Justice of the Slovak Republic. The role of the trustee is to assist the courts in the process of bankruptcy and restructuring.

\r\n

The trustee in this case was appointed by creditors to assess whether the debtor met the conditions of restructuring. The assessment could not be more than 30 days old. The outcome of the assessment was a recommendation for restructuring of the debtor
column52: which also involved the assessment of its economic status. Based on the trustee’s assessment
column53: the request for restructuring to the relevant court was submitted. At this stage
column54:
the court reviewed the formal essentials of the submitted motion for restructuring. The ruling on commencement of restructuring process was issued on 9 November 2010. It protected the company from further moves by creditors.

\r\n

The company
column55: in cooperation with the trustee and the committee of main creditors
column56: developed the restructuring plan. The plan stated how
column57: when and in what amounts the claims of eligible creditors would be covered. In addition
column58: the plan regulated monitoring of the company operation and its financial decisions. This plan was endorsed by the court on 14 April 2011. According to the managing director
column59: the restructuring process has gone smoothly. Under the agreement
column60: the company was required to repay around 60%–70% of its debts. The repayment of the amounts of debt under the restructuring plan has been covered
column61: and the plan came to an end in the spring of 2012. The restructuring was to officially end in May 2012
column62:
when it would be deleted from the commercial register.

Challenges and constraints of restructuring

Restructuring was a challenging process for the company and its management. It was necessary to negotiate with the committee of creditors for an optimal restructuring plan. The main aim of the debtor is to keep the company operating while the creditors are requesting the best possible repayment of their loans. Reconciliation of the two conflicting parties is necessary for the success of restructuring. The final arrangement was formally embedded in the restructuring plan. The consultancy company contributed to this outcome by properly evaluating the potential and prospects of the company. The ability to convince the creditors was important for the overall success. However
column63: fulfilment of the restructuring plan to be realised over three years was also challenging. It imposed tough restrictions on financial operations of the company and constrained its development activities. During this time
column64:
it was very difficult to get any loan or start any activities that were considered risky.

Restructuring advice and support

When the company became insolvent
column65:
the management used the services of a consultancy company that helped them assess whether the company could avoid bankruptcy and apply for restructuring. The consultancy company was instrumental in convincing creditors that restructuring was a viable option.

Outcomes of restructuring

The outcomes of restructuring were straightforward. During the restructuring process
column66: the debtor
column67: bankruptcy trustee and committee of creditors negotiated the restructuring plan that would allow the company to operate and provide the best return for creditors for their financial claims in a reasonable period of time. In this case
column68: the plan was worked out for three years
column69: which meant three years of monitoring business activities by the main creditors and maintaining the restrictions imposed by the restructuring plan. The company paid off its debts within a year
column70: and the creditors were satisfied with the outcome. Subsequently
column71:
the records of restructuring were to be removed from the commercial register in May 2012.

\r\n

There has not been any major change in terms of business activities; the company continues to operate as previously but maintains close relationships with its cooperating companies
column72:
which are crucial to its activities. The managing director did not report any negative impacts as a result of decreased employment numbers. These changes preceded the financial difficulties of the company and the need to apply for restructuring. The existing three employees have not been affected by the restructuring process. The option of restructuring has helped the company avoid bankruptcy.

Commentary

The impact of the global economic crisis on the construction sector in Slovakia has had negative consequences for this company. In order to cut its operational costs
column73: it had to make most of its staff redundant and outsource services to other companies. Despite these changes
column74:
the company had been stagnating since 2009. Late payments from clients eventually led to its insolvency in 2010.

\r\n

Solving the problems of a company that is in financial difficulties is always very demanding. This is especially true when there is an imminent threat of bankruptcy. Slovakian legislation provides the option of restructuring
column75: which can save a company from bankruptcy
column76:
allowing for the necessary changes in management and production organisation in order to become competitive.

\r\n

This legislation has been in force since 1 January 2006. Despite problems
column77: this approach is useful and is considered as a contribution to improving the business environment. However
column78:
more extensive use can bring experiences and new ideas for its improvement.

\r\n

In the present case
column79: the company took the option to restructure and was able to repay its debts within one year. Bringing the external business consultancy on board was crucial for the business; it helped the company assess its financial situation and the possibility of restructuring. The company continues to operate as previously
column80:
but has not become more competitive as a result of restructuring.
