column1:
El León, Spain~"El León "~"

Spanish company El León has experienced decreasing orders and sales since 2007 and reacted to that by first offering incentives for voluntary redundancies
column2: followed by the suspension of employment contracts for 120 days
column3: before finally deciding to carry out compulsory redundancies. This damaged the image of the firm
column4: which had previously been a popular employer in the region. Gossip and rumours are harmful for the company's relationships with its suppliers and clients
column5:
and some people in the area even think that the company has already closed.

"~"

Organisational profile

\r\n

El León was founded in 1964
column6: and is located in Ejea de los Caballeros
column7: a village in the rural area of Zaragoza province. The main activity of El León includes the manufacture of bucket-loaders
column8:
which corresponds to NACE Rev2 28.3 (manufacture of agricultural and forestry machinery).

\r\n

El León was originally a family business set up by two owners. At present
column9: the two founders are about to retire. One of the owners has already handed his shares to his two children and stopped working at the company; the other has started proceedings to transfer ownership to his children. Both managers and workers think the transfer is influencing management of the company
column10: reflecting the high importance of personal decisions
column11:
as suggested by the literature review in the Spanish National Report. As of November 2011 the company has 36 employees 35 men and one woman.It is estimated that the average employee is in the middle age category.

\r\n

The company’s main market is domestic
column12: with a small proportion of export sales. During the last five years
column13: as a consequence of the international economic and financial crisis
column14: sales have plummeted and the company has made huge losses. The general environment seems pretty negative
column15: so future prospects are poor. The company directors are interested in enhancing exports
column16: but this would mean a huge
column17: and currently unaffordable
column18: financial effort. Business aims are to cope with this difficult situation and survive
column19: in the hope that conditions will get better soon. In order to maintain the business running
column20: shareholders have had no choice but to contribute more funds to the company. Before hitting this bad patch
column21: the company used to employ 85 and it was considered a well-established and renowned company in the area. Unfortunately
column22:
circumstances are very different these days.

\r\n

Currently
column23: there is no works council at the company. According to Spanish legislation
column24: designating a works council is only compulsory for companies with 50 employees or more. Therefore
column25: given that El León has only 36 employees
column26: it is not required to elect a works council. Nevertheless
column27:
they do have personnel delegates acting as workers’ representatives.

\r\n

Background to restructuring event

\r\n

The restructuring studied here is an internal restructuring process which took place in January 2011. During this time the management board decided to carry out a plan for the adjustment of employment levels
column28: by which seven employees were made redundant. According to Spanish legislation
column29:
the plans for the adjustment of employment levels (Expediente de Regulación de Empleo) can be of three different types:

  • termination of working contracts (i.e. collective dismissals);
  • temporary suspension of working contracts for a specific time;
  • short-time working arrangements.

Following the criteria of Spanish labour law
column30: the seven redundancies were attributed to ‘objective reasons’
column31: given the economic loss and productivity standards of the firm
column32:
caused by the global economic crisis.

\r\n

Restructuring processes

\r\n

The number of orders and sales had constantly decreased since 2007. The decision to terminate the contracts was seen as the best option for the future of the company. However
column33:
it was unable to offer the seven employees any support to find a new job.

\r\n

In order to understand these redundancies
column34: it is necessary to be aware of the delicate situation that El León has undergone since 2008
column35: characterised by a serious drop in income. Other measures were implemented before the company decided on the dismissals. Since mid-2009
column36: the company has offered incentives to promote voluntary redundancy
column37: which some employees have accepted. During the summer of 2010
column38: the company arranged a plan for the adjustment of employment levels (or ‘ERE’)
column39:
by which the company suspended employee contracts for a period of 120 days. It is clear that the company has been fighting the consequences of the crisis for a few years.

\r\n

Company directors and owners unilaterally decided on the redundancies; employees were not consulted
column40: as managers felt it was the only option to maintain the business. This reflects the difficulties of social dialogue practices within Spanish small enterprises
column41:
due partly to the absence of compulsory social dialogue solutions for smaller enterprises (as suggested in the Spanish National Report).

\r\n

Conversely
column42: the suspension plan arranged in the summer of 2010 was agreed and coordinated with employees
column43: in order to reach a favourable accord between all stakeholders and the company. The negotiation process was not very problematic or lengthy
column44: since everyone was willing to find a solution. At the beginning
column45: workers’ representatives had been rather unwilling to agree to the suspension plan
column46: but eventually accepted the bad economic situation facing the firm. Thus
column47: it was possible to finally make a decision on a suspension plan
column48: as a temporary solution for the good of everyone in the long term. Unfortunately
column49: the situation did not improve and the position of the business became increasingly difficult. The management board described the 2010 sales as a ‘disaster’. In December 2010 and January 2011 management offered incentives to employees to take voluntary redundancy. However
column50:
when employees were unwilling to accept them management decided on the dismissals.

\r\n

From the point of view of the workers’ representatives
column51: the company is in a really bad situation. They feel that the new owners are not really able to adapt to new markets
column52: innovate or find solutions to the current situation. They think that the situation got worse when the founders transferred ownership to their children. Some workers are pessimistic and afraid that company closure will be unavoidable in the medium-term. The lack of exports is seen as one of the main problems
column53:
due to the poor prospects of the Spanish market.

\r\n

Challenges and constraints of restructuring

\r\n

One of the challenges for management was to tell employees about the dismissals. Employers were afraid that their relationship with the workers would be damaged. However
column54:
it seems the situation was not particularly traumatic as the workers acknowledged the firm’s difficulties.

\r\n

On the other hand
column55:
it is interesting to comment on the damage caused to the image of the firm. El León is a long-established company and is very popular in the area (it is located in a village in a rural region) given that it has traditionally hired workers from the surrounding locality. Many employees have worked only for El León and no other company.

\r\n

The difficult economic situation the firm is currently facing has led to internal restructuring with bad consequences for workers’ conditions. This situation is having a very bad impact on the company’s image with people in the area who think the company has already closed. Gossip and rumours are harmful for the relationships between the company
column56:
its suppliers and clients.

\r\n

Restructuring advice and support

\r\n

The company has not received any kind of support for restructuring. Decisions were taken internally with neither public
column57:
nor private external advice or financial assistance..

\r\n

The labour law reform carried out by the Spanish Government in September 2010 (Law 35/2010 on urgent measures for the reform of the labour market) clarified and smoothed the proceedings of the company plans for the adjustment of employment levels. This new legislation facilitated the termination of the seven working contracts. Law 35/2010 was approved in the context of strong crisis with the aim of implementing long-term reform. Some of the measures included are directly linked to the economic downturn and its consequences
column58:
so they could be seen as temporary measures. The new Spanish government was expected to introduce further labour law reform in February or March 2012 which will modify Law 35/2010.

Outcomes of restructuring

The main outcome of internal restructuring has been the dismissal of seven employees. The compensation or indemnity for these has been a huge cost to company owners who paid it as an ‘extra’ amount rather than from internal funds.

The firm’s future does not seem very hopeful. Company directors are thinking of implementing a new employment adjustment plan
column59:
based on the temporary suspension of working contracts. This plan is conceived as a way of getting over this difficult crisis stage. Management interviewees are trying to be optimistic and hope that economic recovery at both national and European levels will start soon.

\r\n

With regard to working conditions
column60:
the work environment is quite tense. The company is operating a ‘wage freeze’ due to budget cuts. Workers accept the difficult situation the company is experiencing and there have been few labour relations problems.

\r\n

Interestingly
column61: the company might also find human resource difficulties if the economic context gets better and orders and sales increase. The dismissal of employees means a loss of knowledge and experience for the company. Moreover
column62: employees are getting used to low production levels
column63: where working rhythms are relatively slow. If production increases
column64:
it might be difficult to make employees work in a more efficient way.

The restructuring process has also caused a loss of prestige for the company.

Commentary

As to lessons learnt
column65: the interviewee reported that one of the weak points which has led to this situation is ‘arrogance’. The company has traditionally been a popular and buoyant business
column66: and the management board may not have been able to notice the gravity of the economic situation early enough. From a critical perspective
column67: a more proactive working group would have reacted in advance
column68: going after its clients and fighting to maintain its market image. An earlier reaction might have softened the current delicate situation. Unfortunately
column69: it has not been possible to talk to a workers’ representative. The company has just 36 employees
column70: and according to Spanish law
column71: it is only compulsory to have a works council for companies over 50. Thus
column72: despite our efforts
column73: it has not been possible to reach the workers’ representative
column74:
especially due to the current delicate situation of the company.

\r\n

column1:
Gero serviso garantija, Lithuania~"JSC Gero serviso garantija"~"

The slump in the hospitality sector in Lituania in 2008 led to a sharp drop in income for restaurant business Gero serviso garantija. The owner took over as manager and developed a restructuring plan which was based on focusing activities only in the most profitable areas. The business has managed to survive due to business optimisation and good cash flow management.

"~"

Organisational profile

The private limited company ‘Gero serviso garantija’ (GSG) was founded in 2005. It was established by Linas Pučinskas as the main owner
column2: with a minor part of shares owned by a trust fund. Since the beginning the company was operating in the food & beverages and restaurant industry. The restaurant was opened in the historical Verkiai Manor estate which consists of a main house
column3: botanic park
column4: stables and outbuildings. The estate is run by the Botanic Institute
column5: managed by the Ministry of Education. The estate is about 10km from Vilnius city centre. It is a very picturesque location
column6:
well known by local residents and a major tourist destination.

\r\n

The restaurant was open every day for visitors to the estate
column7:
while weekends were usually booked for larger events (mainly weddings). It was expected that there would be mutual benefit from the company renting the reception rooms at the historic manor hall for these events and financing the renovation needed.

\r\n

The company’s business is rather local and the only international aspect is the foreign visitors.

\r\n

The company grew from the start
column8: up to 2007. However
column9: in 2008 company had to review operations
column10: and the hired management was replaced by the owner
column11:
Linas Pučinskas.

\r\n

With a background in the hospitality industry
column12:
Linas Pučinskas is involved in several different projects related to tourism. He was previously the manager of Baltpark hotel (later sold to the Holiday Inn group).

GSG has few employees so there is no works council nor union representation in the company. There are no human resources or corporate social responsibility strategies.

Background to restructuring event

Restructuring began in the second half of 2008
column13:
caused by external as well as internal factors.

The greatest of the external forces was the crisis in the Lithuanian economy. The slump in the hospitality sector led to the sharp drop of income. The number of visitors having lunch and dinner at the restaurant decreased dramatically.

One important internal reason was debts from rental arising from the indiscreet actions of a manager which reached significant proportions by 2008.

Restructuring processes

Pučinskas started to manage the company in autumn 2008. He developed a restructuring plan which had two important aspects.

The first
column14: and most important one
column15: was a review of activities. As daily services were no longer profitable because of the drop in visitor numbers
column16:
the challenge was to optimise and concentrate activities only in the profitable areas. A few alternatives were considered:

  • limit activities only to the servicing of contracted events;
  • limit activities only to the servicing of contracted events and enter catering business;
  • close the business.

After evaluation of the market potential and business capabilities
column17: it was decided to limit the business to weekend activities
column18:
mostly for weddings and some other contracted events in the historical estate only.

\r\n

Another important aspect was sorting out the problem of a negative cash flow. The owner tackled this by putting in his own money. The shrinking business and unplanned debt required an in-depth review of expenses
column19: which showed that the biggest expense was salaries
column20:
which had to be reduced.

\r\n

The optimisation of activities and tightened cash flow management were introduced in the beginning of 2009. The biggest impact of those changes was on the salary system. Incomes were now related directly to events. A minimum
column21: unchanging
column22: level was offered to the 36 employees
column23:
with an extra variable amount on top directly related to the events.

\r\n

All employees were offered the chance to stay under new conditions. Employees were very understanding about the situation and management efforts to secure operations. This may have been because the new owner was honest with them. Most employees left the company because of the poor prospects; this
column24: however
column25: allowed the company to secure some financial resources as there was no need to pay lay-off compensation. Also this was in line with the downsizing activities. The most important employees
column26: including the chef and the sales people
column27: agreed to stay on. Nevertheless
column28:
only six people started activities under the new conditions in 2009.

The restructuring process can be evaluated as properly planned. Examples of other businesses in similar situations clearly demonstrated that the inability to change would have led to bankruptcy. Quick reaction to changes in the market and decisive control of a cash flow allowed GSG keep afloat.

Challenges and constraints of restructuring

Restructuring was focused on optimisation and a major reduction in the number of employees. The main challenge was to ensure a smooth lay-off process. All employees left the company on a voluntary basis. If the company had had to pay lay-off compensation it would have faced bankruptcy.

Another important challenge was to ensure the company retained key people
column29:
especially the kitchen chef. This was possible because the company’s new plan to specialise was opening new opportunities.

\r\n

GSG is anchored to a special location
column30:
so it was a challenge to secure the relationship with the tenant. Debt was increasing and tenants felt they could not work any longer with GSG. The ministry had to intervene to ensure further normal cooperation between the two parties. GSG’s flexibility and ability to understand how the tenant’s market was changing could have been better.

\r\n

And the last
column31: but not least
column32: there was a need for additional funding as the business was not able to generate enough income to pay all the ongoing expenditures. Banks at that period were not willing to lend any money
column33:
especially to SMEs. So the owners had to finance cash-flow shortfalls themselves. This was a significant problem for most of SMEs at this time and sometimes a main reason for business bankruptcy.

Restructuring advice and support

There was no crucial advice and support from external sources except one. Sustaining the relationship with tenant was a significant challenge. Debt was increasing and the tenant was not willing to wait for the money
column34:
even though GSG was renting out estate halls and generating additional income for the tenant. If the Ministry of Education had not intervened to help GSG may not have been able to survive. The Ministry’s proper and timely actions in helping to develop a mutually compatible debt payment plan were very important.

\r\n

Planning of the restructuring and financing transition period was carried out by Linas Pučinskas with no financial or managerial support from external sources.

\r\n

Linas Pučinskas is certain that financial support for SMEs during restructuring is crucial. Banks
column35: as commercial institutions
column36: are not willing to support business in such a situation
column37:
especially during a crisis. Even relatively small financial resources can be vital for ensuring the survival of SMEs under these difficult sorts of conditions.

Outcomes of restructuring

The outcome of restructuring can be evaluated as positive because the business is still operating. The company is optimised
column38:
business is sustained and debt for the tenant is covered. Another positive result is that the reputation of Linas Pučinskas as a manager and as an active participant in hospitality industry was secured. This is personally important for him as GSG is just one of the activities in this sector that he is undertaking.

\r\n

In terms of employment
column39: 30 full time jobs were lost
column40: but business was sustained. The new payment system (a minimum basic plus a variable amount dependent on the work load) worked very well for those who stayed with the company. New opportunities for self-development and family life were opened
column41:
and employees’ wages have improved as the business recovers and the work load is increasing.

\r\n

There is now no strict organisational structure; functions are spread among employees
column42: which has led to fewer internal tensions. This is very different to 2005–2008
column43:
where a vertical organisation was developing.

Commentary

Linas Pučinskas feels he learned some important lessons from the restructuring. He thinks that in the case of SMEs it is very important to act decisively in response to external changes. Some SMEs try to delay acting until the last moment
column44: which is a mistake. He adds that quick surgery is preferable to long-drawn-out suffering
column45:
with changes planned and implemented much faster than in big companies.

\r\n

In situations of rapid decline in business
column46:
it is important to relate salary payments to the cash flow and outsource all possible activities in order to reduce fixed costs. Cash flow is one of the biggest threats for SMEs in restructuring periods. State financing during those periods could be very successful in ensuring the sustainability of SMEs.

\r\n

SMEs dealing with public sector in a public-private partnership should be able to expect more flexibility from the public partner. In the fluctuating periods the position of the public institutions remains stable and business (as a less powerful participant) is left alone to weather the changes.

\r\n

However
column47:
the key to successful restructuring in SMEs remains the ability to act and implement changes very quickly.

Author

Edmundas Piesarskas

column1:
Interactive Net Design, Hungary~"Interactive Net Design Ktf."~"

Interactive Net Design
column2: a Hungarian company producing technology for the banking and finance sector
column3: underwent restructuring to pursue a change to its business model in the context of the economic crisis and reduced client budgets. New branch offices were opened in foreign markets
column4: creating new jobs in target markets
column5: but leading to the lay-off of employees at headquarters. Subsequently
column6: the company increased its sales and marketing staff abroad
column7:
and new teams were established within the company to support its business strategy. The company made a major effort to change company culture to adapt from being a small Hungarian player to becoming an international force.

"~"

Organisational profile

Interactive Net Design Kft. (later IND Group) was established in 1997 by three Hungarians who today comprise the top management team of a seven-level functional structure. In 2008
column8: the founders had to give up part of their ownership in order to obtain venture capital investment
column9: but they retained a majority influence on company decisions. With its unique ‘banking front office technology’(BFO)
column10: IND is a leading product developer and provider for the European e-finance market. The front office technology is a comprehensive range of sales and banking services  including branch
column11: internet
column12: mobile and contact centres
column13: on the same centralised platform. The technology delivers high-quality customer service while optimising sales with reduced acquisition and retention costs. IND group employed approximately 145 people in 2011
column14:
including 45 independent subcontractors who work exclusively for IND Kft.

\r\n

Of the 100 people directly employed
column15: 70 are involved in the design
column16: programming
column17:
testing and support of the banking front office technology. Employment has fluctuated in recent years:

  1. 2007
column18: there were 93 employees; in 2008
column21: 98; and in 2011
column22:
102. \r\n\r\n

Their main functions are product development
column23: marketing
column24: sales
column25: administration
column26: office management and finance. All the technology experts have
column27: on average
column28: four years’ experience in delivering internet and mobile banking solutions. Their average age is 28
column29: and 85% of them are male with higher education qualifications in software development or economics. There is no trade union or works council. At the beginning of 2009
column30:
IND bought a majority ownership stake in Simple Soft – a local competitor with six employees – and transferred all e-business clients.

\r\n

IND formed a partnership with Brokat Infosystems Ag.
column31: a major banking software developer
column32: and subsequently acquired their e-channels business unit (and in that context also took over one of the employees) in 2003 to become a primary market player. IND has experienced remarkable growth over the past few and years in the international financial IT market. It operates in several countries (Austria
column33: Germany
column34: Hungary
column35: Romania and the UK) and
column36: through their local business partner network
column37: they are represented in Bahrain
column38: Dubai
column39: Egypt
column40: Italy
column41:
Switzerland and Ukraine. They provide proficiency and state-of-the-art technology in more than 15 countries on three continents.

\r\n

The company has achieved substantial growth
column42:
although income has fluctuated during the last three years. Income in each of the last five years has been:

  1. 2007
column43: HUF 1
column44: 454 million\r\n(€5
column47: HUF 2
column48: 100 million (€7
column51: HUF 1
column52: 434 million (€4
column55: HUF 1
column56: 734 million (€5
column59: HUF 2
column60: 450 million (€8
column62:
000) (expected).

By 2008
column63:
90% of the company’s income came from the e-banking business unit and 10% from small e-business projects (webpage programming and design).

Background to restructuring event

In 2007
column64: IND management changed the business model
column65: from recruiting staff to meet specific software/application development project requirements
column66: to develop their own ‘out of the box’ software
column67: which can be customised for individual bank client needs by other providers. As a consequence
column68: the pricing and income model changed too. Bank clients now pay licence fees. This required a large investment
column69: so IND
column70: for the first time
column71:
acquired external capital. This was in the form of venture capital from Euroventures to invest in product development and entering new markets. This included opening an office in Bucharest office and forming a partnership with BSC Russia (2009); opening offices in Zagreb and Bratislava (2010); and opening an office in Warsaw (2011).

\r\n

In autumn 2008
column72: IND visited all clients to introduce their new product and to map the next year’s needs. Because of the financial crisis
column73: most clients planned budget cuts for 2009 and 2010. Banks were not planning new branch offices
column74: focusing more on electronic sales channels and
column75: therefore
column76:
in need of more e-applications.

\r\n

IND had three possible ways to prepare for the future
column77:
and they used all of them except one:

  1. cutting internal costs
column78:
increasing cost efficiency;
  • searching for new markets;
  • other possible sectors (telecommunication
column79: healthcare
column80:
public institution);
  • finding new customers in foreign markets;
  • getting larger share of its existing clients’ budget.

    • Larger firms/enterprises tend to be more inflexible and ‘froze’ in the crisis. IND
column81: however
column82: was prepared for restructuring
column83:
and had a long-term plan developed by senior management.

Restructuring processes

To pursue the new strategy
column84: new branch offices were opened in foreign markets
column85: creating new jobs in target markets. This meant that 20% of employees
column86: mostly software developers doing basic programming
column87: were dismissed at headquarters. However
column88: IND helped them to find new jobs. The company took steps to increase programming efficiency. Subsequently
column89: they reinforced their sales and marketing staff abroad but
column90: altogether they hired fewer people
column91: only 10%–12% of their original number
column92:
resulting in large savings.

\r\n

They established two new functional teams in the organisation. The first was a gap analysis team. This comprised business consultants
column93: who identified gaps between client needs and software capacity before product implementation. They specified extra functions and development needs
column94:
and ordered it from the platform team.

\r\n

The second group was the platform team
column95:
comprising software developers responsible only for product development.

\r\n

A separate R&D department with ten employees
column96: all redeployed from elsewhere was also created. This screens all innovations and trends on the markets
column97: and ensures that IND has the latest technology in its products. Team members attend conferences
column98:
read the relevant literature and keep an eye on competitors’ developments.

\r\n

In 2009
column99: IND increased attendance at conferences
column100: advertised in foreign scientific journals and became more proactive
column101: including running a sales road show in Europe and organising 150 one-on-one meetings with potential clients. As a result
column102: the number of bank requests for information and for proposals has increased. Twenty ‘hot topics’ (potential development ideas) were collected. These ideas were presented to potential clients
column103: to identify what those clients would buy For example
column104: instead of expensive sms notification
column105: they could develop ‘push alert’ for mobile application. This changed the business model. Instead of selling developer days
column106: they started selling bespoke software for a licence fee
column107:
offering customisation as an extra service.

\r\n

They did not waste time on large impact studies
column108: or detailed analysis. All decisions were made at management meetings
column109:
and followed by rapid execution.

There were painful but efficient steps:

  1. dismissal of employees
column110: quick budget cut on benefits
column111:
focus on those employees possessing most of the company’s knowledge;
  • renegotiation of fixed costs – for example
column112: \r\nchanging mobile operator
column113:
other suppliers;
  • cut overheads (administration and back office);
  • increase trips to sales meetings;
  • invest in foreign offices.

    • IND was aware that it was very difficult to increase its share of the Hungarian market as the domestic financial market was shrinking fast. Therefore
column114: they reduced their domestic operational budget. During the process
column115:
they faced a choice of:

  1. entering other sectors using their competitive advantage in R&D;
  2. continuing to focus on their core activity and enter foreign markets.

Management decided to keep core people and exploit new opportunities
column116: but their plan B in case of failure
column117:
was to retain 20 people capable of rebuilding the company from scratch within a year.

\r\n

In 2010
column118: production support was further cut back while marketing and sales were increased. The marketing department grew from one to five people and became more professional
column119: for example
column120:
preparing product marketing documentation and website development.

\r\n

Negative impacts of restructuring meant a benefits freeze for all staff for 2009
column121: and in 2010
column122: all sales bonuses were cut. Despite the restrictions
column123: they pushed employees to take on increased workload and responsibility
column124:
in order to reach international standard.

Challenges and constraints of restructuring

The main challenge was to encourage employees to believe in the future of the company. Employees were aware of the sales decline and dismissals and were worried about job security. In order to be able to participate in international projects
column125: employees were expected to travel more and to be more fluent in foreign languages
column126:
so training sessions were offered by the company.

\r\n

Management felt constrained by the company culture in trying to adapt from being a small Hungarian player to becoming an international force. The best tool to effect cultural change was intensive internal communication. The founder
column127: Balázs Vinnai
column128: introduced quarterly meetings for employees
column129: to inform them of prior achievements and future plans. A monthly newsletter was also introduced
column130:
to allay employee worries. These measures convinced employees they were able to compete at the international level.

\r\n

A trainer was hired to encourage employees to change the company culture over one year. Team building and internal communication training took place outside the company. Management looked closely at whether employees were spending enough time on their duties
column131: and discovered that although most employees believed they worked long hours
column132: they actually worked fewer than 40 hours a week. Managers also believed employees should take more responsibility for the company and the products. This was difficult to achieve as workers had been used to working in an isolated way
column133: and blaming colleagues rather than helping each other solve problems. Training helped everybody accept responsibility. Management also emphasised product quality as the top priority
column134: in order to distinguish the company from competitors. IND’s products were no longer the cheapest
column135:
but expected to be among the best. Management also wanted the company to be more innovative and adopt the latest technology faster.

Restructuring advice and support

The owners and managers also looked at their own personal development
column136: by reading international business literature
column137:
and books on coping with crises. The company also used internal support for change management.

\r\n

The key success factor was good internal communications and high employee motivation to take responsibility. Following the introduction of these cultural changes
column138:
employees switched from a position of resistance to being strong supporters of restructuring.

The resultant success has led to management predicting that they will be taking on at least 50 new workers in the next three years.

Outcomes of restructuring

The restructuring process was planned and well-managed. Early on
column139: the founders recognised the market trends. They did not hesitate to change their business model completely from quantitative to qualitative growth. Instead of hiring new employees and charging their time to clients
column140:
IND Kft developed a product generating higher added value. This bespoke software product is more of a solution (such as SAP) than a daily billed software development service.

\r\n

IND reached their goal of getting the company back into growth in 2011. Although the company is more vulnerable today by focusing on a niche market
column141: they are also less at risk because of geographical expansion. Despite the large number of organisational levels
column142:
they remain a fast-reacting medium-size company.

\r\n

Investment in software has enabled IND to become a market leader worldwide. Product quality has improved substantially and quality control has worked well. Now they can negotiate with any large international bank
column143: but now they must compete with large international competitors. Forrester Research
column144: one of the world’s largest research companies
column145: has
column146: in a recent survey
column147:
included IND Group among the global players.

\r\n

The focus has shifted towards international sales. For IND
column148:
the goal is to conquer the most advanced financial institution markets. Rapid growth in 2011 offered new opportunities. At the Finovate 2011 conference in New York – a unique conference series showcasing financial and banking technology innovations – the company introduced two new applications. Both received very good feedback from delegates; all experts from financial institutions and banks.

\r\n

Last
column149: but not least
column150:
the young general manager and the company have received numerous innovation and entrepreneur awards.

2009

Knight’s Cross Order of Merit of The Republic of Hungary (civil division) to Dr Balazs Vinnai

Technology Innovation Award for IND iMobile Banking / Innovation Grand Prize by Hungarian Association for Innovation

CIB Internet Bank: Best Retail Internet Bank – Gold-level Award / Privatbankar

Unicredit: Best Bank Website – Gold-level Award / Privatbankar

IT and Consulting Partner of the Year of CIB Bank a Bank of Intesa Sanpaolo

Innovation Partner of the Year of CIB Bank for mobilCIB (IND iMobile Banking)

2008

eFestival 2008 awards: in category Tourism/Settlement for the implementation of tourism portal vendegvaro.hu and in category e-Services for the multifunctional banking portal of Unicredit Bank.

CIB Bank: Bank of the Year 2008 – First place / Mastercard

CIB Bank: Electronic Retail Banking Service of the Year 2008 –First place (among others for mobilCIB)/Mastercard

2007

The Hungarian Venture Capital and Private Equity Association awarded the IND Group as the Company of the Year

The CIB Internet Bank won the Mastercard Innovative Bank of the Year and the Bank of the Year

Commentary

IND participates in EU research and other IT programmes. As leader of an IT cluster
column151:
it does a lot for regional development. Success has positive effects on other SMEs and subcontractors in Miskolc.

\r\n

The case has some general implications. In restructuring
column152:
companies should consider:

  1. preparing different scenarios;
  2. analysing client needs;
  3. acquisition instead of investment;
  4. decreasing risk by geographical expansion;
  5. transparent operations;
  6. ensuring better internal communication;
  7. securing key employees.

Liturimex viešbučiai, Lithuania~"Liturimex viešbučiai"~"

A Lithuanian company operating in hotels and catering ran into trouble when having to guarantee bank loans
column2:
outstanding money and the economic crisis coincided. A court appointed a new administrator to try and save the company. All employees lost their jobs but many were subsequently rehired.

"~"

Organisational profile

Liturimex viešbučiai was established in 1996 as private limited company in the hospitality sector. It owns a hotel and a guest house in the resort of Druskininkai. The company is now a ‘restructuring joint stock company’ because of a court decision. This means it is restricted in transferring the assets and has an obligation to pay off all approved liabilities
column3: but in other actions and transfers may act as other joint stock companies. After the company fulfils its legal obligations and the restructuring period is over
column4: it can claim the status of a joint stock company. The company is based in Lithuania’s capital
column5:
Vilnius.

\r\n

The main activity of Company is the hospitality business (hotel
column6: including provision of conference services
column7: and restaurant). According to the approved restructuring plan
column8:
the company does not intend to change its business profile.

\r\n

The company has two buildings in Druskininkai – the Regina hotel which has 40 rooms
column9: a restaurant and two conference halls
column10: and a guest house with 11 rooms. Both are in the centre of the resort close to the main attractions such as an aqua park
column11: biking
column12: walk and riding paths
column13: a forest park
column14: spa
column15:
and snow skiing/snowboarding arena. The three-star hotel was the first in the town to meet European standards for hotels and kept this status until 2004.

\r\n

Druskininkai is one of Lithuania’s four main resorts
column16: about 130 km from Vilnius and very close to the Polish and Belorussian borders. The resort is a spa town
column17: offering mineral baths
column18: mud and climate therapies. It is becoming an international all-year round resort: the share of foreign tourists is increasing every year
column19: that is
column20:
from 27% in 2007 to 41% in 2011. However the share of local and national tourists has decreased.

\r\n

This trend is reflected in the register of the hotel: in 2009
column21: about half the guests were foreign tourists whereas in 2011 this share had risen to two thirds. The company has an international presence
column22: with sales to foreign tourists counting as exports. The nationality of the hotel guests is also changing. During 2009–2011 there was a significant increase in the number of tourists from Poland
column23: Russia
column24: Belorussia
column25: with a slow increase in the number of tourists from Germany and the UK while the number of tourists from Latvia and Israel remained almost the same. Indeed
column26: the tourists from Poland
column27: Russia
column28: and Belorussia helped to balance out the effect of the financial crisis
column29:
which was at its peak in the hotel business in 2010. About three quarters of Lithuanians staying at the hotel come from Vilnius and Kaunas (the country’s second city) while those living close to Druskininkai are very rare.

\r\n

The company is a part of a larger organisation
column30: of other hospitality sector companies
column31: such as a travel agency
column32:
car rental business and guest house.

\r\n

The company’s main shareholder
column33: before restructuring
column34: was Rimvydas Aniulis who
column35: together with a manager
column36: was involved in running the business on a daily basis. During the restructuring process he became a creditor
column37: when the shares were sold to Liturimex grupė and to another person (who remains anonymous
column38: by law). In January 2012
column39:
the main shareholders were:

  1. private company Liturimex grupė (77.35% of the shares);
  2. private company ‘Liturimex’ (9.4%)
  3. private company SRTP (9% );
  4. an anonymous person
column40: not Rimvydas Aniulis
column41:
(4%)

The previous main shareholder still has some shares in other private companies – in ‘Liturimex grupė’ and ‘Liturimex kelionių agentūra’ (the travel agency) which is undergoing bankruptcy proceedings
column42: but Liturimex viešbučiai is still operating and has good prospects for a successful exit from restructuring and for future development. It is run by a board of three people
column43: chaired by Rimvydas Aniulis (now a creditor) and has enough power to influence the restructuring. It and the group of its indirectly related companies together comply with definition of SME (in terms of turnover
column44: assets
column45: number of employees
column46: including share or managing rights in other companies) and had less than 100 employees before restructuring started. However
column47: before restructuring
column48:
the companies were not legally seen as a group or holding: they were connected simply by having the same shareholder.

\r\n

Business increased for Liturimex viešbučiai after 2001 with significant growth during 2006–2007. There was a drop in sales in 2008–2009 and although there was slow growth in sales in 2011 (LTA 2.1 million

At the beginning of 2009 the company had 42 employees

column53: according to restructuring law. After that only three previous employees were rehired (the chief accountant
column54: administrator in reception and one employee). A new manager was hired

however during restructuring the reception administrator and the employee were dismissed and in January of 2012 only the manager and accountant were employed in the company.

Before restructuring about 20% of employees had high or higher education and were able to speak two or more foreign languages

professional or special education. About two thirds of employees were women. Almost all employees were local.

After restructuring

approved by the creditors board. This operating company has rehired about 60% of the previous employees. The qualifications and experience of the current employees are good and appropriate for the current activities.

Due to the low number of employees before restructuring there was no work council or trade union presence in the company. There were no special strategies for human resources

or corporate social responsibility. There was only a verbal commitment of being honest to all stakeholders.

Background to restructuring event

In 2004
column61: the company decided to extend and modernise the hotel
column62: and it applied for EU structural funds assistance (grant up to 50%). The applicant also put up some own finance

column67:
it asked the company to pay a previous loan before its original deadline. This meant the company would have to complete the project by using its own resources – using all its working capital.

However
column68: the company was also a guarantor of loans to the other related companies. When the economic crisis started in 2008

column70:
at a point when the occupancy rate in the hotel Regina was beginning to fall.

\r\n

This difficult financial situation for the company was worsened by a 5% increase in VAT
column71: to 21%. The company started to run out of working capital; its cash flow from sales decreased
column72: which led to debts to creditors
column73: employees
column74: suppliers
column75: the tax inspectorate and
column76: crucially

column80:
shareholders of the Company and related companies. According to the Restructuring Law of Lithuania creditors have initiated a restructuring case at the Court in 2009. This is a typical example of internal and formal (with proceedings in the Court) restructuring type.

\r\n

Vilnius District Court ruled that the restructuring case for the company should proceed while the other related company (travel agency) should face bankruptcy proceedings. No action was taken on another related company

which was operating successfully.

The external drivers of restructuring were:

  1. the economic crisis in Europe (which affected foreign tourists) and in Lithuania (which discouraged national tourists);
  2. inadequate regulation of banking sector and unfair behaviour of banks;
  3. suddenly increased taxation;
  4. adverse affect of the actions of state institutions.

Internal causes were:

  1. the mismanagement of cash flows;
  2. too high liabilities;
  3. under-evaluation of possible risks.

The impact of external factors was deeper than that of the internal factors and couldn’t be controlled. The changes in business environment (under-regulation of the banking sector
column83: increasing taxes
column84: actions or inaction of state institutions) affected the company not only directly
column85: but indirectly too
column86: as other people and companies facing some or all of the same problems could not use the company’ services any more. The effect of the economic crisis is visible in the nationality of the guests: since 2009 the share of tourists from Poland
column87: Russia and Belorussia
column88: which had been little affected by the crisis
column89:
were increasing.

\r\n

The internal causes could not be explained only by a lack of managerial ability. The owner and managers had long experience in hospitality
column90: and the company had operated successfully for many years. Expanding too fast and over-extending business development is still very risky in Lithuania. Lack of the ability to plan long-term was the main internal cause of the restructuring
column91:
rather than lack of managerial capacities.

Restructuring processes

The company began its restructuring before it was formally ordered to do so by the court. As its financial difficulties mounted after 2008
column92: the company’s shareholders (the main shareholder and small shareholder) started to consider restructuring as possible option to save the company together with selling some shares to other investors. In order to make up for the lost bank loan two new shareholders (Liturimex and SRTP) came into the company. Legal advice was taken and in February 2009 shareholders agreed on restructuring if insolvency problems arose. They also considered inviting the participation of other financial institutions
column93:
but this option could not be realised due to later events.

\r\n

However
column94: the situation then worsened very suddenly in the other related companies and the company
column95: as guarantor for their loans became responsible for paying their debts. The bank announced that it intended to take over all the businesses
column96: including the company
column97:
using bankruptcy proceedings. At this point the shareholders decided to start restructuring proceedings immediately for the company and undergo bankruptcy proceedings with the other companies.

\r\n

A written four-year plan for restructuring was prepared with the participation of the company’s shareholders
column98: board members
column99: creditors
column100:
lawyers and consultants. It was submitted to the court in Vilnius for formal approval at the end of 2009.

\r\n

A restructuring administrator was appointed. A company management body
column101: with a general manager
column102:
was given the task of supervising the plan’s implementation with mandatory accounting to an assembly of creditors. The court gave its final approval of the plan on 4 February 2010.

The plan’s objectives were to:

  1. repay all the creditors according to schedule;
  2. save and continue the business;
  3. avoid bankruptcy;
  4. restore long-term solvency of the Company and its ability to fulfil liabilities to creditor
  5. save existing jobs;
  6. reorganise the company
column103:
putting it back into profit;
  • restore and increase the value of the company and earn higher profit in future.
  • indicative duration of the restructuring plan was four years after its approval with the possibility to complete earlier if all debts to creditors and liabilities were fulfilled before deadline.

    • In order to restore solvency the creditors’ claims were approved

by selling the guest house.

\r\n

Running the hotel and the restaurant were divided into the separate activities and transferred to an operating company in 2010. The restaurant operating contract lasts until 1 September of 2013

The income goes towards paying off debts and other liabilities. The company still disposes the asset (based on reverse leasing contract with bank)

used in the restaurant and hotel operation. It also runs the accommodation at the guest house (although reservations go through the hotel).

A special reverse leasing agreement was signed in 2010. This meant the hotel and restaurant buildings were sold to a bank and then leased back to the company. Income from this was used to pay creditors. Recovery could be realised more quickly by:

  1. finding a purchaser for the estate;
  2. refinancing;
  3. attracting other financial institutions or strategic investor.

Finding an investor might be quite easy if the global economy stabilises because the company is still very attractive. It is in a favourable location (in the centre of resort and the resort is rapidly developing)

column115: loyal clients
column116: and a stable income. However
column117: finding a financial institution might not be so easy
column118:
due to a tightening of requirements in the finance sector.

employees; \r\n

  • third tier

other creditors.

\r\n

The plan meant that all 42 employees were dismissed. Only three were rehired

\r\n

A fund for salaries of employees was established

\r\n

The restructuring period can be counted from the date of shareholders’ decision for restructuring (4 February 2009) or from date of decision of the court to start the restructuring case (11 November 2009). The final date would be 1 September 2013 or the date when all liabilities to creditors will be fulfilled

column136:
restaurant and guest house.

\r\n

In 2011 there were higher incomes than expected from the hotel
column137: restaurant and accommodation at the guest house

column140: as well as in the company’s European export markets (Poland
column141:
Germany and the UK).

Challenges and constraints of restructuring

The main challenges were:

  1. dealing with the banks in court to try to avoid the bankruptcy proceedings;
  2. getting court approval for restructuring;
  3. finding operators for the hotel and restaurant;
  4. getting the operators to rehire at least 60% of employees;
  5. saving the business.

The company needed a lot of legal assistance to withstand the bank’s pressure and intimidation and to act fast against the bank in court proceedings by submitting a great deal of documentation.

The search for people to run the hotel and restaurant was a huge challenge due to the economic crisis
column142: however
column143:
specialist consultants were used and favourable contracts were signed.

Restructuring advice and support

The company paid for the preparation of the restructuring plan and the restructuring process including the redundancy money
column144: and fees for lawyers and consultants. The company and shareholders paid for the court costs
column145: which were significant. No external financial or non-financial support was received either from state
column146: municipal or other public funds or from private institutions such as banks or business associations. Moreover
column147:
the State Social Security Fund froze all the company’s accounts and paralysed all activities which could have contributed to paying debts.

\r\n

While planning the restructuring
column148: and during the restructuring process
column149: lawyers and consultants gave advice to shareholders
column150: including the company board
column151:
and later to creditors too. These services were paid for by the shareholders; their costs were relatively low and effectiveness of such services could be assessed as very high.

\r\n

The important role of the shareholders should also be stressed – they were actively involved in finding possible solutions. Their long-term experience in the hotel business
column152:
and knowledge of business diversification (such as the hotel travel agency and car rental) and membership of a business association helped them be realistic in:

  1. evaluating the situation;
  2. coming up with two possible solutions;
  3. considering and planning restructuring.

The court proceedings were fair and helped to save the business

column154:
with the restructuring plan being implemented in 2010.

\r\n

Lithuanian law does not take into account the need for SMEs to have financial support during restructuring
column155: when the small cost of subsidising redundancy pay
column156: or retraining
column157: or helping employees to find new jobs would be welcome. People can apply for financial support or training at the Labour Exchange only after dismissal. This upset and frustrated the company’s employees

column159:
unpleasant dismissal procedure and uncertain future.

Outcomes of restructuring

The main outcome is that the business has been saved from bankruptcy and has good prospects. The first stage of restructuring is on course to be completed successfully.

Another outcome is the two contracts with the hotel and restaurant operators
column160:
which provide the company with a stable cash flow.

\r\n

The employees’ first reaction to the restructuring announcement was negative

column163:
many employees were upset by the company’s difficult situation.

\r\n

However there was a positive outcome in that about 60% of the employees were given jobs by the restaurant and hotel operators. Another 10%–15% of employees found similar jobs elsewhere in Druskininkai. Unfortunately
column164:
about 25%–30% of employees did not find a job in the resort and have emigrated.

\r\n

Another outcome is the salaries fund
column165: which has special terms for fixed annual growth
column166:
and a possibility of bonuses for achieving sales targets.

\r\n

No human resource strategy is foreseen until after the restructuring process is completed.

\r\n

Overall
column167: restructuring has more positive outcomes than negative ones. The business is saved
column168: the company is on its way to solving its debt problems
column169: and some previous employees are still working in the same hotel
column170: restaurant and guest house
column171:
and there are good prospects for future development and job creation.

Commentary

There are a number of important differences between restructuring in SMEs and restructuring in large organisations.

Large companies have more power in negotiating with banks or other creditors
column172: have more managerial and planning capacities and experience
column173: and therefore they make fewer and smaller mistakes. Large companies are also less sensitive to changes in the business environment
column174:
such as changes in taxation or the introduction of new legal requirements.

\r\n

However
column175: large companies could be affected more by the economic crisis due to higher total operating costs. Also
column176:
when larger companies downsize the effect on unemployment is higher. Sometimes a large company is the only significant employer in a small town.

\r\n

Large companies depend less on public investments because they have their own resources to pay for new facilities. In the hotel’s case there was no public information about the town’s plans for investing in a huge spa complex. If the company had known about these
column177: it would not have invested unnecessarily in such facilities itself. This information was kept secret by the municipality
column178: but the situation has improved since 2007
column179:
because all public investment programmes have now to be published.

\r\n

Large companies have more resources (managerial and financial) to plan restructuring and can call on additional external resources if needed. Therefore they can implement and manage restructuring better than SMEs. As a result
column180: many larger companies are more able to adapt to a changing environment
column182: splitting a restructuring plan into a few stages or postponing some actions
column183: and they have more flexibility to deal early with crises and to dismiss employees step by step. An SME usually has no external support
column184: although the company did use paid external lawyers and
column185:
advisors. Large companies can also apply for financial support for retraining during the dismissal process.

\r\n

Trade unions or work councils can play an important role in the restructuring of large companies. However
column186: sometimes their intervention has negative effects due to groundless claims or the protraction of restructuring
column187:
which may lead to bankruptcy. Trade unions and work councils are much less common in SMEs.

\r\n

In this case study
column188: the absence of a trade union or works council does not appear to have damaged the employees’ interests. However
column189: their absence meant the company did not need to negotiate terms
column190:
allowing it instead immediately to begin restructuring when the situation became complicated. This enabled the company to save the business and a lot of jobs.

\r\n

Employees were informed in proper time and in writing
column191: the terms of dismissal complied with restructuring law
column192:
and all compensation was paid. The fixed annual salary fund was not required by law.

\r\n

This company’s experience demonstrated a need for advisory support. The company’s use of legal and other consultants’ advice was atypical for SMEs
column193: but contributed greatly to successful restructuring. The respondent would advise the use of such services despite costs
column194:
which are relatively low.

\r\n

This kind of support is needed because of weaknesses in the regulation of the banking sector
column195: which enabled a bank to treat an SME unfairly with uneven contracting and negotiation power. Publically supported advisory services for SMEs in planning
column197:
and risk assessments could help prevent many mistakes and consequent bankruptcies or restructuring.

\r\n

The inadequate behaviour of state institutions when SMEs are facing difficulties (such as freezing accounts) paralysed the company’s behaviour. This kind of behaviour must change
column198: if SMEs are to make a full contribution to economic development. This includes providing advisory support for SMEs interested in accessing EU structural funds. State institutions do not seem interested in the success of SMEs’ projects. Also
column199: mistakes by public officials cannot be changed
column200:
whatever a court decides. The decision by the State Social Security Fund to freeze the company’s account was illogical and contributed to the company’s difficulties. This kind of attitude in state institutions should be eliminated as part of a package of measures to improve the business environment in Lithuania.

\r\n

The legal regulation of the restructuring process could also be improved by simplifying and shortening procedures
column201: banning the freezing of accounts of companies in difficulties
column202:
and by eliminating the requirement to dismiss all employees during restructuring while the dismissal of just some would be enough.

The respondent in this study has identified these major success factors in restructuring:

  1. a realistic understanding of the situation;
  2. consensus among shareholders;
  3. timely advice from lawyers and other consultants;
  4. immediate reaction to the situation with a clear and realistic restructuring plan;
  5. court proceedings strengthened the company’s negotiating position with banks;
  6. attractiveness of the business.

In future the company will plan any extensions and business development more carefully
column204: and formulating measures to manage those identified. The EU structural funds support brought unexpected complications
column205: with requirements to fulfil public procurement rules (normally not applicable to companies)
column206: extra requirements introduced during the implementation of the project
column207:
and a different interpretation of whether obligations had been fulfilled.

\r\n

The liabilities to the bank of all the related companies were too high
column208:
and in future the role of the company as guarantor for loans to the other companies should be considered more carefully. Any decision to act as guarantor should take into account the company’s abilities to continue to operate effectively if the other companies experience difficulties.

\r\n

Challenges and constraints of restructuring

\r\n

The main difficulty for managers in restructuring was reaching an agreement with workers. According to the managers interviewed
column97: they tried to build consensus with workers’ representatives
column98: in order to make the restructuring process as smooth as possible
column99: but feel disappointed with the works council. The management board considers that workers’ representatives incorrectly defined the internationalisation process as a ‘delocalisation process’
column100: especially during negotiations for the second employment adjustment plan. They feel workers’ representatives tried to undermine the social image of the company
column101:
as a consequence of the temporary suspensions of working contracts and the dismissals.

\r\n

Nonetheless
column102: it seems that workers’ representatives now recognise that
column103: to a certain extent
column104: the current workload in the Eibar factory exists thanks to the internationalisation process
column105:
the subsequent enlargement of its customer base and the increase in sales. All of the company’s compressors are machined and assembled at Eibar; Brazil and China are only assembly plants.

\r\n

The problems and challenges experienced were typical of any company opening a plant in Brazil or China. Barriers included understanding tax and duty policies
column106: and cultural differences. To overcome initial problems
column107: they contracted a local consultancy firm to obtain all of the required information and support regarding the issues such as local/regional business culture
column108: legal issues
column109:
accounting and tax. They also drew up solid agreements with well-recognised local agents and distributors.

\r\n

To staff the new foreign plants
column110: the company hired local workers
column111: which caused many cultural/social problems. They thought it would be good to have local intermediate managers running the subsidiaries
column112: in charge of the local workforce
column113: mainly because they provide the necessary knowledge of the local business culture and market
column114: and are in a better position to drive the business forward. Moreover
column115: apart from hiring local workers
column116: it was necessary to send two or three expatriated workers from Spain for one to five years in order to control the development of the new plant
column117:
supervise business operations and configure the human resource structure.

\r\n

As a whole
column118: during internationalisation processes
column119: it is common to find problems with expatriate workers as well as with local workers
column120: especially due to culture shock and misunderstandings. Indeed
column121: opening a new plant abroad leads to lots of problems
column122: but little by little
column123:
these problems can be solved.

\r\n

Restructuring advice and support

\r\n

Managers have received good support from Spanish public authorities. The administrative process for the plan to adjust employment levels went smoothly
column124: and outcomes such as the wage compensation arose as expected. Moreover
column125: the company said it received financial and non-financial support for internationalisation from the Regional Government of Gipuzkoa
column126: the Basque Government through SPRI (Basque Society for Competitive Transformation)
column127: and from the Spanish Government through ICEX (Spanish Institute of Foreign Trade). The company is satisfied with all of the support received
column128:
and considers that Spain has good public measures to promote internationalisation.

\r\n

The company also asked a private firm to advise them with regard to their internationalisation strategy and to write a number of market research reports. They also contracted local consultancy firms in China and Brazil in order to get general information and support about issues such as business culture
column129: legal points
column130:
accounting and tax in the destination markets.

The company is also seeking public financial support for their plans to invest in a new research and development plant in Eibar.

Outcomes of restructuring

According to the managers
column131:
restructuring has led the company to be much more competitive and to enlarge its presence in global markets.

\r\n

During 2011
column132: company results improved. More workers have been hired
column133:
so employment levels have fully recovered. The ten dismissals which took place in January 2010 have already been covered again over the last months.

\r\n

Moreover
column134: the company is increasingly making use of subcontracting practices
column135: as it gives more flexibility in relation to fluctuations in demand levels. The experience of the 2009–2010 crisis was so traumatic
column136:
that they do not want to take the risk of hiring too many workers in case of a future drop in demand.(they do not want to have a very rigid and weighty human resources structure).

\r\n

On the other hand
column137: labour relations within the company have also changed over the last couple of years
column138: mainly as a consequence of the tense situation derived from unproductive negotiations and the subsequent strike at the beginning of 2010. Given this delicate situation
column139: a pact was signed in the summer of 2011 between workers’ representatives and the management board
column140:
in order to facilitate and promote a more fluid relationship. The situation is still complicated.

\r\n

Looking to the future
column141: the company is interested in developing its R&D unit
column142: and expanding its sales and service network
column143: particularly its repair and after-sales services. Moreover
column144:
they are working on the opening of a new assembly plant in India.

\r\n

Commentary

\r\n

With regard to lessons learnt
column145: the company management board has had a very poor experience concerning the negotiations with workers’ representatives. Noticeably
column146: these difficulties had a very bad impact on the running of the company and on its social image. Managers have learnt that having a smooth relationship with workers is very positive for business performance. For this reason
column147:
they have signed the previously mentioned agreement with the works council. Managers regret that the works council is not collaborative and they are highly aware that the situation could always get worse.

\r\n

Concerning internationalisation
column148: company managers believe that it is very important to reflect deeply on all issues involved
column149: as it is essential to have very clear objectives. It is also necessary to avoid being discouraged easily
column150: as internationalisation projects are likely to be profitable only in the medium/long term. Internationalisation provides great opportunities for business success
column151: but persistence is needed. For managers
column152: this means remaining open to diversity and to continuous change. Internationalisation is
column153: to a large extent
column154: a ‘learning by doing’ process
column155: and requires an effort to adapt
column156: as each market has its particular specifications. Therefore
column157: in order to overcome all obstacles that arise
column158:
a persistent attitude is indispensable.

\r\n

However
column159: according to an article published in a regional newspaper
column160: workers’ representatives attacked managers for trying to deprive local people of jobs by reducing the level of activity in Eibar
column161: while hiring people in China and Brazil to work in the new plants there. Moreover
column162: workers’ representatives consider that managers have hidden information about the company sales and income
column163: as well as business objectives and strategies. Company managers deny this. Unfortunately
column164: it has not been possible to talk to a worker representative. As was underlined in the previous sections
column165: the relationship between the management board and the works council is still very tense
column166:
so the interviewed managers did not want to provide us with any contact name among the workers.
