column1:
Friedrich Marx, Germany~"Friedrich Marx GmbH & Co. KG"~"

When German company Friedrich Marx was hit by the global economic crisis
column2: it implemented a restructuring process including the injection of new capital and internal reorganisation. This involved the reduction of costs through dismissals and short-time working. In the beginning
column3: this was perceived as unfair by the staff and resulted in a dampened and mistrustful atmosphere
column4: exacerbated by rumours and fears that further dismissals were imminent. The atmosphere improved when management clearly communicated the firm’s situation and its plans
column5:
and when employees could see themselves that the company’s situation was improving.

"~"

Organisational profile

\r\n

Friedrich Marx GmbH & Co KG is a technical wholesale and retail company selling security systems (such as time-recording
column6: access control
column7: video monitoring)
column8: truck and car products (fleet management
column9: navigation and positioning systems
column10: taxi meters)
column11: marine products (motors
column12: leisure boats
column13: equipment for steering and gearing) and motor industry (engines and motor equipment). In general
column14: the company is an exclusive partner of several leading manufacturers in its sales areas and it offers its customers individual solutions and advice from project planning to implementation and maintenance. Furthermore
column15: a garage for trucks
column16: cars and marine craft is run as a subsidiary company. Its customers include small
column17: as well as large well known companies
column18:
and public clients.

\r\n

The company
column19: a fourth-generation family business
column20: was founded in 1905. Since then
column21: there have been numerous change and diversification processes
column22:
seen as necessary to its growth. Current annual sales amount to about €13 million.

\r\n

There are about 60 employees
column23: with a further ten employees in the subsidiary company. They have either trained as wholesale or retail traders
column24:
or are skilled technical workers (such as graduate engineers and motor vehicle mechatronics technicians). They are aged from 18 (trainees) to 62 years. The average job tenure of 16 years means the company is characterised by a low labour turnover.

\r\n

For about 30 years
column25: the management has been designed in such a way that the owner is responsible for technical and sales aspects while another person is responsible for the commercial area (finance and human resources organisation). In the beginning this was done by appointing an authorised officer; however
column26: in the 1990s
column27: the position of commercial chief executive officer was created. The person who currently does this job has been working for the company since 2006. He has a great deal of experience in the field of company restructuring
column28:
having previously worked as restructuring consultant.

\r\n

There are five sales or department managers responsible for the individual business units and the staff members working there. The business units are administered as autonomous cost centres in order to allow them to be individually monitored for effectiveness and efficiency
column29:
while at the same time giving them a certain level of autonomy.

\r\n

There is a works council in the company
column30:
but it was only marginally involved in the restructuring process.

\r\n

Background to restructuring event

\r\n

In 2008
column31: the company experienced sales growth of 9% for the third year in a row and started to adapt its internal structures for the expected further growth. However
column32: the planned restructuring went slowly as profit margins were not very good
column33: the debts of the subsidiary company had to be covered
column34:
and the company could not make many savings.

\r\n

In autumn 2008
column35:
the company suddenly lost some important German clients who were active on international markets but who experienced a sharp drop in their own business due to the global financial and economic crisis and hence could no longer place orders with Marx. The effect of this chain reaction was that the company realised a sales decrease of slightly more than 22% in 2009 compared to 2008. This was mainly based on the development of the trade-oriented business units while the area of security systems was less affected in the short run as it is characterised by a stronger project orientation with longer order cycles.

\r\n

To counteract this decrease
column36: which was caused by the financial and economic crisis
column37:
a restructuring process was implemented. Next to strategies to save costs it included the infusion of new capital and the initiation of company internal reorganisation measures.

\r\n

Restructuring processes

\r\n

The restructuring plan drafted by the company management as soon as the current and future difficulties became obvious was scheduled over two years
column38:
until the end of 2011. This was later supplemented by other measures extending until 2013.

\r\n

The plan
column39: developed by the management
column40: was presented to employees at the beginning of 2009 at a general staff meeting. The plan set out not only measures to reduce costs (mainly dismissals and short-time working
column41:
and also company internal reorganisation) but also to start negotiations with the firm’s banks about access to additional capital.

\r\n

The 22% drop in sales led to immediate cuts in costs. Rent
column42: for example
column43:
was reduced considerably by taking advantage of the change of ownership of the firm’s office building. The lease agreement was terminated and cheaper rooms were rented.

\r\n

All employees who still were in their trial period were dismissed. Workers in the business units most affected by the sales drop were made redundant; employees with the shortest job tenure were selected for this
column44: and a total
column45:
of six or seven employees were dismissed in those two measures.

\r\n

Further redundancies were avoided by introducing short-time working for all the company’s other employees. Working time was reduced by 30% and this measure lasted for two years
column46: although as the economic situation improved and orders grew
column47: the short-time working level was reduced to 10%
column48:
with workers in some sub-units returning to normal working hours six months before their colleagues.

\r\n

Employees
column49: shocked at the news of the measures
column50: felt they were being unfairly asked to bear the negative consequences of a crisis for which they were not responsible. However
column51:
some of the workers understood that management was trying to maintain the highest possible number of jobs with the introduction of short-time working and made their colleagues aware that the alternative would be further dismissals. This raised the understanding and solidarity among the employees so that the introduction of short-time working was accepted. anagement then won over their workers by showing them that a 10% working time reduction did not result in a net wage loss of 10% but only 4% while they could take advantage of 10% more spare time.

\r\n

However
column52: these cost savings were not sufficient to counteract the high sales decrease
column53: and it became obvious that next to the extra cash already injected by the owner additional funds would be needed to promote the liquidity of the company and make it survive the financial and economic crisis. Accordingly
column54: the firm’s three banks were contacted
column55:
the restructuring concept including a liquidity plan presented and access to additional capital negotiated.

\r\n

Due to the expertise and experience of the commercial chief executive officer in the field of restructuring
column56: the firm’s banks were contacted in spring 2009 – when he could see they were heading for a crisis
column57: but before it hit them. Not least because of this early approach
column58: the banks were generally willing to provide capital. However
column59: they requested an expert testimony by an independent third party. This was ordered by Marx from a private specialist consulting company which specialised in accompanying companies in crisis situations. Before the restructuring
column60: the company did not have any contacts with this consultant. However
column61: because of his own experience as a restructuring consultant
column62: the commerical chief executive officer knew the consultant by name. Together with the consultant
column63:
the company again negotiated with the banks and presented the results of the consultant’s assessment in mid 2009.

\r\n

The consultant’s positive forecast resulted in the banks’ agreeing to provide credit worth €500
column64: 000 in December 2009. However
column65: this was conditional on the owner providing further capital
column66: the workers forgoing their Christmas and holiday pay for two years and the largest strategic suppliers agree to a delay in their payment. Furthermore
column67: the banks requested a debt guarantee of € 1.5 million for the offered capital. This was provided by the owner
column68: who assigned his life insurance
column69:
and the charge on his home) and the Hamburg Alliance for Loan Guarantees (Bürgschaftsgemeinschaft Hamburg) (see below).

\r\n

After initial unwillingness the employees accepted the deal
column70:
as management pointed out that the Christmas and holiday remunerations would be paid when it was again economically feasible.

\r\n

The firm’s two or three largest suppliers also agreed: Friedrich Marx had been working for them as an exclusive importer for years and it would have been a considerable effort for them to find a replacement at short notice.

\r\n

The banks’ final condition was that the restructuring consultant monitored the planned measures for two years. This is a very common procedure in such situations. Due to the positive economic development of the company
column71: however
column72:
the consultancy could be stopped in 2010.

\r\n

This restructuring was also used to push forward the internal reorganisation that had been started in 2008
column73: as part of the planned growth strategy. This meant
column74: for example
column75: that sales were restructured. The company had products in its portfolio that were legally required (such as trip recorders for trucks) and was the exclusive representative for the manufacturer who held 90% of the market share. This had led to a rather passive attitude to sales of these items
column76: with the company mainly reacting to customers’ enquiries. In the meantime
column77: however
column78: both the product portfolio as well as the market had changed. Consequently a sales strategy was developed with pro-active sales and the acquisition of clients in the forefront
column79:
leading to more targets set and better monitoring of the achievement of objectives.

\r\n

These adjustments also required changes related to human resources. Due to the long tenure of the staff
column80: the responsibility felt by the employer especially for the older workers
column81: and the high severance payments related to redundancies
column82: the management tried to find within the new company structure new tasks for all employees. This step was supported by education and training measures and individual coaching. As consulting fees could be saved when the consulting contract was terminated earlier than planned
column83:
the company could use these financial means to cover the training costs.

\r\n

One or two workers
column84: however
column85: were encouraged to take early retirement
column86:
and a few other employees were motivated to leave the company on their own initiative when it became obvious that a future with the company was not feasible. These staff members were also actively supported.

\r\n

When recruiting new staff
column87: the company explicitly looks for workers that support the new structure. It had found that
column88: particularly at the departmental manager level
column89: some employees were not able or willing to adapt to the new structures. Their employment contracts were terminated by mutual agreement and without any problems
column90:
as was the recruitment of new staff that well fulfil the new tasks.

\r\n

Challenges and constraints of restructuring

\r\n

One challenge was getting the employees to understand and accept the need to save staff costs. In the beginning they perceived it as unfair; however
column91:
some employees took on the role of mediators which helped ease the tension and foster a feeling of the solidarity in the company.

\r\n

The staff-related changes (dismissals
column92: short-time working
column93: waiving of Christmas and holiday pay
column94:
and retraining) resulted in a dampened and distrustful atmosphere in 2009 and 2010. This was exacerbated by rumours and fears that further dismissals were imminent.

\r\n

However
column95: as the company finances improved and some of the business units began to be excluded from short-time working
column96: a certain level of jealousy arose among the departments. This was because it was not possible for individual workers to compare different units and therefore could not see the reason for what they saw as unequal treatment. Management tried to keep the workers informed by giving facts and figures on the current situation and the planned steps at annual staff meetings. This enabled employees to recognise that the company’s situation was improving
column97: which also improved the atmosphere. The major change of mood
column98: however
column99: occurred because the employees themselves experienced in the course of their daily work that more customers were contacting the company
column100: more offers had to be written
column101:
more orders had to be fulfilled and more staff was recruited to deal with this.

\r\n

The banks’ stipulation that a restructuring consultant had to be engaged resulted in the company having to spend a large part of its new capital on paying the consultant. In the first year of restructuring
column102: for example
column103: the consultancy fees were € 128
column104: 000 (out of a total of € 500
column105: 000 advanced to the firm). The company felt the consulting services were not good value. Indeed
column106: due to the expertise and past experience of the commercial chief executive officer in the field of company restructuring
column107: the external consultants provided hardly any ideas that were not yet known to the management and partly were being implemented since 2008. those measures that resulted in sustainable change for the company were developed within the firm. This was because the management
column108: who had already been working on reorganisation plans for two years
column109: was much more familiar with their own company than the external consultant who had to submit a concept within few weeks of learning company procedures. However
column110: the firm does feel that the changes were implemented more quickly than otherwise might have been possible
column111:
because the external consultant could pose more pressure on the internal structures than the management.

\r\n

Another big challenge was the risk to the owner’s own funds that were additionally put into the company in the framework of the restructuring process as well as the collateral of his home and life insurance requested by the banks – a severe interference in the current private assets and the guarantee for the future of the owner
column112: respectively. In particular
column113: one of the firm’s banks in spite of good cooperation for decades
column114:
requested conditions that were not feasible as they would have risked the livelihood of the owner in case of further difficulties in the company.

\r\n

Restructuring advice and support

\r\n

The restructuring concept and the restructuring measures were mainly developed by the management. The private restructuring consultant
column115: as specified by the banks
column116: came up with suggestions and measures
column117: but although he provided some stimulus
column118: his ideas did not result in the sustainably successful changes that the company itself brought about. Management say this is partly due to its own commercial expertise and knowledge of company restructuring
column119: and partly due to its familiarity with the company and greater breadth of knowledge about its strengths and weaknesses. The obligation to hire an external consultant caused additional costs that did not bring about a commensurate added value. However
column120: management did think that in companies where there is a lack of experience with crisis situations
column121:
it would be a good idea to approach a specialised consultant.

\r\n

The public support for short-time working (also see Eurofound
column122: 2010) which was increased during the economic crisis through the stimulus package II (‘Konjunkturpaket II’) is very positively assessed by the company. Short-time working was seen as necessary to achieve the cost reduction required for the restructuring without losing know how by dismissing employees. However
column123: even though publicly supported further education was available to the workers during their short-time working
column124:
there was no demand for it from the firm’s workers. Participation in training would also have separated the employees from their work for longer than would have been feasible at that time.

\r\n

The Bürgschaftsgemeinschaft Hamburg (Alliance for Loan Guarantees) offered a guarantee for the capital provided by the banks. The Bürgschaftsgemeinschaft Hamburg is a self-help organisation providing loan guarantees up to 80% of the credit amount and up to €1 million
column125: respectively
column126: to foster small and medium-sized enterprises. Associates of the alliance are various chambers
column127:
guilds and enterprise confederations as well as credit institutions and insurances. The city of Hamburg as well as the federal government back the guarantees offered to the companies.

\r\n

The company were very positive about the Bürgschaftsgemeinschaft Hamburg not only because of the opportunity to get access to the required capital
column128: but also in its help in negotiating with the firms’ banks. The Bürgschaftsgemeinschaft
column129: for example
column130: suggested that the company should only pay back the credit which was provided in December 2009 from 2012 onwards
column131:
so that the new capital could be used for restructuring and growth without affecting the liquidity due to a too-strict repayment plan. With this understanding of the company situation the Bürgschaftsgemeinschaft also helped persuade the banks to ease some of their credit conditions.

\r\n

The management also sees the provision of guarantees or collateral as the best public support for restructuring
column132: particularly as in owner-managed small and medium-sized companies it can be the case that the owners do not have enough private assets to finance the restructuring
column133:
nor a sufficient level of collateral to offer the banks in exchange for credit.

\r\n

Outcomes of restructuring

\r\n

The economic situation of the company improved quicker than initially expected and by 2010 the banks agreed to the management’s request to dispense with the services of the restructuring consultant. By the end of 2011
column134: 60% of the sales decrease experienced in 2009 had been levelled out
column135: and it is expected that
column136: by the end of 2012
column137: the firm will achieve the sales levels of 2008. The € 500
column138: 000 credits advanced in December 2009 was to have been fully repaid by April 2012
column139: resulting in considerable cost savings related to credit interest and fees for the guarantee certificate. This will further increase the company’s liquidity
column140:
and the company will not only have mastered the crisis but will have trimmed its structure and improved its competitiveness due to the reorganisation.

\r\n

The restructuring has meant that six or seven employees have been made redundant
column141: with all other employees affected by wage loss for a maximum of two years due to short-time working. However
column142: because of the firm’s access to public short-time working support the net income loss was lower than the level of additional spare time. Short-time working was stopped in mid 2011. The employees also had to waive Christmas and holiday pay for two years. Management
column143: however
column144:
plan to honour these payments as soon as company finances allow.

\r\n

Most of the department managers
column145: and some other workers who did not support the new structures left the company. These employees were supported in their transition to a new job or retirement
column146: and the vacancies have been filled in the meantime. Hence
column147: there were hardly any changes in staff numbers in the medium term. The remaining employees were trained for their new tasks. At the end of 2011
column148:
75% of the workers employed by Friedrich Marx before the crisis were still working for the company.

\r\n

Management
column149: seeing what has been achieved during the restructuring
column150:
are now motivated to introduce further changes as they realise that alterations previously thought impossible during times of ‘normal business’ could now be implemented. The crisis situation is seen as a chance to improve aspects that could not or at least not as quickly have been changed in times of ‘normal business’.

\r\n

Commentary

\r\n

The management feels that the public short-time working support and the credit collateral by the Bürgschaftsgemeinschaft has been an important contribution to the success of the restructuring. Short-time working was a considerable factor in reducing staff costs without loss of know-how
column151:
and the Bürgschaftsgemeinschaft was a valuable mediator between the company and the firm’s banks in the negotiations on credit conditions.

\r\n

As for the hired private restructuring consultants
column152: the management is convinced that such specialised support is of advantage in many cases. However
column153: in their own specific case it did not bring about a satisfactory price/value ratio due to the company management’s own expertise and experience. Accordingly
column154: the generally prevailing idea among banks that they will provide capital for restructuring only if a restructuring consultant is hired should be reconsidered. Any company needing to be restructured which is unhappy with its consultant has hardly any room for manoeuvre as any credit has to be paid back immediately if the consultant resigns. Furthermore
column155: some of the banks’ credit conditions
column156: such as the design of repayment plans
column157:
are seen to be counterproductive as it can lead to a drain on liquidity.

\r\n

The company recommends that others in the same situation should conduct a detailed analysis of the causes of its crisis and develop strategies for dealing with it. The implementation of the measures needs to be continuously controlled and
column158: if necessary
column159: adjusted. It is also vital to be open with banks
column160: employees and suppliers about what is happening
column161: and the plans for restructuring. In order to maintain the trust of the stakeholders it is important to fulfil given promises. When in negotiation
column162: a sound concept should be presented
column163: even if it is felt that the negotiation partner will not agree. It has to be borne in mind that
column164: in most cases a bank is not interested in closing down a company that is to be restructured and is more open to good arguments than might be expected. However
column165:
it is particularly important that in these discussions a company owner stays factual and rational despite their strong personal involvement.

\r\n

An important factor for the success of restructuring is the availability of sufficient commercial steering elements in the company. This may be a problem particularly in owner-managed small- or medium-sized companies as the self-employment is often based on a creative idea rather than on commercial expertise. Accordingly
column166:
it would be important to make entrepreneurs aware that they should organise commercial support (through employees or advisors) before the administration of the company gets too complex.

\r\n

Finally
column167: a company crisis should be seen as chance to improve one’s business
column168: and for the company to come out of the situation in a stronger position. A successful restructuring can motivate managers to change in the future when opportunities arise. At the same time
column169:
it is important to remain self-critical and not to let success blind one to the possibility of crisis.

M-TEC Energie.Innovativ, Austria~"M-TEC Energie.Innovativ GmbH"~"

The internal restructuring of the Austrian company M-TEC Energie.Innovativ resulted in the introduction of a level of middle managers
column2: the separation of office and sales staff
column3:
the establishment of job specification and the formal setting of targets. Company internal and market monitoring is now conducted in a more systematic and comprehensive way.

"~"

Organisational profile

The Austrian M-TEC Energie.Innovativ GmbH was founded in 1972 by Karl Mittermayr as an electronics company. In the early 1980s
column4: it began specialising in heat pumps and heat recovery and was quickly leading the way in this field due to numerous innovations and patents. It has received several awards
column5: including the Upper Austrian Provincial Award for Environment and Nature 2004
column6: the Energy Globe 2006
column7: and Actor of Sustainability 2011. The company deals in refrigeration and ventilation engineering as well as in photovoltaics. Private
column8: trade and industrial clients are offered a comprehensive package including planning and advice related to individual systems solutions
column9:
and fitting as well as after-sales services. Most clients are private customers in Upper Austria.

\r\n

Karl Mittermayr hoped that one of his sons would carry on the business after he retired
column10: but initially this looked doubtful when the eldest opted for a career in banking. The middle son Dominik
column11: after doing an apprenticeship in the family business
column12: started studying medicine. Due to family developments he decided later on not to finalise these studies
column13: but to begin working in his father’s company in the administrative field. At this stage Klemens
column14: the youngest brother
column15: was working in the company. Both brothers liked working in the enterprise
column16: but did not want to take over the management.In 1998
column17: Karl Mittermayr fell sick and during the period of his convalescence
column18: Dominik and Klemens Mittermayr took over the joint management of the company.  This ‘trial period’ proved successful from the company’s viewpoint
column19: and the brothers realised that they would be able to manage the firm together
column20:
even if neither wished to do this on his own.

column30: for example

The company employs about 60 staff in administration

In its mission statement

and is involved in social projects in Austria and abroad.

Background to restructuring event

The majority of the company’s customers are homeowners who want a heating system

column63: for example
column64:
the higher internal communication needs related to the increasing number of employees could no longer be adequately addressed .

At this point the employers’ association

column67: aspects like ecology

In the framework of this initiative

identifying organisational challenges and possible courses of action. This gave the company the impetus to continue working in this direction and to develop – with professional support – internal activities leading to an employee-friendly organisational development.

Restructuring processes

Due to the limited possibilites to plan the order level
column72: the growth process of the company in the beginning was rather reactive insofar as the number of employees increased depending on the number of customer requests and orders. At this time the company was a typical small firm with a familial structure and flat hierarchies. There were only were two levels: the management (Karl Mittermayr
column73: later Dominik and Klemens Mittermayr) and the rest of the staff. It became quickly obvious that the growing number of employees made this structure unsuitable

column75:
and there began to be problems in communication.

\r\n

Consequently
column76: when there were about 30 employees
column77: a first restructuring was realised. This organisational development mainly focused on the administrative field. However
column78: although vital
column79:
the measures soon became inadequate again as the company continued to grow (to about 55 employees).

\r\n

In 2007–8
column80: Dominik and Klemens Mittermayr finally decided to carry out an internal restructuring to ensure that the firm’s growth would not negatively affect the quality of their products and services. They decided to act when the previously good working atmosphere began to experience tensions. Staff members had begun to group together; long-term workers missed the familial structures and the opportunity to approach management directly. The employees no longer felt looked after and either let management know this directly or the brothers observed this themselves due to their operational involvement in the firm. The entrepreneurs
column81: assessing this situation as suboptimal
column82: took steps to create a structure whereby the employees would have a person whom they could contact directly
column83:
resulting in better communication.

\r\n

At about the same time
column84: the Upper Austrian Economic Chamber (Wirtschaftskammer Österreich) informed the company about a joint project of the employers’ organisation and respACT dealing with Corporate Social Responsibility (CSR) to fund  a two-day basic consultation. Dominik and Klemens Mittermayr decided to participate in this initiative and were contacted by a specialised CSR consultant. Up to this time

column86: however
column87:
that a more systematic approach could benefit the company development. The consultation helped identify problem areas and the brothers decided to pay themselves for further help from the consultant.

\r\n

In a first step
column88: a stocktaking of the enterprise was conducted to attain a systematic overview of the management and the strategic instruments and procedures available in the company. This was used as a basis to identify different fields of activities and what measures needed to be taken. The consultant did this by talking to management and conducting an employee survey about their needs. The management had already been aware of some problems
column89: but some of the issues raised were new to them. The planned measures were ranked according to their priority and then a plan was drafted
column90:
outlining when each step should be taken.

\r\n

The measures referred to organisational and staff-related developments. The former entailed the development of an organigramme as well as job descriptions and a systematic documentation of all procedures. This meant that elements that previously only implicitly existed were made more explicit
column91: providing a better orientation and traceability for management and staff. The system of appraisal interviews and employee communication
column92: which had already existed
column93: were expanded and adjusted to the demands of the growing company. For example
column94: there are now structured weekly or monthly employee information sessions as it was realised that the growth made it necessary to keep individual departments better informed. This helps to avoid rumours and the dissemination of wrong information. One employee now has the task of keeping colleagues up to date. This comprehensive coverage is achieved by using everything from company notice boards
column95: to intranet
column96: e-mail
column97:
and Facebook.

\r\n

A milestone in the company’s organisational development was the introduction of another hierarchical level; middle management. There are now service
column98: office
column99: and sales managers
column100: and by mid 2012 a chief fitting engineer should also have been recruited. These positions have been created to guarantee better support; provide a direct contact person for the employees and to relieve higher management. The idea was developed by the management with the support of an external advisor and the involvement of all employees. All affected engineers were involved in drafting the new job descriptions. As the recruitment was planned to take place internally
column101: all the staff were encouraged to apply. However
column102: as no one did
column103:
the management approached those staff members they deemed to be most suitable. After a short time for consideration all candidates agreed to take on the new tasks. This decision was communicated to the employees at a meeting. The new middle managers will participate in a management development programme initiated by management and financed by the company from mid 2012 onwards. This will mainly focus on the development of soft skills.

\r\n

The introduction of middle management also brought about a separation of office and sales staff. Previously

column105: with employees responsible for the whole project
column106: from finding customers to the technical implementation on the construction site. This procedure worked well in the beginning
column107: but as the company grew it led to a very uneven workload. The company is funding an on-the-job training programme for its sales force
column108:
after an external advisor listened to the sales people’s pitches and devised individual training programmes for them.

\r\n

Another big innovation is that for the first time concrete objectives (annual and monthly objectives) have been formulated for the individual departments (and as a result for individual sales people). These will be monitored in future by the new middle managers. Across the company a continuous monitoring of orders and sales now takes place to get a better overview of current and future development.

\r\n

The restructuring process pinpointed the need for training. The company had already had a good experience of participating in a publicly supported qualification network

column110: M-TEC took the lead role in the design of the qualification network
column111: in order to be able to tailor the training to its own needs. Another
column112: anonymous
column113: employee survey was carried out by external experts
column114: on training needs and on more general mood indicators. This allowed employees the opportunity to voice their concerns freely
column115: and the survey showed that training was mostly needed in the fields of communication
column116: team-building
column117: time-management
column118:
and dealing with stress and other soft skills. A training programme was developed and many employees participated.

\r\n

In line with the CSR concept
column119: the management tried to involve the main partners of the company

column121: in the restructuring. Together
column122: they discussed technical/product related issues
column123:
and also how they could improve their cooperation.

\r\n

This process lasted for about three years and in 2012
column124:
is still not fully completed.

Challenges and constraints of restructuring

As with any change
column125: the restructuring led to some anxieties. Employees were worried how it would affect their jobs
column126: their work environment and the power/competence relationships. Management tried to allay these fears by open communication and information. For example
column127:
they explicitly said that the restructuring was not intended to cause job losses but sustainable growth.

\r\n

Management also needed to convince some employees of the need for their involvement in the organisational development and training activities
column128: as in the beginning they did not see the necessity for such measures. The vast majority
column129: however
column130:
were quickly convinced and willing to participate in the restructuring.

\r\n

During the three-year process there was a phase in which the external consultant was very active in the company
column131: resulting in some reluctance by the employees to cooperate. However
column132:
this tendency was counteracted by the brothers’ involvement.

\r\n

The company strongly invests in apprenticeship training

column134:
such as fitters

\r\n

Another challenge is the active steering of growth. As the company mainly serves private new customers
column135: it strongly depends on external requests which it cannot influence. This results in constantly needing to be able to react at short notice. In order to prepare as well as possible for future developments
column136: the company conducts active market monitoring of new construction and internal monitoring of trends (for example
column137: how many requests result on average in an order). In 2011 the company invested in marketing
column138: with a redesigned webpage

which have already increased the number of client requests.

Restructuring advice and support

The company approached consultants from the Upper Austrian Economic Chamber as well as using its own tax consultant in planning the transfer of the business from father to sons. Information from the employers’ organisation is also used for continuous market monitoring. The entrepreneurs are very satisfied with these services

particularly as the recommendations from the public and private consultants complement each other well.

\r\n

The publicly supported consultation on corporate social responsibility can be considered as one of the main reasons for entrepreneurs’ willingness to work
column143: with an external consultant
column144: on further organisational development. The management assesses the advice as very good
column145: and worth the consultancy fees they paid after experiencing the support project’s two-day input. However
column146:
the entrepreneurs also pointed out that it is important to make sure that the external consultant does not have too much influence in the company as this might antagonise the employees.

\r\n

Management is happy with the financial support from the qualification network

column148: the entrepreneurs are convinced they have made the right decision. In 2012
column149: they were planning to participate in a qualification network again
column150: focusing on content oriented/technical training. This time
column151: however
column152: they are not taking the lead role

in order to avoid a big administrative burden.

\r\n

Furthermore
column154: public support that positively influences demand in the energy field is beneficial for the growth of the enterprise
column155:
as this gives an incentive for private customers to buy its products.

Outcomes of restructuring

As the creation of the new management level happened at the end of 2011
column156: no assessment of its effectiveness can yet be given. However
column157: it has been generally welcomed by the employees
column158: particularly as no one was recruited externally. The new middle managers already knew the structures
column159: procedures and employees. In the first months after this measure was put in place there were no conflicts among the employees
column160:
and no one complained that the promotion of specific colleagues was unfair.

The separation of office and sales force is in transition in 2012

column162: however

there will be a more even workload throughout the year for employees.

\r\n

The staff liked the new objectives as they introduced for the first time concrete structures and objectives against which they can measure themselves. Besides the positive motivation due to the challenge
column165:

The company is now following a more strategic approach

aiming to act more proactively. The first steps in this direction have been set by the improved company internal and market monitoring as well as increased marketing activities.

Management thinks the new company structure

The management also wants to give staff the opportunity to continuously participate in training events and is willing to further invest in workers’ skills. At the same time they hope that the employees practically apply what they have learned – particularly in the field of soft skills
column171: such as time and stress management or respectfully dealing with colleagues – and further develop their skills in communication This would not only help the company’s development

\r\n

The restructuring proved an intensive process for the management

giving them someone to talk to at an organisational and a personal level. Their good relationship contributed to the successful achievement of the organisational development and was further fostered by this jointly realised process.

Commentary

The company wants to increase the popularity of its brand M-TEC
column176: expanding its market leading position in heat pumps in Austria. The company development programme is seen as laying the foundations for this
column177:
and management think the employees are crucial to the company’s success.

\r\n

The management also considers that the initial consultation on corporate social responsibility was an important factor in the success of the restructuring as it provided

\r\n

Information and communication with the employees was also an important element during and after restructuring

column183:

\r\n

The management of a medium-sized company should always be actively and strongly involved in the business in order to be aware of what is happening
column184: so that issues can be addressed if necessary. There should be certain proximity with the employees

column188:
to admit that one needs to delegate tasks and to establish a good management team to do this.

\r\n

There is also an important difference between small and large enterprises. In large firms there is already a certain basic structure which is not influenced by further growth. In small

\r\n

To other small and medium-sized enterprises experiencing quick growth

\r\n

For sustainable growth

In Hungary

Restructuring processes

In a family business is not easy to identify the start and end date of succession. The involvement of the second generation is often so natural that even family members cannot remember when and how the process started. However

A family business can be a mixed blessing.. International statistics report that many family firms fail during the succession process due to family conflicts

column97: empathy

Dental implant factory develops
column2: manufactures and sells the Osteoplant ® implant system that was invented and developed in the early 1990s by a team of dentists at the Medical University in Poznan. The financial crisis caused a drop in turnover and financial performance and significant problems with liquidity.  Despite the difficult conditions imposed by restructuring which brought the company to the brink of bankruptcy
column3: Osteoplant was able to meet all the investment obligations of its EU grant agreement and
column4: in cooperation with external institutions
column5:
is continuing to innovate and develop products.

"~"

Organisational profile

The dental implant factory Osteoplant
column6: established in 1989
column7: is owned by the Medical University Foundation in Poznan
column8: Poland. The foundation
column9: a fully independent legal entity
column10: employs
column11: at the time of writing (end of 2011) 33 people and conducts business in several areas
column12:
including:
  • manufacturing and distribution of dental implants;
  • organisation of conferences and scientific meetings;
  • running a retail pharmacy outlet.

Osteoplant was founded in 1996 and has become the main area of the foundation’s activity
column13: both in terms of employment (about 15 people) and turnover. The highly specialised business domain and features of the restructuring process at Osteoplant are the reasons why the study has been limited to its activities. Therefore
column14: the actions and decisions of the owner
column15: the foundation
column16:
are presented only if directly related to the restructuring process at Osteoplant.

\r\n

The main area of activity of the implant factory is to develop
column17: manufacture and sell the Osteoplant ® implant system that was invented and developed in the early 1990s by a team of dentists at the Medical University in Poznań. Since its certification by the Institute of Medicines in 1998
column18: until 2008
column19: Osteoplant rapidly and consistently increased its sales on the Polish market. This period saw a very dynamic development of the market and strong competition from international giants
column20: but the Osteoplant ® system maintained its share of approximately 15%–20% of the Polish market. It should be noted that
column21: in the last few years
column22: there has also been strong direct competition from companies in Israel
column23: Germany and Korea in the price range in which the implant factory operates (approximately 1/3 of the price of products of the global market leaders). In 2009–2011 after trying unsuccessfully
column24: in collaboration with an external company
column25: to enter the Norwegian market
column26: it abandoned any further ideas of trying again to enter any foreign markets. The company’s manufacturing process for medical devices in the company has been conducted in accordance with quality management systems ISO 13485 and ISO 9001
column27:
and all products comply with the European Medical Directive 93/42/EEC and are CE marked.

\r\n

The current Director of Osteoplant joined the company in 1998
column28: initially as a sales/medical representative. Since 2000
column29: he has been given overall responsibility for running the entire business. The director
column30: who is a dentist and who has a dentistry practice specialising in implants
column31: gained his business experience before joining Osteoplant
column32:
while working in the marketing department of an international pharmaceutical company.

\r\n

Osteoplant currently employs three people in the sales office and one mobile sales representative. Its manufacturing department employs a production manager who acts also as the designer-constructor; a second engineer
column33: responsible for quality management and five production workers
column34: operators of digital machinery and two other people involved in the assembly and packaging of products
column35: all with secondary or vocational education. Accounting and personnel matters are conducted jointly with the foundation
column36:
by staff members directly employed there.

\r\n

The implant factory is strongly linked with the region
column37: as its core customers live in the Poznań and Wielkopolska region. The company is also still closely associated with the local academic community
column38: including not only the Medical University
column39: but also the Poznań University of Technology
column40:
the Institute of Metal Forming in Poznan and the local vocational school for digital machine operators.

\r\n

Osteoplant has always been very active in the Polish market for conferences
column41: training and professional development for dentists. However
column42:
the company has no written HR strategy or statement of corporate social responsibility. The company is not unionised and does not have a works council.

Background to restructuring event

During its first 10 years
column43: up to 2008
column44: Osteoplant’s sales volume rose sharply
column45: from about 100 implant sets
column46: to more than 6
column47: 000 sets per year. If we look at sales volumes for the German market (about 900
column48: 000 implant sets per year) it seems that the Polish market
column49: with total annual sales of around 30
column50: 000 units
column51: has still a huge potential for growth. According to Osteoplant’s management
column52: interest in implantology from Polish dentists is very great
column53: although it is estimated only about 5% of dentists in Poland carry out implant surgery. It can be therefore expected that
column54: as the Polish people prosper
column55: the demand for implants
column56: and consequently the factory’s products
column57:
should continue to grow dynamically.

\r\n

The company’s best year for sales was 2008. In 2009 Osteoplant applied for an EU grant for innovation
column58: under the Operational Programme Innovative Economy. It wanted the money for research and development
column59: including the construction of a new factory building. The net value of total investment in development and implementation of new and modified products of the Osteoplant ® implant system in 2009–2011 was PLN 6
column61: 100 (€ 1.4 million as at June
column62: 2012) and a guaranteed share of the European Union grant was PLN 2 643 320 (€ 619
column63: 000). The company began to implement its plan in 2009. Unfortunately
column64: shortly after signing the contract
column65:
the world financial and economic crisis started.

\r\n

The economic slowdown and rising unemployment
column68: meant that many potential patients decided to postpone implant surgery. Sales declined; compared with 2008 there was a 5% drop in 2009
column69: a 19% drop in 2010 and a 17% drop in 2011
column70:
at which point sales stabilised.

Restructuring processes

In May 2011
column71: production was moved from rented premises to a new site in Dabrowa near Poznań
column72: fully owned by Osteoplant. In planning its large investment
column73: management had assumed a long-term trend of sales growth. However
column74: the financial crisis caused a drop in turnover and financial performance and significant problems with liquidity. This was aggravated by its rigid investment commitments under the contract for EU funds. The crisis also led to banks demanding more stringent conditions before being willing to offer financing
column75: and this meant Osteoplant’s suppliers
column76: especially from abroad
column77:
started asking for 100% payment in advance.

\r\n

As a result
column78: Osteoplant found itself in a difficult financial situation. In 2010
column79: the foundation suspended the payment of bonuses to management and all employees at the implant factory and demanded cuts in production costs
column80: and the budgets for training and marketing. All available funds were transferred to research and development
column81:
in order to comply with the EU grant agreement.

\r\n

The conditions of the EU grant to build the production site required that
column82: not only had the level of employment to be retained
column83: but also that additional staff should be recruited. This obviously affected the restructuring process at Osteoplant. In effect
column84:
the only negative consequence of the restructuring on employment was several months delay in recruiting an employee to replace one of the white-collar workers who had voluntarily left.

\r\n

As for the formal aspects of the restructuring process
column85: the company did not have a restructuring plan upon which Osteoplant employees were consulted
column86:
as decisions were taken unilaterally by the foundation and then announced to the management and employees.

Challenges and constraints of restructuring

The crisis arising from falling sales and serious problems with liquidity
column87: aggravated by the rigid requirements of the EU grant agreement
column88:
has been the first in the history of the company. Sales are expected to drop again due to cuts in the budgets for training and marketing. The cuts in direct production costs have also caused additional anxiety and stress among production workers.

\r\n

However
column89: in spite of its short-and medium-term  difficulties
column90: Osteoplant has been meeting all the investment obligations of its EU grant agreement and
column91: in cooperation with external institutions
column92:
is continuing to innovate and develop products.

\r\n

Much of the current difficulty is caused by the very time-consuming and bureaucratic procedure of getting the EU payments. The company been close to bankruptcy for months because the regional office responsible for the management of EU funds is delaying payments
column93: by asking for the company to correct minor errors with an interval of one month between each request. As a result
column94: in late November 2011
column95: the company is still awaiting payment of the first instalment of funds
column96: even though the relevant documentation was submitted in April 2011. In the meantime
column97: Osteoplant has completed the second stage of its investment project
column98:
putting itself on the verge of insolvency.

Restructuring advice and support

The company has not sought and did not use consultants or any other external bodies to support the preparation and implementation of the restructuring programme. The restructuring was carried out relying only on staff and resources at Osteoplant and the foundation.

Important factors for success in the restructuring process have been the loyalty and commitment of staff
column99:
built on trust and good relations between them and management.

Outcomes of restructuring

The survival of the company still seems to be seriously at risk. Despite this
column100: the company continues to implement the investment project agreed in the EU grant contract according to the original schedule. In 2012
column101: it plans to purchase a new
column102:
modern digital machine as the grant was in fact associated with investment in machinery and equipment to be installed in the new building.

\r\n

Fortunately
column104: after two years of decline
column105: the level of sales has stabilised. However
column106: if the payment of the EU subsidies for already completed stages continue to be delayed
column107: this award-winning
column108:
innovative company may face bankruptcy.

\r\n

The management points out that if it had known what problems would be involved in the use of the EU grant they would not have invested funds in developing their manufacturing capacity
column109: but would instead have made greater use of outsourcing. Osteoplant did this very successfully in 2005–2006
column110: when
column111: unable to keep up with demand
column112:
they used companies in the US and Switzerland.

Commentary

Osteoplant was named one of the three most innovative companies in Wielkopolska
column113: in a competition organised by the Marshal’s Office. However
column114: the company is on the verge of bankruptcy due to delays in payments by the Regional Financing Institution
column115: part of the same Marshal’s Office
column116:
and this merits attention and action.

\r\n

Regional officials
column117: often very young people
column118: keep finding formal errors in the documents and reports sent to them. They generally spend nearly the whole of their allotted month going over the documents before requesting clarification or additional documentation. The company then has seven days to respond. After another month
column119: the office requires further clarification on another minor point and the company
column120: again in seven days
column121: complements and enhances it. This has been going on from April 2011 to the point of writing
column122: in November 2011
column123: and none of the grant has been paid to the company. This has made it almost impossible to plan financial flows
column124: especially in a small and medium-sized enterprise with limited financial resources
column125:
and this can be very harmful for the business.

\r\n

Another conclusion to be drawn here is that there should be more flexibility in the way the EU finances innovative projects
column126: because current rules do not permit the introduction of any deviations from the plan during its implementation. This condition is very difficult to meet
column127: and can even be counterproductive. For example
column128: in tests conducted
column129: Osteoplant discovered that a device it had previously planned to purchase was not after all needed
column130:
but found that it could not change the EU agreement and cancel the purchase.

Background to restructuring event

Plastika Skaza has been restructured several times during the last 13 years. The first took place in 1999–2000 when Igor Skaza took over the business from his parents. Employees remember this period as a major milestone for themselves and the company. Under the new leader

The next restructuring began in 2007

The time period for the restructuring event described here cannot be defined precisely: management indicates that this is an ongoing process.

The third restructuring process involved a 10-year strategic plan to set up the company’s own brands. However

Restructuring processes

The decision to enter the own-brand market raised a series of questions

  • convenient waste disposal;
  • practical dishware with a cutting-edge design;
  • modern eco-friendly home products.

The decision about which product to launch was based on detailed market research. The first

column62: development
column63: planning)

column65: starting in 2007. By the end of 2010

column68:
000 units were sold.

‘Yodo’

column72:

column73: cup

The administration informs middle management every week about plans and receives feedback. The remaining employees are informed about the strategic plans at annual meetings held for production workers or at the closing ceremony at the end of the year

Challenges and constraints of restructuring

When Plastika Skaza lost its contract with Gorenje

Restructuring advice and support

Outcomes of restructuring

The restructuring took place according to the initial plan

Management staff considers the third (and current) wave of restructuring projects to be a time of new challenges and opportunities to prove themselves in areas where they have previously had limited experience. Employees are aware that the company’s future depends on their joint efforts to achieve specified goals. Staff feel they are learning the necessary new knowledge from their formal education as well as from self-education and their own ingenuity. Employees also believe that management ‘has an ear for their new ideas’. They are trying to see novelties as a challenge

column99: or to contribute to the optimal use of resources. The investment is greater than their usual investments in development

000 per year.

column106: and Gorenje have been retained

Plastika Skaza expanded employment from 130 to 160 during 2011. They aim to grow to 300 by 2015 by increasing completion services for foreign buyers and selling own-brand products. By automating production and emphasising development

column111: 000 by the end of 2011. Additional employment is planned in R&D

Commentary

Flexibility is the highest priority in the restructuring of small businesses. As the management team had only three members

The company built their restructuring processes on a philosophy that state aid is not needed for success. Another difficulty relates to the problem of domestic companies’ protection in many foreign markets. This is becoming a regular issue

and technological equipment. Such activities results in the demolition of competitiveness that a company can achieve in the Slovenian environment.

Restructuring processes

The process of internal restructuring within the Probuild Group lasted from the last quarter of 2008 until February 2010. It was carried out as a reaction to the collapse of the market for professional real estate services in Poland
column36: which had been badly affected by the crisis in the global economy. The group was hit when banks withheld the funding for major construction (Andersia Business Centre Hotel in Poznan and Gdansk Długi Targ) for which it was project manager. As a result

the group lost a lot of its planned revenue and had to slash operating costs to guarantee financial liquidity. The restructuring measures it took were:

and interior design) with the loss of four jobs;\r\n

column51:

Redundant workers were not offered any support in the form of outplacement

because of the integral culture of the company.

Restructuring advice and support

The only external advice and support came from legal experts who prepared the agreements to amend staff contracts in the very first phase of restructuring.

column58:

column65: confidence and motivation have been rebuilt. New employees have been hired and a new
column66: more specialised team has emerged

column68: the restructuring resulted in a limited amount of services offered by the group
column69: but this allowed a focus on selected areas of activity. Later

such as technical due diligence.

motivation and confidence in performing in specialised areas. The business profile has refocused on the most profitable areas. The restructuring process has not undergone any formal evaluation although

As the owner of Recipe Plus explains
column70: their salaries remained the same and the main trick was related to psychology: ‘If the person is given a choice of two options
column71: he or she would definitely choose the alternative which is considered to be “better by society.”’ That is
column72: if the title of the position sounds better
column73: it will be filled faster. So he offered them the title of ‘chief analyst’. Surprisingly
column74:
they were not much concerned about the wage issues. They received good compensation for lacking the necessary skills.

Restructuring advice and support

No external advice or support was used
column75:
as the knowledge that was necessary for the restructuring process was brought into the firm by hiring new people and training existing staff.

Outcomes of restructuring

The new Procurement Department significantly improved the performance of the company. New professional staff took over responsibility for reaching clients
column76: developing connections between stores and suppliers
column77: and creating the company brand. From the viewpoint of one of the company employees who was directly involved in restructuring process
column78: positive changes became possible due to more attention being paid to the information resources. The whole process of acquiring market information
column79: communicating and analysing the information
column80: and using it to make business decisions was reviewed. Training of employees (paid by the company) was implemented
column81: paying particular attention to communication and sales skills. Elements of good teamwork and delegation of responsibilities were also addressed
column82:
and all this resulted in a positive effect on net profits.

\r\n

Overall
column83: the restructuring had a positive influence on the company. In fact
column84: the company has already decided to use this positive experience in the future by further expanding the Procurement Department. According to the owner of the company
column85:
‘this should not only help increase profits but also ensure better competitive advantage for Recipe Plus’.

\r\n

\r\n

Yet
column123: as usually happens
column124: many activities were implemented in order to achieve positive financial figures. The main ones are as follows. First of all
column125: the variety of goods offered by Recipe Plus increased as a result of restructuring. Due to better communication and sales skills
column126: the company was able to work more professionally with both local and international customers and suppliers
column127: and that has resulted in a more diverse product portfolio. Thus
column128: the increase in profits was very much fostered by an increase in sales that
column129: in turn
column130: resulted from the increase in the variety of products that Recipe Plus offers. Furthermore
column131: as explained by the owner
column132: ‘Sales managers became better at finding suppliers that could offer better prices
column133: thus we could offer more affordable products to our customers.’ Recipe Plus also became more favoured in the market; the owner explains
column134: ‘Customer trust depends on the quality and diversity of products. As soon as the company becomes a provider of cheaper and differentiated products
column135: it starts to win over the market. If we add a marketing element
column136: the firm simply starts winning the market
column137:
leaving the competitors far behind.’

Commentary

Recipe Plus had various issues that had to be solved if the company was to remain in the market
column138: especially after the economic downturn. The most important issues
column139: however
column140: were related to the people that directly influence the price of the product. As the company owner reflected
column141: during the rapid economic growth that Latvia enjoyed before the downturn in 2008
column142: many companies
column143: including Recipe Plus
column144: simply forgot how to work effectively and had to relearn this skill as fast as possible when the crisis came. This is easier done in a small business than in a big one
column145: where changes usually take longer. As Recipe Plus is in the SME category
column146:
it might be interesting to compare how the same problem would be solved in a large company.
