column1:
Rehm Race Days, Germany~"Rehm Race Days"~"

The owner and manager of the German company Rehm Race Days received emotional and personal support
column2: as well as practical recommendations and help from a friend and fellow entrepreneur while preparing to diversify
column3:
as well as during the business transfer process of a previous company.

"~"

Organisational profile

Rehm Race Days organises race training for motorbikes and sports cars in France
column4: Croatia
column5: Italy
column6: Portugal
column7: Spain and the Czech Republic. The firm offers everything from instructing beginners
column8: sprint races
column9: children’s races
column10:
a women’s cup and races for older cyclists.

\r\n

The company hires race courses
column11: and prepares and organises the races (dealing
column12: for example
column13: with the registration of participants and instructions on the race course) and conducts them (including scoring and awarding prizes
column14: but also technical support and medical emergency services) (Heinen et al.
column15: 2005). They also store motorbikes between events and transport them
column16: on demand
column17: to a race course
column18:
as well as doing minor maintenance and servicing.

\r\n

Karl Rehm
column19: the company’s owner and manager
column20: trained as a motor mechanic with master craftsman certification
column21: and then spent 17 years building up a company trading in motorbikes. During this time he started organising race training
column22: first informally
column23: and then making it a feature of his company. In 2001
column24: the huge success of these events prompted him
column25: after doing a qualification in business administration
column26:
to focus his business exclusively on organising race training and to sell his motorbike business.

\r\n

Since 2009
column27: Rehm Race Days has employed him
column28: his wife and one full-time employee. Karl Rehm runs his events using local people who can participate in the race training for free in exchange for their support in getting ready
column29: clearing up
column30:
monitoring and general organisation.

\r\n

Due to the low number of employees
column31:
there is no works council or relationship with a trade union in the company (as in the initial motorbike trading company).

Background to restructuring event

At the end of the 1980s
column32: Karl Rehm
column33: an enthusiastic motorbike rider began to look into how he could have a go on race courses as an amateur. He soon discovered that this was not possible. However
column34: on the assumption that there were many enthusiasts just like him
column35: he decided to rent a course himself and organise race training for his customers and fellow members at his motorbike club. The first day he organised was such a success that it became an annual
column36: and increasingly popular
column37:
event.

\r\n

After some time
column38: it became obvious that the race days could be the basis for a business. He suggested to other motorbike traders that they and their customers could also participate
column39: which resulted in an increased awareness about the events which
column40: at this point
column41:
were organised alongside his other activities in his motorbike business.

\r\n

In 2001
column42: the organisation of the days became so time-consuming
column43: and involved so much travel
column44: that Karl no longer had the time to deal with the customers or administrative tasks in this initial business
column45: in spite of the good support of his employees. He tried to fulfil his business obligations by working evenings
column46: weekends and on public holidays
column47:
which increased his stress levels and resulted in a situation where he hardly had any spare time.

\r\n

The motorbike trade is strongly competitive. Margins are tight because product differentiation is hardly possible
column48: customers compare prices on the internet and are willing to travel to the cheapest offer. Traders must invest a lot of capital
column49:
with the result that a decent profit is possible only if a company owner puts in a lot of work and personal engagement.

\r\n

The motorbike trade is also seasonal
column50: but organising race events is much more evenly distributed across the year as during the winter events can be organised in southern Europe
column51: or motorbikes can be prepared for the next season. Furthermore
column52:
Karl Rehm discovered that one particularly popular event could bring in a profit equal to the annual profit of his motorbike business.

\r\n

To begin with
column53: he had hardly any competition. There is only a limited number of potential race dates
column54: and he benefited from his longstanding contacts with the owners of the race courses
column55: giving him access to more dates than any of the other organisers who began to spring up. Consequently
column56:
Karl Rehm decided to sell his motorbike retail business and concentrate exclusively on organising races.

Restructuring processes

In the late 1980s and early 1990s organising the race days was more like a hobby. However
column58: after Karl Rehm qualified in business administration in the skilled trades
column59: he began to consider his idea in a more strategic and entrepreneurial way. One of his lecturers told him about a public support programme called ‘innovative ideas in the craft sector’ and encouraged him to participate. Under the programme he drafted a business plan and a market analysis (including an assessment of the future potential) for the business idea. This took about six to nine months. The positive results of the analysis encouraged him to spend increasing time and effort in organising events. However
column60: it soon became obvious to him that this was at the expense of his motorbike trade as both activities depended much on his personal involvement. He did not want to let down his customers and therefore realised that he had to decide which of the two business models to continue. Due to the more promising future economic potential of the race trainings and his personal interest in this new challenge
column61:
he decided to sell the motorbike business.

\r\n

At this point
column62: Karl Rehm’s company employed four workers
column63: including his sister. He suggested that one of his top mechanics could become his successor
column64: but the man in question rejected the idea and left the company. However
column65: his replacement agreed to take over the company after one year. The technical details of the transfer were clarified and agreed
column66:
and the employees were informed accordingly.

\r\n

However
column67: in autumn 2000 when the sale was meant to be finalised
column68:
the buyer had to pull out as his family withdrew their promised financial support.

\r\n

Karl Rehm then contacted other local companies to see if they were interested in buying the company. It took him two months to find somebody who
column69: for example
column70: was also accepted by banks and business partners. It was particularly important for Karl Rehm that the business continued as before
column71: with clients knowing they would get continued good service
column72:
and the firm’s employees keeping their jobs.

\r\n

The new owner was a car dealer and the company was moved to a new site
column73: six kilometres away
column74: where its business has continued successfully. Karl Rehm did not need any additional staff in the early phase of organising the race days and therefore could not offer his workers a job in his new firm. Instead
column75: all the workers were transferred with the old company to the car dealership
column76: under the same terms and conditions. The only exception was the employee who had hoped to buy the company. There was no need for him at the car dealer’s
column77: but Karl Rehm found him a job at a company owned by one of his friends
column78: where he is still working
column79:
as a customer relations manager. Karl Rehm still keeps in touch with his previous employees and the car dealer.

\r\n

Karl Rehm says the actual transfer process was easy. Due to his time in the business and his contacts with other traders he succeeded in selling all his stock before the transfer. Furthermore
column80: he contacted the motorbike manufacturers whose bikes he sold and asked if he could transfer his contracts to the successor company. His main business partners
column81: after checking the successor out
column82: agreed to cooperate. However he did have a bad experience with one manufacturer. This happened when he found somebody interested in taking over a trade contract and then mediated between this person and the manufacturer. However
column83:
the manufacturer bypassed Karl Rehm and concluded a new contract with the interested party. This meant Karl Rehm had to terminate his own contract without financial compensation.

\r\n

The whole transfer process took about two years
column84: involving bank meetings
column85: re-registration of the motorbike trading company
column86: cancellation of the insurance
column87: registration with the local community administration. However
column88: it was a continuous
column89:
reasonably stress-free process.

\r\n

Karl Rehm’s new company has become very successful
column90: and could still be expanded. Its services have been extended from organising race days to storage
column91:
transport and carrying out small repairs to customers’ motorbikes. This has enabled him to take on an additional employee. The company also bought a new company building in which the customers’ motorbikes and the trucks used to transport them are stored between race days.

Challenges and constraints of restructuring

The main challenge in the transfer process was to find a new successor quickly when the expected successor pulled out. Also Karl Rehm’s projected financial take from the deal was hit when a manufacturer sidelined him over a contract.

Another difficulty was the emotional cost of selling the company
column92: which he had founded and successfully run for 17 years. However
column93: he was persuaded by a friend
column94: himself an entrepreneur
column95:
of the better business potential of organising race training compared to the motorbike trade as well as the effects on his own health and work-life-balance (impossibility to run both business activities).

\r\n

Karl Rehm encountered many problems while developing his new business. It was a very specific
column96: new activity for which standard products could not be used. For example
column97: available software for inventory control and merchandise management was not suitable for administering the race days
column98: nor could the standardised line-ups for transporting motorbikes be used. In such cases
column99: Karl Rehm himself
column100: in cooperation with specialists
column101:
developed the products he needed.

Restructuring advice and support

The main reasons that Karl Rehm began to approach the idea of organising race days in a more strategic way were encouragement from his lecturer and participation in the support programme.

He was supported while preparing to diversify
column102: and during the transfer process
column103: by his entrepreneur friend
column104: who gave him emotional and personal support as well as practical recommendations and helped him to search for and contact suitable successors. This friend started up his business
column105:
expanded it to about 300 employees to date and also changed his business focus during his entrepreneurial activities

\r\n

Karl Rehm feels that
column106: as an entrepreneur
column107: it is important to find one’s own solutions to challenges
column108:
rather than asking for help from public bodies or lobbying organisations. For this reason he did not look for such support during the restructuring process.

\r\n

To clarify specific questions
column109: for example regarding legal or tax issues or concerning specific procedures concerning the transfer
column110: he approached his tax consultant
column111: with whom he had a long business relationship
column112:
which still exists.

Outcomes of restructuring

The motorbike trading company is still being successfully run since the transfer
column113: with Karl Rehm’s old customers benefiting from a known and trusted service
column114: and all the workers being kept on. Although the company was relocated
column115:
this did not cause any inconveniences for the employees as the new location is only six kilometres away.

\r\n

Karl Rehm’s new company is prospering
column116:
making higher profits at a lower risk (due to lower capital employed) than his motorbike trade. There is less competition than in the motorbike trade and a good and sustainable level of demand. Due to the good business performance and continuous expansion an additional job was created..

\r\n

The enterprises that cooperate with the new company
column117: such as motorbike dealers or garages offering their customers the chance to participate in the race days
column118: benefit from higher customer loyalty and increased demand for servicing and such products as tyres
column119: cover panels
column120: high-value vehicle mechanics
column121: etc. (Heinen et al.
column122:
2005).

\r\n

Karl Rehm is convinced he made the right decision and is still satisfied with the re-orientation of his business activities. He is continuously on the lookout for new race courses and customer groups and appreciates the challenge to develop new business.

\r\n

His experience has given him a more strategic perspective towards his ideas
column123:
and he increasingly conducts analyses of the market and potential ideas. As a consequence he might decide not to pursue with ideas that appeal to him personally if they prove not to be economically feasible.

\r\n

The switch has improved his work-life balance. Although his workload is the same
column124:
he has more flexibility in setting his working times because of fewer customer contacts.

Commentary

One of the major reasons for Karl Rehm to turn the organisation of race training into a business was his participation in a support programme. This meant that he first had to spend time doing strategic considerations and elaborating data and facts (market analysis and assessment of future potential). He sees the economic outlook of his forecast as an important success factor for the restructuring
column125:
and since then also increasingly applies such criteria when considering further business ideas. He now gives more importance to the acquisition of knowledge and information on business issues.

\r\n

The decision to sell his long-established motorbike business
column126:
as well as going through the actual transfer process was mainly supported by a friend who is also an entrepreneur. Karl Rehm did not see any need for support from public bodies or lobbying organisations as he feels that he alone is responsible for his entrepreneurial decisions and challenges and does not want to outsource this responsibility.

It was important to him that the company he had founded and successfully established should continue and not only maintain the jobs of his employees but also guarantee to long-standing customers that they would get the quality of service they had come to expect. He has committed himself personally to ensuring this. He points to the major success factors for his restructuring as:

  • the proactive and strategic approach in getting information and developing his own knowledge
column127:
as well as the drafting of the\r\nbusiness plan and the market analysis\r\n
  • his personal interest in the business activity
column128:
his own\r\ninitiative and engagement when realising the ideas\r\n
  • personal support from a friend
column129:
particularly as this also included entrepreneurial/business administration advice.

column1:
Samat Kovoizospol, Slovakia~"Samat Kovoizospol s.r.o."~"

This Slovakian company produces aluminium window frames and other construction parts and has an international customer base
column2: with 80% of its overall production being exported. The aim of the complex restructuring was the implementation of new technology and innovative production process of fibreglass window frames. While the company has experienced financial problems due to the recent global economic crisis
column3:
its ability to innovate and compete has helped it to give it a competitive edge.

"~"

Organisational profile

Jan Pauschek is the founder and sole owner of Samat Kovoizospol
column4: s.r.o. The business is a limited liability company
column5: and the owner is also the managing director. Despite its ownership structure
column6: the company is a family business employing other family members
column7: including Mr. Pauschek’s wife and children. Mrs Pauschek
column8: who was interviewed for this case study
column9: is employed at Samat Kovoizospol as an economist. She joined the company at its inception
column10: and in her management capacity makes important decisions concerning company operations.  The family members constitute the core of the firm’s management
column11: including its economic
column12:
production and technology-related functions.

\r\n

Jan Pauschek started his first venture in 1988 by establishing Kovoizospol as a cooperative. This was the only way to run any entrepreneurial venture under the socialist regime in what was then Czechoslovakia. Kovoizospol produced metal structures and roof hydro-isolations. Using his experience and contacts with clients
column13:
the owner was able to follow new trends in the construction industry.

\r\n

In 1992
column14: Kovoizospol created a joint venture with the Italian producing and trading company Samat Aluminio
column15: whose main products were aluminium and aluminium profiles. The limited liability company Samat Kovoizospol was then established
column16: with production facilities located in several garages in a suburb of Bratislava. When its production increased
column17: the company moved to a more spacious production facility in Čunovo
column18: outside Bratislava. Later on
column19: the company started production also in High Tatras
column20: mainly due to intensive construction activities in this region and to be closer to customers. In 2006
column21:
Mr Pauschek bought his partner’s share and became the sole owner.

\r\n

The company produces aluminium window frames and other construction components for buildings
column22: including plastic window frames
column23: where demanded by customers. Its customers range from individuals to large construction companies. Samat Kovoizospol has extensive international contacts with its suppliers in China
column24: which supply the highest quality raw materials
column25: as well as with its customers
column26: exporting to EU countries
column27: mainly France
column28: the Czech Republic and Belgium. It exports also to Russia
column29: Egypt
column30:
Vietnam and China. Around 80% of overall production is exported.

\r\n

Samat Kvoizospol constantly monitors the newest construction trends and innovations. In 2005
column31: it started production of fibreglass profiles for the construction industry. In 2006
column32: the company acquired a large site in Miloslavovo
column33: where it built a new production facility for a new fibreglass technology. In 2007
column34: it decided to buy a Canadian patent for the production of pultruded fibreglass profiles. The mechanical and thermal isolation characteristics of this material make it an excellent construction material for window frames. It eliminates the need for metal reinforcement structures regularly used in plastic windows. Additional advantages are stability
column35:
long-lasting durability and smooth surface.

\r\n

Even though the price of fibreglass is about 20% higher than plastic
column36: fibreglass is much cheaper than aluminium window frames. This makes it a very competitive product
column37: and it is becoming better known by prospective customers. Due to patent protection
column38: Samat Kovoizospol has no competitors in Slovakia or in Europe. There is no mass production of window frames
column39: all business being based on specific customer orders. Production runs  are short
column40: which makes management of production quite demanding. Nevertheless
column41:
it provides jobs for about 40 employees. This level is quite sustainable despite the recent crisis in the construction sector and financial difficulties of the firm.

The company does not have any relationships with trade unions nor a works council present.

Background to restructuring event

The restructuring process of Samat Kovoizospol has been quite complex. The company has always tried to innovate to increase its competitiveness. Developing steadily from the start
column42: it soon prospered in terms of performance and employment. When it found a new technology that was able to compete in terms of mechanical and thermal characteristics with aluminium window profiles and which offered considerably lower production costs
column43: the company decided to use it. They bought the patent and implemented the new technology. To do this
column44:
the company needed large investments covered by bank loans.

\r\n

With the new technology in place
column45: Samat Kovoizospol became the only company in Europe able to produce pultruded fibreglass profiles and hence substantially increased its competitiveness. Under stable market conditions during the planning phase
column46: the innovation project would have proceeded without any substantial problems. However
column47: the onset of the economic crisis hit the construction industry particularly hard
column48:
and the loss of a large contract resulted in a cash flow problem and insolvency.

\r\n

Problems arose in 2007 when the company lost a large contract in Prague that should have lasted for five years. The reason for this was a late shipment of new technology related to the patent for fibreglass profiles from Canada. For Samat Kovoizospol
column49: it was impossible to replace such a big contract by new orders of a comparable size immediately
column50:
especially when the emerging crisis was already affecting the whole construction industry. It was necessary to look for new customers. This had a negative impact on cash flow and repayment of bank loans.

\r\n

However
column51: the events that triggered real financial difficulty for the company were the insolvency of one English customer and a Slovak company in 2008
column52: when Samat Kovoizospol had not received payments for large deliveries to them. The company was in a state of failure
column53:
as it had a number of creditors and was unable to discharge its liabilities to them within 30 days.

\r\n

The Act on Bankruptcy and Restructuring in Slovakia defines failure as when a business becomes insolvent and cannot pay creditors (in other words
column54: where a debtor is more than 30 days late in paying what is owed)
column55: and it has more than one creditor
column56: and the value of the amount due exceeds its asset value. In the case of a debtor becoming insolvent
column57: the procedures for the administration of this event are bankruptcy or restructuring. Bankruptcy means the liquidation of the company and the lay-off of all employees. Restructuring (reštrukturalizácia) is a legal process whereby the debtor will continue operations in the hope that it recovers and creditors can write off part of their claims
column58:
as it is in their interest to do so.

\r\n

As with bankruptcy
column59: both creditors and debtor can apply for restructuring
column60:
and the debtor can appoint a bankruptcy trustee (správca konkurznej podstaty) to assess whether restructuring is possible. The trustee is a physical or a legal person listed under the Register of Bankruptcy Trustees of the Ministry of Justice of the Slovak Republic. The role of the trustee is to assist the courts in the process of bankruptcy and restructuring.

\r\n

If the trustee recommends restructuring
column61: the debtor may apply for a restructuring permit. The assessment must not be more than 30 days old. The restructuring procedure begins with publication in the trade journal. Only those creditors who have registered their claims on time through a declaration are entitled to make claims during restructuring. The declaration
column62: together with attachments
column63: is submitted to the office of the trustee
column64:
and to the court. The declaration must be received by both the trustee and the court within 30 days of the restructuring permit being issued. A list of registered claims is drawn up by the trustee under court supervision. The restructuring procedure ends with the publication of a court resolution on the completion of restructuring in the trade journal.

Restructuring processes

To avoid bankruptcy
column65: Samat Kovoizospol appointed a consulting company to assess whether restructuring was possible and to propose the best plan to convince and satisfy creditors. This is a common practice in Slovakia
column66: and there is an entire market in consultancy firms that offer their services to help facilitate restructuring. Thorough analysis showed that the company had the potential to overcome its difficulties. The company had production capacity and there was market for fibreglass window frames. As a result of discussions with the consultancy
column67:
the company decided to apply for restructuring and managed to get an agreement from its creditors.

\r\n

The company started to communicate with its creditors about the situation concerning its financial problems. At this stage
column68: the creditors authorised a trustee to make a restructuring assessment
column69: to find out if the conditions for debtor’s restructuring had been met. The outcome of the assessment
column70: which could not be older than 30 days
column71:
was a recommendation for restructuring and the assessment of the debtor’s economic status.

\r\n

Based on the trustee’s recommendation
column72: it was possible to submit the request to permit restructuring to the relevant court. The court ruling on commencement of the restructuring process was issued on 6 July 2010. At this stage
column73:
the court reviews the formal essentials of submitted motion for restructuring. The issuing of a ruling on commencement of the restructuring process has protective effects against further aggressive activities by creditors.

\r\n

The company in cooperation with the trustee and the committee of main creditors developed the restructuring plan. The plan states how
column74: when and what amount would be covered in claims of eligible creditors. Accordingly
column75: the court ordered that the repayments be made to creditors every six months. The debt of a company that undergoes restructuring can be written off by as much as 85%. The company plans to cover the repayment by increasing their production and sales; the investments made in recent years to introduce fibreglass products potentially have made Samat Kovoizospol highly competitive. In addition
column76:
the plan regulates monitoring of the company operation and important decisions with financial effects. This plan was approved by the court on 3 May 2011.

Challenges and constraints of restructuring

The whole process of restructuring has been very challenging for the company. Above all
column77: it was difficult work to convince the main creditors about the realistic prospects for company operations in the market and its ability to pay creditors’ claims agreed in the restructuring plan. After the approval of the restructuring plan prepared by the trustee and creditors
column78: a plan must be endorsed by the court. In this case
column79: the restructuring plan was developed for the duration of eight years. During this period
column80: the company’s financial operations will be thoroughly monitored to ensure fulfilment of the restructuring plan. The company will be prevented from obtaining a bank loan for a large project during this time. The business will have to look for smaller projects that are less lucrative
column81:
and its new production capacities will not be used as efficiently.

Restructuring advice and support

In this case
column82: the consulting company was an important factor in managing the restructuring process successfully. The assessment of the company’s potential to restructure and the restructuring plan are the key documents in the process of restructuring. These can only be produced by the registered trustee. However
column83: the assessment involved lawyers as well as economists from business consultancies
column84:
who provided a full analysis of the company’s financial situation. They helped with the development of a comprehensive assessment document and the successful implementation of restructuring.

Outcomes of restructuring

The main outcome of restructuring was the implementation of new technology and mastering of the whole innovative production process of fibreglass window frames. However
column85: such financial restructuring presented difficulties for the company. Despite the partial reduction of debts
column86: there will be ongoing monitoring of financial operations to eliminate the possibility of the accumulation of excessive debts. During this period
column87: it will be almost impossible to get a bank loan. It means that Samat Kovoizospol cannot take on any large projects and the opportunities to gain new customers are restricted. Nevertheless
column88: the outcome of restructuring has been a success in terms of allowing the company to continue in its production activities. Due to innovative technologies
column89: competitiveness
column90: excellent position in the market and good relationships with suppliers and customers
column91:
the company is able to maintain production levels and the number of employees. Restructuring did not have any effect on the existing staff numbers.

\r\n

According to Mrs Pauschek
column92: the restructuring event was very demanding for the company and for her personally. The financial performance of the company was a central issue in the deliberations and decisions made during restructuring. On the other hand
column93: the company is a family business
column94: and this adds additional pressure
column95: such as working longer hours
column96:
on all family members who are involved. Mr Pauschek said he felt he had aged by 10 years as a result of the whole process.

Commentary

Samat Kovoizospol is a successful construction company that constantly innovates in its product range. In 2005
column97: the company introduced fibreglass products as an alternative to plastic and aluminium. As the only company in Slovakia producing fibreglass window frames
column98:
Samat Kovoizospol has no competition. This places the company in a favourable position.

\r\n

The company has experienced financial problems due to the recent global economic crisis; however
column99: its ability to innovate and compete has helped it to continue in operation despite the problems in the construction sector. The possibility of the legal process of restructuring that is available in Slovakia has helped the company avoid bankruptcy and continue its activities without making cuts to employment or production. As a consequence of restructuring
column100: the company is restricted in terms of business expansion; however
column101: it has lowered its debts and continues producing. In these difficult times
column102:
the company will need to make a huge managerial effort to keep performing and provide employment for its staff.

column1:
Sanako, Finland~"Sanako Corporation"~"

The restructuring in Finnish digital language lab company Sanako was aimed at reorganising its business functions and diversifying its product portfolio. Despite the redundancies which were a necessary part of the cost-cutting process
column2: the CEO has put in place a remuneration system to motivate current employees towards the development of the company
column3:
with 15%–30% of the company’s profits to be shared among the employees.

"~"

Organisational profile

Sanako Corporation is a company that develops language learning solutions. Sanako’s products and services include software and hardware-based digital language labs for classrooms
column4: cloud-based solutions for virtual environments
column5: flexible content integration and training modules
column6: as well as consultation. The aim of the company is to enable language learners to speak  and understand language better and to have good communication skills. Sanako’s history dates back to 1961
column7: when the first Tandberg language lab was produced. During the 1960s and 1970s
column8: Tandberg grew and became the global leader in language labs. The educational division of the company was acquired by Teleste Corporation in 1984. In 2003
column9:
Sanako was born as a spin-off of Teleste.

\r\n

Sanako operates internationally. The company has two offices in Finland: in Espoo and its headquarters in Turku. In addition
column10: it has subsidiaries in India
column11: the UK and the USA
column12: and representation offices in China
column13: Dubai and Mexico. Sales also take place via a worldwide partner network. The markets are divided rather evenly across Europe
column14: Asia
column15:
and North and South America. Only 2% of Sanako’s sales come from Finland.

\r\n

The company employed 48 people in March 2012. About 25 employees work in Finland and the rest abroad; 90% are male and 10% female. Women work mostly in finance and administration and men in product development and sales. Most of the employees have a higher education degree (bachelor’s or master’s)
column16:
typically in engineering or business.

\r\n

The current CEO Tobias Elgh joined Sanako in June 2011 as sales director. In September 2011
column17: he was promoted to CEO after the growth strategy of the company had failed. Elgh’s task was to make the company profitable again and put it back on the path to growth. Sanako is privately owned
column18:
with equity investment from a group of varied investors. The CEO does not own any shares in the company.

\r\n

There is no works council present in the company
column19: but there are two shop stewards representing the employees. The shop stewards serve as local negotiators
column20:
conciliators and channels of communication between the employer and the employees. Shop stewards have been involved in the restructuring procedures related to dismissals (codetermination negotiations). This is required by the Act on Cooperation within Undertakings (or YT Act) applied in all businesses with a regular staff of at least 20 employees in Finland.

Background to restructuring event

Sales as well as the profitability of the company decreased greatly during the global financial and economic crisis. Neither Asian nor European markets maintained the demand Sanako expected. The political situation in certain countries also had a direct influence on Sanako’s business where they were selling to ministries of education. For example
column21: the company expected to have major projects from Egypt and Libya
column22: but due to the unstable situations in these countries no deals were made. At the same time
column23: Sanako’s focus shifted from hardware to software
column24: which in turn decreased the price per sale. Therefore
column25: bigger projects became even more important for the company. The CEO considers it impossible for the company to grow with their current offering. There has been a declining trend in the sales of hardware-based digital language labs. If not enough compensating products are offered
column26:
sales growth is impossible.

\r\n

The turnover of the company had remained reasonably stable
column27: at a level of €10–11 million
column28: from 2005
column29: but in 2011
column30: turnover dropped to €7.8 million. At the same time
column31: fixed costs increased to €7.5 million. The first unprofitable year in company’s history was 2010
column32: and 2011 was even worse. The whole company was built for growth
column33: and it had expected to grow by 40% from 2010
column34: resulting in a turnover of €40 million by 2014. Many investments in new markets were made
column35: and new employees were recruited (resulting in the increase of fixed costs)
column36: but growth did not ensue. In order to improve the cost-efficiency and create more synergies
column37:
the restructuring process was started.

Restructuring processes

The restructuring in Sanako is related to reorganisation of its business functions and product portfolio. Previously
column38: the sales and marketing organisations were located around the world. There were two sales organisations
column39: one for projects and one for ‘normal’ sales. Projects refer to custom projects done jointly with national governments and ministries of education
column40: where Sanako takes care of planning
column41: financing
column42: installation
column43: user training and support. Normal sales refer to smaller-scale sales of the company’s products. Each subsidiary and representation office was responsible for its own marketing. To achieve greater cost efficiency and to promote more synergies
column44: these activities
column45: along with financial services
column46: have been integrated and are currently centralised in Finland. A service centre has been created in Finland
column47: which serves the subsidiaries and partners abroad. Previously independent subsidiaries are now operating as sales companies. Centralising the financial administration and sales and marketing organisations in Finland was done during 2011. The business operations of Sanako are now reorganised into three functions: 1) business services (financial department and back office)
column48: 2) product and service production
column49:
and 3) sales and marketing.

\r\n

Product development has always been led by Sanako headquarters
column50: but reorganisation has also taken place there. Some product portfolios have been terminated
column51: and due to this
column52: some employees have been let go. The focus has been directed towards the development of new products in the form of cloud-based services. This will change the revenue generation model of the company. Whereas customers previously paid once for the hardware
column53: they are now paying annually for services. The old products are currently in maintenance mode; as long as they are selling
column54: they are kept in the product portfolio. The aim is to launch three to six new services per year. The company has a separate unit of product designers
column55: who are responsible for designing new products and services. Within three to five years
column56: the company should have found a service that can replace the hardware-based language labs
column57:
as they are coming to the end of their life cycle. The renewal of the product portfolio started at the end of 2010 and should be finished by the end of 2012.

\r\n

Cutting all kinds of costs has been central in the restructuring done in Sanako to build a healthy basis for the business in the future and to make the company profitable by the end of 2012. All cost items have been reviewed and even small costs are cut. One example of this is ending coffee machine rental. In addition
column58: the number of management team members has been cut from nine to three. All the former members of management left the company
column59:
so the current management team consists entirely of ‘fresh’ faces.

\r\n

The biggest cost-saving was made from redundancies. The management also looked at options to make some working time adjustments
column60: such as short-time working and compulsory paid leave
column61: but these were not considered sufficient. The company had two codetermination negotiations resulting in lay-offs
column62: the first in September–October 2011 and the second at the turn of 2011–2012. The process was carried out according to the regulations of the Act on Cooperation within Undertakings. The shop stewards represented the employees’ side in the negotiations. According to the interviewed employee
column63: the first negotiations were tougher as it was the first time for all parties involved. There were meetings every few days. The second time
column64: the process was much faster (the minimum time was two weeks as the number of people dismissed was fewer than ten). At the time of the second codetermination negotiations
column65: the new collective agreement took effect. An across-the-board increase of 2.4% in salaries
column66: a standard annual raise varying slightly in size
column67: was included in the agreement. There was a possibility to negotiate a lower increase or no increase at all
column68:
but the employees did not accept the offers made by the employer.

\r\n

One alternative to the restructuring was outsourcing the financial administration. A proposal was requested
column69: but it was impossible to implement it in the timeframe set by the board
column70: that is
column71: by the end of 2011. The CEO also considered selling one of the product portfolios that had been profitable for the company and making the company solely a software business. Both of these options are still possible. However
column72:
currently the focus is on stabilising the business and gaining back the trust of the employees.

\r\n

The CEO has had the main responsibility for the costs savings and strategic renewal. The CEO examined all functions thoroughly and interviewed employees all around the world to get to know the company and to identify the functions where savings could be made. He also listened to employees’ suggestions for potential cost savings. Employees were encouraged to share their views in meetings and via e-mails. After that
column73: the CEO made a written proposal regarding cost savings to the board
column74: which accepted it. The employees were informed of the codetermination negotiations a week before the negotiations started
column75:
following the YT Act.

Challenges and constraints of restructuring

The biggest challenge was related to change management. The news about the dismissals was a shock to the employees. It was the first time they had experienced such an event
column76: and they did not know what exactly was going on. As the codetermination negotiations affected the whole staff
column77:
there was huge uncertainty about future employment among the employees. The lay-offs had a crippling effect on employees’ performance for a long time after the decisions were made.

Restructuring advice and support

The CEO has had the main responsibility for the costs savings and strategic renewal
column78: but he has worked closely with the board and has been able to share ideas with the members. The CEO’s own support network
column79: mainly his friends
column80: relatives and other business contacts
column81: has also been important. No financial or non-financial support has been received for the restructuring. The CEO considers that this is partly because there is not enough information about available support for SMEs. The company has received financing from Tekes (the Finnish Funding Agency for Technology and Innovation) for development of the service business
column82:
but this support is applied continuously and it is not directly related to the restructuring.

Outcomes of restructuring

As a result of the restructuring
column83: the company aims to reach a turnover of €9.8 million in 2012 and cut fixed costs to €5 million. Before the restructuring
column84: the company had around 74 employees
column85: and of these
column86: 26 were let go; 60% of the lay-offs took place in Finland and 40% abroad. In Finland
column87: employees in all roles were let go
column88: whereas abroad employees were reduced from marketing. There is still potential to reduce employees in India or China. The company now operates on quarter-year basis
column89: and if the budget is not balanced
column90: new restructuring will be considered
column91:
but mainly in the units abroad.

\r\n

When the announcement of the first codetermination negotiations was given in September 2011
column92: the reactions of employees were mainly disbelief
column93: anger and fear for their jobs. Sanako had been considered a stable workplace
column94: and the communication from the former management team had not given any clear indication about the company’s problems. In the beginning
column95: there was a confrontation between the employees and the employer. The second time was easier
column96:
but the employees still found it very hard to believe: ‘Wasn’t the first time enough?’

\r\n

The current management has paid a great deal of attention to open communication with the personnel. Monthly meetings are organised
column97: where topics such as sales development and cost levels are presented. Regular e-mail notifications are sent to inform the personnel about topical issues. This is important as the management team is in Espoo
column98:
although they visit the headquarters every week.

\r\n

The trade unions have been informed about the restructuring via the shop stewards. Also the reseller network has been informed
column99:
as quite a few of the contact persons changed in the process.

\r\n

The CEO has reviewed all the tasks of each employee in order to better know the company and to see if everyone is doing relevant tasks. As a result
column100: the responsibilities of five employees have been widened. Three people have received a small increase in salary. One person agreed to have a pay cut. It has not been possible to offer any training to the employees. This is unfortunate
column101: as training is needed in the company
column102:
but the company cannot afford it.

\r\n

At first there was some confusion about the roles and responsibilities of each person. When interviewed early in 2012
column103: the CEO believed that it would be a year of getting used to the new ways of working. The interviewed employee considered the expanded job descriptions to be positive for career development
column104: even though that has not been possible for all employees. The workload has increased for everyone
column105:
with the same amount of work having to be done by fewer people.

\r\n

It is too early yet to know if the restructuring will lead to burnout
column106: but the workload and stress levels have been high
column107:
especially among employees in financial administration. The codetermination negotiations happened simultaneously with the financial reporting of the company.

\r\n

The employees have also been able to suggest costs savings. This has been a good way to motivate people and to improve the work atmosphere. One idea suggested by the employees was to get rid of the extra office space in the headquarters after the lay-offs. The previous office space of 1
column108: 000 square metres has now been reduced to 500. Moving to new workstations acted as a symbolic new start for the business that has been built by all the employees jointly. Also a remuneration system has been developed to motivate the employees towards the development of the company
column109:
and 15%–30% of the company profits will be shared among the employees.

\r\n

The restructuring process has been a great learning process
column110: although a very tough one
column111: for the CEO. He came to the company to grow the sales and ended up addressing totally different tasks. As he was quite new in the company
column112: it may have been easier for him to make rational and more analytical decisions
column113:
because he was not yet that emotionally attached to the people in the company.

\r\n

Even though the restructuring process is still ongoing (the renewal of the product portfolio) and all the decisions were made quite rapidly
column114: the CEO considers the outcomes positive for company profitability and also for the personnel. Costs have decreased
column115: and sales have started increase compared to last year. The CEO says he has received positive feedback from the employees. Everybody understands now that the restructuring was necessary
column116: although painful
column117:
to keep the company alive. The interviewed employee states that the current atmosphere in the company is reasonably good and the company feels strong.

Commentary

SMEs are able to react faster to changes in the markets
column118: but sometimes it can be hard to find the best people to implement a restructuring plan
column119:
as there are not that many people to choose from. Not all employees are able to act as change agents in the company.

\r\n

The CEO of Sanako recommends other SMEs going through restructuring to carefully follow market trends and to react to them. It is important to analyse rationally the strengths and the weaknesses of the business and try to turn the weaknesses into strengths. He considers that if a company is not profitable
column120: something needs to be done
column121:
and the sooner the better.

\r\n

A personnel matrix recording the strengths and weaknesses of each employee is a useful tool for restructuring. It makes it easier to find a back-up person for each employee and to transfer employees from one task to another when needed. This is especially important if the company has gone through codetermination negotiations
column122:
as they are not allowed to recruit new employees for nine months after the negotiations.

\r\n

The public support available for SME restructuring should be promoted more. It should also be easily accessible because in a time of crisis
column123: SMEs do not have extra time to spend on the application procedures. Restructuring often demands cost savings and
column124: therefore
column125:
support must not be expensive.

column1:
Sjølund, Denmark~"Sjølund A/S"~"

When Danish firm Sjølund established a subsidiary in China
column2: a blacksmith was sent to China for three months to train the new staff. Furthermore
column3: as management felt that the Chinese plant had become a bit too autonomous
column4:
it was decided to send an employee from Sjolund to China to monitor that it was running as a Sjolund clone and not just as a plant in China doing the same kind of work.

"~"

Organisational profile

\r\n

Sjølund A/S is a specialised subcontractor in aluminium and steel section bending. ‘We want to be the world’s best to bend profiles’ is the officially declared vision
column5: and the company currently considers itself the European leader when it comes to competence and quality. The company was founded in 1936 by a local blacksmith
column6:
and had developed into a specialised subcontractor by the second generation. Sjølund is now highly specialised in bending profiles.

\r\n

Today the company is owned and managed by managing director Søren Ravn Jensen
column7: who has been the sole owner of Sjølund since he bought out his three partners in 2007. He was export manager at Sjølund for 13 years before he took over the company completely. Apart from being a skilled worker and engineer
column8: Søren Ravn Jensen also has a Certificate of Business Administration (CBA) from AVT Institute and has studied strategy
column9:
innovation and leadership at INSEAD (the European Institute of Business Administration).

\r\n

Sjølund is located in the village of Sjølund
column10: Denmark
column11: but in 2009 it established a production plant in Hefei
column12: which is located between Beijing and Shanghai in China. Sjølund Profile Bending (the company name in China) is managed by a Chinese general manager
column13: John Fang
column14: in close cooperation with Sjølund in Denmark. The Chinese subsidiary produces for its own customers and is not an outsourcing unit for Sjølund in Denmark. The customers of both companies are mainly companies in the wind energy
column15: transport and building sectors. Sjølund owns the majority of Sjølund Profile Bending
column16: with IFU (the Investment Fund for Developing Countries) as equity partner with 20% of ownership. IFU is a self-governing fund associated with the Ministry of Foreign Affairs in Denmark
column17:
which invests public money in business projects in developing countries. The challenges and advantages of this management structure are described further in this case study.

\r\n

Sjølund currently has about 65 employees and another 45 employees at Sjølund China. Employees are mainly skilled metalworkers with many years of experience
column18: typically organised in the Dansk Metal union. The majority of employees are men; four women work in administration. Since Søren Ravn Jensen took over the company
column19: Sjølund has strategically hired a few people with higher education and solid management experience at the management level
column20: among them the CFO
column21:
the sales director and the production manager. This has raised the level of education and experience in the management team considerably. The team members are all in their forties.

\r\n

Sjølund in Denmark is an international company
column22: with 60%–70% of its turnover from exports. However
column23: it still has a local presence
column24: with 100 mainly local customers
column25: whose orders are small. Establishing a subsidiary in China is part of an internationalisation strategy that has been generally defined by Søren Ravn Jensen and planned in detail by the management team
column26:
where Sjølund will establish ‘clones’ of Sjølund in new growth markets especially.

\r\n

A CSR (corporate social responsibility) strategy has been developed for the new production plant in China. This was one of the conditions for funding by IFU
column27:
and it provides the staff at Sjølund Profile Bending with better working conditions than regular Chinese standards.

\r\n

Sjølund has been profitable throughout the financial crisis
column28: even though sales and profits fell dramatically in 2008–2009. The crisis also caused a reduction in staff from 75 to 65 in Sjølund
column29: Denmark – the same level as in 2005–2006. Sjølund Profile Bending in China had losses in the start-up phase
column30: but was profitable for the first time in the first quarter of 2011
column31:
and the number of employees has increased from 15 in the start-up phase to 45 in the first quarter of 2012.

\r\n

\r\n

Background to restructuring event

\r\n

The restructuring of Sjølund started in 2007
column46: when Søren Ravn Jensen bought out three co-owners in the management team. He had tested and trained his management skills while attending a CBA programme and had become ambitious for the company. Studying with managers from large and well-known companies raised his confidence in his own management abilities
column47: and he believed that he could take Sjølund to a higher level by establishing production in other markets. His partners and colleagues in the management team were not quite as ambitious and thought ‘why bother when things are going very well anyway?’ So Søren Ravn Jensen offered to buy them out. He wrote a business plan to raise funding from the bank
column48: mentioning the option to establish production in India or China. Søren Ravn Jensen felt that with his vision of becoming the world leader in section bending and with the global development of the industry
column49: the company was vulnerable because of its mainly European customer base. One of the reasons was that these European customers were
column50: or would potentially be
column51:
moving production to new markets like China or India.

\r\n

His former partners agreed to leave the company within a year of the buy-out
column52: and this left Søren Ravn Jensen with the option of setting up a completely new management team that fitted the company vision. While the original management team were all people with a long background at Sjølund
column53: Søren Ravn Jensen decided to recruit a management team with a higher level of education and with management experience from other companies. The impact of this strategy was illustrated in the interview with the CFO at Sjølund
column54: who has experience of business development from working in different large corporations. At the job interview
column55: he told Søren Ravn Jensen that if he wanted to hire him
column56: it should be because he wanted to develop and grow his company. ‘Business development is the fun part of the job’
column57:
as he said.

\r\n

In 2008 the new management team decided to start working on establishing a production plant in China to be able to serve customers there. That China was chosen
column58: and not India
column59:
was due to the fact that Sjølund was already delivering to a customer operating in China. Therefore the management team expected that they would have a customer base to start on.

\r\n

Restructuring processes

\r\n

The restructuring process described in this case study is mainly the process of establishing a production plant in China as a subsidiary of Sjølund. However
column60:
the decision to expand to China was to a large extent a consequence of a restructuring in ownership and management. Therefore these events are also integrated in the case study.

\r\n

When the decision was made
column61: a specific business plan for the production plant in China was made. The new CFO
column62: Finn Mortensen
column63: had previous experience in establishing new business units
column64:
from working in large international corporations.

\r\n

The process of establishing production in China started with hiring a Chinese engineer with a Danish MBA
column65: who at that time worked for the big Danish corporation Danfoss. After some scepticism over why an educated man in a big corporation wanted to work for a small company like Sjølund
column66:
the company hired John Fang in September 2008. He started out by working for three months at Sjølund in Denmark to learn more about the company and to ‘breathe the air’ of the Sjølund culture. The company began creating scorecards for the different factors they should look for when they decided where to establish the company.

\r\n

Greenfield phase

\r\n

In the early greenfield phase
column67: the only resources were John Fang and a lot of extra work for the management team. The CFO visited seven different sites in China and had a lot of meetings with IFU (before John Fang was employed)
column68:
while Søren Ravn Jensen focused on contacting potential customers.

\r\n

Sjølund contacted private Danish business networks in the industrial centres on the east coast of China and got a lot of advice from people there and looked at potential facilities. However
column69: the company finally chose a project in a smaller industrial area in Hefei
column70:
west of Shanghai. This meant that it got a lot more attention for a small project from the local authorities than it would have got in the larger industrial cities along the coast.

\r\n

Technical set-up

\r\n

After finding the right place and getting formalities in order
column71: the next step for Sjølund was the technical setup. In this phase
column72: one of the most important tasks was investing the capital from Sjølund and IFU in machines and training the new staff of 15 people. In a company where 80% of the work is craft and 20% is standardised industrial processes
column73:
there is a lot of tacit knowledge to be transferred. Therefore a blacksmith was sent to China for three months to train the new staff.

\r\n

However
column74: getting customers wasn’t as easy as expected. Sjølund’s expected customers in China didn’t place any orders
column75: but a European train manufacturer that knew Sjølund from the European market placed a big order. This customer had been the only one notified regarding the establishment of the production plant in China. Its order all of a sudden provided plenty of work
column76:
more than the Chinese plant was able to deliver in terms of the quality Sjølund wants to be known for. This meant that the Sjølund Profile Bending had to involve the Danish mother company in executing the order from China. It led to extra work and capacity challenges in Denmark on the operational level as well as for management. The project lasted a full year.

\r\n

However
column77: the big order and the fact that training takes time also forced Sjølund to be innovative and rethink the Chinese strategy. Since the company couldn’t train people fast enough
column78:
it involved one of its experienced blacksmiths in transferring all of his tacit knowledge about a specific process into a machine that could automate the job.

\r\n

After this experience
column79: Søren Ravn Jensen has been rethinking and has learned that maybe the production in the Chinese plant should not be based on 80% craftsmanship and 20% production but maybe rather 50/50 or even 20/80
column80:
since it is a long process to train and develop good craftsmen.

\r\n

During the process
column81: Sjølund Profile Bending was managed mainly by general manager John Fang in frequent dialogue with the management in Denmark. However
column82: Søren Ravn Jensen felt that the Chinese plant was becoming too autonomous. In the summer of 2011
column83: he decided that he wanted an employee from Sjølund in Denmark posted to China at a high level
column84: to monitor that it was running as a Sjølund clone and not just as a plant in China doing the same kind of work. The devil is in the detail
column85:
and becoming a Sjølund clone takes more than some months of training in the start-up phase. As Søren Ravn Jensen says: ‘There is no easy way to learn how we do things at Sjølund. Here we breathe it in the air.’

\r\n

He subsequently hired a supply chain controller who had just finished his masters degree
column86: but had been working at Sjølund during his studies and knew the company very well. His job in China is to monitor the quality
column87:
key performance indicators and human resources and send reports to Sjølund in Denmark. The job is not planned as a permanent job for him.

\r\n

Søren Ravn Jensen has started considering posting a Danish production manager in China to strengthen the production management
column88:
but he is not yet quite sure how to do it so that the Chinese management doesn’t lose face.

\r\n

Staff involvement

\r\n

Staff at Sjølund were not involved in the process of planning the China project
column89:
except for the management team. They were informed of it at a company meeting before John Fang started working in the company in September 2008.

\r\n

There were some sceptics in the beginning
column90: who were concerned that production would be moved to China
column91:
even though the major purpose was to strengthen the company and bring in new customers. Therefore it was helpful to morale to see that nobody was laid off and that it actually created jobs in Denmark too.

\r\n

During the process
column92: there was some scepticism when the project in China was still losing money
column93: but as it started getting customers and as employees actually saw that Sjølund could also operate in China
column94:
they developed a sense of pride as well.

\r\n

At the management level
column95: Sjølund offered shares in the China plant to the management team at the beginning to motivate them. The production manager was not interested and wasn’t really that keen on the Chinese project and the travelling it implied. According to Søren Ravn Jensen
column96: the lack of commitment from a key person in Denmark delayed the project by about a year. The production manager chose to leave Sjølund during the process
column97:
which enabled the company to hire a new production manager who knew what the job would involve from the beginning.

\r\n

Challenges and constraints of restructuring

\r\n

According to Søren Ravn Jensen
column98: the most significant challenges and constraints in the early process were getting customers
column99: keeping the staff and making them believe that things would work out in the end and that customers would come. As for any start-up
column100:
it was also important to keep the costs low.

\r\n

Hiring Chinese workers was difficult in the early stages when there was no operating production plant to show
column101:
so they had to imagine the place where they would be working.

\r\n

Søren Ravn Jensen also learned that particularly in the early stages
column102:
it is important to have a native Chinese person involved in the process who understands how bureaucracies and relationships work in China.

\r\n

Another lesson learned was that it is difficult to transfer work that is based on good craftsmanship to China. Søren Ravn Jensen subscribes to the belief that it takes 10
column103: 000 hours of practice to master a craft. There is no easy way around that
column104:
and it doesn’t work if people try to come up with their own solutions when they lack the basic skills.

\r\n

Furthermore
column105: the company’s culture of quality
column106:
order and cleanliness can be difficult to adopt for Chinese employees. Søren Ravn Jensen understood why when he was taken to the places where workers live their daily lives to see the physical environment that was part of their reality.

\r\n

One thing that was easy to integrate
column107: however
column108:
was the team-building activities that are also a part of the culture at Sjølund. This seems to fit well with the Chinese culture.

\r\n

Regarding sales
column109:
Sjølund also realised that it is very difficult to win orders before you have a production plant to show to your customers.

\r\n

Restructuring advice and support

\r\n

Sjølund has received loans and equity capital from IFU
column110: and it is a partner in Sjølund Profile Bending in China. Søren Ravn Jensen considers IFU a very valuable partner that
column111: apart from funding
column112:
can offer advice on Chinese regulations and access to local networks. The presence of a Chinese person from IFU on the board is also very helpful when Danes and Chinese try to sort out issues caused by different cultures and different views on management.

\r\n

Apart from IFU
column113: Sjølund has not taken advantage of any public support programmes
column114: but it has experienced a very helpful attitude from other Danish companies in China
column115:
and Nordic Industrial Park has been very helpful in finding a good location.

\r\n

Outcomes of restructuring

\r\n

In general
column116:
Sjølund Profile Bending is running according to plan – just delayed by about a year. This means that an enduring positive impact on earnings is yet to be seen.

\r\n

During the process
column117: the profitability of the company suffered since it had to produce some units for the first orders in Denmark and sell them below cost price
column118: since the cost price of producing in Denmark is higher. Furthermore
column119: the process created a lot of turbulence at Sjølund in Denmark since it had to solve problems that the Chinese plant couldn’t solve. It even had to compromise on quality for new customers
column120: which everyone at Sjølund disliked having to do. Existing customers haven’t suffered on quality
column121: but have had to accept longer terms of delivery. And in this turbulent period
column122: the production manager had to split his time more or less equally between Denmark and China. This has been very costly
column123:
Søren Ravn Jensen points out.

\r\n

Søren Ravn Jensen’s conclusion is that it is possible to make a clone of Sjølund in another country – even though he may have been sceptical about whether it was actually possible. This has given him the courage to do it again in other BRIC countries (Brazil
column124: Russia
column125: India and China) or the USA. However
column126:
it is necessary that Sjølund Profile Bending is up and running before management resources can be allocated to new projects. He expects nevertheless that his ambitious management teams will be ready for new challenges when the most important Chinese problems are solved.

\r\n

On the employment side
column127: Sjølund Profile Bending has created 45 jobs in China
column128:
as well as four or five jobs in production and one or two administrative jobs at Sjølund Denmark.

\r\n

Apart from that
column129: it has required different meeting schedules due to the time difference and obviously more travel activity. The management team especially has a considerably increased workload
column130:
since they have had to split their time more or less equally between Denmark and China.

\r\n

The heavy workload also had some positive consequences. The CFO had to delegate as much as possible down the organisation
column131: and that was a gift to the bookkeeper
column132: who had asked for new challenges. However
column133:
the CFO points out that you have to have the right staff to do that and to be careful to delegate the right jobs to the right people.

\r\n

Salaries in general haven’t been affected by the restructuring
column134: but as Søren Ravn Jensen points out
column135:
the staff has got first-hand experience of the competition from China – and some are probably happier with what they’ve got when it comes to wages and working conditions.

\r\n

Travel and cooperation with the Chinese subsidiary also involves middle managers
column136: and that has raised standards for new middle managers. In future
column137:
Sjølund will require English skills from all middle managers.

\r\n

As indicated earlier
column138: operating in China hasn’t just required new skills. It has also added new skills to the company
column139: such as new ways to control and monitor quality and performance
column140: which may be useful for similar projects in the future. Structure and documentation have become keywords in the organisational strategy. As the CFO explains
column141:
Sjølund has done something for the first time without the know-how to do it. Next time it will know better.

\r\n

Sjølund Profile Bending in China wasn’t expected to be profitable in the first two to three years. Because improving sales took longer than expected
column142: and because indirect costs were higher than expected
column143: it wasn’t until the first quarter of 2011 that the Chinese subsidiary was profitable for the first time. Furthermore
column144: the lack of focus on China in-house at Sjølund has harmed the performance of the Chinese plant
column145: according to Søren Ravn Jensen
column146:
since they didn’t spend enough time following up. He expects overall profitability in 2012.

\r\n

On a personal level
column147: the Chinese plant has given Søren Ravn Jensen a lot of extra work
column148: but also an opportunity to closely compare his original factory to something similar. It has also given him a good networking icebreaker to have production in China
column149:
and it gives Sjølund and Søren Ravn Jensen a different status among other business leaders in his network.

\r\n

Commentary

\r\n

In Sjølund
column150:
Søren Ravn Jensen has experienced both advantages and disadvantages in being an SME trying to establish a production plant in China.

\r\n

First
column151: he mentions the speed of decision-making and taking action in an SME as an advantage. During his CBA studies
column152: he was stunned how little top managers in large corporations knew about what was going on at the lower levels of their organisations. ‘I’m an “undercover boss” every day’
column153: he said
column154:
with reference to the Undercover Boss television franchise. ‘I constantly know where they are and whether they are with me or not.’ He also points out that a certain degree of sympathy for the owner can make hard decisions easier to accept. The authority of an owner-manager also makes it possible to say and do things that would never be accepted from an employed CEO. And having built the company gives an owner-manager an instinct for how people feel and what can be done.

\r\n

The close relations between owner-manager and staff are underlined by the absence of an elected employee representative at Sjølund and very limited union involvement in employee affairs.

\r\n

Being a well-educated manager in a very non-academic world
column155: he points out the importance of having a hands-on approach to restructuring. But he has also learned the importance of having academics around you to keep the management team dynamic. The management team Søren Ravn Jensen originally bought out was more homogeneous
column156:
maybe too homogeneous.

\r\n

One reason why a management team in an SME may become very homogenous was offered by the CFO at Sjølund. With experience from large corporations
column157: he has noticed how people in large corporations tend to be more focused on their actual profession
column158: whereas a CFO at Sjølund will also get technical questions about profile bending. In an SME
column159:
the managers have to understand the company as a whole.

\r\n

The disadvantages for SMEs in a restructuring process are mainly the limited financial and management resources and the dependency on a few key employees. In the Sjølund case
column160: it was a further challenge that the production and sales managers have been replaced twice since 2007. The dependency on a few key employees means that there is no backup
column161:
so these employees simply have to work longer hours when they start a restructuring project.

\r\n

Søren Ravn Jensen is sure that it is better to be a big company if you want to start up production in China
column162: but the project has given Sjølund the confidence to start new plants in other BRIC countries. For the next project
column163:
he has learned that the process will have to be managed more tightly from the parent company through reports and through close communication between functions in different countries (matrix organisation).

\r\n

Furthermore
column164: he wants a key person from the parent organisation to be on the spot to observe and report
column165:
somebody who has breathed the culture of the organisation and is able to see the small deviations from the overall culture and philosophy.

\r\n

And finally he points out that next time he will appoint the best man for the job
column166:
not just the person it is most convenient to allocate to at the time.

\r\n

Concerning advice to policymakers
column167: Søren Ravn Jensen points out that access to funding can make a big difference. However
column168: he says that the Danish guarantee schemes from Vækstfonden are ineffective because banks do not want to take their share of the risk. (Vækstfonden is a state investment fund that aims to create new growth companies by providing venture capital and competence. It invests equity and provides loans and guarantees in collaboration with private partners and Danish financial institutions.) In relation to China specifically
column169:
he mentions that the help of mayors can make a difference.

Søren Ravn Jensen’s best advice to colleagues is to make sure they have the necessary financial and management resources and do not underestimate the resources needed – and to appoint the best man for the job.
