"~"Denmark"~"25 - manufacture of fabricated metal products

column1:
Software company, the Netherlands~"Software company"~"

This Dutch company provides software services and products for both private and public sector organisations. The restructuring was triggered by a drop in turnover in 2008 which created acute financial problems. When it proved impossible to obtain bank finding
column2:
the owners were forced to put their own money into the company. This helped them to survive through tough times and when turnover figures started to increase they were able to get bank credit again.

"~"

Organisational profile

Founded in 2003
column3: the company provides software services and products to deliver
column4: process
column5: analyse
column6:
and manage geospatial information. The company is a reseller of a software package and delivers related training and support.

\r\n

The company provides its services in the Benelux countries. About 80% of turnover is generated in the Netherlands and 20% in Belgium with a very small percentage generated in Luxembourg. The company provides services to both private and public sector organisations. Public customers are very diverse
column7: including the Ministry of Education
column8:
Ministry of Defence and Ministry of Infrastructure and the Environment.

\r\n

The company is formally part of a holding company (Company C) whose activities can be divided into two business lines: software (Company A) and data (Company B). Companies A and B operate independently. Company A has six employees and Company B has two employees. The holding company has three owners (stockholders). Two stockholders (and founders) are also directors of one of Companies A and B. Because of the size of the workforce there is no works council.

\r\n

In 2011
column9: company A moved from Reeuwijk to Capelle a/d IJssel. The main reason for this was to be in easier reach for customers. The new location is close to a highway and a more urban area
column10:
with more (potential) customers in the immediate vicinity.

\r\n

An interview was held with one of the three stockholders
column11:
the director of Company A.

Background to restructuring event

The formation of a holding company with two companies under it is the result of the restructuring. Before this
column12: there was only one company (Company D). At start-up Company D had six owners (stockholders)
column13: five of whom worked in the company
column14:
and comprised three business lines:

  1. data
  2. software
  3. projects

Company D achieved constant turnover and employment growth in 2003 to 2008. They started with three employees in 2003 and by early 2009 were employing 14. Most of the employees are highly educated in the field of geographical science or mathematics.

The main problem Company D had to face in early 2009 was that turnover declined in the last two quarters of 2008 and in the first quarter of 2009. The fourth quarter of 2008 was especially troubling
column15:
since this period was normally the best in terms of turnover. This decline was mainly the effect of the (economic) crisis on the sector and it mainly affected the projects department of Company D.

\r\n

Because of this decline
column16: and the fact that the six stockholders did not agree about (re)financing (for example
column17: getting additional private funds)
column18: the company had to file for bankruptcy in 2009. Three of the stockholders made a restart with the company
column19:
with only two business lines intact (data and software) as separate companies (A and B) with a central holding company (C). The projects business line was not deemed profitable enough for a restart. The owners did not see enough growth potential in the projects business line which was the weakest link in the three business lines.

Restructuring processes

The company took several actions before Company D went bankrupt at the end of 2009.

First
column20: the company decided to make use of the part-time unemployment benefit scheme. This scheme
column21: documented by a 2010 Eurofound report (119kb PDF) was launched by the Ministry of Social Affairs and Employment to cope with the crisis
column22: making it possible for employers to retain skilled workers in difficult economic times. Under the scheme
column23: employers could reduce employees’ work hours (laid down in the working contract) by up to 50%
column24: with employees receiving unemployment benefits for non-working hours. Use of the scheme has to be approved by the ‘UWV Werkbedrijf’ (administrative office for the Employee Insurance Agency). The company used this measure for three employees during the last quarter of 2008 for a period of six to nine months. The employees that were selected (by the management) for this measure were the ones who had the lowest workload
column25:
and were informed in one-to-one talks with the management.

\r\n

During 2009
column26: it became clear that the company needed increased financial means to survive. The bank would not give them an additional loan
column27: and finding another (private) investor was not an option for all stockholders. This meant they had to refinance Company D on their own
column28: by investing additional (private) funds. The six stockholders were unable to agree on a common solution: half wanted to refinance and half did not. Due to this division
column29:
the only possibility was to start a bankruptcy procedure and in November 2009 the company filed for bankruptcy.

\r\n

During 2009
column30: two employees left the company at their own initiative. Both worked in the projects department
column31: and recognised that their workload was declining. Their employer helped them search for new work via managers’ networks. The management assisted them because they felt responsible for their employees
column32:
and because formal dismissals would cost a lot more time and money.

\r\n

In addition
column33:
the workforce was downsized further by:

  1. not extending the contract of a temporary employee;
  2. offering two employees a settlement.

The settlement meant contracts were voluntarily dissolved in return for financial compensation. These two employees had the least amount of work within the company at the time. They received a compensation which the company could just about financially bear
column34:
in light of their financial problems.

\r\n

One administrative employee was not given a job with the new organisation after the bankruptcy
column35:
because this position was no longer necessary.

\r\n

There was no formal plan setting out these activities.

\r\n

One stockholder wanted financial compensation for leaving the company. It was not possible to come to an agreement and the case was settled in court
column36:
with no financial compensation to be paid.

\r\n

The company filed for bankruptcy in November 2009
column37: and a trustee was appointed by the court. Early in the bankruptcy process (still in 2009) the interviewed stockholder took the decision to restart
column38: together with two other stockholders. The interviewed stockholder was asked by the trustee if he wanted to make a restart. He decided that he would like to continue with company activities (he still had a passion for his work and company) and asked two other stockholders to join him
column39:
and they agreed.

\r\n

In order to restart
column40: the (potential) new owners had to write a business plan for the trustee describing the plan to organise the restart (financial and organisational). Most work for the plan was done during November 2009. They eventually got the green light from the trustee to restart. But the total process took a long time
column41: finishing in January 2012. In this process they decided that working with a holding company (Company C) and two separate companies for the data and software business lines (A and B) was the best option. By having only one person responsible for one business line there was more clarity of responsibility (instead of six stockholders who all had a say in the entire company). They decided to drop the projects business line because it was the least profitable. The three stockholders also had to invest additional private money in the company
column42: because they were unable to get additional funding from a bank. During the restart process
column43: a lot of time and energy went in setting up the new structure
column44: deciding the size of the workforce
column45:
coupled with the additional administrative burden regarding the bankruptcy and restart.

\r\n

At the start of the bankruptcy process
column46: a potential buyer came forward
column47: and one of the other stockholders (besides the three that joined together
column48:
as mentioned above) also made an attempt to take over the company. The trustee eventually chose the restart plan of the interviewed stockholder.

Challenges and constraints of restructuring

An important challenge was how
column49: and what
column50: to tell employees about the problems experienced during 2009. What information do you want to tell the employees
column51: and what information do you want to hold back? Because it is a small company
column52:
it was no secret that times were difficult. The interviewed stockholder updated the situation for employees every Monday morning.

\r\n

It was very difficult for the six stockholders to achieve a consensus
column53:
even with the help of a mediator. This process took a lot of time and energy away from trying to save the company in a decisive manner.

\r\n

In the spring of 2009 (before the bankruptcy process) it was possible to obtain additional bank funds and the company was able to postpone payment (including a payment arrangement) to the Dutch Tax Office (Belastingdienst). This helped the company to survive a little longer. But most loans were too large for the company to repay on their own
column54: encouraging the stockholders to refinance the company later in 2009. This meant that they had to put additional (private) funds in the company. Because this failed
column55: the company had to file for bankruptcy. A big challenge for the restart was to acquire additional bank funding. Because there were fewer potential financiers (stockholders)
column56: additional bank funding was preferred. But the bank refused
column57: feeling it too risky to invest in a bankrupt/restarting company. However
column58: the three owners/stockholders felt the company would be able to exploit the growing market
column59: even with the reduced work force
column60: and keep on working without bank credit. By working on a monthly basis
column61: they were able to keep the company running with their own limited financial resources. When the company was able to show increasing turnover figures
column62:
they were able to obtain bank credit.

Restructuring advice and support

During the restructuring process and bankruptcy
column63:
several parties played a role. These were:

  • the UWV Werkbedrijf;
  • a commissioner of the supervisory board (of Company D);
  • the accountant of the company;
  • a private legal office specialised in human resources;
  • a private mediator;
  • a trustee.

The UWV Werkbedrijf (administrative office for the Employee Insurance Agency) is responsible for the part-time unemployment benefit scheme. It took the company more paperwork than expected to get the employees in such a scheme. But the office was very quick in responding to questions the company had about the application and duration of the benefit.

The commissioner of the supervisory board helped the interviewed stockholder by giving him advice and support. The accountant advised on the financial aspects. Both helped the interviewed stockholder to get a better handle on the situation during 2009. Furthermore
column64:
a private legal office specialising in human resources was hired to handle personnel issues during 2009.

\r\n

Stockholder disagreement regarding refinancing led to a mediator being hired at the beginning of 2009
column65: to facilitate discussions. Stockholders hoped that the mediator would help them come to an agreement. However
column66: this was not the case
column67:
and the bankruptcy went ahead at the end of 2009.

\r\n

When a company files for bankruptcy
column68: a trustee is appointed by the court to manage the assets of an individual or a corporate entity. The trustee is responsible for the interest of the creditors of the bankrupt's estate
column69: for liquidating the estate and for making payment arrangements with creditors. In the first weeks of the bankruptcy process
column70: the trustee suggested that the interviewed stockholder might restart the company
column71: and helped him in the bankruptcy and restart process
column72:
by giving practical advice and helping with the necessary paperwork.

\r\n

The interviewed stockholder is generally happy with the help received from the private advisors mentioned above. He sees no need for public advisors
column73:
even though they might charge less than private advisors. He said:

\r\n

\r\nWhen you need help
column74: especially in challenging times
column75:
you\r\nwant a good advisor and that will cost the company some money. \r\n

However
column76: the interviewed stockholder underestimated the administrative burden of a bankruptcy followed by a new start-up and was very satisfied with all of the support he got
column77: with one exception: the duration of the bankruptcy process. This started in November 2009 and ended in January 2012. The interviewed stockholder felt the trustee took longer than was needed
column78:
in his opinion to declare more time (and get more money) for the process.

Outcomes of restructuring

The outcomes of the restructuring event (reorganisation/bankruptcy) were that:

  • the business line ‘projects’ was dropped;
  • the total number of employees decreased from 14 to 8;
  • there are now three stockholders instead of six;
  • Company D was transferred to a holding company (C) covering two separate companies (A and B).

Most employees made redundant found new work quickly. Employees were very cooperative in accepting a settlement. Only one stockholder wanted financial compensation
column79:
which ultimately led to a legal process.

\r\n

Current forecasts (spring 2012) for the company are good. After a turbulent year in 2009
column80: the market is stable at the moment
column81:
and some slight growth is expected.

Commentary

The interviewed stockholder says that
column82: looking back
column83: little attention has been paid to employees. Those still working for the company are glad they are working
column84: but the process was undoubtedly chaotic for them. The problems in the organisation meant that the owners have a lot to deal with
column85: and human resource management is not as high on the priority list as it could be. Creditors are their most pressing problem
column86:
and the threat of bailiffs is a more acute problem than possibly dissatisfied employees. It is also hard to keep looking at the ‘bigger picture’ during difficult times.

\r\n

This problem is also because small company owners perform many different roles
column87:
being responsible for:

  • human resources management;
  • ensuring an adequate workload for the employees;
  • the financial position of the company.

There are no different specialised departments as there are in larger companies.

Another important lesson learnt was that it is very difficult to manage a company with six shareholders
column88:
especially when they disagree during difficult times.

The interviewed stockholder has also learned a lot on a personal level during the process of reorganisation and bankruptcy.

We are used to prosperity and there was always work to do. But when times get tough you notice that you have taken a lot of these things for granted. You also realise that the concept of being an employer is often seen as an abstract thing. Employees look to the owner for their job
column89: they\r\ndepend on you. But as an owner you know that it is your money that is really\r\ninvested in the company
column90:
and it is at risk if the company is unprofitable.\r\nEmployees don’t see it that way.\r\n

Another important thing to mention is that ‘as a part owner of a company you use your own network to find people that can help you’. The interviewed stockholder found the mediator that helped in the talks between the six stockholders this way. He is a member of a soccer club
column91:
and via one of his teammates he found the mediator.

\r\n

The interviewed stockholder is also disappointed by the level of bank commitment to finance entrepreneurs. Banks are looking only for safety and follow internal regulations
column92:
which is understandable but which can stifle entrepreneurship with its associated risk.

column1:
TAD, Latvia~"TAD Ltd."~"

TAD was formed when entrepreneurs unrelated to the business bought out DUNI
column2:
a bankrupt provider of disposable dishes and household items that operated three shops and a wholesale base in Latvia in 2010. Most employees (23 out of 28) were let go and replaced by more qualified staff. The new staff had to work overtime and nights and help to win new business to save the company. Cash flow problems meant salaries were not paid every month and staff were offered shares in the company instead. The company was turned around and in early 2012 had 22 staff.

"~"

Organisational profile

TAD was established in November 2010
column3: after purchasing the company DUNI (established in 1996) following the bankruptcy of DUNI in 2010. TAD’s main focus is on the distribution of disposable dishes and household items. In spring 2012
column4: TAD had three shops and one wholesale base
column5: all located in Riga
column6: the capital of Latvia. TAD is mainly focused on a business-to-business approach
column7: targeting relatively large
column8: mainly local firms. It is an independent SME
column9: owned by a group of people
column10: some of them having other businesses
column11: and managed by the CEO. TAD’s chief aim is to be a major supplier of disposable dishes and household items for these companies
column12: which
column13: according to the company owners
column14: can only be achieved by a creative approach in sales. Good networking and logistics with direct manufacturers that ensures best price
column15:
quality and timely supplies of products is another prerequisite for the success of TAD.

\r\n

Out of 22 employees working for TAD in spring 2012
column16: nine deal with monitoring and quality assurance. According to the company owners
column17: monitoring supplies is crucial for TAD
column18: since most of the products the company sells in Latvia come from abroad
column19: mostly Poland and Estonia. Overstocking
column20: failure to deliver on time
column21: and orders not meeting customer requirements (and changing requirements) are all factors that can harm TAD’s business. In view of this
column22: TAD implements monitoring activities every other month
column23:
thus minimising losses.

The company has no works council or trade union presence.

Background to restructuring event

Following its establishment in 1996
column24: DUNI achieved reasonable profits. The successful internal structure of the company and well-organised control of cash flow played a significant role in this regard. Yet
column25: the situation changed drastically in 2006 with a change of the board members. The strategy of the new board was focused on saving money whenever possible
column26: not excluding salaries. This in turn changed the employee structure of the company: less-experienced employees willing to work for lower salaries were hired. According to the owners of the firm
column27: the major problem with this move was that higher skills were required from relatively low-skilled people. For instance
column28: low-paid staff got involved in projects of highest importance that required fundamental skills and knowledge. As a consequence
column29:
it was not uncommon for decisions that had a direct influence on the company’s performance indicators to be made without proper evaluation.

\r\n

Still
column30: perhaps in part due to the rapidly growing economies of Latvia and other Baltic countries during 2006–2007
column31: the company managed to be profitable while ignoring the basics of doing effective business. This
column32: however
column33: changed with the economic downturn in 2008
column34: and the company started losing money very fast. In 2010 the inevitable happened: DUNI declared its bankruptcy. To summarise
column35: the poor quality of management from the board
column36: poor strategies that led to hiring low-skilled employees
column37: in combination with the economic downturn
column38:
led to bankruptcy.

Restructuring processes

Four months after the initial filing for bankruptcy
column39: DUNI was bought out by a team of entrepreneurs not previously linked with the firm
column40: and renamed TAD. The delay of four months is a legal restriction. After it has filed for bankruptcy
column41: a company can be bought out only after four months
column42: and every legal action in which the company is engaged is transferred to the new company. This implies fulfilling the firm’s obligations to employees
column43: suppliers and customers. In this case
column44: the restructuring process was initiated by the bankruptcy. Success of acquisition
column45: however
column46: usually depends on the quality of decisions
column47:
the competence of the people involved and their speed of action.

\r\n

The restructuring process was semi-formal
column48: that is
column49: based on a short action plan prepared by the new owners that allowed for various ad hoc activities where necessary. As the owners put it
column50: restructuring as a process lasted some six months and had to be quite radical
column51: as almost everything
column52: starting from equipment and ending with employees
column53: had to be changed. This is how the new owners tried to answer the question ‘What now?’
column54: a common question that follows acquisition of bankrupt companies. To be more specific
column55: TAD started restructuring with the factor that is most important almost for any business
column56: namely
column57:
its employees.

\r\n

First
column58: all employees were informed about the forthcoming restructuring process using informal communication methods. Then
column59: the new management team assessed all employees
column60: and as predicted
column61: the quality was far from good. The owners considered various strategies to overcome this challenge. One option was to train existing staff
column62: but this was counter to the main goal of the new owners
column63: which was to start to earn profits as soon as possible without investing considerable amounts of money. The process of training existing employees
column64: even though it could potentially bring positive results
column65: promised to be a long and expensive process. In addition
column66:
the previous experience of the new owners suggested that spending time and money on employees that did not manage to do their work properly for years is often waste of time and money.

\r\n

The company did not have free financial resources and also had time pressure
column67: so the new owners took quite drastic action: most employees (23 out of 28) were let go and replaced by more qualified staff. With this approach
column68: the company faced yet another problem: the temporary cut in its operation while former staff were replaced with new employees. Overall
column69: searching for new employees took two months
column70: and during this process the company suffered some losses. The length of time to replace people
column71: however
column72: can be justified
column73: as the board decided to hire only experts with good references and more than ten years’ experience. TAD did not choose an open competition where anyone could apply. It was a ‘closed door’ process
column74: where only people known by the board were invited to apply
column75:
and jobs were offered to the best.

\r\n

After the replacement of most employees
column76: in mid-2011
column77: three more employees were hired to take over the import and horeca departments. (Horeca refers to a sector of the food industry that services food and beverages; the word is an abbreviation of hotels
column78: restaurants and catering.) This was when ‘real’ restructuring processes
column79: with new people on board
column80: could start. Every employee was involved in the restructuring process by collecting and analysing necessary market information
column81:
presenting suggestions to the board and deciding upon the best strategies to make TAD a more competitive company.

Challenges and constraints of restructuring

It is often said that ‘you don’t need to reinvent the wheel’
column82: and according to owners of TAD
column83: this thinking can be applied upon purchasing a company. Despite having to deal with a lot of paperwork and countless meetings with lawyers and court visits
column84: TAD already had some foundation
column85: the ‘leftovers’ from DUNI. These included a number of suppliers and customers; thus in case of TAD
column86: it was indeed restructuring
column87: rather than a new start-up when these would be acquired newly. What had to be generated anew
column88: however
column89: were attitudes and image. TAD had to convince both previous customers and also suppliers that it ‘meant business’
column90:
and the only way to do that was showing customers that both products and services provided by TAD were of the highest level.

\r\n

The company also had to deal with many legal issues
column91: and the associated paperwork was onerous. To understand the context
column92: it should be mentioned that
column93: for instance
column94: the staff that were laid off were very disappointed and often argued that there had been no reason for them to be let go. In some cases
column95: ex-employees demanded compensation from TAD
column96:
yet TAD managed to avoid paying extra money without good reason. There were also no court cases for any of the disputes.

\r\n

Apart from solving human-resources-related issues
column97: restructuring processes usually also involve answering several questions with regard to financial resources. Luckily
column98: the new owners of TAD had enough money to complete the restructuring. Without doubt
column99: this played a role
column100: as the company was not dependent on any other stakeholders
column101:
as in cases when restructuring is funded by a third party.

Restructuring advice and support

TAD’s owners undertook restructuring without much external advice or support. Only in some circumstances were experts invited
column102: especially during the phase when most of the decision-makers that did not work efficiently had been let go and replacement staff were yet to come. External experts were hired on a short-term contract basis. Experts included accountants that dealt with financial issues
column103: and lawyers that ensured the smooth transition from the bankruptcy of DUNI to the creation of TAD. Attracting experts was not cheap
column104: yet with the right people on board
column105:
such investment paid off.

Outcomes of restructuring

Soon after the internal restructuring
column106: the atmosphere in the company improved substantially
column107: and TAD began to generate its first noticeable profit. Yet
column108: the sacrifices that were made to achieve this were staggering. Out of 28 staff
column109: 23 were laid off in order to keep the system up and running. That makes it approximately 82% of people that were let go. Those that were newly hired had to work overtime
column110: sometimes even at night
column111: to implement the restructuring process
column112:
including winning new clients.

\r\n

The investments that were necessary to replace employees had some influence on the cash flow. As a result of restructuring expenses
column113: TAD’s financial resources were rather limited. In some cases
column114: it meant that employees were working a month or two without a regular salary; they were paid as soon as some income was generated
column115: but it didn’t happen on a regular basis due to adjustments made on the fly. Not all companies would be able to handle that kind of pressure
column116: and most employees would simply march out of the company without looking back
column117: demanding financial compensation. The employees that were hired
column118: however
column119: were well informed about the possibility of such a situation and accepted it for the sake of ‘achieving good times together’. Yet
column120:
they needed some guarantees that salaries would be paid whatever the future looked like. The situation was handled by offering employees company shares.

\r\n

Months later
column121: TAD started to generate its first profit. People were getting salaries on a regular basis and TAD started to flourish. New employees were hired
column122: reaching 19 full-time employees. This was the point when the idea of expanding the market became interesting
column123:
and TAD’s particular interest was in the horeca concept.

\r\n

TAD
column124: as many other companies
column125: faced the challenge of meeting its target client base requirement to find the cheapest possible products
column126: combined with good to exceptional quality. Meeting the needs of these customers
column127: however
column128: proved to be difficult since existing suppliers were setting prices too high
column129: rendering the generation of profit next to impossible. Thus
column130: in many cases
column131: new suppliers had to be sought
column132: and were found in Poland. As a consequence
column133: TAD managed to decrease cost per employee by almost 40%
column134:
increasing the competitiveness of the company. Contracts with previous suppliers were cancelled.

\r\n

The horeca department soon expanded from non-existence to being one of the biggest departments in the company
column135: and one that brings a major income share. Furthermore
column136: tackling the concept of horeca (that is
column137: introducing the new service of food and beverages) decreased expenses by almost 30%
column138: implying that goods could be offered at lower prices without greatly affecting the profit. Since the factory in Poland produces only for TAD
column139: the relationship is a monopsony
column140:
where a company produces only for one company in great amounts but for a lower price.

\r\n

Having a wholesale base
column141: international suppliers and a new target market meant that more effort should be allocated to marketing the company. The obvious thing to do was to set up a website. That
column142: apart from serving a marketing function
column143: also helped to monitor stock levels. Yet
column144: it was not enough to attract any significant customers. It was simply not paying off in the beginning. An interesting method was applied to increase the levels of supply and to achieve more contracts. TAD representatives started calling companies that would be able to spend much more than smaller firms
column145: trying to create partnerships. This method of marketing worked surprisingly well
column146:
generating a good share of income.

\r\n

The next big step was to engage in active competition with market leaders such as leading retail chains in Latvia
column147: RIMI and Maxima. Such companies have their suppliers and factories and usually avoid signing deals with small companies like TAD
column148: and this
column149: in fact
column150: happened. As a consequence
column151: TAD faced the risk that both giants would easily out-price it in the market. TAD decided to diversify location-wise
column152:
by opening three shops in Riga.

\r\n

Because RIMI has focused on disposable dishes much more than Maxima
column153: RIMI is TAD’s main competitor. It didn’t seem worthwhile to RIMI
column154: so it ignored the competition from TAD. Soon after
column155:
there was a noticeable drop in demand levels of disposable dishes from RIMI and the company started to lose it profits. Then a ‘competition dance’ began.

\r\n

In microeconomic terms
column156: such situation is called a Stackelberg competition
column157: where the market leaders set their price and the smaller company (defined as a follower) adjusts its price accordingly. The fact that TAD could offer goods in bulk gave the company the edge
column158: and RIMI kept losing money. Thus
column159: the only reasonable way out for RIMI was to sign a partnership deal with TAD. TAD
column160: however
column161: was not interested in such a deal
column162: as the company managed to grow outside these retail chains
column163: and the offer was declined. This
column164: in turn resulted in something that was even hard to imagine at the beginning: RIMI simply had to react to a newcomer into market
column165: TAD
column166:
by adjusting its product range in given categories according to the decreased demand.

Commentary

As common sense suggests
column167: dealing with restructuring in small companies is much easier than in large corporations. It takes less financial investment and also less time to implement changes. There are also fewer employees to deal with
column168:
and it is easier to keep everything organised in the way owner or managers want to see it.

\r\n

According to the experience of TAD
column169:
timing is the most important factor to determine the success of the restructuring. Taking immediate actions to maintain a positive economic profit is not an easy process. Assembling a strong team in a short period of time was difficult for TAD. It was even more challenging to ensure that the newly hired team started working efficiently from the very beginning. There was simply no time for a slow start: results had to be achieved immediately.

Background to restructuring event

The restructuring event described in this case study is an internal restructuring in management
column58: with the purpose of establishing a management team and making the staff  in a group of companies see and understand themselves as one company
column59: with common goals and values. However
column60: the background to this internal restructuring in management has been a series of acquisitions that have created the need for a new management structure and a common identity. Therefore
column61:
the challenges of acquiring and integrating new companies are also mentioned during the case study.

\r\n

Restructuring in the form of acquisitions has been an ongoing process in the company for more than a decade and a key to growth for The Whole Company. Since it is important to be the largest or second largest supplier to retailers in a product category
column62: it has been a deliberate strategy to acquire new products or companies
column63: but the individual acquisition has been more about current opportunities. However
column64:
around 2008 a series of internal and external events led to a major internal restructuring.

\r\n

Everything was moving very fast and the company was continually growing. Relocating the company in 2007 to new facilities in the same town (Køge) and moving the subsidiary Fredsted from Glostrup to the new headquarters in Køge took a lot of Henrik Winther-Olsen’s management resources. Trope was acquired in 2008 and then suddenly the financial crisis came. This was a shock that made Henrik Winther-Olsen stop and take a critical ‘helicopter view’ on his company. Do we still live by the values we had when we started? Are we still one company or are we separate units? Are we still working efficiently? Does the management system fit a company with more than 50 employees or are we still running it as a start-up? And do we actually know where we are heading?

\r\n

In 2009 these reflections led to a strategy development process involving all employees
column65: the building of a management team and rebranding the group of companies under a common name – The Whole Company – from 2011. Until then
column66:
each company had been branded as separate entities.

\r\n

Henrik Winther-Olsen remembers that during the high-growth period before 2008 the company had hired almost anybody who applied for a job – perhaps too many were hired. The financial crisis made the company stop and take a critical view on the organisation. Subsequently
column67: eight people were laid off
column68:
and the organisation decreased to around 50 employees.

\r\n

One of the reasons why employment had run somewhat out of control could have been the relocation of the company in 2007 and also the move of subsidiary Fredsted The to the new facilities. This took up a lot of Henrik Winther-Olsen’s attention in that period.

\r\n

At that time
column69: there was no real management team and no real common identity for the conglomerate
column70:
so Henrik Winther-Olsen decided to start a strategy process in 2009 in order to build a new management structure that would be able to grow the company further.

\r\n

Like in many owner-managed companies
column71: there is also a personal twist to the story. Henrik Winther-Olsen is driven by continuous learning and forcing himself out of his comfort zone. After successfully building and developing a number of small companies
column72:
it was time to try his management skills on building a larger company by bringing the existing small companies under one umbrella. Therefore he set himself the aim of doubling the size of The Whole Company conglomerate within five years and developing a strategy and management team that could take the company to a new level.

\r\n

Alongside the strategy process
column73: the company continued its acquisition strategy and acquired the brands or companies Trope
column74: Urteteket
column75: Womega and Jemo-pharm. Trope was actually a brand that the company had originally built and later sold to snack-market leader Kim’s in 2004
column76:
when Henrik Winther-Olsen planned his early retirement. So in a way it was the original company that was bought back in 2008. Urteteket was a relatively small purchase of a brand that is now integrated in the headquarter operations. Jemo-pharm was a larger acquisition that still operates from a separate location.

The acquisitions were not directly caused by external events

although the increasing size and purchasing power of customers has meant that it is important for The Whole Company to grow.

Restructuring processes

The process of developing a strategy and building a management team started in 2009 and lasted until the summer of 2011.

A part of this process was defining a common brand name for the conglomerate of brands and a common identity for the company. Until then
column78: only the brand names from each subsidiary were known to the public
column79:
and the common owner was just an anonymous holding company called HWO Holding A/S. The name was changed to The Whole Company in 2011.

\r\n

Decisions about acquisitions had been made by Henrik Winther-Olsen alone
column80: but for the strategy process he decided that he wanted a high level of involvement from the organisation. An external strategy coach was engaged to manage the process
column81: and a management team was established internally from existing managers to be highly involved in the strategy process. During the process
column82:
all employees were also involved in defining the company values – and everybody got a personality profile (personality test).

\r\n

According to Henrik Winther-Olsen
column83: the company had become too big and complex
column84: so it was necessary to write down who was doing what and what had the highest priority. It took a couple of years to implement the strategy plan
column85:
and the strategy coach helped with building the management team until the summer of 2011.

\r\n

Operating staff were involved in defining the values early in the strategy process through a company workshop
column86: and they also now meet twice a year for social and team-building events. At these events
column87: staff received information about the key financial figures of the company
column88: like sales
column89:
orders and costs and earnings. They get current information through a monthly newsletter.

\r\n

To keep in touch with each of the three physical locations in Denmark
column90:
Henrik Winther-Olsen pays quarterly visits to each location.

\r\n

The employee interviewee saw the information meetings as very valuable and informative
column91: and points out that Henrik Winther-Olsen encourages the staff to ask questions when the key figures for the company are presented and explained. He admitted
column92: though
column93: that it could be difficult for some staff members to completely understand what the numbers mean. But
column94: according to the employee
column95: the meeting creates a sense of unity in the company
column96:
where people understand that a problem in another department is also their problem.

\r\n

An important part of the new growth strategy and a new management challenge for Henrik Winther-Olsen is international expansion. The Whole Company established Castus UK as a sales subsidiary in 2010
column97: selling dried fruit snacks in the United Kingdom. This is still a minor activity
column98:
but an important part of the long-term strategy.

Challenges and constraints of restructuring

Running a comprehensive strategy process while still integrating and managing new acquisitions has obviously given The Whole Company a few challenges.

For the factory manager
column99: especially
column100: the integration of acquisitions has been a big challenge
column101: since he has had to travel frequently to different locations. It has been important for Henrik Winther-Olsen to build the company as a unified company and not as separate units with separate management. After the acquisition of Jemo-pharm
column102: it actually considered running Jemo-pharm as a separate unit
column103:
but soon learned that management and administration would be too heavy that way. Now the only local management is a production manager.

\r\n

In the process of integrating and harmonising management practices
column104:
the management has learned also that not everything can be done in the same way across different locations. The company has to accept and adapt to regional differences.

\r\n

For Henrik Winther-Olsen
column105:
it has been important to maintain a flat structure in management to keep in touch with staff and to communicate that there is no difference in status between production and administration and that each should respect the other.

\r\n

In the process of building a management team and organising the company
column106:
the major challenges have been the shift in mindset of the team.

\r\n

One of the challenges in the transformation from entrepreneurial company to an established organisation has been to integrate strategic thinking in the organisation. As a small company with the execution virtues of entrepreneurship
column107: it is challenging to integrate graduates in the company. But Henrik Winther-Olsen acknowledges that long-term thinking and strategic planning is important for the company now
column108:
and he wants to employ more graduates in the company.

\r\n

Henrik Winther-Olsen defined the overall goal as doubling sales within five years. The management team found this somewhat ambitious
column109:
but it forced them to focus on projects that had the highest impact on the overall goal.

\r\n

One learning outcome from the implementation of the strategy has been that too many strategic projects should not be prioritised. The original strategic plan had about 20 strategic projects. That was too many
column110:
so now only the big common projects like IT systems and new concepts are on the agenda for the management team.

\r\n

The ambitious goals have been a challenge in the Castus UK unit and that is a little behind schedule. According to Henrik Winther-Olsen
column111: this is mainly due to the fact that recruiting a manager for international operations has taken longer than expected. Furthermore
column112: entering the British retail market is an either-or situation
column113:
where the right customer can mean instant growth.

Restructuring advice and support

All acquisitions in The Whole Company have been funded by bank loans without further problems.

The Whole Company has not taken advantage of public advice and support schemes in the process
column114:
apart from some advice from the Trade Council under the Ministry of Foreign Affairs in relation to exporting to and establishing a subsidiary in the UK market. The Trade Council offers free initial counselling and subsidised market research on new markets.

\r\n

However
column115: Henrik Wither-Olsen actively uses advisors to the board and advisory board
column116:
and he is an active networker.

\r\n

One of the public schemes that he is currently considering is the Videnpilot scheme
column117:
where the company can get a subsidised graduate to work on research and other projects in the company. He also mentions that he would really like it if it was possible to receive subsidies for an energy-saving project.

Outcomes of restructuring

The main outcome of the internal restructuring process has been a stronger management structure for a larger and growing organisation. It has changed from entrepreneur management to team management. Furthermore
column118: The Whole Company has become a more unified company
column119: with common values and with a higher level of communication with employees. Finally
column120:
it has become a leaner organisation after the years of abundance leading up to 2008.

\r\n

According to Henrik Winther-Olsen
column121: the company has traditionally been better at focusing on daily operations than long-term goals. However
column122:
the strategy process and setting ambitious goals has forced it to think more in terms of long-term growth and to focus on projects with higher impact. It has learned to say no to small projects and customers.

\r\n

Before the strategy process
column123: there were no formal management meetings and no real management team. It was more like separate departments that were at times in conflict with each other. Today
column124: the management team representing the different functions of sales
column125: marketing
column126: purchasing
column127: financials and production has strategy meetings four times a year and a strategy plan running until 2014. However
column128:
the more specific planning is generally only for a year; changing conditions makes it hard to plan much further. The strategy process has meant that different functions and levels in the company respect each other more. They are working towards the same goals and help each other more.

\r\n

The personality profiles have been very valuable to people in understanding each other’s behaviour. ‘Some think it is fantastic when we grow
column129: while others are less enthusiastic. But I have learned that the people who are less enthusiastic are also contributing’
column130: Henrik Winther-Olsen says. And getting to know each other better also means that they are better at dealing with conflicts directly and openly. Understanding each other’s personality profiles was also valuable at the operational level
column131:
where the employee interviewee reported that it was an active part of his daily communication with colleagues.

\r\n

Henrik Winther-Olsen sees the restructuring process as a restart of the company and a mental shift from being a small entrepreneurial business to an established company. The company had grown so fast that it was hard to see the original company values in all the new employees. ‘We had become to self-complacent’
column132:
he says and points out that his motto is that ‘you always come out stronger after a crisis’.

\r\n

The strategy process has also led to a trimming of the organisation
column133: and Henrik Winther-Olsen perceives The Whole Company as a very lean organisation today. After the lay-off of eight people in 2008
column134: the trimming has been gradual. The exception was Jemo-pharm
column135: where staff were reduced from 28 to 22 after the acquisition
column136: which was mentally tough on the organisation. Furthermore
column137:
the weekly work hours were harmonised upwards since Jemo-pharm had a shorter working week than the rest of the organisation.

\r\n

From an employee point of view
column138: there was a calm reaction to the lay-offs in 2008. There was already a feeling that there was too little to do. Before the staff selected to be laid off were named
column139: they received a lot of information about what would happen and why
column140:
and it was underlined that people were not laid off because they weren’t performing. Some of those who left have subsequently been recruited back to the company.

\r\n

From a personal perspective
column141: another outcome of the restructuring was a learning opportunity for Henrik Winther-Olsen. His ambition is to learn how to run a bigger company and not just a small niche company. This also meant involving the management team in decisions
column142: so while acquisitions were earlier made by Henrik Winther-Olsen alone
column143:
the big 2010 acquisition of Jemo-pharm was planned by the management team.

\r\n

The acquisitions have had varying impacts on the company performance. Some have contributed strongly to profitability
column144: whereas others had to be trimmed to be profitable. One learning outcome has been that buying small brands selling around DKK 5 million (€650
column145: 000) or less per year is not worth the effort. Because of the work involved in the process
column146:
new acquisitions should have an annual turnover of at least DKK 20–25 million.

\r\n

For production employees
column147: the acquisitions involve work intensification or longer working hours. The extra workload depends on whether the acquisition must be integrated into current production or is run as a separate company. On one occasion
column148: the integration of a new acquisition happened very fast and with little information in advance. This is probably why employees pointed out that ‘We like it when something new happens. This makes it interesting to work here
column149:
but also tough. But information is gold!’

\r\n

It also makes things more complicated – or ‘advanced’ as the employee interviewee said – to manage products from separate companies in one order
column150:
but for the employee it was a better feeling that he was now handling larger orders.

Commentary

In his reflections on differences between SMEs and big corporations
column151: Henrik Winther-Olsen points out that a large corporation has more financial resources and more skilled and experienced employees who may have undergone the process before. On the other hand
column152: an SME is faster and more dynamic
column153: but the challenge is that employees are also occupied by daily operations in the restructuring process. ‘We can’t just take out five people for a month’
column154:
according to Mr Winther-Olsen.

\r\n

When asked about what he would do differently
column155: the only thing he mentions is that he would not buy companies or brands that are too small
column156:
as mentioned above.

\r\n

The employee interviewed had worked in a large retail chain before and found that it was very valuable in an SME to have direct access to the owner or top management. ‘We in the store are experienced people from the retail industry
column157: and we know a problem when we see it
column158: so we just go to the management and tell them.’ His experience is that in large corporations some ideas are never uttered because the path to the decision-makers is too long. In addition
column159: if each business unit perceives itself as a separate entity
column160:
it starts to function sub-optimally and avoids sticking out – top or bottom – because it attracts attention from top management.

\r\n

Henrik Winther-Olsen’s opinion on public support schemes is that they are often too general. He would like to see more targeted programmes for companies with growth potential and recommends that companies focus their resources on a few large projects for committed companies. Furthermore
column161:
he mentions the strict and inflexible administration of food security regulations as a major administrative constraint for the company.

\r\n

In his advice to other SMEs who want to do the same
column162: Mr Winther-Olsen recommends using advisors and sparring partners in the process and getting strong competences in-house. And
column163: finally
column164:
he highlights the importance of always knowing whether you are making money at the present time.

column1:
Trosa Tryckeri, Sweden~"Trosa Tryckeri"~"

The Swedish printing business Trosa Tryckeri was established in 1919 and bought by the family of the current CEO in 1982. An unsuccessful acquisition in 2008 exposed it to likely bankruptcy and it was forced to apply for corporate reconstruction. One-third of the staff (20 people) were given notice and the remaining staff worked with management and the reconstruction administrator to save the company. In the end
column2:
only eight people had to leave the company and it has been successfully restructured.

"~"

Organisational profile

\r\n

Founded in 1919
column3: Trosa Tryckeri is a printing business involved in graphic production. The business produces four main products: traditional printed matter
column4: wall calendars
column5: store advertising and packages. When the Lundberg family bought Trosa Tryckeri in 1982
column6: the company had 15 employees. The company has grown and merged with other companies and at its peak had 69 employees. Today
column7:
the company has about 50 employees and 15 seasonal employees during the high production period in the autumn.

\r\n

The company is divided into three different departments – sales
column8: administration and bookbinding
column9:
all located in the town of Trosa.

\r\n

Within the administration
column10: most employees are recruited from other companies within the same industry. In the production unit at Trosa Tryckeri
column11: the majority are trained as apprentices
column12: and thereafter they develop within the company and take up other positions
column13: such as project leader. The workforce is a balanced mix of men and women
column14: with slightly more men
column15:
and the average age is 40 years old.

\r\n

The business isn’t directly international since the customers in general are Swedish and local. However
column16: some customers are active globally and have English as their corporate language. Trosa Tryckeri prints in multiple languages and distributes worldwide. It also works with brokers in England working for Swedish clients. Trosa Tryckeri sometimes distributes products directly to Asia; however
column17:
most clients are situated in the Stockholm region.

\r\n

The company has an operations handbook that includes management process protocol and job descriptions
column18: and this is developed continuously since the company works actively on quality and environmental issues. There is no human resource manager in the company; however
column19:
there are managers in charge of the different units and a manager of quality and environmental issues. The company has several certifications which it follows in its production in order to improve operations.

\r\n

Trosa Tryckeri is a member of the Confederation of Swedish Enterprise
column20: an employer organisation. Connection to trade unions is low. Most of the trade union members are white-collar workers
column21:
while less than 50% of blue-collar workers are enrolled in a union.

\r\n

For the last few years
column22: the company has experienced falling profits and sales. In 2008
column23: it decided to acquire a company from a bankrupt competitor. It recruited employees from this company
column24: but results did not turn out as expected. In 2009
column25: all of the recruited people left the company and profits were insufficient to cover costs. As a result of this
column26: Trosa Tryckeri applied for a company reconstruction under Swedish law in August 2010
column27:
which ended in May 2011. Now the business is stable and recruiting employees to its sales department again.

\r\n

Marie Lundberg
column28: together with her husband and son
column29: owns the company. Her family bought the company from the former owners in 1982
column30: and since then she has worked at Trosa Tryckeri in sales and marketing
column31: and currently she is the CEO. Her educational background is elementary school
column32: and before she acquired Trosa Tryckeri
column33: she worked night shift at the police department. While working at her former job
column34: she started a part-time printing paper broker business. That was how she got involved in the printing business
column35:
which led to the decision to buy Trosa Tryckeri.

\r\n

Background to restructuring event

\r\n

In 2008
column36: the company experienced an increase in its business and made investments in a bankrupt company
column37: recruiting the employees of that company. This was
column38: looking back
column39: a bad decision since the company’s profit and sales went down. The unsuccessful acquisition and recruitment led to a crisis where the company
column40: after getting advice from a lawyer
column41: realised that if it did not apply for a corporate reconstruction
column42: it would probably go bankrupt within two to three years. When the management realised this
column43: it took less than a month to decide to apply for and start a reconstruction process. Other options considered before they decided to go through corporate reconstruction were to find a partner
column44: sell parts of the company or find a financier. However
column45:
they realised that it was too late to choose anything else but corporate reconstruction.

\r\n

Restructuring processes

\r\n

The management team
column46: the board and the owners were involved in the decision. Together with the reconstruction administrator
column47: a legal official appointed by the court
column48: they investigated where the company was bleeding money and where it was making a profit. They realised that parts of the production could be outsourced
column49: and therefore they announced they would give notice to 20 people
column50:
one-third of the work force. Marie Lundberg invited the local newspaper as soon as they had filed for reconstruction. There was no speculation in the press before the announcement was official.

\r\n

A corporate reconstruction is formally planned and implemented and has to follow specific rules under Swedish law. Any business that has severe difficulties paying its debts has the opportunity to establish a specific procedure to reconstruct its business. Companies applying for reconstruction have to complete it within one year
column51:
and the process consists of four three-month phases.

\r\n

For Trosa Tryckeri
column52: the reconstruction was completed after three phases
column53: lasting nine months from August 2010 to May 2011. The reconstruction administrator was made responsible for ensuring that the subcontractors to Trosa Tryckeri got paid
column54: and he guaranteed they would get their payment. During the process
column55: the reconstruction administrator took over Trosa Tryckeri’s account
column56: and the company had to have permission from the reconstruction administrator before buying anything worth more than SEK 10
column58:
130). This guarantee made the subcontractors stay with Trosa Tryckeri even though the company had informed them it was in trouble early on.

\r\n

The first months were very intense
column59: and the management adjusted the plan as they went along. For instance
column60: one initial idea was to outsource many of the company production units; however
column61:
they realised this would be less profitable than to keep the production within the company.

\r\n

Trosa Tryckeri has a meeting with the entire workforce every month to inform the workers of ongoing developments and the condition of the company. When management realised what path the company was taking
column62: they gathered the workers to inform them. The reaction was a mix of anxiety that positions were going to be cut and a constructive ‘we can solve this’ attitude. Some workers had never worked anywhere besides Trosa Tryckeri
column63:
and these employees became especially concerned since they had never applied for another job and did not want to leave.

\r\n

The workers were not involved in the decision to undertake corporate reconstruction but did participate in every three-month phase of the implementation. Together the workers
column64: the managers and the administrator tried to find solutions in order to prevent the company from going bankrupt. The trade union was only present when the notice was given to staff but did not object to the decision
column65:
since it understood the lay-offs were a necessary part of the reconstruction and not personal.

\r\n

Challenges and constraints of restructuring

\r\n

The main challenge for Trosa Tryckeri was that when it informed its bank that it would apply for corporate reconstruction
column66: the bank froze the company account and left it without credit. It had no economic support from public bodies
column67: so the reconstruction was financed entirely by the company. As a consequence
column68: it had to be extra careful and bill clients right away in order to ensure income was stable during the period. One thing Marie Lundberg would have done differently given her recent experience is she would not have told the bank early about the company restructuring. They had two choices: tell the bank afterwards or go to the bank before the restructuring was official. They decided to go to the bank before they applied for reconstruction. The bank froze all their accounts and suspended their credit. In hindsight
column69:
she would have gone to the bank afterwards as it can be assumed that the bank would have been more cooperative when approached by the administrator rather than by the company. Today the company has a different bank.

\r\n

Another challenge concerned how the company would convince clients to stay with it during the restructuring. Marie Lundberg had a dialogue every three months with the main clients to inform them of how the restructuring was going and to give an update. Only one client terminated its contract
column70:
and Trosa Tryckeri lost one job to a completely new client who believed the company was too unstable and therefore withdrew the order. Other clients kept their confidence in Trosa Tryckeri and stayed.

\r\n

The company also put a lot of effort into assuring clients that it was committed and trustworthy
column71: in order to persuade subcontractors to continue delivering the necessary equipment so that production could be maintained. The reconstruction administrator took much responsibility in this work and convinced them to stay
column72:
assuring them that the debts to suppliers and subcontractors would be paid

\r\n

According to Marie Lundberg
column73: for SMEs it is harder to take decisions
column74: and as a result
column75: they wait too long before starting the restructuring process. Large companies act faster and have a better overview of fluctuations in the economy. Large companies also have a better view of European conditions and of sectors where they are active. Furthermore
column76: larger companies have more opportunities to educate their workforce when production goes down. They can go down to four-day working weeks and still always have someone present at the enterprise. Conversely
column77: SMEs may not be as aware of possible restructuring strategies and lack a clear overview of the situation. An SME with a smaller workforce can’t reduce one unit in the same way. Mrs. Lundberg concludes that SMEs might have a disadvantage when it comes to one unit making demands on another. In a larger enterprise
column78: the sales unit might place specific requirements on another unit and the production unit might in the same way place demands on the HR manager in order to make production more efficient. In an SME
column79:
it is harder to place specific demands on another unit within the company since personal in different departments are close and find it difficult to make straight demands on one another since they are friends working together.

\r\n

However
column80: according to Marie Lundberg
column81: SMEs might be more flexible and have better customer contact
column82: which makes customers more reliable. Large companies probably have less personal contact with their clients
column83:
making them more vulnerable in times of restructuring.

\r\n

Restructuring advice and support

\r\n

Marie Lundberg concludes that the company has received the support that it needed and that the advice and guidance from the reconstruction administrator was particularly helpful. He had experience from similar situations
column84:
and together they worked out a solution. Also the lawyers advising the company to apply for corporate reconstruction did this at the right stage.

\r\n

It was difficult at times when every cost over SEK 10
column86: 130) had to be approved by the administrator
column87: since the company has a turnover of over SEK 80 million (€904
column88: 500). However
column89:
the administrator tried to improve the administration as much as he could.

\r\n

There are no specific recommendations regarding public support. Trosa Tryckeri had great help from the reconstruction administrator. The company received the governmental salary guarantee
column90:
meaning the state paid the salaries during the period and the company are repaying this loan today. The government is obliged to pay the workers if the company is unable to do so due to bankruptcy or corporate reconstruction.

\r\n

Outcomes of restructuring

\r\n

Initially
column91: 20 people were given notice that their employment was to be terminated. This number was adjusted to 16 and in the end 12 were given notice. Of these 12
column92: 4 were given notice that they could stay but only on a part-time basis. Today
column93: these four employees are back full-time again. So
column94: in total
column95: eight people had to leave the company. Some still return as seasonal workers during the autumn production. The company adjusted the numbers given notice because it realised it could keep some more employees than anticipated by its initial forecast
column96:
as production increased.

\r\n

The employees made redundant had to leave right away and received compensation of six to twelve months’ salary. The company tried actively to find new positions in other companies for the workers made redundant. Some have been offered to work temporarily on piecework assignments
column97:
and others were encouraged to start a training course.

\r\n

The sales department was the unit most affected during the process since this was the least efficient area. It outsourced some work in order to cut costs and this caused positions to be made redundant. Since some positions were cut
column98: some tasks were delegated to other workers; however
column99:
this has been positively received by the remaining workforce.

\r\n

The reconstruction turned out better than expected. Production has improved and become more efficient. The company has learned a great deal by this experience on every level. It also managed to withdraw some of the proposed lay-offs since production increased.

\r\n

Marie Lundberg has not experienced any personal effects of the restructuring. The value of the company might have gone down
column100: but she has learned a lot during the process. The company has become more careful with expenses and has begun to outsource some production. Regarding salaries
column101: Trosa Tryckeri has not been able to raise salaries in the last year; however
column102:
everyone gets paid according to their contracts.

\r\n

The company works on a long-term business plan and has just initiated the development of one-year
column103: three-year and five-year strategies for the business. It reviews its business ideas and has asked different work teams to give input to this development in order to make everyone aware of the vision of the company. So far
column104:
many good ideas have been developed within these groups consisting of employees from different production units.

\r\n

Commentary

\r\n

Trosa Tryckeri experienced a very formal reconstruction
column105: which explains the focus on the business rather than on employees in this case study. If the company hadn’t applied for a corporate reconstruction
column106: it would probably have gone bankrupt. This case study also offers an example of how important it is
column107: in times of restructuring
column108: to find a way to stay trustworthy and keep clients. The fact that the loss of a big client can mean the end of the business is a clear vulnerability for SMEs compared to larger companies. Therefore
column109: in this type of situation
column110:
support from an experienced reconstruction administrator can really save the company by guaranteeing the payments to subcontractors and by giving strategic guidance on how to enable a business in a downward spiral survive.

\r\n

Marie Lundberg has learnt that a person cannot run a company with their heart. The CEO has to look at the needs of the company and figure out if all the positions are necessary. They have to look at the circumstances of the company and act. There is no reason to maintain a stance that the company delivers everything on its own and never outsources
column111:
if this is less profitable than to outsource.

\r\n

Marie Lundberg recommends other companies in the same position to inform the workforce early and keep them in the loop in order to prevent anxiety among the workers. Also
column112:
it is important to be one step ahead of the newspapers so that it doesn’t come as a surprise for the workers that reconstruction is on the way.

\r\n

If an enterprise is experiencing difficulties
column113: it is
column114: in Marie Lundberg’s opinion
column115: important to look into what possibilities are available. The reconstruction administrator concluded that Trosa Tryckeri was one of few companies taking action on time. Most companies wait too long to start a reconstruction process. When they finally start
column116: it is too late
column117: and they realise after three months that they will not succeed. Even though it might be awkward to admit that there are problems within the company
column118: it is important to take action early and try to solve them
column119:
using guidance from experienced administrators and lawyers.

\r\n

Authors

\r\n

Jan Persson and Ingrid Broman
