column1:
TWO Services, United Kingdom~"TWO Services Limited"~"

In 2008–2009 TWO Services (a family-run cleaning
column2: repair and maintenance business in the UK) reacted to slowing demand and growing competition with actions to cut costs and generate revenue. These included reducing prices
column3: cutting costs  (advertising and fuel for transport)
column4:
maintaining staff levels and seeking to grow business. The main restructuring events of recent years were opening a new office in 2009 and a new telesales department in 2010 as part of a strategic adjustment to build the business even in a challenging market.

"~"

Organisational profile

Established in 1986 in Basildon
column5: Essex
column6: TWO Services is a family-run cleaning
column7: repair and maintenance business that operates across the UK. The business is registered – TWO Services Ltd – and divided into three operations. In the current form
column8:
it offers the following services:

  1. TWO Catering Equipment Supply & Maintenance: this includes maintenance of catering and refrigeration equipment
column9: gas and electrical\r\nmaintenance
column10: breakdown repair of kitchen equipment
column11:
and an emergency response\r\nservice; \r\n
  • TWO Kitchen Hygiene Services: deep-cleaning of kitchens
column12: \r\nincluding ventilation systems
column13: all equipment
column14: walls
column15:
ceilings and floors;
  • TWO Daily Cleaning: cleaning of commercial premises and offices
column16: including the cleaning of windows and carpets
column17:
and dusting.

The first two services are in most demand
column18: each representing around 45 % of the business. The company started as a kitchen cleaning business but gradually introduced supply
column19: maintenance and repair of equipment in the mid-1990s
column20: initially as a separate company. This was
column21: however
column22: creating too much administrative work
column23: and so the directors decided to incorporate the second company into the existing TWO Services Ltd. Since 2008
column24: the demand for maintenance of equipment has increased as a result of recession. In the difficult financial times
column25:
many clients have opted to have their kitchen equipment repaired and cleaned rather than purchasing new equipment.

\r\n

Alan Osborn is one of the five directors of TWO Services and chairman of the company. Mr Osborn used to be a chef in the 1960s in hotels and later moved into industrial catering. He was made redundant in 1985 and then opened his own business
column26: a catering consultancy
column27: in 1986. Soon after
column28: the business focus changed from catering to cleaning services
column29:
following the owner’s experience of taking on a cleaning job which proved more profitable.

\r\n

Over the years
column30: the business has expanded from south-east England to the rest of the country
column31: with offices in Basildon
column32: London and Leeds. TWO Services works with most of the leading catering contractors in the business and industry market. The catering contractors that provide catering to big blue-chip companies would usually nominate TWO Services to be their supplier of kitchen cleaning and maintenance and for equipment supply and installation for their catering contracts or tenders. If the contractors are successful in winning the tender
column33: then  TWO Services also gets the job. The company works for individual restaurants but also directly for major facilities management companies
column34: along with large businesses within the UK. It also works for the public sector
column35: hospitals
column36:
care homes and charity organisations.

\r\n

Mr Osborn is nearing retirement and has passed responsibilities to his sons
column37: who are both directors. The business has grown massively over the past 25 years
column38: from employing 2 people in 1986 to 120 in 2012. The company prides itself for building relationships with clients
column39: offering good quality service
column40: and investing in its staff. As a family business
column41:
the motto of TWO Services is ‘It takes two’.

\r\n

TWO Services has a written corporate social responsibility policy and a human resource (HR) policy. Its first HR policy was developed in the 1990s. Over the years
column42: as the business expanded
column43:
it sought the services of an outside consultant to help it develop a new policy and quality operating standards. The company holds management meetings on a monthly basis to discuss company performance and any issues.

\r\n

TWO Services is accredited under the government’s Contractors Health and Safety scheme (CHAS) and the safecontractor Health and Safety Assessment scheme. Moreover
column44: the company holds various quality ISO certifications
column45: including quality management systems (ISO 9001:2008)
column46: environmental management systems (ISO 14001)
column47:
and occupational health and safety management systems (OHSAS 18001).

Background to restructuring event

In 2008–2009
column48: TWO Services took a number of actions
column49: both cost-cutting and revenue-generating measures
column50: in response to slowing demand and growing competition. Its main competitors targeted the company’s clients by offering to charge 10% less than TWO Services for the same work. In order to maintain the existing level of profits
column51:
the company took steps to increase turnover and cut costs.

\r\n

To enable it to maintain a high-quality service
column52: TWO Services decided to readjust costs rather than cut down on staff. It reduced prices by 20 % in order to retain the existing customer base. At the same time
column53: it continued to provide a quality service for a value price rather than trying to be cheap. It reduced its prices but only up to a point where it was not making loss. Other measures TWO Services have taken to cut costs include putting speed limiters on vans so they can only drive at a maximum of 70 miles an hour
column54: and trackers
column55: which make them more fuel efficient. It has also put duel-fuel vehicles on road and purchased a number of Toyota Prius vehicles. These hybrid vehicles can be propelled by both gasoline and electric power
column56:
which makes them one of the most fuel-efficient cars.

\r\n

Mr Osborn notes that there are more people entering the kitchen-cleaning market. As a result of much stricter food safety regulations
column57: there is a greater demand for kitchen-cleaning services and therefore more opportunities in the industry. While competitors may have taken advantage of the recession by offering cheaper services and thus attracting clients who look for savings in difficult times
column58: they are not a serious threat to the company in the longer term. The directors believe that many are short on the quality of services
column59:
qualifications and public liability insurance that TWO Services offers.

\r\n

Despite the slowing demand
column60: TWO Services was able to increase sales gradually. Its income has been  increasing steadily. Rather than retrench during the recession
column61:
the company decided to expand its business. The main restructuring events undertaken in recent years have been the opening up of a new office in 2009 and a new telesales department in 2010 associated with strategic adjustment.

Restructuring processes

The owners had been planning to expand the business for some time and considered opening a telesales department as part of their plans for 2009–2011. The telesales department was intended to cover all services. The motivation was to increase the client base and subsequently turnover as a way of keeping its profit margins at a level consistent with previous years.

The company sales department had always been ‘reactive’: when a request was made for quotation
column62: someone was sent to quote. It was decided to change this approach so that sales staff would make a proactive contact with companies and increase the client base. A telesales person was employed in 2008
column63: but this did not work out for both parties
column64:
and it proved to be difficult to get the right people.

\r\n

The company advertised the telesales positions a number of times over 2008 but no suitable candidates came forward for the roles. In early 2010
column65: a company near the head office in Essex
column66: which used to sell office machines
column67: photocopiers and fax machines
column68: was acquired by a large multinational firm
column69: and the staff were made redundant. This company had a telesales department
column70: so TWO Services took this opportunity to recruit
column71: offering the vacant sales positions to two experienced sales staff from the acquired company
column72:
who both had a good track record. The employees took redundancy payment from their previous employer and almost immediately started working for TWO Services.

\r\n

The telesales department
column73: with two new employees
column74: started working at the beginning of 2010. Initially
column75: the sales staff had to learn to understand the business and its requirements and needs in relation to kitchen cleaning and maintenance. They were given specific training for this. To familiarise themselves with the business operations and the services offered
column76: they were taken out by the company’s sales manager to visit various operations. The employees also underwent an internet-based training programme
column77: covering health and safety
column78: environment and driving
column79:
as part of the company standards.

\r\n

Apart from the two telesales staff
column80: the company recruited another five external people during that time. A northern office was opened in November of the same year
column81: as the volume of new business in the north was increasing. Three employees moved from the south to the new office
column82:
one as northern operations manager and one as cleaning supervisor. The other employees were employed locally from advertising. TWO Services had far too many applications for the remaining positions.

The restructuring event was financed from internal funds obtained by reducing advertising expenditure in the Yellow Pages in 2009. This has enabled TWO Services to cover the additional overhead cost of the new staff.

Challenges and constraints of restructuring

In order to open a new telesales department
column83: TWO Services needed to recruit experienced sales staff. This has been a challenge for the company as this is not a job for just anyone
column84: due to the nature of this type of work. Additionally
column85: the company had an issue with one new employee who was quite strong minded
column86: and it took a time for that person to adjust to the new working conditions and the type of services being sold. This
column87: however
column88:
was soon resolved and their work generally improved.

Restructuring advice and support

The company received advice and support from two business consultants regarding the development of an integrated quality management system
column89: including the environment policy
column90: health and safety policy
column91: and staff induction training programmes. It did not seek any specific advice during the restructuring process
column92: but its management plans were developed with the help of these two consultants
column93:
who have worked with the company since 2008.

Outcomes of restructuring

The new telesales department proved to be a success for the company. As a consequence
column94:
it has employed seven new staff members. Having dedicated sales staff enabled the company to set itself targets. Deals are now regularly closed by making appointments via telephone and visiting clients face-to-face. The company introduced a bonus payment for the sales staff. The staff work towards targets and receive a bonus payment if they meet the target. This has increased the volume of sales.

\r\n

While previously the company was rather reactive
column95: mainly responding to clients’ queries and providing quotes
column96: it has since become more proactive by telephoning existing and potential clients and trying to bring in new business. Moreover
column97: the process has become more organised. The telesales department keeps records of sales and can make comparisons with previous years. The information is recorded in a sales database so that all staff have access to it and can plan visits without duplication. As a result
column98:
they have become much more efficient.

\r\n

Opening a telesales department has also affected the existing employees. Due to the increase in sales
column99:
the sales staff who go out to meet clients and complete quotes have become busier. There is also an increase in the volume of work for staff organising and arranging dates and times and for employees undertaking the cleaning and maintenance work.

\r\n

Anne Haydock is the contract manager for the Maintenance Department. Her role is to administer all documentation related to new contracts
column100: to do quotes and to respond to queries. Anne previously worked for the NHS. She started working for the company in 2007 on a part-time basis
column101: 25 hours a week. Due to increased volume of work generated through the telesales department but also the growing demand for maintenance services in recent years
column102: her workload has also increased in terms of quotes and documents that she has to process.  Ms. Haydock subsequently moved into a full-time position in 2011
column103:
which has been a positive development for her personally.

\r\n

Laurence Freeman joined the company in 1996
column104: initially working as a cleaner. About six years ago when an employee went on maternity leave
column105: Mr Freeman progressed into a managerial role and became responsible for office cleaning services. When TWO Services introduced the telesales division
column106: it started to produce more opportunities
column107: increasing sales. At the time
column108: Mr Freeman was offered the position of sales manager. This was not a vacant position advertised externally. As the business started to expand
column109: TWO Services required more sales staff and tried to draw from its existing human resources. As a sales manager
column110: Mr. Freeman meets clients face-to-face and converts quotes into sales. Although he did not have any prior sales experience
column111: he had a working knowledge of kitchen and office cleaning. Mr. Freeman attended several training courses for the role in order to learn how to price jobs and provide quotes for customers. Becoming a sales manager has been a positive experience in terms of personal progress
column112: job satisfaction
column113: financial rewards as well as company benefits such as having a company car
column114:
mobile phone and laptop.

\r\n

In terms of net profit
column115: 2009 was one of the best years ever for TWO Services. In 2010
column116: the company sales were higher than in 2009 as a result of restructuring. However
column117: due to the investments made into the new office and the additional overhead cost of seven new full-time employees
column118:
profit margins in 2010 were lower than in 2009. Calling and getting in touch with previous clients has helped the company maintain its profile in the market place.

Commentary

The case study of TWO Services provides an example of a company with a successful expansion strategy in difficult economic circumstances. The restructuring was associated with strategic reorientation in response to shifting demand patterns. The recession has strengthened rather than weakened the business. The company has capitalised on its strong market and financial positions
column119: using these to expand the business by opening a new office in the north of England and a new telesales department in the head office. As a result
column120:
it has employed additional people as well as making use of its existing human resources to strengthen sales and organisation of work. Increasing its turnover meant that the company was able to drop its prices and still retain good profit margins and good quality of service.

\r\n

For Alan Osborn
column121: the main lesson learnt from the restructuring event is the importance of having the right employees
column122: with experience and knowledge
column123: who can do the work and who have the right attitude. In the case of TWO Services
column124: the sales employees need to be confident communicators and be able to use certain techniques to elicit information from potential clients and to get them interested in talking in order to sell the service. Potential clients can often be abusive on the telephone
column125:
so this work requires a strong personality. The experience of restructuring would not have been positive and the subsequent increase in sales would not have occurred without having the right team of people in place.

\r\n

Mr Osborn believes that the company has made the right decisions at the right time. It has also been lucky to operate in the services industry
column126:
which has not been severely hit by the recession. The director’s understanding is that people still have to go out and eat and still spend money on food. TWO Services has taken advantage of its strong financial position by implementing measures that can put it in an even stronger position when the crisis is over and clients are ready to spend again.

column1:
Vialle, the Netherlands~"Vialle"~"

In the Netherlands
column2: alternative fuel systems provider Vialle carried out restructuring in 2009 including 60 redundancies as it faced bankruptcy. However it grew again shortly afterwards
column3: from 60 to 70 staff
column4:
and had to be reorganised once more in 2010. The second restructuring involved a newly formed works council that did not exist in 2009 and took a different approach to the smaller number of redundancies involved. The company has now resumed growth and by early 2012 once again had 70 staff in a market boosted by rising fuel prices.

"~"

Organisational profile

Vialle develops and manufactures alternative fuel systems. The company is involved in liquefied petroleum gas (LPG)
column5: diesel-blend
column6: natural gas and dimethyl ether technologies. Vialle distributes the advanced liquid LPG injection (LPi) system
column7: currently enjoying great popularity in cars. Its excellent performance
column8:
maintenance-free operation and very high reliability puts the LPi liquefied petroleum gas system ahead of the field.

\r\n

Vialle and BK-Gas (another Dutch supplier of LPG) together developed GasFX. Vialle and BK-Gas supply consumer and commercial markets in the Netherlands with an LPi package
column9: including installation
column10: service
column11: guarantee and fuel discounts. The system is supplied in many commercial markets and countries
column12:
both through the network of installation centres as well as in collaboration with car manufacturers and importers.

\r\n

Established in 1967 in Eindhoven
column13: the business is a private limited liability company and began by importing parts for liquefied petroleum gas installations from Italy. As a result of the 1970s oil crisis
column14:
Vialle grew and quickly became the market leader for liquefied petroleum gas installations in the Netherlands – a position the company still holds today. In less than 15 years the company grew from a trading company to a manufacturer with its own research and development capability. Some management members hold shares and there is also a co-investor.

\r\n

Driven by the sharp increase in interest from car manufacturers and high demands from motorists
column15:
manufacturing activities were gradually outsourced to third parties in the 1990s. This allowed Vialle to focus on new product development and quality improvement.

\r\n

Vialle employs approximately 70 people
column16: divided fairly equally among technical
column17: assembly and administrative departments. Approximately 10% of sales are in the Netherlands; the rest are from the EU
column18:
Asia and the Pacific.

\r\n

Peter Rutten has been chief executive (and one of the owners) since 2002
column19:
as well as a major shareholder and director. Auke Faber started working for Vialle in 2006 and has been head of the works council since 2010. Both have been interviewed for this case study.

Background to restructuring event

Vialle has reorganised three times in the past 10 years
column20: once in 2001–2002
column21: again in 2009 and then in 2010. This case study is mainly about the 2009 and 2010 reorganisations. The company was successful in the period leading up to reorganisation in 2009. In 2008
column22: turnover doubled compared to 2007
column23: mainly due to increasing fuel prices. Rising prices encouraged consumers to use LPi in their cars. However
column24: growth suddenly stopped in 2009 because of the economic crisis
column25: which saw orders decline drastically – to 5% of the level of 2008 (a very successful year). The company reduced employment in 2009
column26: but it wasn’t enough. The company increased the workforce after reorganisation by about 10 employees
column27:
but this occurred too quickly and so in 2010 jobs had to be cut again.

Restructuring processes

There was no works council during the reorganisation in 2009. Vialle management asked employees if they wanted to form one
column28: but no one did. Management introduced a plan
column29: with the guidance of a private legal office
column30:
to ensure there were no legal problems with the process because of the absence of a work council.

\r\n

The 2009 restructuring plan was limited: it mainly described the process regarding the reorganisation. The company was at the edge of bankruptcy
column31: so drastic measures were needed. The management decided who was going to be made redundant and the redundant employees received minimal compensation. If the employees voluntarily ended their contracts
column32: they could get 100% compensation for their loss of wages in the first month after termination. Because of the urgency
column33:
there was a very tight timetable and everything had to be arranged in a couple of months. The process was finalised according to this timetable.

\r\n

The management informed employees of the restructuring plans and decisions concerning their employment in one-to-one talks. A couple of lawsuits from redundant employees are still running but so far court rulings have been in favour of Vialle.

\r\n

After the 2009 reorganisation
column34: the company grew from 60 to 70 employees. But
column35: looking back
column36: this growth perhaps took place too quickly because the organisation had to be downsized again in 2010. After this reorganisation
column37:
the company grew again to about 70 employees (early 2012).

\r\n

Before the 2010 reorganisation
column38: a works council was formed as a mutual employer–worker initiative: the management wanted a works council and there were employees who wanted to be part of it. The management plans for the reorganisation were shown to the council
column39: before being communicated to the workforce. One works council member
column40: however
column41: leaked the plans to the media
column42: causing considerable employee unrest
column43:
so speed was of the essence.

\r\n

The works council agreed with management that downsizing was the only option. They made some minor requests regarding the departments where people were going to lose their jobs. Some positions/departments were vital for the continuation of Vialle. The management agreed to their suggestions.

\r\n

Following the works council agreement
column44: management took a different approach from the one taken during the previous
column45: larger
column46:
2009 reorganisation. They invited all the employees from a specific department to a meeting at which they informed the group who was going to be let go; this was followed by one-to-one talks with these employees.

Challenges and constraints of restructuring

Looking back
column47: the 2009 restructuring was not drastic enough
column48: and the subsequent growth was not a good idea. After 2009
column49: work pressure on remaining employees increased
column50: leading to a rise in sick leave
column51:
and Vialle incurred extra costs because of this.

The main challenge for the 2009 reorganisation was the absence of a work council. A company without one generally has to wait one month before the public office in charge of national insurance (UWV Werkbedrijf) will issue a collective discharge permit. However Vialle’s problems were so great and speed was so essential that the Minister of Social Affairs and Employment (Sociale Zaken en Werkgelegenheid) had to sign the plans to get priority at the ‘UWV Werkbedrijf’.

The main challenge in the 2010 reorganisation was the leaking of restructuring plans to the media. Employees were understandably alarmed given the downsizing that had occurred the year before.

Restructuring advice and support

For both the 2009 and 2010 restructuring events management sought legal advice from a service provider with whom they had previously done business. Compulsory redundancies are not to be taken lightly because of their complexity and the financial/economic implications and advice and guidance is necessary.

For the 2009 reorganisation
column52: the UWV WEKRbedrijf gave a presentation and information to employees regarding the consequences of dismissal. This was a joint initiative by the public office and management. Since works councils are made up of company employees
column53:
they don’t necessarily have experience in dealing with management restructuring plans. Vialle therefore paid for advice from a private expert regarding severance arrangements.

Outcomes of restructuring

The most important effect of restructuring was on employment numbers. In 2009
column54: employment decreased 50% from approximately 120 to 60. Following the 2009 reorganisation
column55: the workforce grew by 10 employees
column56:
but then had to be decreased again to about 60 employees.

\r\n

The 2009 reorganisation led to a number of employee-related challenges. First
column57: reorganisation produced a large increase in employee workload
column58: with a subsequent rise in sick leave. There was also an unexpected problem in the form of feelings of guilt among the retained employees. This is something that received more attention during the 2010 reorganisation. For example
column59: one employee offered to resign in place of a dismissed employee. Such emotions are very difficult to manage
column60: underlining the point that retained
column61: as well as newly redundant
column62: employees often need support during a reorganisation. Third
column63:
downsizing affected workforce expertise as skilled employees had to go.

\r\n

The current forecasts for Vialle are good. After a turbulent couple of years
column64: the company is growing again. By the beginning of 2012 it employed 70 people
column65: and with increasing fuel prices
column66:
LPi systems should have a lot of potential growth.

Commentary

Employees to be made redundant were approached differently in the 2009 and 2010 reorganisations
column67: and both approaches worked. Because of the large group affected in the 2009 reorganisation
column68:
an individual approach to handling redundancies worked. All employees got time with management to talk about reorganisation motives and effects.

\r\n

In the 2010 reorganisation
column69: a team approach worked very well
column70: because they were very close-knit teams and employees could be informed quickly. So there is no ‘one best way’ of dealing with this kind of situation. If redundancies were to happen again
column71:
the management would again carefully consider how to tell individual employees.

\r\n

Management–works council relations are important influences on restructuring processes. When relations are poor
column72: discussing plans can be difficult. In this case
column73:
the works council had no complaints about the process.

\r\n

A very important learning point for management is to be firm when deciding the number of employees that has to go. Perhaps
column74: if management had not been so ‘friendly’ during and after the 2009 reorganisation
column75:
the 2010 reorganisation might not have been necessary.

\r\n

However
column76: the chief executive emphasises that every situation is unique. This is why legal advice is very useful.  The chief executive
column77: while working for a previous company
column78: downsized a workforce from 560 employees to 140. On that larger scale
column79: one looks less at individual employees. It is a much more personal process in a small or medium enterprise
column80: where management knows the individual employees. Furthermore
column81: he is also a part-owner of the company. This means that one looks differently at restructuring events
column82:
because one is more financially involved in the company. It is important that one is personally involved and that one empathises with all employees.

\r\n

The most important learning aspect for the head of the works council is that reorganisation can be an emotional and difficult process. Employees can take a lot of the burden to heart. It is important to think more generally
column83: because when you think too much about the individuals involved
column84:
the job of a works council member can be very tough.

column1:
Zet Transport, Poland~"Zettransport Sp. z. oo"~"

Increased regulation after Poland joined the EU in 2004
column2: plus growing competition
column3: put pressure on Zet Transport
column4: a transport and freight forwarding business. Its turnover was growing but profit was falling. Two periods of restructuring in 2006–2008 and 2010–2012 saw wide-ranging change
column5: including changing the legal form of the company
column6: extending operations
column7: partial relocation and setting up a subsidiary to service its fleet. The company gained in business and economic terms
column8:
although these benefits took some time to become clear.

"~"

Organisational profile

  • Transport was established in March 1993 as a private family partnership of Józef
column9: Jan and Józef (junior) Załubscy.\r\nJózef and Józef jr. are passive shareholders. Jan Załubski
column10: \r\nthe company president and main shareholder
column11: had the idea of starting up a\r\nbusiness in this form. He holds an MSc in engineering and graduated from\r\nKraków Technical University in 1994. Prior to founding Zet Transport
column12: he\r\nhad some business experience
column13:
as during his studies he ran a small trading company called Bentax.

Zet Transport Sp. z o.o. is a family business specialising in transport services. It is a follow-up of a transport service run by Józef Załubski senior
column14: who was involved in this type of business since 1983. In 1993
column15: two sons
column16: Jan and Józef jr.
column17: joined the company wishing to continue the family tradition. The company was originally based in Żbikowice
column18: a village in Łososina Dolna municipality in the Malopolska region. From the start of its operations
column19: the company focused on the development of international transport. Getting an inside knowledge of this trade
column20: careful observation and understanding of economic trends
column21: as well as applying modern technologies allowed the company to build a strong and modern enterprise and its status as a reliable business partner. In a short time
column22:
Zet Transport developed its operations with a new office in Nowy Sacz and a transport base for rented vehicles.

\r\n

From its start-up in 1993
column23: Zet Transport has conducted the same type of activity – the transport of assets and goods
column24: as well as freight forwarding. The company has branches
column25: in the form of joint ventures
column26: in Slovakia
column27: Ukraine and Austria. The branches are autonomous; they have their own competences and scope of activities. They did not take part in the restructuring
column28: but they complement the Zet Transport offer. The company’s staff mainly comprise drivers with a basic education who hold special licences (appropriate driving licence categories) that authorise them to drive trucks. The company is international due to the number of operations carried out in foreign markets
column29: its clients and its suppliers. Only 20% of customers are local
column30: while 30% are national and 50% are foreign (international). The company has a corporate social responsibility policy
column31: which was developed in 2007 in the course of the restructuring process described in this case study. However
column32:
it does not have trade unions or employee representatives (employee council).

Background to restructuring event

Since 2005
column33: company turnover had been growing
column34: while profit was declining. This was a result of a complete change of parameters (new legal regulations after accession to the EU) in the sector
column35: which mainly came into effect following Poland’s accession to the EU and increased competition in the sector. That is why the implementation of the restructuring process was necessary. It also allowed the company to ensure the stability of its operations
column36:
protect its staff from dismissals and search for new strategies in the new market conditions.

\r\n

Obtaining outsourcing contracts from SGL Group (one of the world’s leading manufacturers of carbon-based products) was a key decision in the corporate development strategy.

\r\n

Changes occurred as a response to the changing business environment and increased competition in the market. Growing labour costs
column37: on the one hand
column38: and changing requirements for the transport sector and efficiency of its operations
column39: on the other
column40: forced the decision on amending the investment strategy in terms of obtaining vehicles. Decisions on implementing restructuring measures were usually made three to six months in advance by the owner and the board of management
column41:
including middle management.

\r\n

Adapting to the changing market parameters and openness to other options
column42: such as a merger with another transport company
column43:
capital injection and so on were the main reasons for restructuring.

Restructuring processes

The company underwent two stages of restructuring in 2006–2008 and 2010–2012. The restructuring processes involved several measures.

  • The legal form and status of the company was changed from private partnership to limited liability company (spółka z ograniczoną odpowiedzialnością or sp. z o.o. in Polish). The change of its legal form resulted from the development strategy adopted. A one-person management was established. The company has no supervisory board or auditing committee.
  • The decision to change the legal form was due to both planned investment measures and the need to limit risk. The limited liability company is a universal economic structure
column44: which depending on needs and the\r\nspecific strategy
column45:
may take different approaches to obtaining capital.
  • The company’s operations were extended through the insourcing of loading and unloading of trucks
column46: and packaging and pallet making.\r\nThis implemented a management strategy that was modified following the\r\nrestructuring process
column47:
and which involved the generation of alternative revenues earned from activities associated or complementary to the main activities.
  • A partial relocation was implemented through establishing joint ventures (search for a new location for the business due to the tax and labour regulations) with local and well-known partners in Slovakia
column48: Ukraine and\r\nAustria
column49: to provide services for these markets
column50:
and to the east and south of Europe. The aim was to activate an operational structure in these specific countries both to search for additional business through obtaining new customers as well as to provide a better standard of service to current customers.
  • Servicing and sale of spare parts have been allocated to Truck Partner Sp. z o.o.
column51: a new subsidiary that has 11 employees and developed\r\non the basis of Zet Transport’s experience. It was established to service\r\nthe Zet Transport fleet. Previously
column52: the company’s fleet was serviced by\r\nZet Transport to certain extent
column53: or servicing was outsourced. Both companies are\r\nmanaged by Jan Załubski. At the initial stage of developing the fleet
column54:
having appropriate support services was of key importance as Zet Transport purchased imported second-hand vehicles.

The final decision was made by the owner and company’s board of management. It was focused on implementation of a follow-up development strategy after the restructuring
column55: which was based on the company’s own concept and implemented independently
column56: excluding any capital injection
column57:
which had been initially considered.

\r\n

Restructuring measures commenced without any formal (that is
column58: written) restructuring plan. However
column59:
they were all delivered based on an informally defined plan and assumed objectives. The timetable of specific measures was modified in accordance with changing market conditions.

\r\n

The company had to address economic situation and changing market and political conditions and correct the restructuring process as it proceeded. Examples of that approach include responding to the need of a key customer to receive the additional service of loading and unloading goods in this customer’s premises
column60:
and extending operations with making pallets and packaging . The decision on joint organisation of the Euro 2012 football championship by Poland and Ukraine was another key element – the company perceived this event as an opportunity to increase the volume of cargo and trade outside of EU territory. It was an additional argument for establishing a company in Ukraine. (These changes were part of restructuring process and were associated with insourcing and relocation.)

The Truck Partner company was established to meet Zet Transport’s service needs and is located in the local market. It continually developed its operation and provides services to other transport companies in the region.

Financial restructuring was delivered exclusively with the company’s own funds and through a modified form of leasing. New vehicles were financed through a new and ‘special’ structure for financing the leasing of vehicles developed by the company’s board of management and delivered by Millennium Leasing. This enabled the company to complete the financing of a given vehicle at any time (without the need to wait until the end of the financing period laid down in the contract). This helped to reduce technical costs generated by use of the vehicles under the warranty period.

Employees were informed of planned changes and measures to be implemented during information meetings that took place prior to and during restructuring. In general
column61: they demonstrated understanding and active participation (without strikes) in the restructuring process. The favourable approach of the employees towards the planned restructuring resulted from the fact that the company pursued an active information policy and encouraged acceptance of the restructuring strategy adopted. That allowed the company to maintain the same number of staff
column62:
upgrade working standards and improve the company’s position.

\r\n

Each department implemented the restructuring measures allocated to it. The company’s organisational units implement the strategy according to the separation of corporate duties and responsibilities. The operational tasks of the freight forwarding department had to be optimised in terms of availability of vehicles
column63: emphasising the maximum use of working time by the drivers
column64: reducing the so-called empty kilometres and amending fuel policy. Those changes required that the former financial settlement process
column65: information flow had to be modified
column66: and workflow developed and implemented. The other departments of the enterprise were involved in drafting new guidelines
column67: and
column68: where necessary
column69:
staff underwent IT training in computer software and new solutions.

Challenges and constraints of restructuring

The main problems related to human resources
column70:
that is lack of knowledge and skills among the staff. New tasks required employees to change their way of working. Other problems concerned legislative changes and adaptation to EU requirements.

\r\n

Another element that caused modifications to the planned restructuring process was the lack of stability in the euro exchange rate
column71:
which in the Polish economy strongly affects both the price of fuels and the balance of the cargo mass intended for transport on the market.

Restructuring advice and support

In the course of the restructuring process
column72: the company sought IT support
column73: access to know-how and training. It received EU-funded support under the Phare 2002 programme for the ‘purchase of hardware and software to modernise teleinformation network’. Cofinancing granted by the Polish Agency for Enterprise Development reached 50%
column74:
with the same level of match funding.

\r\n

In order to address changing market conditions and when starting the restructuring
column75: the company made efforts to upgrade vocational qualifications of its staff through professional training. In this context
column76: training cofinanced by EU funding was also used. In 2007
column77: management took part in the Interpersonal Communication and Motivation course. In 2008
column78: all staff of the freight forwarding department
column79: the company’s operational department
column80: were trained in selling techniques for the freight forwarding sector. In parallel
column81: commercial transport-related training was made available in response to changes in areas such as new EU legislation
column82:
on an ongoing basis.

The owner is of the opinion that obtaining funds is difficult due to the obligatory procedures. Many EU cofinanced projects also exclude participation of transport companies – or immediately reduce the scoring in an evaluation if an applicant operates in the transport sector. Funding provided under this type of assistance may not be spent on purchase of new vehicles.

Outcomes of the restructuring

Restructuring followed in accordance with the restructuring plan adopted. It accomplished the goals set both for the company and its employees. Maintaining the same number of staff and avoiding dismissals was one of the objectives successfully accomplished that were of importance to employees.

The structure of management was also changed by changing the legal form of the company into a limited liability company. The strategy of actions and restructuring plans convinced the owner that it would be easier to restructure the company by changing its legal form. Moreover
column83: as has already been explained
column84:
it provided a formal structure to facilitate any future capital solutions.

\r\n

The outcomes included the requalification and reorganisation of staff. Staff were trained in how to operate in the open EU market. The way drivers used their working time had to be reorganised
column85: and this was facilitated by a specially developed
column86: dedicated tool for carriers to help them to plan their work. It enabled online tracking of both the vehicle and driver’s available working time in order to select appropriate tasks
column87:
which contributed to increased efficiency in vehicle use. Working hours and time of the company’s staff remained unchanged.

\r\n

Among various outcomes achieved
column88: the introduction of an incentive scheme (bonuses) for operational staff is worth emphasising. Acquiring new skills and competences resulting from changes in work organisation is also of importance. In order to address challenges
column89: the board decided upon providing the staff of the shipment department with Transics software tools to support the operational process. In this context
column90:
the shipment department staff and drivers had to undergo training to learn to use the equipment and change their structure of operations. The use of modern information technologies in planning and freight forwarding enhanced the quality of services. Transics software also facilitated exchange of information among employees.

\r\n

The restructuring measures protected the staff from dismissals
column91: and since 2006
column92: the number of staff has been growing steadily. In 2006
column93: it reached 125
column94: with 89 drivers
column95: 6 involved in loading and unloading  and 30 others. Currently (2012)
column96: the company employs 155 people where 103 are drivers
column97: 16 are loading team staff and make pallets
column98:
and 36 work elsewhere in the business.

\r\n

Positive outcomes of the restructuring measures
column99: economic ones in particular
column100: were not immediately apparent. It was a long-term process that is easier to assess from a longer perspective. A small improvement in the company’s financial situation was observed in 2007
column101: when a loss smaller than in 2006 was recorded. In the second stage of restructuring
column102: which took place between 2010 and 2012
column103: net income was significantly better. In 2011 the company recorded a profit
column104:
which facilitated capital investments including purchase of new trucks.

Commentary

In general
column105: the outcomes of restructuring were beneficial as market potential was extended. Employees’   career prospects improved
column106: due to the acquisition of new skills
column107: opportunities for professional development and new responsibilities. In its strategic plans
column108: the company expects to enter into new markets and to enhance its market offering
column109: and in terms of its staff
column110:
opportunities for further upgrading of their qualifications and new skills acquisition through vocational training and courses.

\r\n

Listing key differences between restructuring of SMEs and large enterprises
column111: the owner stressed that in small and medium-sized enterprises
column112:
the restructuring process is faster than in large enterprises.

\r\n

Disadvantages for SMEs include the lack of relevant knowledge
column113: know-how and funds to finance restructuring processes
column114:
while advantages include less company ‘inertia’ and accelerated decision-making process and execution of the decisions.

\r\n

The recent experience of Zet Transport indicates that restructuring should be implemented more dynamically. Introducing restructuring changes faster would save time and resources.

\r\n

Mr Załubski thinks that the key issue that should be recommended in terms of public support for planning and implementing restructuring by businesses is greater tax flexibility for restructuring enterprises and introducing ‘friendly’ procedures and service from public authorities. ‘Careful observation of the business environment
column115: monitoring market trends
column116:
benchmarking and anticipating changes on the market’ were further recommendations.

  1. Kogut
column117: an employee (35 years of age)
column118:
shared her opinion
on Zet Transport restructuring. Ms Kogut has worked for Zet Transport for five
and a-half years as the board’s representative responsible for the quality
management system. (Before joining Zet Transport
column119: she worked in a school and in\r\nthe brewery industry.) She took part in the restructuring process
column120: and had\r\ndirect contact with the staff of the freight forwarding
column121: finance
column122:
IT and human
resources departments as well as with the company’s board. Ms Kogut
benefited from the process by gaining restructuring-related know-how and
experience. Her role in the restructuring process involved dissemination of
information
column123: training and overseeing introduced changes. In connection with the\r\nquality management system
column124:
she took part in amending the existing procedures or developing new ones. Drafts were developed in cooperation with representatives of the specific departments. Presenting new solutions and training in the field of new methodology of operations was another stage.

Ms Kogut thinks that due to the restructuring
column125: the company gained benefits through insourcing of loading and unloading of goods and making pallets and packaging
column126: which allowed it to keep its current customers. Similar benefits were gained as a result of the partial relocation to Slovakia
column127: Ukraine and Austria. Implementation of the Transics IT system was another benefit. The system reorganised work of the company’s staff and additionally prepared the operational structure for additional vehicles
column128:
without the need of employing extra administrative staff.

\r\n

Employees were not involved in the decision on implementing restructuring. However
column129: they were informed and familiarised with the restructuring projects planned. They were able to present their conclusions
column130: comments and even doubts
column131: which were considered by the management. That process took the form of consultations with the staff concerning operational potential in terms of implementation of restructuring plan. It was attempted to identify tools necessary to accomplish that objective – for example
column132: access to data via remote desktop (in case of Zet Transport Ukraine or Zet Transport Slovakia)
column133:
or a single programme to manage repairs in case of Truck Partner.

\r\n

There were no staff dismissals or reductions. Employees received support to requalify in the form of training and courses. As a result of information meetings organised by the management
column134: the employees started to understand the process and actively supported implementation of the changes. The company employed staff responsible for preparing and training new employees from the branches in Slovakia and Ukraine. Their stay in the company’s base in Nowy Sacz provided an opportunity to get familiar with the procedures and general operational rules enforced in the transport and freight forwarding company. The IT department received the task of developing a platform for sharing information about loads and vacant vehicles
column135:
which gave a competitive advantage of the company.

\r\n

Mutual cooperation was also translated into other areas of the company’s operations
column136: such as recruitment of drivers from Ukraine. Opening of European markets resulted in the migration of Polish drivers to the EU states
column137: thus drivers from the east became an alternative. In this context
column138:
the HR department staff had to learn procedures of recruiting staff from non-EU states.

\r\n

Staff showed creativity and entrepreneurial behaviours. They acquired new skills and competences. Rapid development of the company between 2004 and 2008 resulted in a problem of recruiting drivers holding required vocational qualifications. The changes were implemented in an optimum manner
column139:
during the process of planning and implementation.

column1:
Acropolis Dry Cleaners, Cyprus ~"Acropolis Dry Cleaners"~"

Founded in 1975
column2: the family-run Acropolis Dry Cleaners is a market leader in the dry-cleaning sector in Cyprus. It comprises six micro-businesses
column3: having expanded its operations and services over the years. Expansion however has been hampered by poor trade and pressure to cut costs. Striving for operational efficiency in the crisis
column4: to cut costs the business had to close a retail unit and outsource services
column5:
as well as integrate a hybrid franchised workshop store into its network of retail shops. Yet the business has managed to retain 25 employees since 2007.

"~"

Organisational profile

Eracleous & Sons Ltd
column6: trading as Acropolis Dry Cleaners
column7: is one of the market leaders in the fragmented dry-cleaning sector
column8: offering the highest standards of service
column9: due to continuous investment in modern technologies. Today
column10: the company employs 25 people (including owner/managers) and enjoys sustainable business success
column11: steady growth and financial stability. It constitutes a group of micro-businesses that are integrated into Acropolis
column12: which is the ‘parent firm’ and is wholly owned by the family owner/managers. The organisational structure of this small enterprise is very flat
column13:
managerial positions are held by family members and there is no works council.

\r\n

Acropolis Dry Cleaners was founded in Larnaca in 1975 by the – now semi-retired – owner Zacharias Eracleous when he was aged 28 years
column14: following a long apprenticeship (16 years) in the industry. In the early days
column15: the original firm was a sole proprietorship
column16: run by the founder
column17: offering dry cleaning from a one-stop workshop and retail unit (often referred to as a store in the industry). Zacharias Eracleous established a loyal clientele in the town
column18: but also used to organise the collection of clothing from nearby villages
column19: notably Aradhippou
column20: where the family is based. Following early growth
column21: the firm progressed to the profitable stage of the business life cycle model
column22:
with no formal strategic plan to expand further. The emphasis has been on offering quality service to its loyal customer base. The store was profitable enough for the founder to buy out the freehold of the property and to be able to support the growing family of five sons. Family developments have proved the trigger for business growth in order to provide the expanding family with jobs.

\r\n

Thirty-six years after its establishment
column23: Acropolis Dry Cleaners opened its second store in 2002
column24: after buying another company in nearby Livadhia village
column25: with a view to scaling up operations via horizontal integration. In 2004 and every year until 2008
column26: they embarked on an ambitious expansion through horizontal integration by opening up stores in new locations in the suburban village towns of Aradippou
column27: Kiti
column28: Nissou and Anglisides around Larnaca town. The range of services has been expanded and now includes laundry cleaning and ironing
column29: leather and carpet dry-cleaning
column30: fabric repairs
column31: curtain cleaning
column32:
specialist cleaning and pressing of wedding dresses and tuxedos.

\r\n

In recent years
column33: the firm has triggered new business activities such as laundrettes
column34: which also act as points-of-sale for the dry-cleaning operation
column35: and a rental service offering table and chair covers. Acropolis Ltd evolved from one small retail workshop into a fully integrated owner-managed family business that dominates the dry-cleaning market in the Larnaca district. Following incremental growth
column36: the firm today enjoys a leading market position
column37:
with a network of shops that are vertically integrated with a state-of-the art central production plant for the cleaning operations.

\r\n

Following its business expansion
column38: Acropolis Dry Cleaners went through a series of restructurings and reorganisations
column39: as part of a multi-dimensional strategic plan
column40: addressing managerial
column41:
ownership and financial issues.

\r\n

In the context of the prolonged macro-economic-financial crisis
column42: two major restructuring events are the focus of this case study. In its search for operational efficiency and sustainable competitiveness
column43: Acropolis decided to close a retail unit operating on the high street and outsource the service to a local supermarket. The company also abandoned a hybrid franchising route by wholly acquiring a retail unit that involved a partnership with the managing director
column44:
and they have integrated the business unit into their network of shops that outsource the dry-cleaning to a central depot located in the industrial estate.

\r\n

Today
column45: the firm does not suffer from a funding gap – a shortage of bank loans coupled with escalating late payment of trade debtors – that often hinders growth and jeopardises the survival of smaller firms. During recent tough times
column46: the Eracleous have ‘shaken the tree’ and got rid of some business clients (such as hoteliers that fail to honour their terms of engagement by delaying settlement of their invoices). Today
column47: Acropolis Dry Cleaners remains focused on developing high value added services to their loyal customers
column48: as emphasised by their slogan: <i>Αlways offering clear solutions ! Πάντα
column49:
Καθaρές Δουλειές!

Background to restructuring events

In 2006
column50: as a result of market development through the establishment of a network of workshops (retail units)
column51: the company embarked on an ambitious investment in a central production plant in Larnaca’s industrial estate to serve all of their shops. This was geared to standardise certain processes to achieve operational efficiency
column52:
reduce cost structures and ensure quality of service across the chain.

\r\n

This investment has been critical in the effective adoption of operations management systems across the integrated platform which allowed the building of sophisticated logistics (collection and delivery to the shops) and production systems employing state-of-the-art
column53: ecologically friendly technologies and solutions. Through the standardisation of production and service across the network
column54: training of staff and adoption of modern shop management techniques
column55: the firm has achieved unparalleled success
column56: offering high value added services to a growing customer base. However
column57:
the production plant has not managed to reach operational efficiency due to under-utilisation. Thus the firm is under pressure to expand and bring in greater volumes of apparel for cleaning.

\r\n

In recent years
column58: and in the context of the prolonged economic crisis
column59: the owner/managers have pursued a restructuring process that primarily involved the closure of a retail store and outsourcing the service to a supermarket (cost-cutting)
column60:
and the integration of a hybrid franchised workshop store into the network of retail shops (cost cutting and enhanced independence).

Restructuring processes

Given the predominance of Acropolis Dry Cleaners in Larnaca
column61: the firm decided there was scope to expand geographically with partnering. It was imperative to grow in order to bring in more work for the central production plant seeking enhanced utilisation
column62: but also to fence off any rivals entering the market. The owner/managers of the firm crafted the restructuring on an ad hoc basis
column63: a step-by-step growth plan
column64:
which from time to time they discussed with their bankers and accountants.

\r\n

In 2008
column65: the Eracleous set up an independent shop in Anglisides village
column66: on the road to Limassol – a thriving metropolitan business centre. Basically
column67: they took on a shop with a flexible lease to act as point-of-sale offering Acropolis services. In 2009
column68: they established a limited company jointly (with a long-time associate who had also formerly been an employee) to acquire an existing dry-cleaning workshop venture in Nissou which is on the road to Nicosia – the capital city of Cyprus. Both shops have been equipped with their logistics systems and refurbished with their classic well branded model of operations. Given the small distance
column69: experienced employees from the existing Acropolis operations were transferred to the new shops and then using word-of-mouth and networking they recruited additional staff
column70: initially on a part-time basis and then
column71: based on performance
column72:
on a full-time basis.

\r\n

Unfortunately
column73:
their appetite for expansion has been hampered by poor trade and pressure to cut costs in order to cope with the recession. Thus the restructuring events as described below have been pursued.

Outsourcing

In the light of performance management
column74: the Acropolis team decided to close the retail store (collection point
column75: outsourcing the jobs to the central production plant) located on the high street in Anglisides village and relocate the service into a supermarket. Basically
column76: this involved the closure of the store (capitalising on cost economies in terms of rentals
column77: and saving on labour costs due to shedding a full-time job and a pro rata
column78: part-time job). This action is effectively outsourcing
column79:
as the supermarket hosting the Acropolis service provides the counter for the collection and deliver of the treated apparel. Acropolis rewards the supermarket with a commission on the trade volume. This win-win partnering is proving fruitful for both parties. This model is under review in order for Acropolis to activate more collection points in other supermarkets in other locations.

\r\n

The Anglisides project
column80: which took over a year to plan and implement
column81: had to be re-engineered. Despite the fact that it has not violated their patient investment pay-back period
column82: and there was optimism that through effective marketing the financial numbers would have picked up
column83: after a year of running it the family decided to close the shop and simply outsource the operation as ‘a counter service’ in the leading supermarket in the village. The supermarket that hosts their service is adding value to their range of services
column84: plus they get their commission from the Acropolis Cleaners. The new arrangements meant a lower cost structure because of savings on the rental payments
column85:
and a greater flow of people. The economic crisis has signalled a more conservative approach to growth.

\r\n

Thus
column86: based on this business model innovation strategy
column87: Acropolis Dry Cleaners now operates a partnership with the supermarket
column88: considerably reducing its cost structure and offering its services to a higher flow of clients that are out shopping for essentials around the clock. As a result of this retrenchment
column89: Acropolis continues to operate in the Anglisides area with a representative agent – who is rewarded by a commission on trade. Thus
column90: Acropolis enjoys savings after exiting from the shop
column91:
saving on overheads and eliminating staff costs.

Acquisition of a sister firm

Acropolis acquired a sister firm by owning/managing a retail unit located in Nissou. Basically this store
column92: which was owned by Acropolis and the managing director of the operation
column93: was a type of hybrid franchising which was being investigated in order to expand further by establishing more units (based on partnership between Acropolis and the appointed managing directors). Unfortunately the economics of this workshop store (where production-dry cleaning was taking place on premises of the retail unit) were not very efficient. Thus this  restructuring is part of the strategic effort to consolidate the firm’s business model (and
column94: for the owning family
column95:
to simplify the ownership and governance regime and consolidate control) in order to achieve cost savings essential to help reconfigure its business model to weather the crisis.

\r\n

The Nissou project
column96: which involved geographic expansion with external growth strategies – the initial informal plan was to build a partnership via a franchising agreement with a few entrepreneurs in the region – also had to be revisited. More specifically
column97: the Eracleous decided to buy out their Nissou partner with cash simply in order to save on management overheads and enhance their strategic independence to integrate the store into the network and make the operation more profitable. Again
column98: in the context of the recession
column99: the firm streamlined the Nissou workshop-store and fully integrated it as a point of sale store (collection and delivery of apparel) into their Larnaca network of shops
column100:
allowing the central production plant to do the cleaning.

Challenges and constraints of restructuring

Acropolis exemplifies the prolific small family business where the founding and/or successive generations of owners/managers play a protagonistic role in strategically navigating the family business across its development path. The Eracleous family have established a reputation as masters of the dry-cleaning trade. Acropolis Dry Cleaners is now synonymous with innovation and high value-added service. They have developed a cash-rich business model
column101:
enabling the Eracleous family to manage the classic challenge facing growing smaller firms: getting funding.

\r\n

Moreover
column102: the entrepreneurial family have managed to accommodate the aspirations of the new generation
column103: kick-starting ventures to allow siblings to carry out entrepreneurial activities under the umbrella of the Acropolis confederation. As the siblings expand their own family units
column104: it is envisaged that in the context of parallel strategic ‘family in business’ planning
column105: each business unit will be matched to a family unit. Thus
column106: the Eracleous have to master the challenge of building inter-generational goal congruence as the members of the second generation are taking more managerial positions in the firm and naturally want to impact on the decision-making process that governs venturing
column107:
growth and financing.

\r\n

As a result of the expansion of the network of workshop-stores as part of the integrated business network
column108: the owner/managers have to cope with transitions and challenges overshadowing their evolving family and business organisation. More specifically
column109: on the business axis
column110:
the firm has made a lot of progress and the quest for new growth horizons continues. They are mapping new ventures in order to fuel growth as the family has been growing faster than the business.

\r\n

On the family axis
column111: the second generation (five sons) are working together with the founder who is acting as the executive chairman of the firm. Currently
column112:
there is inter-generational (father and sons) cooperation and intra-generational goal alignment – sons are working harmoniously to build business consolidation in the competitive market. The question is when/how will the next generation take over? How do they plan for the introduction of the third generation of family members?

\r\n

On the ownership axis
column113: the father is still the controlling owner as he has the majority of the shareholding. Strategic succession planning is needed in order to ensure the smooth transfer of ownership rights
column114: stewardship roles and responsibilities to the next generation. Currently they are all involved
column115: working in the business
column116: and there is a memorandum of understanding that shareholding will be distributed on equal terms. But already a son is exiting from the family business in order to pursue his own venture. This means that there is an emerging challenge concerning the ownership related succession
column117: which is how to reorganise the shareholding on a more equitable terms
column118:
rather than an equal split of shares.

\r\n

The managing director
column119: Andreas Z. Eracleous
column120: has been working tirelessly to develop a more effective organisation and governance structure
column121: management and operations systems in order to master the company’s growing empire of small business units. Integrated into Acropolis are shops
column122: laundrettes
column123: a trading firm selling technology and chemical solutions (this helped them collect market intelligence)
column124: and another trading firm hiring linen such as table and chair covers to function halls
column125: small hoteliers
column126:
etc.

\r\n

One of the challenges facing the Acropolis owner-management team is to safeguard goal alignment of the five brothers that represent the siblings’ partnership regime. They do not always agree on strategic goals and approaches
column127: as they do not have a homogeneous entrepreneurial DNA. Occasionally
column128: family issues do overshadow business management best practice
column129: thus causing inertia
column130:
erosion of professionalisation and confused communication and blurred lines of command. Already one brother is seeking more entrepreneurial independence.

\r\n

There is growing pressure to re-evaluate the current business structure with a view to set up a holding group which can offer scope for better governance
column131: better access to growth capital from the banks and make succession planning more systematic. Moreover
column132: the new group structure allows members of the owning family to pursue their own ventures
column133:
in which the parent company can act as investor. This is why the family decided to buy out the Nissou partner in order to exercise full ownership control and thus embark on the new holding regime – which will involve the transfer of shares from operating companies to the new parent holding company.

An emerging challenge is the banking crisis in Cyprus which resulted in reduced bank liquidity and subsequently credit rationing. Banks are seeking to renegotiate lending to SMEs using stringent collateral conditions.

Restructuring advice and support

The Eracleous family as artisan entrepreneurs have managed to master growth challenges
column134: but now they are revisiting their strategic plan in order to survive in this ongoing recession. They have been learning from their mistakes
column135: and somehow engineered entrepreneurial strategies with limited outside advisory support. Normally
column136:
they discuss strategic matters around the Sunday lunch table. The weekly management meeting is on Tuesday afternoon and the agenda mainly concerns operational matters.

\r\n

This forum was open to the non-family managers – when they were around in the jointly owned trading firm before the family decided to exit (to concentrate on their core business) and in the Nissou partnership venture which the family now wholly owns. Andreas Eracleous
column137: as the CEO
column138: often attends executive development seminars geared for smaller companies and tends to invite trainers/consultants to the family business meetings. This has helped the Eracleous to develop a consensus on the need to explore the strategic ‘family in business’ planning process which has to address multiple important business matters (such as leadership
column139: management
column140: taxation
column141: funding
column142:
risk diversification) but also sensitive family issues such as succession which involves ownership and employment rights (governed by equality or meritocratic / equitable principles).

\r\n

With the support of their accountants-auditors and bankers
column143: who act as the main source of advice
column144:
the Eracleous continue to strategically manage their integrated business model. They consult business advisors on an ad hoc basis on certain marketing tactics and strategic steps that focus on how to streamline operations in order to further improve the efficiency of the core business.

Outcomes of restructuring

In a nutshell
column145: as a result of the restructuring process Acropolis has managed to keep its leading market positioning and level of employment to 25 people since 2007. Due to the restructuring
column146: their network now has six stores. Jobs were lost in three stores
column147: but three jobs were generated in the labour-intensive production plant. Normally
column148: affected employees get an option to be relocated in other operations
column149:
in order to ease the impact of the restructuring. The company is proud that they have managed to sustain employment for their loyal employees.

\r\n

The outcome of the two restructuring events has impacted favourably on the bottom line
column150: by saving on labour costs. Three employment posts have been cancelled: one full-time and one pro-rata
column151: part-time sales assistant positions in Anglisides and one more supervisory post at Nissou workshop store. In addition to substantial labour cost savings
column152:
Acropolis have managed to enhance operational efficiency for the central production plant.

\r\n

In the words of the owner/managers ‘restructuring has been very positive as it has led to sustainable business success
column153: stable sales performance and profitability’. In the short term
column154: the restructuring events have resulted in the loss of jobs
column155: but this is part of flexible entrepreneurial management
column156:
which can now allow the firm to embark on a coherent strategic plan to expand steadily.

\r\n

Next on the horizon
column157: according to the CEO Andreas Eracleous (the eldest son of the founder) is further restructuring in the quest for efficiency. This involves the relocation of other retail shops to better positions and mapping out step-by-step growth via geographic expansion. Historically
column158: the financing philosophy of the family owner/managers has been faithful to financial prudence and adherence to the pecking order principles of funding: retaining profits and securing short-term bank finance. Given the financial discipline of the owner/managers – as reflected in the systematic retention of profits – and in conjunction with the cash basis financial model of the business
column159:
the firm is weathering the current crisis and continues to enjoy an optimal capital base and sustainable bankability.

Commentary

It is axiomatic that the restructuring of Acropolis pursued by the Eracleous family
column160: both in the context of internal and external growth
column161: was initially driven by market opportunity; but with the crisis hitting Cyprus
column162:
they had to fend off market pressure in order to safeguard sustainability and financial stability.

\r\n

The owning family took the strategic decision not to simply grow the numbers
column163: but to reconfigure operations with a view to getting better operational performance and profits which are imperative for long-term survival and step-by-step growth. Moreover
column164:
the brothers in business decided to exit from the company trading related to dry-cleaning technology and chemical solutions and to concentrate their efforts in the core business and fledgling ventures that enjoy a competitive advantage.

\r\n

As Andreas Eracleous stated: ‘Growth has been healthy for us to identify our ‘fortes’; we are now keen to unfold growth opportunities for our family managers and other loyal staff to develop
column165: by building on our successful business model; after consolidation
column166: we envisage to generate “managerial partnerships”.’ In a nutshell
column167:
the company has mapped out their next growth horizon which will embrace next-generation family managers (and other loyal non-family insiders) who will be supported to set up new operating units in the metropolitan centres that can be served by the central Larnaka production plant.

\r\n

It is envisaged that the younger brothers will be incentivised to set up their own ventures in order to ‘franchise’ the Acropolis concept across the Larnaka region. This family confederation is necessary to test out the partnership formula which is based on the new retail units outsourcing the dry-cleaning of the apparel to the central production.

\r\n

In the context of strategic succession planning
column168: the brothers
column169: as a result of their renewed family independence
column170: are now exploring how they can build integrated ‘family-in-business’ strategies balancing personal
column171: familial and business goals. They aspire to match a business unit to each family unit
column172:
so that each brother can control one venture each.
