column1:
ADV, Romania~"ADV"~"

The downturn in 2009 meant that Romanian advertising production company ADV had to take on smaller contracts. Cost-cutting measures included not replacing temporary workers or those resigning
column2: re-negotiating contract terms with suppliers
column3: moving two departments to one single space
column4: freezing wages
column5: cutting senior staff salaries and not paying bonuses. ADV returned to profitability in 2010 and one year later the company moved to a new location
column6:
raised salaries and increased staff by 5%.

"~"

 

\r\n

Organisational profile

\r\n

ADV is an advertising production company. The company was started in 2000 by ‘Mr T’
column7: who at the time was working as a cameraman for a Romanian TV channel. Mr T is the general manager of ADV advertising. The company employs 50 people and does not have a works council. In 2010
column8:
Mr T offered shares as an incentive to five of his senior staff. One person was promoted to the position of partner and given a separate line of business to run (Public Relations).

\r\n

Although Mr T did not consult anyone in this decision
column9: he says that from own experience he felt that some people would react better to shares than to a salary raise. He says that he did not have any prior expectations but felt it was the only option at the time to motivate the staff. One deliberate decision he made was to choose people who had stuck with him over time
column10:
although others would have qualified also.

\r\n

Mr T had studied theology and film. He attended the EMBA Berlin School of Creative Leadership. He toyed with entrepreneurship since he was in school and while he was a student at the Buzau Theological Seminary he got to know the world of television
column11:
when he collaborated with a local station and also with the national TV station TVR on the Spiritual Life programme. He left in 2000 to establish ADV.

\r\n

In Romania
column12: the name of Mr T and ADV are linked to successful campaigns for brands like Timisoreana
column13: Alexandrion
column14: Bucovina
column15: Apa Nova
column16: Boom
column17: Cosmote
column18: Monte Banato
column19:
Omo and Millennium Bank.

\r\n

Mr T coordinated a successful communication campaign in over 10 election campaigns
column20:
five for the current Romanian President.

\r\n

In recent years
column21: ADV has crystallised its mission: ‘We help brands to help people.’ Thus
column22:
people are the centre of most brand communication and most of the brands ADV deals with focus on values.

\r\n

Background to restructuring events

\r\n

ADV is 100% focused on clients that have their activity in Romania and thus target Romanian customers. In 2009
column23: due to the deterioration of the economic conditions
column24: the majority of firms in Romania cut their advertising budgets. Naturally
column25: this affected most of ADV Advertising SR’s clients. The advertising budgets were the first ones to be cut for the majority of companies in Romania. The only examples where budgets have remained similar to previous levels were a few multinationals in telecommunications and gasoline distribution
column26:
according to ‘Ms I’. But even in those cases the duration of the economic crisis has forced even those companies to cut their advertising budget in 2011.

This meant in the first stage that for 2009 and 2010 the company had to accept smaller contracts and some clients gave up new advertising altogether. For 2009 Mr T was able to keep his entire staff and to pay them their salaries. In fact he hoped until the end of the year that the situation would turn around. But at the end of 2009 Mr T was facing a new year with fewer clients and much smaller advertising budgets. Thus at the end of 2009 he had to take some tough decisions.

Restructuring processes

At the end of 2009
column27: Mr T and his senior staff had to find ways to reduce costs. As in the case of other SMEs
column28: the financial crisis took Mr T by surprise. Also
column29: this was the first time he and his colleagues were facing a financial crisis as managers. They did not have a plan at first
column30:
they just had to cover ‘holes’ as they appeared. Action needed to be taken as the turnover had been falling constantly throughout the year and the prospects for 2010 were not encouraging.

\r\n

Some decisions were more obvious than others and implied less management involvement
column31: and thus were easier to take. As Mr T said
column32: he had no formal management training and thus he tried to find decisions that were easy to take from this perspective but also fast to implement and with less trauma for the employees. For example
column33: employees who resigned or were hired on temporary contracts were not replaced. The main costs besides salaries were identified as cost for supplies
column34:
rent and utilities. Mr T and his senior staff hoped that by looking at these costs first the economy will turn around and would not have to adjust any costs related to the personnel.

\r\n

Also
column35: some suppliers agreed to re-negotiate the contract terms even though it was before the official negotiating date stipulated in the contract. These negotiations between the management of ADV and its suppliers did not have direct implications for the employed staff. However
column36: as the company as a whole saved money and improved the cash flow the implications for the staff were long term as they kept their jobs. Among the suppliers that agreed to renegotiate were the phone provider
column37: the internet provider and the office equipment provider. But further adjustments were needed. Until 2009 the PR and the Advertising side were renting two different spaces. In 2010 Mr T took the decision to move both of them in one single space
column38: which was much cheaper. As the two business lines are connected
column39:
the new setup suited everyone. One added feature that was mentioned by Mr T and a favorite of the staff was that in the new location almost everyone had a parking space (parking is a serious problem in Bucharest).

\r\n

Mr T said that getting the suppliers to adjust their prices before the negotiating date stipulated in the contract was easier than he expected. On the one hand he had to deal with the same issue on his side as his clients demanded the same attitude from him. Thus
column40: he used his own situation of being forced to cut revenues to bring his suppliers to the negotiation table. The contracts were rewritten to include the new prices for supplies and services. There are two main points here: the date of the contracts was extended and in some cases the quantities of the supplies were increased in the later years of the contract. Of course
column41:
the only costs that could not be reduced were those with the utilities and that was one of the main reasons for relocation. In this way the utilities bill was reduced and as mentioned before there were improved results from the business lines synergies.

\r\n

As the recession dragged on new decisions to cut costs were needed. These decisions were harder to take and
column42: most importantly
column43: more difficult to convey to the staff. The least painful was to freeze salaries for six months at first and then for another six months. At the same time senior staff’s salaries were cut by 25% for six months. Also
column44: no bonuses were paid for 2009 and 2010. Understandably
column45: the reaction of employees to the salary freeze was at first bad. They all argued that their own bills have gone up and counted on higher wages. Unfortunately they did not have the same negotiating power to reduce their own costs as a big company has. However
column46: Mr T and Ms I had meetings with all employees
column47: explaining the financial situation of the company
column48:
the costs that were already cut and their view of the future of the company. They also presented scenarios with salaries increasing as before and salaries frozen (or cut as it was the case for senior staff). The staff attitude towards the salary freeze improved once all the information was presented to them. The alternative could have been that they all would have lost their jobs if they insisted on salary rises as in the boom years.

\r\n

Mr T completed the move to the new location in 2011. He also decided to share the space in the new location with another company
column49: an internet developer who had worked with them before
column50: to share the costs. The nature of Mr. T’s business is that it relies quite heavily on internet development. Both business lines
column51: advertising and PR
column52: have been relying more and more in recent years on internet development. Therefore
column53:
besides the costs argument there was also the business interest to bring in the same location the internet provider company that it is being used for 90% of the ADV’s projects.

\r\n

Challenges and constraints of restructuring

\r\n

As the restructuring process involved cutting and freezing wages
column54: there was a risk that some of the senior and professional staff would leave. Also
column55: there was a risk that the quality of work would suffer. Thus Mr T had to get involved in the day-to-day business of the agency more than ever before to demonstrate to the staff that the measures were temporary and necessary. For example
column56: any expense – lunch with a client or a pitch – had to be approved personally by him. He would participate at meetings with the most sensitive clients or senior staff. The purpose was twofold: to motivate his own staff but to make sure that he kept a personal relationship with clients in case one of his senior people would be offered an opportunity by a client or a competitor. He attended internal meetings with junior staff as well as senior staff. The staff were positive about this experience and took every opportunity to ask about the welfare of the company
column57: about new projects
column58:
about the future direction or about how to respond to different moves made by the competition. Mr T said that he expected his staff to enjoy his visits and interest in the details of the projects but he did not expect it to be ‘this much fun’.

\r\n

The other problem still faced by the agency was the still tough market conditions in a bad economic environment. In this environment Mr T was trying to acquire new clients to increase his business’ profitability. The challenge faced by Mr T was an obvious one and it is faced by all companies during economic crises: lower revenues due to lower budgets from clients (some going bankrupt) while costs were harder to cut. In this environment
column59: after cutting costs as much as possible the only way to increase profitability was to acquire new clients (if he wanted to stay in business and not wither away). On top of everything his agency lost one of the most important clients to a competitor. Also
column60:
the next election year was 2012 and thus no short-term political project was in sight.

\r\n

In the end he managed to bring in new clients
column61:
including a beer company who has been one of the more consistent accounts.

Restructuring advice and support

Mr T did not use outside advice or support throughout the restructuring process. He said that there were two reasons for this: he knows his company best and in Romania restructuring consultants are expensive and tend to specialise in big companies and financial institutions.

Outcomes of restructuring

Mr T had to implement some tough measures to keep his business alive. The crisis has hit the Romanian advertising market harder than anyone would have expected. Mr T knew that the measures were necessary to keep the company profitable. It was hard to get his staff on board but in the end he managed.

As a result ADV was able to return to profitability in 2010. It kept its key people and is now again winning new clients. It is important to note that the company remained profitable while the rest of the industry is still in the red.

In 2011
column62: the company moved to a new location
column63:
managed to increase salaries and to increase staff by 5%. The staff increase was related to a new account that the PR business line acquired at the beginning of 2011. Some of the staff hired for this project only had temporary work contracts. All of this was done even though 2012 was another a challenging year.

\r\n

Commentary

\r\n

Without any outside help
column64: Mr T has managed to survive and even improve the condition of his company during the ongoing economic crisis
column65: based on a programme of cost-cutting that included a salary freeze. He claims it shows that he knows his business best
column66:
but most importantly that he knows his people.

\r\n

The main lessons here are: in times of crisis make sure you keep your staff informed and motivated. Also
column67:
it helps if top management gets involved in the day-to-day work of the different projects as the staff feel empowered by this attitude.

Aktis, Greece~"Aktis S.A."~"

Employees of the Greek firm Aktis have been strongly involved in the process of setting up a joint venture with a Romanian partner. As their expertise was a crucial asset while the new production unit was set up in Romania
column2:
three or four employees had to move there in order to monitor the process and train their Romanian colleagues.

"~"

Organisational profile

Aktis S.A. is a company that has been in the construction industry for more than 20 years. Its main operations involve the development and application of new technologies in the field of road construction and maintenance
column3: both in Greece and in the Balkans. The company’s headquarters are located in Thessaloniki (northern Greece)
column4: while its production unit is in Romania. Another branch (administrative offices) of Aktis S.A. is also located in Romania
column5: in the capital city Bucharest
column6: in order to enable better monitoring of the local market (construction projects). The company operates a subsidiary firm in Bulgaria
column7: with Aktis engaged in projects there since 1992
column8:
hence exhibiting a strong orientation to international activities during the last 20 years.

\r\n

Since its foundation
column9: the company has continuously diversified its activities
column10: based on a commitment to invest in research and technological development and in quality assurance systems. Aktis has established effective cooperation with universities and research centres in Greece
column11:
which have driven the expansion of its scope so as to include the following activities/fields:

  • Maintenance and improvement of road pavement 
  • Traffic management and Intelligent Traffic Solutions (ITS) 
  • Routine Maintenance Management System (RMMS) using digital video 
  • Ground Radar Applications for non-destructive determination of the various layers of thickness of the pavement or rail base.

The company’s history dates back to 1975 when the company Vitoumina S.A. was founded by Aktis’ current managing director’s father and partners. Vitoumina was initially engaged in asphalt
column12: chemical and oil products processing and trading. In 1984
column13: the owners decided to develop the technical department
column14: and Aktis was founded as a subsidiary. The primary aim was to operate in the construction industry
column15: particularly road construction
column16: by utilising a core product that the parent firm was producing: a specialised emulsion. Since then
column17: Aktis has focused on an  innovative technique for road construction and maintenance – ‘slurry-sealing’ or ‘micro-surfacing’ –becoming the only company in Greece capable of performing this technique (now widespread in several European countries including Germany
column18: France and Spain). This competitive advantage enabled the company to participate in numerous public construction projects in Greece (for example
column19: ‘Macedonia’ airport’s runway maintenance in 2010 and the construction of slurry seal micro-surfacing on the Alexandroupoli–Kipoi section of the Egnatia Odos motorway) and in the Balkan region (for example
column20:
the maintenance of the national road network of Romania during the last 25 years).

\r\n

In 1991 the founder of the company decided to sell his shares in Vitoumina but retained ownership (together with four other owners) and the position of General Manager in Aktis
column21: which continued to operate autonomously
column22: even though it still constituted one of Vitoumina’s main clients until 2007–8. In the meantime
column23: his son entered the business and replaced him (as the new General Manager) in 2006
column24: while the founder still holds a position in the company’s managing board
column25: together with the four other owners. His son holds a PhD in economics in the field of economics of innovation and knowledge and worked in Brussels from 1998 to 2003 in the European Commission’s Directorate-General for Science
column26: Research and Development
column27:
before returning to Greece as Managing Director of Aktis S.A.

\r\n

The company has shown stable growth over the last 20 years
column28: with annual turnover during the last five years of €3 million. Almost 30 people are employed in Greece
column29: with up to 50 when projects require it
column30: especially during the summer period. However
column31: this number was recently reduced significantly
column32:
as company performance was severely affected by the ongoing economic recession in Greece. There is no collective employee representation; the majority of employees are highly specialised and well-experienced engineers.

Background to restructuring events

Aktis S.A’s innovative technique for road construction and maintenance is based on the utilisation of a specialised emulsion that constitutes the major raw material. This emulsion was exclusively produced by Vitoumina S.A. until 2007. Since then
column33: however
column34: Vitoumina experienced poor financial performance and extended debts
column35: and discontinued its operations after 2009. The current manager of Aktis was aware of this situation by 2004–5 and started worrying about the main supplier’s ability to produce this emulsion. Aktis examined alternative solutions to overcome this barrier – which could constitute an extremely significant problem in the near future
column36: since more than 1
column37: 000 tonnes were needed on an annual basis. At the same time
column38:
the company had acquired the knowledge and the skills required to produce this emulsion.

\r\n

During 2008
column39: the company undertook the completion of large-scale construction projects in Romania
column40: where the particular technique of ‘micro-surfacing’ is also known and used
column41: after tendering the lowest bid. The company’s collaborators in Romania had also informed the manager of Aktis that several other projects were to be put out to tender
column42:
as there were some ongoing discussions and preparations regarding the public assignment of construction projects to the lowest tenders.

\r\n

It was then obvious that Aktis should fully ensure access to the specialised emulsion if it was to participate in these tenders
column43: given that the company’s intention was to expand further in the Balkan region. The performance of the main supplier was a major barrier and
column44: thus
column45: the managing board decided that the best solution was to expand production of the emulsion through a vertical integration strategy. This decision was taken in 2008 during a meeting of the managing board
column46:
in which alternative options were discussed. The company acquired the specialised mechanical equipment needed to produce the emulsion. There remained the problem of where to install it.

\r\n

Alternatives were assessed
column47: as the managing board initially decided to install the equipment on land the company owns in the neighbouring Thessaloniki area (35 km from Aktis’ headquarters). However
column48: previous participation in numerous projects in Romania has shown that transportation costs could significantly raise total costs and in this case transportation of the emulsion to Romania would represent an additional cost of 75%
column49: which the company could not bear. Given the emerging opportunities in Romania
column50: as well as the extensive experience gained through participation in several projects there
column51: it was decided that installing the production unit there would constitute the most suitable solution
column52: since the business environment in Greece was deteriorating and prospects were less encouraging compared with Romania. Thus
column53: the company presents an example of a combination of restructuring events
column54: namely internal restructuring (that is insourcing and vertical integration)
column55:
as well as business expansion.

Restructuring processes

The restructuring decision was taken in 2008
column56: and it was further advanced after Aktis made the lowest bid for another construction project in Romania in April 2009. As soon as the owners realised the extremely positive prospects in the Romanian market and calculated the costs of the emulsion’s transportation there
column57: the managing board decided to install the recently acquired equipment
column58: which was a transportable production unit
column59: close to Bucharest
column60:
where Aktis had located a type of office premises in early 2009.

\r\n

The plan was to set up the production unit there in the next four months (April–July 2009)
column61: since the company had to complete a project in August 2009. The managing board decided that the production unit should be fully operational by that time
column62:
in order to enable the company to fully take advantage of it for this specific project and avoid additional (transportation) costs. Then the managing board decided that it was in the company’s interests to establish this production unit as a ‘separate’ company and different options were assessed.

\r\n

The company soon reached an agreement with a Romanian partner
column63: long engaged in subcontracting assignments and familiar to the managing director and his father since the early years of Aktis’ operations in this market. Thus
column64: a type of ‘consortium’ or ‘joint venture’ was founded
column65: in which Aktis and the Romanian partner contributed 50%. Aktis’ know-how
column66: as well as the recently acquired mechanical equipment
column67: formed the new company’s main assets
column68:
while the Romanian partner offered land and the containers needed to produce the specialised emulsion.

\r\n

This decision proved to be extremely helpful
column69: according to the Managing Director
column70: since the existence of the Romanian partner ensured that legal procedures would be followed without any problems
column71: while the two partners shared a common understanding owing to their extensive collaboration in the past
column72:
enhancing trust between the two sides.

\r\n

As soon as the decision was taken
column73: the managing director informed all employees about the process. There were no reactions from employees
column74: as most were used to travelling back and forth quite often during projects in Greece and abroad and the majority of employees were aware of the emerging opportunities in the Romanian market. As a result
column75: no significant problems were reported
column76: since there would be no reductions in employment. On the contrary
column77: employees were extremely active participants during the implementation of the restructuring event
column78: since their expertise was a crucial asset during the period April–July 2009 when the new production unit was set up in Romania. During this period
column79: some 3–4 employees had to move to Romania
column80:
in order to monitor the whole process and train their Romanian colleagues in the production of the specialised emulsion.

Challenges and constraints of restructuring

Despite extensive experience of operating in a foreign market
column81: there were some important challenges and constraints evident during the restructuring process. The first one was time – given that the production unit had to be set up in less than four months
column82: due to the company’s obligation to start working there in August 2009. As the managing director stated
column83: this constituted a significant source of pressure for everyone
column84: including the Romanian partner
column85:
given the increased workload imposed by the tight time schedule.

\r\n

Apart from the legal procedures that were necessary in order to form this joint venture in Romania
column86: which in the end did not constitute a problem
column87: given the involvement of the Romanian partner
column88: Aktis also had to ensure that the production unit and related equipment would be fully operational from the outset
column89: a fact that constituted a form of technical constraint. This was a major challenge
column90: since the Romanian partner lacked the skills and knowledge regarding the setting up and use of the acquired equipment. As a result
column91: several employees from Greece
column92: mainly technical staff
column93: had to visit the new production unit
column94: in order to monitor the process and train their Romanian colleagues. As one employee involved in this process stated
column95: this was not an easy task to perform
column96: since it required different skills and adaptation to a different working mentality for both parties. However
column97: their expertise proved to be a critical success factor since
column98: as the managing director admits
column99:
the procedure would pose several additional barriers if there was no valuable support from personnel employed in Greece.

\r\n

Moreover
column100: a financial constraint was also apparent
column101: since the company already had extended loan debts
column102: owing to the recent acquisition of other specialised equipment necessary to participate in projects outside Greece. However
column103: the managing board reached an agreement with a Greek bank to finance the investment through an equipment leasing scheme; this proved to be extremely helpful during the restructuring process and the general manager reported it to be a rather smooth process
column104: since the Greek banks were more supportive back then
column105: compared to the current situation
column106:
in which a general reluctance to finance Greek SMEs is evident.

Restructuring advice and support

The case study findings confirm the informal and internal character of restructuring events in Greek SMEs. The whole planning and execution process mainly involved the managing board
column107: the managing director and the employees. No external support was received in this case for two reasons: first
column108: public support instruments are not able to cover the needs of most Greek SMEs
column109: especially when a company decides to delocalise (parts of) its activities abroad. On the contrary
column110: this decision is considered a negative form of exit from the country
column111: as it usually results in decreasing employment. Second
column112: both the members of the managing board as well as the company’s employees (including those in Greece and the Romanian partner) have extensive experience through an active engagement in the sector in recent past years. As a result
column113: taking up private external assistance was not considered at all
column114:
at least in the sense of consulting services.

\r\n

Financial support received through the banking sector
column115: involving the equipment leasing agreement
column116: was an extremely significant factor for the successful implementation of restructuring. Despite that
column117: though
column118: the managing director holds a negative view of the banking sector’s functioning in Greece
column119: especially nowadays
column120: during the ongoing financial crisis. The agreement his company was able to reach in 2009 would not have been possible today
column121:
owing to the banks’ reluctance to support Greek SMEs even though they have received valuable financial support from the Greek government.

\r\n

The company managed to implement restructuring successfully by relying primarily on employees. This involved Greek employees commuting and training staff employed in Romania
column122: and reliance on employees whose expertise proved to be of crucial importance during the whole period of restructuring. An indicative example refers to a person previously employed on a contractual basis in Romania
column123: who is a chemical engineer and was actively involved in the process of setting up the production unit there. As the managing director of Aktis reported
column124: even though this collaboration pre-existed
column125: it was significantly intensified during the implementation period
column126:
in terms of workload and payment levels. The expertise of this chemical engineer was essential in order to complete the installation of the new mechanical equipment in Romania.

Outcomes of restructuring

The outcomes of restructuring are evaluated positively by both the managing director and by a representative of the employees
column127: since the number of employees remained the same in Greece and some 10 jobs have been created in Romania. Even though Aktis was not able to implement restructuring during the scheduled period
column128: this did not affect the evaluation of the process as a whole. The company was forced to continue with the transport of the specialised emulsion during the first half of the project in Romania
column129: while the remaining part was completed by using emulsion produced there. Obviously
column130: this has increased the total costs of the project
column131: but
column132: as the general manager stated
column133: this shift proved to be of crucial importance for the company's growth in the long run. Thus
column134:
these costs were covered by the savings achieved through the projects that followed.

\r\n

This shift proved to be of crucial importance
column135: since turnover enhanced financial performance and allowed the company to remain active and competitive. As the managing director argued
column136: the company would not have been able to survive in the current economic recession if it had not been for the internationalisation of the production process to Romania. Indicatively
column137: some 50% of turnover during 2011 was produced in this market
column138:
while achieving 30% reductions in total operating costs. These facts illustrate the successful implementation of restructuring and its positive outcomes for company performance.

\r\n

Future prospects in Romania create a certain level of optimism among the managing board of Aktis
column139: given that market opportunities are far less promising in Greece. The existence of the production unit in Romania
column140: and the establishment of the company’s branch there
column141: are likely to enhance future growth
column142: given their participation in several construction projects there. As a result
column143: the company can reap the benefits of specific competitive advantages in the neighbouring market
column144: a goal less achievable in Greece
column145:
since Aktis’ techniques are not always considered to form an advantage in the national market.

\r\n

A significant employment impact was recorded in Greece. On the one hand
column146: Greek workers were able to enjoy higher wage incomes
column147: given additional pay for working abroad. Added to that
column148: the company’s restructuring created some positive outcomes as far as skills and expertise are concerned. As one employee interviewed noted
column149: they had to turn themselves into trainers overnight in order to help their colleagues in Romania. This was a major challenge
column150: but one in which they proved to be successful
column151:
thus representing a form of workforce upgrading.

\r\n

Equally important are the experiences gained and the managerial lessons learned throughout the whole process. Specifically
column152: the managing director argued that
column153: despite extensive experience from working and collaborating with international companies
column154: the experience gained through restructuring is valuable. He is now aware of the legal procedures regarding the preparation of consolidated balance sheets
column155:
and he is also able to monitor the operation of a branch located in another country. The outcomes of the process are extremely positive for company operations and on a personal level as well.

Commentary

The case of Aktis illustrates a successful instance of vertical integration and expansion by Greek SMEs. This company has managed to fully implement the planned restructuring activities mostly owing to its extensive experience from operating in international markets
column156: the skills and abilities of employees
column157: and by exploiting its competitive advantage in a foreign market
column158: namely specialisation in an innovative technique. Hence
column159: this case seems to highlight that SMEs with a (previous) international orientation are more likely to establish their presence abroad through foreign direct investment
column160: due to the extensive networks of collaborators. Moreover
column161:
a high educational level and expertise of the owner/managing director and employees seem to form another critical success factor for companies that wish to expand their activities in international markets.

\r\n

The main reasons behind the decision to restructure were mostly associated with market specificities
column162: such as restricted access to raw materials
column163: and the lower operational costs of Balkan countries
column164: compared to Greece. Hence
column165:
these findings confirm the motivating role of cost differences in internationalisation.

\r\n

Added to that
column166: this case study highlights
column167: once more
column168: the informal and internal nature of restructuring among Greek SMEs. Most firms that implement a restructuring event rely primarily on their own strengths
column169: while the whole process is usually managed without a detailed plan
column170: as small firms are forced to seize any emerging opportunity. Receiving external assistance to reorganise an SME’s activity is rather unusual among Greek firms
column171: since
column172: as this case also illustrates
column173:
the role of the owner and employees are central in this process.

\r\n

Finally
column174: even though Aktis has managed to implement these radical changes successfully in a very short time and despite the fact that the main goals have been achieved
column175: the company faces difficulties accessing finance. This fact
column176: mainly due to the current economic crisis in Greece
column177:
confirms that financing constitutes one of the most significant barriers to growth in Greek SMEs. Restructuring cannot always succeed if this barrier is not removed.

column51: the unemployment rate in Prague-East
column52: the district in which Čelákovice is located
column53: was at 3.3%) In Uhlířské Janovice
column54: which is located further from Prague
column55: the work team is much more stable. (In December 2011
column56: unemployment in the Kutná Hora district was at a level of 9.2%) In spite of the fact that the Ukrainian employees are agency workers
column57: they are more stable and almost irreplaceable within the manufacturing process and hold higher positions
column58: usually as technicians
column59: tool setters
column60: and machine operators. Employee turnover has in fact displayed a certain degree of stabilisation
column61:
primarily in relation to the economic crisis.

\r\n

The company does not have a documented human resource development strategy. According to the executive officer
column62: a company such as Amirro does not need this type of strategy because training needs are met at the moment when they occur. As a result
column63: the company does not organise any external training for its employees. However
column64: as the company’s executive officer claims
column65: the employees learn internally within the company with the assistance of their supervisors and thus ensure their career progress (as can be proven in the case of several production employees). There have been no unions established at the company and there is no works council; however
column66: an effort is made to hold open discussions and information meetings (bi-weekly)
column67:
at which everyone has the opportunity to voice their personal opinions.

\r\n

Amirro’s executive officer defines his company as an international enterprise and emphasises that
column68: within the current environment
column69: maintaining a nationalist perspective and opinions does not serve any purpose. The deliveries of glass are provided by a Czech manufacturer; however
column70: that manufacturing plant is owned by the international concern AGC Glass Europe. As far as sales are concerned
column71: approximately 60% of production output is exported. The main Czech customers consist of international DIY chains; however
column72: the company is being forced out by cheaper (and lower quality) products imported from China. As a result
column73: Amirro no longer does business with Baumax and Globus. Further expansion to the German market is planned for the future
column74: aimed specifically at intermediate consumption. At the beginning of 2012
column75: the company began searching for a German partner
column76: as the company’s executive officer believes that his products are not as marketable under the Czech image. In addition
column77:
the large German market was the least impacted by the economic crisis.

\r\n

On the domestic market
column78: specifically through its company store in Prague
column79: Amirro does not achieve even 1% of its total sales turnover. It delivers 40% of its production nationally and the remainder is exported
column80: with 95% of the exports going to European Union countries. In the period 2009–2011
column81: turnover was stable at a level of CZK 90-95 million (€3.6-3.8 million). Prior to the economic crisis
column82: however
column83: turnover was approximately CZK 115 million (€4.6 million in 2008). The company estimated a turnover of CZK 120 million (€4.8 million) for 2009
column84: but many planned contracts were called off. An even larger drop in sales was prevented through the acquisition of new contracts. The company’s profits over the long term have been in the positive numbers
column85: with the exception of 2011
column86: when there was a CZK 2 million (€80
column87: 000) loss. In that particular year
column88: the company relied on one large customer who promised a turnover of CZK 15 million (€600
column90: but in the end the total was only CZK 7 million (€280
column91: 000) and during the interim period
column92:
the company’s smaller customers found different suppliers.

\r\n

In this crisis situation
column93: the company was looking for solutions which would increase its competitiveness. It focused on its weaknesses – an obsolete information system
column94:
inflexible employment of workers and low profitability of the plant in Uhlířské Janovice.

Background to restructuring events

Up to 2009 Amirro used a simple management system designed using Microsoft Access
column95: which collected data separately for production
column96: warehousing and accounting management. This data administration was performed internally. The way the system was set up caused many problems. In addition to the separate data flows
column97: the main problem was the inability to access instant information about production
column98: warehousing and despatching
column99: which made it impossible to react immediately to developments on the market. According to Mr Holejšovský
column100: in today’s fast-moving environment
column101: rapid access to information is invaluable
column102: particularly in relation to further production planning. In this respect
column103:
it is possible to say that the restructuring was a flexible response to changes in the market.

\r\n

The company has had employees working on the basis of short-term contracts since the very beginning (approximately 10% of the employees have such contracts
column104: while the rest of the staff have permanent contracts). However
column105: most of the short-term workers have been of foreign origin (mostly from Ukraine) and this fact caused some difficulties concerning the administration of these workers which required work permits
column106: complicated billing
column107: and other issues. Also the employment of such workers did not allow Amirro’s managers enough flexibility. When there was a lack of contracts
column108: there was not enough work for all the employees
column109:
but some of them could not be made redundant immediately as the notice period in the Czech Republic is two months.

\r\n

Prior to 2008 products produced in Uhlířské Janovice were very similar to those manufactured at the plant in Čelákovice. However
column110: the profitability of this production was low
column111: up to the point of loss
column112: due to the frequent flow of materials and information between this location and the central site in Čelákovice. Originally
column113: the company planned to shut down this manufacturing plant
column114: but due to a fairly capable work team and the lower wages in the region
column115:
a decision was made to maintain the production at the site with the condition that it would be rationalised. Therefore the managers of Amirro started to look for a new business opportunity for the plant in Uhlířské Janovice.

Restructuring processes

Two types of restructuring have taken place within the company. The first type
column116: outsourcing
column117:
was accomplished in two different ways: outsourcing IT services and workforce outsourcing. The company also underwent internal restructuring by means of shifting production between Čelákovice and Uhlířské Janovice and rationalising production.

\r\n

In 2009
column118: the company started cooperating with a Nymburk-based company with regard to the implementation of a new information system. The IT company was contracted on the basis of a recommendation of a friend of Mr Holejšovský. The existing hardware was
column119: however
column120: inadequate and a new server had to be purchased. By chance
column121:
at the same time CzechInvest (the investment and business development agency of the Czech Republic) published a call for projects which promoted ICT services in enterprises. The company decided to apply for a subsidy. The subsidy application was prepared in cooperation with an external company. It was subsequently approved and new hardware and software were installed in 2010. This made it possible to establish online interconnectivity between the production and the accounting modules for all three of the company’s sections (the production plants in Čelákovice and Uhlířské Janovice and the company store in Prague).

\r\n

The second form of outsourcing involved temporary agency workers. In 2009–2010 the company’s management decided to transfer all short-term workers to a temporary agency. The reason for taking this step was to ensure greater workforce flexibility
column122: to decrease the administrative demands associated with the employment of these workers
column123: and
column124: no less importantly
column125: to attain certain financial benefits as the use of agency workers is somewhat less expensive for the company. There was no written plan for implementation of this measure. The entire procedure took a few months from the date of the management announcement as only five people were transferred under the temporary work agencies. Concerning the opinion of the employees on the transfer
column126: their reactions were negative
column127: because their salary decreased after the transfer. Later
column128: all of the temporary workers who experienced the transfer left the company because of various reasons (return to their home countries
column129:
death of one worker) and now there are approximately 10 people in the company whose jobs are mediated by the temporary work agencies.

\r\n

As regards the internal restructuring or more specifically the rationalisation of the business activities of Amirro
column130: thanks to the acquisition of a contract to grind glass nail files for Blažek Glass s.r.o. in 2008
column131: the company was able to place this order in Uhlířské Janovice
column132: where there is no other activity now. After a switch in staff
column133: when an older less ambitious worker was replaced with a very capable younger employee (the older worker retired although he could have continued to work in Amirro in another position)
column134: work productivity increased greatly at this branch and the plant currently grinds approximately 150
column135: 000 nail files a month. This fact has allowed the production plant to be maintained
column136: and thereby also the jobs in Uhlířské Janovice. The number of employees has not
column137: however
column138: changed significantly since the acquisition of the contract because
column139: as explained above
column140:
productivity increased both in Uhlířské Janovice and Čelákovice.

\r\n

The project for implementing the information system was completed in 2010
column141: although the preparations for this project were started in cooperation with an external firm in 2009 and the running-in period for the system lasted several months after the project was physically completed at the end of 2010. The transfer of all hired personnel to the employment agency took place at the end of 2009 and the start of 2010. These workers continue to be hired also in 2012. The process of rationalising production at the Uhlířské Janovice plant took place from approximately 2008 to mid-2009. There was no precise plan for the above-mentioned restructuring steps – only several key points were documented. Mr Holejšovský believes that in the case of a company as small as this one
column142:
a very detailed plan is not necessary.

\r\n

The company’s employees certainly had to be informed about the implementation of the new information system in order to ensure a smooth conversion to the new system. In this regard
column143: the company cooperated with an external company for providing employee training. In addition
column144: there was one member of the work team who already had experience with the new system. Because the short-term workers have been working at the company since it was established
column145: the introduction of the new working arrangement which caused their transfer under the temporary work agencies
column146: was not anything new as far as the permanent staff was concerned. For this reason
column147: it was not necessary to provide extensive information about this change. Mr Holejšovský describes the relationships between the regular employees and the agency workers (who are Ukrainians for the most part) as peaceful and without animosity. The workers were informed in advance of the new focus of the production at Uhlířské Janovice in order to facilitate their preparation for the new production activities. In fact
column148: this information was gratefully received as
column149: at that time
column150:
some employees were feeling very uncertain about the future of operations in Uhlířské Janovice.

Challenges and constraints of restructuring

The company did not encounter any of the major problems sometimes associated with restructuring. In spite of a drop in salaries of workers who were transferred to a temporary work agency
column151: Mr Holejšovský did not notice any decrease in the productivity of workers. There was only an error made by the consultancy firm at the time the subsidy application was prepared
column152: when it did not take note of a change in the methodological instructions for holding a tender and thus the correct procedure was not followed during the tender for the information system and
column153: as a result
column154:
the tender process had to be completed at a later date. Otherwise Mr Holejšovský is not aware of any serious errors that affected the restructuring.

Restructuring advice and support

A subsidy from the Industry and Enterprise Operational Programme provided 60% of the financing for the purchase of the hardware and the software required for implementing the company’s new information system. The total subsidy received was CZK 1
column156: 844 (approximately €64
column157:
000). A loan corresponding to the amount of the subsidy was used for the advance financing for the project. It was not a big problem (concerning negotiations with a bank) to obtain it. The remaining restructuring steps either did not require any financing or the company financed them from its standard operational loan.

\r\n

Other than the financial support
column158: which Mr Holejšovský considers to have been very beneficial
column159: the company’s executive officer did not feel the need for any special support for the restructuring processes. The company did
column160: however
column161: take advantage of support provided in the form of information at the time the subsidy application was prepared
column162: both from the firm that actually prepared the application as well as from the firm that is currently responsible for administering the company’s information system and which also defined the system requirements for the subsidy application. However
column163: for future cooperation with consultancy firms
column164: Mr Holejšovský recommends selecting only a firm with a good reputation on the market in the interest of preventing any possible misunderstandings. There was a slight problem with the subsidy application for the implementation of the information system
column165: when the consultancy firm did not take note of a change in the methodological instructions for the tender proceedings and
column166: as a result
column167: the proper procedure was not followed in the tender for the information system. Fortunately this problem did not evoke the necessity of resubmitting the application; however
column168:
the provided subsidy had to be cut correspondingly.

Outcomes of restructuring

The benefit of the new information system was summarised by the company’s accountant
column169: Jitka Müllerová (almost ten years employed in Amirro). As an accountant
column170: she has abundant experience with the new information system as well as with the situation prior to the time it was implemented. Mrs Müllerová mentions that the new information system has made her job much easier. Before
column171: she had to complete analyses using data from numerous sources
column172: which was demanding from the perspective of time and also very stressful. Thanks to the interconnectivity between the production and accounting modules
column173:
she can export the required data almost instantaneously. The implementation of a barcode system made it possible to obtain immediate data and the company switched over to a just-in-time manufacturing strategy. Another benefit of the barcode system was the introduction of a motivational programme for employees which is based on observation of the employee performance.

\r\n

Although the search for an ideal setting of the motivation system is still in progress
column174: this change enabled growth of the productivity of work and also most of the workers perceived it positively. There are various reasons for this. Firstly
column175: no punishment for defective work has been implemented. Secondly
column176:
the whole production process is better arranged now. The workers can immediately control the amount of already completed products and they do not need to rely on lists on paper or in the head of a foreman.

\r\n

Outsourcing of temporary agency workers will lead to significantly high savings in labour costs during periods when there is a lack of orders. As far as the hired workers are concerned
column177: from the point of view of Mrs Müllerová
column178: the fact that they are hired through an employment agency has made her administrative tasks much easier (before
column179: the company had to obtain work permits
column182:
etc.).

\r\n

Internal restructuring in the form of rationalisation and redeployment of production has created a clear division of tasks between the two Amirro plants in Čelákovice and Uhlířské Janovice. This led to significant savings in the costs associated with transporting materials and preservation of approximately 25 jobs in Uhlířské Janovice.

\r\n

Although there was no written restructuring plan and all the restructuring steps proceeded on the base of verbal communication
column183:
Mr Holejšovský says that it is advisable for the communications between members of the management involved in the restructuring to be documented at least in the e-mail system in order to prevent possible misunderstandings.

\r\n

According to Mr Holejšovský
column184: the restructuring steps that were completed fulfilled their purpose. At the time they were implemented
column185: the aim of the restructuring measures was not to guarantee immediate growth
column186: but rather to stabilise the company during the economic crisis and to prepare it for future growth. The individual forms of restructuring that were selected made a significant contribution towards this objective. The new information system made it possible to improve the effectiveness of production thanks to setting up a motivational programme for employees (bonuses based on employee performance). In addition
column187: it was possible to preserve the production operations at the Uhlířské Janovice location. Production is now managed in a much more sophisticated manner
column189:
and the company is prepared for further expansion.

\r\n

Although the number of employees continues to be more or less the same
column190: if the production programme for the Uhlířské Janovice plant had not been modified
column191:
it is most likely that production operations would have been completely terminated at this location and all the employees would have been made redundant.

\r\n

Mrs Müllerová was trained to use the new information system without any problems. The changes associated with the hiring of agency workers became more apparent in the company’s administrative section. The individual permanent employees and agency workers were not affected in any way
column192: as the regular employees were already accustomed to hired workers from the Ukraine (in addition
column193: many of these workers have been at the company for a long time). As far as Uhlířské Janovice is concerned
column194: Mrs Müllerová is glad that production operations were maintained – all in all
column195:
she also benefits from this.

No employees were let go as a result of the restructuring if they were performing their work obligations conscientiously. All the redundancies in the period of restructuring related to the natural turnover of employees. The employees’ reactions to the restructuring processes were therefore all positive (especially in Uhlířské Janovice) and the restructuring changes were only for the better.

Commentary

Mr Holejšovský claims that small and medium-sized enterprises are much more flexible during the restructuring process than is the case with larger companies because SMEs are not as bound by various regulations
column197: etc. during the restructuring process. On the other hand
column198: SMEs lack the expert personnel who would be able to draw attention to the possible risks associated with restructuring steps. As a result
column199: large enterprises can more easily determine the expected results of the restructuring. In addition
column200: they have fewer problems with access to bank loans (the bank that provides Amirro with its operational loan is starting to have more concerns with regard to providing credit to the company for future years
column201:
in spite of the company’s almost completely stable financial results).

\r\n

Mrs Müllerová shares the same opinion as Mr Holejšovský concerning the flexibility of SMEs which is the main advantage of small and medium-sized enterprises due to their flat organisational structure. Many agreements can be reached ‘over lunch’. On the other hand
column203:
certain decisions made within such a small group can be too hasty.

\r\n

When asked if he has any recommendations for other small and medium-sized enterprises
column204: Mr Holejšovský referred to the current turbulent global economic environment. He said that certainty is required
column205: as uncertainty will require further restructuring. In this regard
column206: he mentioned such things as currency exchange fluctuations
column207: which have a great impact on business success (in the past
column208: the company exported products valued at almost CZK 40 million (approximately €1.6 million) to Russia
column209: but when the dollar weakened in relation to the crown
column210: this was no longer worthwhile and now hardly any products are exported to Russia). For this reason
column211: Mr Holejšovský supports the implementation of the euro in the Czech Republic and has already partially converted to using this particular currency – other than for employee salaries and sales
column212:
he conducts all business only in euros. Mr Holejšovský also notes that it is necessary to always be flexible and to respond quickly to market requirements – it is necessary to remain consistently active with regard to seeking out investment companies.

The third solution was rejected

Thus

Restructuring processes

The family moved fast regarding the acquisition and
column78: as a result

\r\n

The new owners identified several weaknesses in the new company such as low productivity

These measures were announced by the management as soon as the new owners came into business

\r\n

By applying a combination of restructuring measures
column113: such as acquisition

column115: internal restructuring and insourcing

column117: while the major goal of focusing on artistic marble processing could be secured. However
column118: a detailed plan and timetable was not prepared

to set milestones for each procedure and implement the necessary changes until the end of the year.

Challenges and constraints of restructuring

A major challenge in these restructuring events centred on the managing board’s ability and experience to perform such a combination of radical changes in the newly formed company. As the managing director stated
column123: things proved to be more difficult and complex at the end than they seemed at first. Specifically
column124: one significant challenge was the legal status of the company (S.A. – unlimited liability)
column125: whose management is different and requires enhanced skills and capabilities
column126: compared to a ‘general partnership’ (that is
column127: limited liability type of business). As the general manager reported
column128: the expenses related to the publication of annual financial data – which is obligatory for an S.A. – are much higher than expected
column129:
while the same is true for other operational expenses. The managing board was not fully aware of these specificities and this proved a hindrance to the successful implementation of restructuring.

\r\n

The owners were also not fully aware of the work mentality and the productivity rates among the acquired company’s personnel. As a result
column130: they were forced to implement some changes related to the number of employees (firings and hirings)
column131: which resulted in some unexpected expenses in the form of compensation. However
column132: the total number of employees remained roughly the same
column133: as five people left the company and four new employees came into the business. These changes prolonged the restructuring event
column134: given they were not planned from the outset. Additionally
column135: it created some psychological pressures among the remaining workforce and the owners had to (re)establish an effective communication link in order to improve their relationship with employees. Specifically
column136: as one employee mentioned
column137: there was a 'certain air of tension' between the new owners and the employees
column138: given that the new measures (firings
column139: hirings
column140: and wage reductions) were announced as soon as the former took over the management of the company. Hence
column141: an anxiety was evident as well as a rather negative attitude towards the new management
column142: which led the owners to apply some measures to mitigate the negative results (for example
column143:
daily communication with the employees in order to confirm that no more firings would be made).

\r\n

Another constraint involved the absence of any type of ‘external’ assistance regarding the management of the whole process. As the managing director admitted
column144: the lack of an efficient advisory service constituted a major problem
column145: given that the owners lacked the expertise or previous restructuring experience. Both the scope and the intensity of the implemented changes
column146: combined with the strategic reorientation that was necessary
column147: rendered the utilisation of external assistance extremely significant
column148: especially in terms of legal and strategic management consulting services. However
column149: this could not be achieved either through the public or the (local) private sector. This is why the managing director is seeking cooperation with a consultancy company in Thessaloniki
column150: even though he believes this will be extremely difficult
column151: owing to the peculiarities of the marble processing industry
column152:
which should be taken into account in order to plan and execute a programme with realistic and achievable goals.

\r\n

The timing of the restructuring event constituted another major constraint in two different ways. First
column153: the deteriorating business environment
column154: due to the economic crisis in Greece
column155: put extended pressures on sales
column156: as regards the standardised production line in particular (for example tiles). On the one hand
column157: it caused a reduction in sales in the national market (in the firm’s particular market segment)
column158: while
column159: on the other hand
column160: it affected levels of trust among foreign clients and created pressures regarding price levels. As the managing director stated
column161: orders would be completed through a single phone call or fax before the crisis
column162: but now the procedure has become much more complex
column163: since international companies have become more ‘suspicious’ of Greek companies. Obviously
column164: this has affected implementation and the success of restructuring
column165: in that it harmed the particular market segment that the owners believed would support diversification into artistic marble processing. Specifically
column166: the general manager stated that his family believed that sales of the company (referring to exports to wholesalers
column167: that is 'standardised production') would provide the necessary capital to invest in the 'artistic marble processing industry'
column168: something that was not achieved
column169:
given the economic downturn that affected export sales after 2010.

\r\n

Second
column170: the rental of the quarry to ensure access to raw materials has not yet proved to be a suitable solution
column171: for environmental reasons. Specifically
column172: the winter of 2011 was one of the worst recorded in Drama and heavy snow hampered the quarrying of marble in satisfactory quantities due to heavy snow. Hence
column173: the owners are not in a position to predict the volume of future production. As the general manager reported
column174:
some two or three fully operational months of quarrying are needed in order to be able to predict the future levels of extracted raw materials.

Restructuring advice and support

The restructuring process was exclusively developed and managed by the three family members. This is attributed to the lack of public or private sector support
column175: at least in the type of consultancy or financing mechanisms that were essential in the specific case. Hence
column176: the owners relied primarily on their own skills and experience
column177: while support was received internally from an employee
column179: who has worked for BM during the past years. His help was valuable
column181: in the sense of providing advice and support related to the evaluation of the financial performance of the target company
column182: even though a relative lack of expertise was evident in this case as well
column183: as this person has been working with the family in their previous business (that is a ‘limited liability’ type) and he was not always able to assist them in the management of the acquired company
column184:
due to differences (in the legislative framework) between the two types of companies.

\r\n

Thus
column185: apart from the necessity of a specialist consultant who could advise the owners as regards the strategic reorientation of the company as a whole
column186: a significant need emerged vis-à-vis the procedure of buy-out and management of the acquired firm. The managing director identified several differences with regard to expenses in a company of this specific legal type (S.A.) that were not foreseen. This lack of experience constituted a significant barrier to restructuring that has augmented the need for an external consultant
column187: for whom the firm would pay. This need is related to management and the evaluation of alternative growth strategies that can be implemented and executed in the near future. However
column189: the company has not had access to this particular type of support
column190:
either through the public or the private sector.

\r\n

Regarding public support
column191: the instruments available at national level primarily target the establishment or restructuring of larger companies and
column193: the managing director stated that alternative options were assessed (such as building a new production unit). However
column195: the extended delays and the bureaucratic procedures that characterise the Greek administrative system as regards the business environment were reported as being the greatest obstacle. Thus
column196: even though financial assistance was required during the restructuring event
column197:
the owners decided to rely mainly on family backing in the form of private capital injections. The major concern reported relates to the means that could assist – especially the smaller – Greek firms to overcome the barriers created by the recession and deteriorating business opportunities.

Outcomes of restructuring

The assessment of financial results during the first year after restructuring produces a mixed picture. The managing director stated that none of the goals have been entirely met
column199: the economic crisis has severely affected the company’s annual sales in the standardised products market. Moreover
column200: it has also created enormous pressures for price discounts mainly from foreign customers
column201: such as international trading companies. Given the undifferentiated nature of products in this market
column202: their demand exhibits a strong price elasticity
column203: which has also increased competition from neighbouring producers
column204: such as those in Bulgaria. The general manager stated that
column205: partially as a result of the crisis
column206: competition from Bulgarian competitors has increased
column207: as they have been able to enter the local and national market. This rising competition has undoubtedly affected restructuring outcomes
column208: at least in this market segment
column209:
which was not fully appreciated prior to restructuring.

\r\n

Restructuring has also affected the employment side: five employees of the acquired firm have been made redundant
column210: while a wage reduction scheme was also brought in for inexperienced or less skilled employees. On the one hand
column211: these procedures have improved financial performance
column214: have created anxiety among the remaining workforce. It is worth mentioning that there is a continuing legal dispute between the company and a dismissed employee over the compensation offered to him. Even though this was a single incident
column216: both in qualitative and quantitative terms
column217: restructuring can pose to employment. On the other hand
column218:
there have not been any direct impacts on the initial employees of BM.

\r\n

The vertical integration efforts
column219: which involved quarry rental to ensure access to raw materials
column220: cannot be assessed positively so far. However
column221: given declining orders in the standardised products’ market
column222: it might have not constituted a major problem until today
column223: as customer demand could be covered by relying on long term supplier networks. Indeed
column225: a certain level of worry was observed regarding the outcome of this decision
column226: particularly about the exact levels of materials to be extracted
column227:
since the owners are not yet able to estimate them.

\r\n

On the other hand
column228: the outcomes of the restructuring  are evaluated in a more optimistic manner by both the managing director and an employee who was also interviewed
column229: regarding productivity rates and employees’ working mentality. Specifically
column230: the owners have successfully implemented changes involving the knowledge and skills of the personnel by clearly demonstrating a different management culture that can also enhance the upgrading of the workforce. This is related to the new machinery in the production unit
column231: whose operation requires new employee skills
column232: as well as to the different environment in which the company functions
column233: which is more internationalised but also more family-orientated
column234: thus ensuring a more favourable working environment. As one employee said: ‘It feels good to see a family working here all day long
column236: compared to the previous situation. The previous owners were almost invisible here. Hence
column237:
the current situation certainly creates a family-like atmosphere for all of us working here’.

\r\n

At the same time
column238: outcomes are more promising as regards the artistic marble processing segment. A major goal
column239: which involved the installation and exploitation of previously idle mechanical equipment
column241: offering the company a major opportunity to expand in this market
column242: where competition is less intense and profit margins are considerably higher. This area constitutes a strong competitive advantage
column243: while it has also allowed the owners to fully take advantage of their experience and expertise
column244:
a fact that constitutes a major positive impact of the restructuring process.

\r\n

Hence
column245: the owners are currently in the phase of inducing further changes in the future
column246: which illustrate the ‘learning by doing’ fashion in the case of this particular case of restructuring. The outcomes so far could be characterised as moderate and even though certain goals have not been achieved
column247: the owners are optimistic they will manage to overcome the barriers
column248:
even if the process is prolonged.

Commentary

The case of Bairaktaris Marble S.A. constitutes a good example of restructuring among smaller firms in Greece. It is characterised by an extended mix of actions and types of restructuring events (that is internal restructuring
column251: combined with the relatively small size of the firm and the low levels of experience related to implementing radical changes. It clearly demonstrates the need for external assistance (especially in the form of consulting services) and possible barriers for smaller firms
column252:
such as restricted access to finance and lack of consultancy experts specialised in particular sectors.

\r\n

Partially as a result
column253: the process is managed by the owners
column254: which confirms the general argument regarding their ‘hegemonic’ role in the management of smaller firms. At the same time
column255: lack of expertise and experience does not seem to hinder the restructuring efforts per se
column257: as the case of BM illustrates
column258: owners and managers in these smaller firms are often forced to implement radical changes in their businesses even though they lack the experience. However
column259: they are able to proceed by employing a ‘learning by doing’ approach and by relying on the company’s internal strengths
column260: even in the absence of a well-defined and accurate plan
column261:
given that there are often factors that cannot be foreseen.

\r\n

At the same time
column262: the case of BM showcases the vulnerability of smaller firms to the deteriorating business environment
column263: such as the one currently prevailing in Greece during times of economic crisis. In turn
column265: in the form of redundancies or wage reductions
column266: which seem to be the only solution
column269:
given their limited access to finance that is further restricted during this financial recession mainly by the banking sector.

Authors

Lois Labrianidis and Nikos Vogiatzis
