column1:
Boutiquehotel Stadthalle Wien, Austria~"Boutiquehotel Stadthalle Wien"~"

The owner/manager of the Austrian Boutiquehotel Stadthalle Wien was surprised by the media interest that was sparked when she expanded her premises to make it the first zero-energy-balance hotel in Vienna. By taking advantage of this
column2: she achieved national and international awareness for her hotel. Two to three years after the restructuring
column3: her company’s performance is not only considerably higher than anticipated
column4:
but the hotel has also received several awards and has been the subject of numerous national and international press articles.

"~"

Organisational profile

The Viennese three-star Boutiquehotel Stadthalle Wien is the world’s first zero-energy balance (ZEB) hotel in urban areas. The hotel has 80 rooms
column5: 38 of which are located in a new building
column6:
the construction of which is the subject of this case study.

\r\n

Respect for nature and its resources can be seen in all the company’s activities. For example
column7: the hotel uses solar energy for heating and rain water for toilet flushes. Guests are also offered a 10% reduction on their room price if they travel by train or bike. If they have electric cars they can charge them for free at the hotel’s electric fuel station. Also
column8: the substantial breakfast buffet consists
column9: as far as possible
column10:
of organic food.

\r\n

Michaela Reitterer is the sole owner and manager of the HS Hotelbetriebs GmbH of the Boutiquehotel Stadthalle Wien which administers the hotel and the real estate. Furthermore
column11: she is the chair of the Österreichischen Hotelvereinigung (ÖHV)
column12: the Austrian association of hotels. Before she bought her parents’ business in 2002
column13:
she ran a travel agency and worked as assistant to the chief executive officer of a catering company.

\r\n

The Boutiquehotel Stadthalle Wien employs 32 staff members
column14: which corresponds to 26 full time equivalents. Skilled and unskilled workers as well as administrative staff are active in four areas: housekeeping
column15: breakfast service
column16:
reception and utilities management. There is no works council in the company.

Background to restructuring event

In 2002
column17: Michaela Reitterer bought the hotel ‘Zur Stadthalle‘ from her parents and decided to consider ‘environmental awareness’ as the main vision of the company. Her parents were already interested in this issue and their hotel had been certified with the Austrian ‘Ecolabel’. Michaela Reitterer wanted to follow this route. Just after taking over the hotel in 2002 she had a solar energy plant installed. It is important personally for her to use natural resources and environmentally friendly and protective measures as far as possible
column18:
even if this does not immediately result in financial savings for the business.

\r\n

In spite of the fact that
column19: with the solar energy plant and the other environmentally friendly measures
column20: the hotel was already the leading hotel with regard to the environment and sustainability in Vienna at this time
column21: Ms Reitterer did not feel these measures were sufficient. Consequently
column22: in 2007 she started planning a ZEB hotel which was to be an expansion of the initial company. At the same time
column23:
the original hotel was to be renovated to guarantee a coherent character of the whole company.

The aim of the restructuring was to increase the level of ecological sustainability the company was already embracing. Michaela Reitterer was more inspired by her personal interest in using natural resources than by the business idea.

Restructuring processes

Next door to the hotel which Ms Reitterer had bought from her parents
column24: there was a residential building in a poor structural condition
column25:
which she also owned. She decided to have this demolished and a new hotel building erected in its place to expand the existing company. This new building was planned as a ZEB hotel.

\r\n

When Ms Reitterer started in 2007 to develop her idea for a ZEB hotel
column26: she soon realised that this was nationally and internationally an innovative issue. Environmental considerations were not yet very widespread in tourism or the economy in general
column27: but there was increasing interest. Accordingly
column28:
there were hardly any experts available for her to approach.

\r\n

As a consequence
column29: it was mainly Michaela Reitterer who planned the new building
column30: in cooperation with a technical planner and an architect. She describes the development of the ideas as a joint process. In the beginning
column31: she pinpointed her objectives and received feedback from the technical planner and the architect regarding the feasibility and implementation of  her ideas. However
column32: the two soon realised what Michaela Reitterer wanted and made suggestions themselves. Some of them were incorporated
column33:
some rejected. In the later process – during the construction site meetings – other craftsmen and specialists involved in the construction of the new building also made suggestions that were jointly evaluated.

\r\n

The planning phase took about one year
column34:
during which Michaela Reitterer met the technical planner and the architect about every two to four weeks. The entrepreneur describes this process as ‘intensive’.

\r\n

During this year
column35: the required construction and operating approvals were applied for and received. Long waiting periods were experienced. However
column36:
this did not delay the progress of the project.

\r\n

At the end of 2008
column37: the construction of hotel began. The new six-storey building had 38 guest rooms. It was concrete with a façade specific to a ZEB house. The new building is a stand-alone structure
column38: linked to the initial hotel only in the cellar and the ground floor. Plastic pipes through which water is circulated were installed in the massive ceilings and walls
column39: enabling controlled heating and cooling. Furthermore
column40:
a photovoltaic plant was installed.

\r\n

During the construction of the new building
column41: the original hotel was also renovated (being given for example
column42: a new heating system
column43: new windows
column44: and LED lighting) to ensure a coherent and authentic link between the existing hotel and the new building. At the beginning of the renovation
column45:
the original hotel was completely closed. During this period guests were accommodated in a nearby little boarding house also belonging to Ms Reitterer. One of the rooms of the boarding house was temporarily used as an office to administer sales and reception.

\r\n

Of the 18 staff members working at this time at the hotel
column46: about six or seven were employed in the boarding house during the renovation. These were mainly receptionists and cleaners. The other employees were temporarily dismissed (for differing durations
column47: but with a maximum of four months)
column48: but given a written offer of reemployment. After completion of the renovation
column49: all of them were reemployed. The employees could freely choose whether they wanted to be employed during the renovation or not
column50: and the majority opted for a brief break which was
column51: for example
column52:
used for travel or child care.

\r\n

The atmosphere within the staff was positive
column53: even somewhat euphoric due to the opportunity of participating in such an innovative project. This can
column54: for example
column55:
be shown by the fact that the temporarily dismissed workers repeatedly visited the construction site to see the progress.

\r\n

As the renovation progressed an increasing number of rooms were rented in the original hotel
column56:
and hence the business activity and employee number increased. Potential guests were clearly informed that construction was taking place and prices were adjusted accordingly. These ‘facelift prices’ were favourable for the guests and also cost-effective for the hotel. With the progress of the construction – and the quieter it became – prices were increased again.

\r\n

The construction of the new building
column57: for which Ms Reitterer herself conducted the site supervision
column58:
lasted about 11 months. The opening of the new building took place on 27 November 2009.

\r\n

When Michaela Reitterer developed her restructuring idea in 2007
column59: she was aware that her ZEB hotel would be the first in Vienna
column60: but she was not aware that she would also take a leading role in city tourism internationally. Accordingly
column61: as soon as her idea became public she was surprised about the media interest. Nevertheless
column62: she immediately took advantage of this for marketing purposes
column63:
to achieve national and international awareness for her hotel.

\r\n

The restructuring was financed by a leasing company which drew up an agreement relatively quickly
column64: and without major difficulties. The leasing company recognised the innovation and appreciated it
column65:
and it saw some potential for know-how and knowledge transfer for itself.

Challenges and constraints of restructuring

A challenge in the restructuring process was the novelty of the idea. Michaela Reitterer repeatedly encountered people who made statements like ‘this cannot be done
column66: as such a thing does not yet exist’. This resulted
column67: for example
column68: in long durations before required authorisations were granted as the authorities had to be convinced about the new ideas first
column69: or there were no any standardised procedures for authorisation. Other challenges were the refusal of the banks to finance the project as the innovative concept was considered as unrealistic or too optimistic
column70:
and the very limited access to public financial support.

\r\n

Another aspect of the novelty of the idea was that there were no or hardly any experts in the field for Ms Reitterer to consult. This situation has since improved
column71:
and due to her experience the entrepreneur now knows specialists in various fields who can support her in the further development of her ideas.

Restructuring advice and support

Michaela Reitterer involved a technical planner and an architect in the planning of the ZEB building. The technical planner was recommended to her by the environmental advisor who awarded her the Austrian Ecolabel. The technical planner
column72: in turn
column73:
recommended an architect with whom he had already built a ZEB building.

\r\n

She was very satisfied with this cooperation and would happily work again with this team
column74:
despite the fact that there are now more experts in this field.

\r\n

Further support from private consultants was not used. Ms Reitterer carried out all meetings/discussions with banks or authorities herself and conducted the construction site supervision.

\r\n

She received a small financial grant from the city of Vienna for the erection of the photovoltaic plant. However
column75: this was paid for two years after it was built. Furthermore
column76: she received a small grant from the climate energy fund
column77:
stemming from EU funds.

\r\n

With regard to public support the entrepreneur wishes
column78: first of all
column79: that she could have had better understanding and open-mindedness from the authorities
column80:
followed by financial support and technical advice.

Outcomes of restructuring

The new building not only expands the original hotel but also offers a zero-energy balance. The hotel heating uses water heated by a 130 m2 solar energy plant. A ground-water heating pump
column81: three wind wheels and the more than 80 m2 of large photovoltaic plant create so much energy that not only can the energy needs of new hotel be entirely served
column82: but energy can also be emitted to the original hotel and the ecological electric supply network. The filling of the toilets’ flushing tanks as well as the watering of the garden is done through a rain water collection system. The fresh air for the controlled air conditioning is warmed by a solar energy plant
column83: and during the summer the building can be cooled by cold ground water which is pumped through the concrete ceiling. Thereby
column84: the company does not have to use energy-consuming air conditioning
column85:
and energy consumption is also reduced by the use of LED and energy saving lighting reduces.

\r\n

In 2012
column86: more than two years after the restructuring
column87: company performance (guest numbers and sales) is about 20% higher than initially expected. The new building and the renovation of the initial hotel resulted in a doubling of the hotel’s capacity which also led to an increase of the number of employees from 18 to 32. New positions were also created
column88:
such as a quality manager and a person responsible for dealing with social media.

\r\n

At the same time
column89: it has to be mentioned that the company restructuring brought about changes for the employees which were not thought of as positive by all of them. There were
column90: for example
column91: staff members who could not cope with the higher pressures related to the now larger hotel. Two of the initial workers left the company for this reason
column92: which can be seen as negligible
column93: bearing in mind the generally high staff fluctuation in tourism. However
column94:
there are also employees who feel the current hectic business activity is inspiring and for whom the visits from ministers or EU clerks as well as the media spotlight on the hotel is motivating and rewarding.

\r\n

Before the restructuring
column95: the entrepreneur expected the changes to improve business. However
column96: she did not expect that the results would be so positive. Business development and progress are now also closely monitored (sales
column97: number of guests)
column98:
and marketing is strategically conducted.

\r\n

The restructuring was carried out according to the initial concept
column99: but went beyond this in some fields as it was only during construction that some aspects materialised which the entrepreneur could not have foreseen. For example
column100: it became gradually apparent that the guests expected breakfast to be organic
column101: although this is only in a wider context related to the ecologically sustainable concept of the hotel. Nevertheless
column102: this concept was developed in a flexible way
column103: based on demand. To a certain extent also diversification can be seen to have taken place
column104:
as next to the hotel’s day to day business activities now there are also activities related to ecological sustainability. For example there are daily tours of the hotel to show the innovations to interested people.

\r\n

From a personal point of view
column105: the process of planning and implementing the restructuring was a very intensive process for the entrepreneur. However
column106: she did not experience this as such
column107:
as she worked towards her objective in a very concentrated way. Only at the end did she realise how exhausting the process had been.

\r\n

The company is the role model for environmental friendliness and sustainability in tourism in Vienna and has been awarded the EU Ecolabel as well as with numerous Austrian eco awards (for example
column108: Ecolabel of the Republic of Austria
column109: eco award of the city of Vienna
column110: climate protection award
column111: Green Brands Certificate). Furthermore
column112: the hotel is showcased in numerous national and international press articles and events as a successful practical example of what can be done in this field. Ms Reitterer presumes that the reason for this interest from institutions and media is based on the tangibility and the success of her project. Her example shows that measures for ecological sustainability are not only theoretical scenarios
column113:
but can be realised in practice and work well.

\r\n

Together with her team
column114: Michaela Reitterer again and again initiates new projects
column115:
particularly to raise awareness among international guests on the topic of sustainability and environment. As a sign of success the entrepreneur would like to further expand the hotel..

Commentary

The restructuring of the company was a very ambitious undertaking as there were no national or international reference projects for the entrepreneur to follow. However
column116: Michaela Reitterer was of the opinion that somebody needed to make the first step and was willing to take this role. She wanted to show colleagues in the industry
column117: guests
column118: banks and supporting authorities that such an undertaking not only is ecologically valuable and economically sound
column119: but can also set an example for Austrian tourism. To other people thinking of following her example
column120: Ms Reitterer recommends not getting diverted by scepticism from authorities or banks about innovative entrepreneurial ideas
column121:
but to question this scepticism in order to arrive at a situation in which arguments and discussions are purely factual.

\r\n

The entrepreneur mentions the support and motivation of her employees as an important success factor for the restructuring. In this respect
column122: it is important to communicate to the staff from the very beginning the reasons and plans for the restructuring and to get their commitment. A personal management style
column123: as well as the personal commitment by the entrepreneur
column124: are good ways of achieving this. At the same time
column125: the individual needs of employees need to be considered
column126:
for example by offering job security if such is necessary while finding other motivators (such as the possibility to participate in innovative developments) if this is more suitable.

\r\n

Also the optimal timing – to be involved from the very beginning in a new development which later on proved to be seminal – considerably contributed to the success of the new idea.

\r\n

The entrepreneur sees an important difference between SMEs and large companies: on account of their small scale
column127: SMEs can present their concepts and visions in a way that is more authentic
column128: practical and closer to the needs of its customers
column129:
which is a big advantage..

\r\n

Michaela Reitterer is very willing to share her experiences
column130:
participate in national and international discussions of the topic and advise sectoral colleagues in Austria and abroad. She does not think that this could harm her business due to increased competition as she thinks that the market is large enough and can further benefit from increased customer awareness.

\r\n

Finally
column131: she applauds the recent trend of including successful entrepreneurs in think tanks
column132: thereby leading to a better liaison of economy
column133: science and policy. In her opinion
column134:
this is advantageous for the creation and implementation of innovation.

Author

Irene Mandl

column1:
Brian Mordaunt & Sons, Ireland~"Brian Mordaunt & Sons"~"

Started up in 1982
column2: the Irish car retail business of Brian Mordaunt & Sons went from selling second-hand cars to having four dealerships under their control by 2007. Helped by the government’s ‘scrappage scheme’
column3: employment grew to 53 people. In 2008
column4: the banking system collapse meant fallen demand for new cars. The company was forced to cut wages
column5:
make redundancies and sell cars at a loss to reduce stock. Major financial difficulties meant the company finally closing down in 2011. The owner since started up a smaller venture of selling cars online and employs nine people.

"~"

Organisational profile

\r\n

Brian Mordaunt
column6: George Mordaunt’s father
column7: started his car retail business
column8: Brian Mordaunt Limited
column9: in August 1982 in Clonmel
column10: the county town of South Tipperary
column11: which has a population of approximately 17
column12:
000.

\r\n

Brian Mordaunt initially focused on selling second-hand cars and in January 1987 invited his eldest son
column13: George
column14:
to join the business as a general runner and car polisher. George had been dismissed from two jobs before he started in the family business.

\r\n

In 1988
column15:
the Mordaunts secured the Nissan franchise for the area; Japanese car manufacturers such as Nissan and Toyota had been making a sustained assault on the Irish car market and were perceived to be brands with good sales potential.

\r\n

Later that year
column16: the family became the local dealership for another car franchise
column17: Daewoo
column18: the Irish franchise of which was owned by Nissan Ireland. The Mordaunts opened the Daewoo dealership as a separate company
column19: Daewoo Clonmel
column20: in a separate location to their Nissan garage. Initially
column21:
the family rented the premises for their Daewoo operation but later built a purpose-built showroom.

\r\n

Between 1989 and 2007
column22: employment in the businesses controlled by the Mordaunt family grew to 53 people. The majority of employees were male in their 20s and 30s and worked in sales
column23: marketing
column24:
financial and technical positions. The employees were not members of any trade union.

\r\n

The Mordaunt group of companies was renowned for its innovative approach to sales and marketing; however
column25: despite the fact that the number of employees had grown to over 50 and involved a considerable recruitment and training process
column26:
there was no formal HR policy.

Background to restructuring event

The car market grew strongly in the early 1990s following the introduction of the ‘scrappage scheme’ under which the Irish Government gave a financial incentive for people owning a car of ten years old or older to trade in for a newer model.

The expansion in the car market prompted a recruitment drive by Brian and George Mordaunt (who were joined in the business by George’s younger brother
column27: Brian) to take on more sales staff to handle the extra business. Reflecting the involvement of the two brothers in the business
column28:
the company name was changed to Brian Mordaunt & Sons Limited (BMS).

\r\n

Not everything was rosy: the Mordaunt family had concerns for the future of Daewoo Clonmel following the bankruptcy of the Daewoo conglomerate in 1999 (General Motors acquired Daewoo’s motor division in 2001). The Mordaunts later changed the name of their company from Daewoo Clonmel to Mordaunt Chevrolet in 2005.

\r\n

Tensions arose between George and his father over the future direction of the company: the former wanted to expand quickly while the latter was more cautious. The strained relations between George and his father escalated following the 9/11 crisis when car sales plummeted with the result that the Mordaunts were left carrying a large amount of stock. However
column29:
George’s flair for advertising meant that the business was able to reduce this to a manageable level.

\r\n

George’s parents had given him 24% of the family business in 1993 but he was frustrated by his lack of control of the business and his father’s cautious approach. Following a tense and heated meeting in October 2001
column30: Brian Mordaunt agreed to cede control of the original family company
column31: BMS
column32: to George but
column33: under the deal
column34:
retained control of Daewoo Clonmel.

\r\n

In 2003
column35:
a Block Exemption Regulation (BER) was introduced by the European Commission to promote competition in the automobile retail sector by giving car owners the freedom to have their vehicles serviced and repaired at a workshop of their choice. The BER also sought to increase competition between dealers of the same brand and strengthen the dealer’s position vis-à-vis the manufacturers.

\r\n

One outcome of the BER was that car dealers would be required to build large — and expensive — showrooms. The new regulations also specified that garages had to employ a ratio of 1.25 sales staff for every 100 new cars sold.

\r\n

A more fundamental and immediate impact was that dealers had to re-apply for their franchises and with some existing dealers wanting to retire or being unwilling to make the investment in new facilities
column36:
it was inevitable that there would be franchises changing hands.

\r\n

Aware that there might be a risk that he would lose the Nissan contract
column37: George wrote to the other main car franchise holders in Ireland. He was rewarded with a phone call from Renault who following negotiations awarded him the Renault franchise contract for Clonmel and the neighbouring town of Kilkenny. The new Renault contract required the acquisition of new premises and the recruitment of staff in both locations. George set up a new company
column38: GBM (George Brian Mordaunt)
column39: to operate the Renault franchise in Clonmel. He secured loans from three banks to fund the new development
column40:
which opened in 2004.

\r\n

George then opened a Renault dealership in Kilkenny even though he was required to make a substantial investment in the Nissan garage in Clonmel to meet the new showroom requirements; the added complication was that the site was subject to flooding necessitating a complete rebuild.

\r\n

Using Mordaunt Chevrolet as security
column41: George was able to secure finance for both projects. It resulted
column42: however
column43: in three of the four dealerships controlled by the family having a debt attached to them. The new Kilkenny venture
column44: GBM Cityside
column45:
was scheduled to open in December 2006. Renault was keen to involve their existing financial partner in the new arrangement even though George would have preferred to stick with his banks.

\r\n

With four dealerships under his control at the start of 2007 and though the car market had grown strongly up to that point
column46: George was concerned with his high stock levels of used cars. The major manufacturers dominate the car market in Ireland for whom a key market performance indicator is the number of cars registered (it is important to note that the number of new cars registered does not equate to the number of new cars sold). Dealers were given lucrative incentives to hold new cars and they in turn incentivised customers to buy new cars
column47:
often by taking used cars as part-payment.

\r\n

Two years previously
column48:
he had begun to worry about the lack of cash that his dealerships were generating. He consoled himself at the time that this was a common feature in fast-growing businesses and would be temporary.

\r\n

The growth in the Irish economy resulted in competition for staff and consequently salaries and wages rose as employers vied with each other to recruit sales people to take advantage of the booming consumer market. George Mordaunt found that it was increasingly difficult — and expensive — to recruit experienced car sales people and consequently had to put considerable investment in staff training.

\r\n

Towards the end of 2006
column49: there were signs that sales growth within the Mordaunt group of companies was beginning to tail off. Stock levels of used cars were proving difficult to shift and profits were proving illusory. Despite the rebranding of Mordaunt Chevrolet
column50: the marque never recovered
column51: internationally
column52:
nationally or locally. George Mordaunt sought another franchise to attract customers to Chevrolet.

\r\n

Purchasers of new cars in Ireland must pay two taxes: Value Added Tax (VAT) and a Vehicle Registration Tax (VRT). In 2008
column53: the Government
column54: prompted by its minority partner
column55: the Green Party
column56: changed the basis on which VRT was charged from engine size to CO<sub>2</sub> emissions; cars with high emissions would pay a higher VRT while those with lower emissions would pay less. While laudable in intent
column57: from a dealer’s perspective the new tax meant that every car had a price adjustment
column58: some up
column59: some down
column60: depending on its emission level. A combination of VAT and the new CO<sub>2</sub> emissions-based VRT changes pushed a number of cars into a higher price bracket. Additionally
column61:
high emission cars also incurred a higher level of road tax. The impact for dealers of these developments was that they were now carrying stocks of cars that were substantially more difficult to sell.

\r\n

Restructuring processes

\r\n

At the end of 2007
column62: while there were storm clouds looming on the horizon
column63: the Mordaunts’ group of companies had sold over 3
column64: 000 cars during the year
column65: generating a turnover of €34 million. George was concerned
column66: however
column67:
that the business was not generating any profits nor did it have any cash cushion if there was any downturn in sales.

\r\n

The collapse of Lehman Brothers in 2008 and the full extent of the disastrous lending policies of Irish banks became apparent and sent shockwaves through not only the banking system but also throughout the economy.

\r\n

Customers stopped visiting George Mordaunt’s dealerships
column68: which at the time had large stocks of high emission cars that were proving almost impossible to sell because of the changes in VRT. George developed a new innovative radio advertising campaign that helped to restore customer footfall. This improved cash flow but did result in any profits; in fact
column69:
some losses were incurred.

\r\n

George’s employees were aware of the difficulties within the business but it was only afterwards with the publication of his book
column70: <em>Shepherd’s Pie: Family Business
column71: Recession and Recovery
column72:
that they realised the full extent of the problems he was grappling with. His employees could see that the lack of customer footfall signified a fall in demand for car sales. Sales staff saw their overall income fall because of reduced commissions.

Junior staff had more reasons to worry because they would have known that when a company downsizes it was usually the last in who are the first to be made redundant.

The Mordaunts held review meetings with staff to brief them on the evolving situation; George addressed all employees together approximately four times during the restructuring process. He told them that it was a fight for survival and that nothing should be taken for granted.

As the company’s difficulties increased
column73: the salaries of employees were cut (reductions ranged from a minimum of 20% to a maximum of 50%
column74:
though in the case of the latter there was a corresponding reduction in responsibility) and a new method for calculating sales commissions was introduced.

\r\n

George realised that a plan was needed to pilot the business through the crisis; he saw it as his responsibility to develop and implement the plan. One element of the plan involved the closure of the Chevrolet showroom and its relocation to his main Nissan premises. Another element of the plan saw cars being sold at a loss to reduce stock levels.

\r\n

Despite his strategy for dealing with the difficulties facing his business
column75: George was not prepared for the next thunderbolt: a demand from one of his banking partners to either return the €2 million they had lent him or secure it. To placate this bank
column76:
George agreed to secure it on a property that the company owned in Clonmel.

\r\n

Another shock followed shortly afterwards: the decision of a second banking partner to terminate its relationship with George Mordaunt and to seek the return of their money. They demanded their money back (€0.9 million) within a month.

\r\n

In addition
column77:
George was facing his own personal financial difficulties; his investments in the stock market — particularly in bank shares — were showing significant losses. He lost €0.3 million on shares in one bank alone.

\r\n

In late 2008
column78:
George approached Kia Ireland and secured the franchise for Clonmel. He tried to operate the Kia brand in the vacant Clonmel Chevrolet showrooms but the lack of sales and profits forced him to relocate it to his main showroom. He then closed the Chevrolet showrooms for good.

\r\n

With the business losing money every month
column79: more employees had to be made redundant. These were difficult decisions for George Mordaunt because he soon realised that one round of redundancies was not sufficient
column80: and more redundancies followed (from the first redundancies in September 2008 to the final round in 2011
column81:
the Mordaunts let all 53 of their employees go).

\r\n

The redundancy programme operated initially on a last-in–first-out basis but then the Mordaunts introduced a points system which evaluated senior employees on past performance and future ability. As noted above
column82: George organised four major briefing sessions for staff to apprise them of the difficult situation facing the business. The employees could see for themselves that sales were falling and therefore knew the business was in trouble
column83:
and because of the dynamics of small towns they also had to contend with rumours circulating about the impending closure of their employer’s business. Employees experienced a shock when following the company’s decision to change its redundancy selection method from a last in-first out to a points-based system a senior manager was let go. This change brought home to long-serving employees that their jobs might not be as safe as they previously had thought.

\r\n

The employees noticed that George was constantly closeted away in meetings with managers
column84: suppliers and bankers. With these meetings taking place behind closed doors and in the absence of any communication from management
column85: the internal rumour mill went into overdrive
column86: further adding to the employees’ sense of anxiety. As mentioned above
column87:
it was only after the publication of George’s book that they became aware of the full extent of the challenges he was facing to keep the business alive.

\r\n

It soon became apparent to George that he did not have enough working capital to keep all four dealerships operational. He decided to close the newest one
column88:
GBM Cityside in Kilkenny. He discussed the matter with the bank that had financed the property but following their advice decided not to follow through with the decision. The bank advocated holding onto the business to see if the market would recover.

\r\n

Six months later
column89:
he followed through on his original decision and closed the Kilkenny operation. He realised he should not have discussed strategy with the bank; if he had followed his own instinct he could have saved money — money which was needed to support his other dealerships.

\r\n

Trading conditions continued to worsen and the business continued to haemorrhage cash. George had to deal with relentless pressures from distributors
column90: banks and the tax authorities
column91: all of which were simultaneously seeking reports on the business
column92:
particularly in terms of its ability to pay its debts.

\r\n

High levels of car stocks proved stubbornly difficult to shift but George managed
column93: between March 2008 and July 2009
column94:
to reduce these from a value of €6.7 million to €1.2 million. Reducing the level of stocks was important — even though George incurred huge losses in doing so — in persuading his bank in 2009 to provide working capital. The bank took six months to finally approve the loan. There were a number of conditions attached to the new finance and all of the business’s assets (bar the family home) were now used as collateral for the new finance.

\r\n

George and his brother
column95: Brian
column96:
had made a number of trips to the UK to examine the feasibility of importing second-hand cars into Ireland. They hired a UK consultant to open doors to them in the UK car trade.

\r\n

The Mordaunts took the decision in 2009 to wind down their second oldest company
column97:
Mordaunt Chevrolet.

\r\n

Additionally
column98: as part of the process of closing the Kilkenny dealership
column99: George Mordaunt had to put two companies
column100: GBM Motors and GBM Cityside
column101: associated with it
column102: into voluntary liquidation. These liquidations took place in January 2010 and unfortunately for him attracted the attention of the national press. One national newspaper
column103: the Irish Independent
column104: featured a story on the two liquidations and
column105: more damagingly
column106:
used the Renault logo and the logo of GBM Cityside in its detailed article.

\r\n

Two days later
column107:
Renault summoned George Mordaunt to its head office and told him that their relationship was ending. George was devastated by the news as he had planned to base his recovery on the Renault franchise which was experiencing good sales. He closed the Renault operation in Clonmel in March 2010.

\r\n

In 2011
column108: the Mordaunt family closed their last remaining company
column109: Brian Mordaunt & Sons
column110: and made all of their remaining employees redundant. The Mordaunts also handed back their two last remaining franchises
column111:
Nissan and Kia.

\r\n

With new external funding
column112: George Mordaunt and his brother
column113: Brian
column114: set up a new company
column115: wesourcenecar.com
column116: trading as the Mordaunt Group
column117:
in 2011 to source new and second-hand cars for customers. Their new company now employs nine people (including two part-time employees).

\r\n

Challenges and constraints of restructuring

\r\n

George Mordaunt faced a number of challenges in restructuring his business. Firstly
column118: he had to make a number of employees redundant. In a small town such as Clonmel
column119: making employees redundant was difficult
column120:
both personally and professionally. George and his family socialised in the same circles as the families of the employees being made redundant which created its own tensions.

\r\n

The very public liquidation of his two newest companies brought a host of unwelcome local and national media attention. Additionally
column121:
the dynamics of small towns is such that news — both good and bad — circulates quickly and also gives rise to a particular Irish trait of taking pleasure in others’ misfortune. A number of rumours about the business began to circulate Clonmel — one even suggested that George had left the country.

\r\n

More ominously for George
column122:
the negative publicity reached Renault which was not happy to see its logo in an article on the closure of George’s garages in Clonmel and Kilkenny in Ireland’s largest selling newspaper. The unfavourable publicity was one of the factors that precipitated Renault’s decision to end its business relationship with the Mordaunts.

\r\n

A major constraint on George’s efforts to restructure his businesses were the banks who were facing a significant business crisis of their own — namely
column123: an inability to raise funds largely because of the huge losses they were carrying — and thus many were not in a position to provide funding for the changes that he planned in the business. Additionally
column124:
the banks that did have access to funds took a long time to make up their mind.

\r\n

The extent of borrowing by his various businesses was also an impediment to the restructuring process
column125: as was the lack of cash reserves. As George’s business had grown from one dealership to four
column126: so too had the level of external borrowing. The lack of attention to car stocks also had a negative impact on profitability
column127:
with the result that the business was poorly resourced internally to fund the restructuring.

\r\n

George’s own personal resources that he might have been able to contribute to the re-structuring of the business were already depleted as a consequence of his ill-judged investments on the stock market.

\r\n

George says that
column128: if he is brutally honest
column129: in retrospect he should have reduced his staff count quicker and he should not have made any redundancy payments because this decreased his working capital that he needed for his business to survive. He says he would have told all of his employees being made redundant to seek redundancy payments from the State (the very last group of his employees did not
column130: in fact
column131: receive any redundancy payments from the company). If an employer cannot afford to pay the full statutory redundancy lump sum payment to their employees the Department (Ministry) of Social Protection — which is responsible for the social security system in Ireland — will make payment out of the Social Insurance Fund
column132: provided that the employer provides evidence that they are not in a position to pay. Recently audited accounts
column133:
or a statement of affairs signed by accountant/auditor would be accepted as evidence of the employer’s inability to pay.

\r\n

Restructuring advice and support

\r\n

The Irish economy had
column134: up until 2006
column135: been on an uphill growth curve since the mid-1990s — even though it is now realised that the latter years of the so-called ‘Celtic Tiger’ were built on a credit-fuelled boom. This period of continuous economic growth meant that many Irish entrepreneurs had never experienced a severe business downturn and thus were ill prepared for dealing with adverse market conditions — and
column136: more importantly
column137: with a dysfunctional banking system. For the same reason
column138:
there were no external advisers who could provide advice and support to George in the restructuring of his business —particularly in terms of his dealings with the banks who were going through a severe funding crisis of their own.

\r\n

At one stage in the restructuring process
column139: George sought the advice of one of his banks on what he should do with his newest dealership
column140: the Renault operation in Kilkenny; his own inclination was to shut it down. The bank counselled that he should wait to see if the market would recover. George realised after a few months that it had been a mistake to rely on the bank’s advice and he closed the Kilkenny branch. He said that if he had closed the branch earlier he could have saved a lot of money. This was an important lesson to George: don’t discuss strategy with banks. He felt it was bizarre that a bank would talk a customer into a decision that
column141: potentially
column142:
could have brought down the whole business.

\r\n

George believes that the banks were not experienced enough in dealing with their own liquidity issues arising from the collapse in the Irish property bubble and the global financial crisis. The banks’ immediate and panicked response to the evolving situation was to demand their loans back
column143:
which created undue pressures on businesses who themselves were struggling to survive.

\r\n

However
column144: George has since identified a number of experts in helping businesses and owners of distressed assets to communicate and to negotiate with the banks
column145:
particularly in the context of the new rules and regulations governing the financial services sector. These experts are skilled in:

  • identifying the problems between borrowers and lenders;
  • presenting the solution to lenders.

His family were an important source of advice and support. However
column146: his father was pre-occupied with his own financial difficulties and
column147: additionally
column148:
the difficult transfer of the family business from father to son had fractured relationships. Perhaps because of these issues his father was not in a position to advise George.

\r\n

Though it was not directly intended as a support for SMEs within the motor retail industry going through a restructuring
column149: the decision in 2010 by the Irish tax authorities
column150: the Revenue Commissioners
column151: to make adjustments to the VAT administration system helped dealers to reduce their VAT bill and thus improve their profitability and cash flow. Additionally
column152: the government introduced a new scrappage scheme in 2010
column153: allowing people to claim a rebate of up to €1
column154:
500 for trading in their old car.

\r\n

Outcomes of restructuring

\r\n

Despite having to cope with three empty buildings
column155: all with significant mortgages
column156: George was determined to press ahead with his new venture of selling second-hand cars from the UK via the internet. Virtual car sales
column157: that is selling cars via a web site
column158: was a brand new concept and
column159: more importantly
column160:
did not eat cash.

\r\n

He and Brian had made a number of visits to the UK and had linked up with a UK consultant to open doors to large dealers who could provide them with second hand cars that they could sell via their new website.

\r\n

One of the many lessons that George had learnt was that the old business model – of selling cars in volume – was no longer going to be sustainable in Ireland in the short and medium-term future. He realised that a new business model
column161: such as virtual car sales
column162: was the way forward even though it might mean a smaller number of employees. His new online business
column163: wesourcenecar.com
column164: allows purchasers to choose the model
column165: the make
column166: the year
column167: the specification
column168: the mileage
column169: the colour and
column170: finally
column171:
the price. George or his brother Brian personally signed off on all cars purchased by customers.

\r\n

The negative outcome of the restructuring for the employees of the four companies controlled by George and his family was that they all lost their jobs. However
column172: seven former employees have been recruited by George and his brother’s new internet company
column173:
which in 2012 employs seven full-time and two part-time employees.

It is understood that most of the Mordaunts’ other former employees have managed to find alternative employment and in many cases were assisted to do so with references provided by George Mordaunt.

Commentary

One of the issues that George Mordaunt had to grapple with during the restructuring process was communication with the banks. He had to deal with a situation where the banks were panicking because of the collapse in the property sector and their lack of access to wholesale funds. Their anxiety was manifested in their demand to George Mordaunt to return the loans they had provided to him and in delays in sanctioning new funding for the restructuring of the business.

Finding experts to help businesses negotiate with the banks was very difficult but George Mordaunt has subsequently managed to identify two experts who were skilled in helping him and other borrowers in a similar position. Since the publication of his book
column174: George has become an unofficial mentor to many SMEs who are in difficulties with their banks and his main advice to them is to get in touch with these experts. He explains to them that these experts are skilled in identifying how to present their case to the banks
column175:
and how to use their contacts within a bank to influence its key decision-makers.

\r\n

Surprisingly
column176: George Mordaunt says the whole restructuring experience has been hugely beneficial to him. He asserts that he will never lose money again on a business venture (he will focus on his key business strengths and will put greater emphasis on digital social media
column177:
creativity and low overheads) and says the process has changed his perspective on life.

\r\n

He also predicts that
column178: within the new business model of using the web to reach customers and keeping overheads down
column179:
staff will have to multi-task.

\r\n

The restructuring process — which resulted in 53 people losing their jobs — was traumatic for both the Mordaunts and the employees concerned. It is understood that the vast majority have now found alternative employment and some of these now work in the Mordaunts’ new virtual car sales company. Reference has been made to the fact that
column180: in a small town such as Clonmel
column181: news — good and bad — travels fast. While George Mordaunt had to deal with rumours regarding the fate of his business
column182: employees too had to cope with a work environment in which rumours were circulating that they or a colleague were losing their jobs. Though George held group meetings throughout the restructuring process to keep employees abreast of the perilous situation facing the company
column183: this was not enough to keep the rumours at bay. It is speculated that in a larger company with more structured HR processes
column184:
there might have been clearer communication processes between management and staff.

Calcedonio Camilleri started the family business as C. Camilleri & Sons in 1843 when he opened a small confectionary shop in the heart of Valletta. It did not take long before the shop started to attract customers from all corners of the island
column6: whose visit to the capital city would include a stop at the popular sweet shop in Merchants Street. Consequently

of which 45 are male and 70 are female.

\r\n

The company has recently appointed a consultant to prepare a risk management report for the whole group. The objective of the report
column36: which is tailored to meet EU policy standards
column37: is to map out risks and uncertainties within the business environment and analyse how such factors could influence business performance. By identifying and proactively addressing risks and opportunities
column38:
the company will be better able to address its policies and strategies in favour of the employee by strengthening positive influences on the workforce.

\r\n

The human resource policies adopted by the company ensure that employees are well respected and motivated. Together with its young employees
column39: the management boasts of having people who have been working with the company for almost 30 years
column40:
a reality which is considered to be a reflection of the good working practices adopted by the company.

Background to restructuring events

The Camilleris have been exposed to the business world since their early childhood and thus believe themselves to have an almost inherent predisposition for trading.

Camilleri Group considers business expansion to be the best way forward for any business that is performing well and delivering sound results. In fact
column41: business expansion has always featured as an integral process in the management of the group and came about initially from the desire to increase the company’s market share locally. Business expansion has also allowed the company to remain sustainable within a highly competitive market
column42:
securing employment for a growing number of employees which also includes family members who are now gradually taking over the management of the business.

\r\n

This said
column43: the decision to extend its operations beyond the catering sector dates back to 1988
column44: when a business opportunity presented itself to open the first BHS store in Valletta. Another two stores were later opened in Sliema (1993) and Birkirkara (2004). In 1997
column45: having successfully managed the BHS franchise for almost a decade
column46: Camilleri Group was appointed franchisee of Mothercare in Malta
column47: with brands specialising in mothers-to-be and children’s products. Four outlets have been opened since – Valletta (1997)
column48: Sliema (2003)
column49:
Birkirkara (2008) and recently Victoria Gozo (2011).

\r\n

As part of its most recent restructuring activities which is the focus of this study
column50: Camilleri Group has continued to expand its business both locally and abroad. In 2009
column51: Camilleri Group opened its first BHS store in Libya. It also inaugurated the first Golden Point store in the town of Sliema
column52: with the latter specialising in hosiery
column53: lingerie
column54:
beachwear and underwear brands. The idea to launch Golden Point in Malta was one based on the experience already gained through the operation of its BHS lingerie and sleepwear departments.

\r\n

In 2010
column55: the group opened its second outlet in Tripoli
column56: Libya for BHS. In 2011
column57: another two sweet shops were opened in Birkirkara and Rabat
column58: Malta. In the same year
column59:
the second Golden Point was opened in Valletta and Mothercare was launched in Gozo.

\r\n

Apart from the opening of its new stores
column61: Camilleri Group also carried out a complete refurbishment of its flagship sweet shop situated in Valletta; and in 2011
column62:
the company undertook the refurbishment of its BHS store in Sliema.

Restructuring processes

Business expansion has always occupied a strategic function within Camilleri Group’s development strategy. Over the years
column63: the company’s reputation with the confectionary trade has evolved and extended to other areas such as the outside catering service
column64: clothing
column65:
home furnishings and mother-to-be and baby products.

\r\n

Forecasting and planning for growth can be a challenge. The study that goes behind each and every project is a lengthy process which requires thoughtful and meticulous planning. Generally
column66: the idea to tap into new business opportunities stems from management’s own extensive experience in the field of importation
column67: retailing and catering business
column68:
together with its understanding of the local market. The company aims to maintain continuous strategic investment in activities that will help it become more competitive.

\r\n

Management considers the planning stage to be the most crucial phase within any project. As a first step
column69: management would undertake an initial assessment of the potential of its anticipated investment within the context of the economic environment at the time and the consumers’ response to that activity. If the results are favourable
column70:
it would then proceed with carrying out the necessary consultations with key individuals from within the company who would need to be involved in the realisation of the project.

\r\n

Once the vision is set
column71: management proceeds with setting out a formal business plan that clearly maps out the objectives to be pursued
column72:
and the actions needed to be taken in order to reach those objectives. The business plan would also include an assessment of the financial sustainability and profitability of the project.

\r\n

A decision is also taken with regard to the financing of the project. If company funds are insufficient then negotiations commence with the company’s bankers in order to secure a bank loan. Once negotiations are concluded and all legal requirements are satisfied (contracts/agreements)
column73:
management proceeds with preparing a Gantt chart to map out the project schedule and work structure of the project. Project monitoring is consistent throughout the project to ensure both timing and quality.

\r\n

Although timeframes are key to project management
column74: the so-called bargaining stages of the process are generally followed by a period of reflection and careful projection which does not necessarily take place within strict timeframes. Such projections would also involve the preparation of a feasibility study
column75:
together with discussions and consultations concerning management.

\r\n

The planning stage also provides a means to involve other personnel from within the company in the management of the project. Management emphasises the importance of ensuring that all members of staff are well informed and prepared in advance of any restructuring activities which may require either their direct support or which can influence their work indirectly. Involvement in planning also fosters a greater personal commitment to the plan and to the company. These positive attitudes are found to improve the overall organisational morale and enthusiasm within the company.

\r\n

Due to unforeseen events which may crop up during the restructuring process – such as changing market conditions – the company is sometimes confronted with the need to revise its plans as it goes along. Nevertheless
column76: there have been instances where the company would decide to push forward with its plans
column77: despite unfavourable conditions. For example
column78: when the refurbishment of one of its leading brand stores was being carried out
column79: management took into consideration the enduring credit crunch which had impacted largely on the economy at the time. It decided however to take advantage of this somewhat destructive reality and push forward with its works as planned
column80:
thereby obtaining a competitive advantage once the critical period was over.

\r\n

Partners and suppliers are informed of the company’s expansion plans on a need-to-know basis only. Where this is not the case
column81: disclosure of business expansion plans are usually limited to the board of directors
column82: management and consultants (when involved)
column83:
together with the company’s bankers.

Challenges and constraints of restructuring

Management did not encounter any major challenges or constraints which could have disrupted the restructuring process. The smooth manner in which restructuring is carried out is mainly attributed to the time invested in the planning and consultation stage which would ensure that all key players – both internal and external (including consultants
column84:
when involved) – are on board and committed to the successful delivery of the established targets once the implementation phase kicks in.

\r\n

Business expansion does
column85: however
column86: bring about a considerable increase in workload. The pressures that come with this are mainly taken on by the directors and managerial staff. In order to mitigate this situation
column87: store managers are instructed to delegate parts of their work to other members of staff – resulting in a sharing of work responsibility – or to look into the recruitment of additional support. If the former approach is considered the preferred option
column88:
work is delegated to individuals that display the necessary abilities and skills to perform any new tasks effectively. This uptake of responsibility will effectively lead to a better remuneration package for the employee.

Management emphasises the importance of ensuring that in-house operations are functioning smoothly prior to being able to assess the external impact of any project.

Restructuring advice and support

Business expansion requires thoughtful planning and research which would help determine market conditions and gauge consumer market response prior to moving forward with restructuring.

All decisions concerning business expansion are taken by the board of directors
column89: following consultation with the respective brand managers. Management believes
column90: however
column91: that given the investment which goes into such projects
column92:
it is advisable that external support be sought by economic and legal consultants who would be able to assess the financial and economic implications of the project and gauge the risks/benefits of the new venture.

Outcomes of restructuring

Camilleri Group has always dealt with business expansion as a normal process within the evolution of the business. The management team at Camilleri Group looks positively on the outcome of the restructuring carried out to date and envisages business expansion as an integral part of its future business plans.

The group has reportedly continued to register positive growth in turnover
column93:
which is the result of the continued investment injected into the company and into business expansion.

\r\n

Management claims that it has always sought ways in which to shelter its workforce from any adverse effects which may arise from restructuring. Having said this
column94: business expansion has reportedly resulted in employment growth for the company. Since 2008
column95: Camilleri Group has inaugurated over eight new shops both locally and abroad. Prior to the business expansion after 2008
column96: the total number of full-time employees within the Group stood at 95. Today
column97:
the company has a total of 115 full-time workers.

\r\n

As mentioned earlier in the report
column98: business expansion generally brings about an increase in workload which is duly alleviated through the distribution of work amongst employees and where necessary
column99:
the recruitment of additional staff. Both management and employees feel that restructuring activities instil a sense of motivation on the job and bring about an opportunity for the owners / management and staff to work together towards reaching the desired company goals.

Commentary

The management at Camilleri Group feels that SMEs in Malta tend to garner less support than larger companies given that the latter represent a larger workforce. At the same time
column100:
the SME sector is also seen to be disadvantaged when it comes to EU funding opportunities which are largely targeted towards assisting micro enterprises employing less than ten employees.

\r\n

Moreover
column101: management claims that companies operating in the retail sector are also disadvantaged when compared with the manufacturing industry
column102:
which qualify for greater assistance when compared to retail operators.

\r\n

When it comes to financing
column103: management claims that access to bank loans is less daunting for large companies given their financial projections. SMEs are allegedly faced with more bureaucratic and stringent procedures by bankers in comparison to large companies
column104:
which is allegedly due to the misconception that SMEs may not hold enough security for their loans.

\r\n

Management believes that in order to alleviate these disadvantages
column105: SMEs operating in the retail industry should benefit
column106: at the least
column107: from tax-rebates on investments and employment
column108:
while efforts should be made to reduce bureaucracy and related excess costs.

\r\n

The success of Camilleri Group is largely attributed to its ability to anticipate and adapt to change
column109: which is considered crucial if one intends to stay ahead in the business. Although it is considered important to invest in the planning of any restructuring project
column110:
management insists that once a decision is taken there should be no looking back and every effort should be made to implement those plans into a successful outcome for the company.

\r\n

Another crucial element within the restructuring process is that of keeping employees well informed of any development plans. Maintaining good communication channels with employees is a vital factor which helps to ensure the smooth implementation of a project. Employees may express different reactions to the restructuring project
column111: depending on their different character types
column112: however
column113: management stresses that
column114: in the end
column115:
reason prevails and employees are able to see that such decisions are taken in the interest of all parties.

column1:
Company AS, Romania~"AS"~"

Set up in 1997
column2: Company AS operates in the film and advertising production business in Romania. The current owner acquired a loan to buy out the company in 2008 but this coincided with the economic slowdown. Due to delays in payments
column3: fewer new contracts and competition from neighbouring countries
column4: the company had to cut temporary contracts
column5: outsource half the post-production jobs and look for alternative financing from other banks. In 2011
column6: the company was again able to expand
column7:
stop outsourcing jobs and increase the workforce from 40 to 50.

"~"

Organisational profile

Company AS is involved in the film and advertising production business. Currently it has only one shareholder
column8: Mr G.  The company does not have a works council. Many of the clients are from overseas (40%)
column9: and the rest are from Romania. Also
column10: some of the production is done in Romania but
column11: since 2009
column12: more and more is done in locations outside the country
column13:
for example South Africa.

\r\n

The company scouts locations and hires extras
column14:
prepares and organises the shootings of the film or commercial and then does post-production filming and editing. In 2011 it also began to offer vision effects and 3D animation.

\r\n

The owner is Mr G
column15: who has been in this business for almost 20 years
column16: starting on the sales side. The company was established in 1997. In 2008
column17: when Mr G’s partner wanted to sell his shares
column18: Mr G borrowed the money from a bank to buy them
column19:
and thus became the sole owner of the company.

\r\n

Company AS is a privately owned company
column20:
and in December 2011 employed 50 people. Part-time help is hired during filming. On these days catering and security companies are also hired.

Background to restructuring event

The Romanian economy was dealt a tough blow in 1990. The shock of liberalising prices
column21: and attempts to introduce market practices after the 1989 revolution
column22: pushed the economy into recession. The first private TV station
column23: PRO TV
column24: appeared in 1995. About the same time
column25:
the local TV advertising industry was starting to take off.

\r\n

In the beginning
column26:
Mr G and his partner were just using commercials shot outside Romania and dubbed them into Romanian. At the same time they were able to win a few accounts for the post-production of films and commercials shot outside Romania.

\r\n

Around 2000 the company upgraded its equipment and expanded its area of services with the most important being the production of foreign films in Romania. The company has expanded
column27:
hired people (up to 40) and built new offices.

In 2008 Mr G’s partner wanted to exit the company and Mr G had to take out a substantial loan in order to buy his part of the shares. The following year the global crisis hit Romania.

Restructuring processes

The acquisition of the loan coincided unfortunately with the global economic slowdown. Payments for the company’s services were delayed and there were fewer new contracts. At the same time competition from neighbouring countries exacerbated the situation
column28:
as companies there dramatically decreased their prices.

\r\n

In this environment it was not surprising that the cash position of Company AS deteriorated
column29: and this led to the bank downgrading the company’s credit score
column30:
and asking Mr G to repay the entire amount of the loan.

\r\n

Faced with this difficulty
column31: Mr G chose two paths to solve the problem. The first was internal restructuring and the second was looking for alternative financing solutions. As he had never done this before he did not have a well laid out plan
column32:
or a time frame. He looked to solve the problem one step at a time and he leaned towards solutions that would relieve some of the immediate cash flow problems. As restructuring would take some time he used most of his efforts to find short-term financing.

\r\n

Regarding the internal restructuring
column33:
Mr G first informed employees one month in advance about his decision not to renew four temporary contracts for the production team. At the same time he temporarily outsourced half the post-production jobs which would otherwise have required investment in new equipment.The outsourcing was done by contracting some of the post production process to the only other company in the market doing similar work. This was the first time the two competitors shared a working relationship. He did not have to get rid of any of the other workers as he outsourced the post-production part of the business which could be done more efficiently by another company. The remaining part of the post production process was done by his team.

\r\n

On the second front
column34: Mr G asked for financing offers from a few different banks in an attempt to retain the amount of credit
column35: while lowering the cost. As Company AS is an SME
column36: and it was this particular sector that got hit the most during the 2009–2010 crisis
column37: negotiating a new deal with a different bank was not easy. More specifically
column38: it was easy to get their attention but the terms and conditions they offered were worse than those offered by his original bank. However
column39:
he did get offers from three other banks and started advanced negotiations with just one of them.

\r\n

With the cash problem solved
column40: Mr G could return to his previous plans of expansion. He was able
column42: to acquire the equipment needed for post-production and thus stopped outsourcing his business to his competitors. Also
column43:
he was able to increase the number of employees from 40 to 50.

The internal restructuring process lasted 18 months.

Challenges and constraints of restructuring

The main challenge for Mr G was finding new financing to replace his previous credit line. His bank
column44: under pressure from its headquarters
column45: was continuously decreasing the amount available. Under those conditions Mr G was finding it difficult to pay for his monthly costs
column46: such as bank loans
column47: salaries
column48: utilities
column49: rent
column50:
production and maintenance.

\r\n

The other major challenge was due to a surprising turn of events in the market for film production and advertising. All of a sudden there was a need for 3D production and there was increased demand for advertising production from outside Romania. However
column51:
Mr G could not immediately respond as he was still dealing with the financing issue.

Restructuring advice and support

After waiting for few weeks Mr G received a few financing offers from different banks. He asked the help of a former bank employee
column52: a family friend
column53:
to identify the best terms. At the same time he told his bank that he was thinking of changing banks. This forced it to offer new loan conditions.

\r\n

With the help of the family friend
column54:
Mr G was able to choose between offers from a new bank and one from his current bank. He chose to stay with the current bank but with better terms; he was also able to keep the original amount of his credit line.

\r\n

Mr G has followed the advice of the family friend on cutting costs first. They first cut the easiest one
column55: temporary contracts
column56: and then looked at other flexible parts of the business (for example
column57:
the part of the post-production that could be outsourced). He also he left the renegotiation of the loan terms to the end in order to reduce this interest cost to his business.

Outcomes of restructuring

Company AS has always been a successful company. It grew organically into a leader in post-production for films and commercials but also lately film and commercial productions.

Throughout 2010
column58: it had to deal with a cash flow problem which was finally resolved. With this out of the way Mr G was able to invest more and expand the business in 2011. It increased the number of employees from 40 to 50. Also
column59:
the overall turnover increased by 12%.

Commentary

It is interesting to note that Mr G
column60: like most entrepreneurs in Romania
column61: was taken by surprise by the current economic crisis. The reaction to the slowdown in demand for his services was unsurprising
column62: as he turned first towards the easiest costs to cut. As he did this without outside help it shows that
column63: for small companies
column64:
managers/owners react naturally to adverse shocks and they look at minimising costs first. One other aspect to mention is that Mr G was able very quickly to switch his focus to growing the business as soon as the cash flow problem was solved.
