column1:
Eurofreight Logistics, Cyprus~"Eurofreight Logistics Ltd"~"

This forwarding and logistics company decided to take advantage of the economic crisis by supplying a market demand for a total logistic solution under one roof – low-cost road and sea freight of smaller consignments with an international perspective. This required the firm’s expansion; while risky
column2: given the economic climate in Greece
column3: the project was able to capitalise on the availability of highly skilled staff who were rescued from a struggling Greek firm. The contraction of lending by Greek banks is a challenge for this company and similar smaller companies
column4:
who have problems accessing growth capital in the form of long-term loans.

"~"

Organisational profile

Eurofreight Logistics Ltd (EFL) is a leading forwarding and logistics company in Cyprus
column5: with 73 employees (64 in Cyprus and 9 in Greece)
column6: delivering a wide range of specialised capabilities and solutions to clients across all industries. It was established in Larnaca in 1999
column7: as the outcome of a merger of two micro-enterprises
column8: G & L Forwarding
column9: founded in 1990 by Leonidas Leonidou and George Papachristodoulou
column10: and CPA UCS Clearing & Forwarding
column11: founded by Christodoulos Partou and George Adamou. It is a privately held company
column12:
with the four owner/managers enjoying equal distribution of shares.

\r\n

The owner/managers play key roles in the organisational structure which is driven by the services offered. There is no formal works council in the firm but
column13: due to a very participative management and a family-like culture
column14:
employees are often invited to participate in open forums so that they can be updated on developments.

\r\n

In the early years
column15: EFL focused predominantly on the Larnaca market
column16: offering clearing and freight services to local firms and associates. Following their early success
column17: the founding team expanded operations to offer more integrated solutions to an expanding client base operating across the small island economy. With the configuration of the business model
column18: EFL enjoyed steady growth
column19: expanding via economies of scale and scope. More recently
column20: and in the context of overseas expansion via a merger and acquisition in Greece
column21: the firm is active in international development. EFL has been developing in the context of a five-year strategic plan designed to strengthen its overall competitiveness and performance. The company has engineered efficient processing systems and is employing technologies to stay at the forefront of a constantly evolving industry. EFL has developed from a forwarding company into a leading logistics provider in Cyprus
column22: thus strengthening its supply chain capabilities
column23: which in turn present new opportunities for growth and efficiency for clients. Moreover
column24: Eurofreight partners
column25: representing some of the leading forwarding companies in Europe
column26:
are offered a high-quality service at a reasonable cost.

\r\n

More specifically
column27: the firm continues to invest in state-of-the-art facilities – integrated offices and warehousing
column28:
located at a prime location (characterised as a transport hub linking motorways and the main international airport) – which enables both operational efficiency and the engineering of logistics solutions for local and international firms.

\r\n

EFL has managed to grow from its small base and has evolved its business model into an integrated logistics firm that offers total customised transportation solutions
column29: for example
column30:
providing third-party logistics in Cyprus and being the first Cyprus company to offer supply chain solutions to a multinational corporation – Merck Animal Health.

\r\n

With the accession of Cyprus into the European Union and the opening of more trading channels across eastern and western Europe
column31: third-party logistics (known as 3PL; and sometimes 4PL when another firm
column32: as a subcontractor
column33: undertakes to deliver certain services) has been promoted as an innovation process that can offer operational and working capital efficiency to trading partners
column34: which is so vital in their quest for competitiveness. Eurofreight engineered the 3PL solution that can address the mounting pressures on trading parties both on the demand and supply side of the market. The operation is also integrated into a software platform that enables efficient ordering
column35: invoicing
column36: shipping
column37:
and working capital management by the trading partners. This operation reduces the lead time and enhances the responsiveness to customer demand.

\r\n

This winning business model has also earned for EFL the 2007 Cyprus Employers and Industrialists Association Innovation Award for pioneering 3PL logistics services for local and international partners
column38:
for example Adidas and Miele.

\r\n

Today
column39: EFL continues to partner leading brands such as Adidas and Miele which seek improved lead times
column40: better management of the supply chain
column41: working capital efficiencies and valued-added services. The successful development of 3PL solutions for international firms has leveraged EFL operations in the core business which includes freight services. However
column42: in the middle of a prolonged financial and economic crisis
column43: EFL is experiencing a combination of growth pains
column44:
for example resource bottlenecks and competitive pressures to discover new avenues of growth.

\r\n

The purpose of this case study is to discuss the strategic issues emanating from the latest major restructuring
column45:
namely: the expansion of the firm by developing the 3PL business model that offers integrated logistics solution to key brands and internationalisation strategy with Eurofreight Hellas in Greece to exploit the Athens-Thessaloniki-Cyprus hub.

Background to restructuring event

Core business model – early growth: In the early days
column46: growth focused on attracting partners via freight services but gradually it has shifted focus to offering integrated logistics management services to local firms and also
column47: increasingly
column48:
to world class companies seeking a local logistics firm to manage their local and regional distribution hub.

\r\n

New business model innovation-based growth horizons: With the accession of Cyprus into the European Union and the opening of more trading channels across east and west Europe
column49:
third-party logistics (3PL; and sometimes 4PL) has been promoted as an innovation process that can offer trading partners operational and working capital efficiency.

\r\n

The firm has been working on its core business
column50: which is logistics
column51: but also on offering high value based solutions to its clients
column52:
as follows:

  • Costs: striving for cost leadership
column53:
following investment in purpose-built efficient-scale facilities and continuous pursuit of cost reduction across operating processes without sacrificing business performance.
  • Efficiency: using state of the art technologies
column54:
building partnerships with professionals streamlining processes allows integrated supply chain solutions with high-end efficiency—to deliver on time.
  • Differentiation: engineering new innovative solutions
column55: \r\nfor example
column56:
3PL and 4PL tailored to the business model of their clients and partners.
  • Supply chain management focus: campaigning for value-added services that can enhance the competitiveness of their clients.

    • The major restructuring event to be further analysed in this case study is the development of the Cyprus-Athens-Thessaloniki hub. It constitutes the latest strategic activity of EFL which is proving ‘the opportunity’ triggered by the current crisis.

    The firm also has a number of projects that offer additional revenue streams and will help build a long-term relationship with its clients. The winning business model has been the 3PL (sometimes 4PL) logistics which offers operational efficiency to its clients. In a nutshell
column57: a total logistic solution under one roof is an integral part of process innovation as it offers better cost structure and higher customer loyalty. It adds value to all stages of the distribution process: from shipping out of the factory
column58: to receiving at port/airport
column59: to order execution and re-export. EFL
column60: with its regional expertise
column61: masters freight issues with airlines
column62: shipping lines
column63: customs
column64: and port authorities and ensures an efficient flow of products. Overall
column65: the engagement of EFL as a strategic partner contributes to reduced lead times
column66: with timely and frequent shipping of goods within 24 hours. Moreover
column67: it can offer more added value to products through repackaging
column68: relabeling and allowing flexibility in order sizing. Obviously
column69: 3PL logistics allows EFL to offer all its services to their partnering firms
column70:
thus boosting the operational efficiency of the core business.

\r\n

The firm is also exploring several new ideas for strategic innovation. During the good times
column71:
EFL could offer training programmes to employees with a view to promoting innovation-based growth by looking at the new business models under investigation. The firm is now investigating the launch of a dedicated logistics service to cater for the needs of pharmaceutical and food-related ventures –as these sectors are proving resilient during the crisis. Another emerging growth opportunity is the energy sector.

Restructuring processes

For many years EFL has been partnering with Greek firms in order to deliver air and sea freight services to trading firms. In the midst of the prolonged economic crisis
column72: more and more firms sourcing their products from Europe looked for low-cost road transportation for smaller consignments to reach the Greek ports of Piraeus and Thessaloniki and then via sea-freight further on to Limassol
column73:
in Cyprus.

\r\n

Eurofreight was the first freight forwarding company in Cyprus and Greece that offered a reliable and fast door to door courier service for small parcels at a cost lower than that offered by traditional couriers.

\r\n

This trend has shown EFL the opportunities that can emerge in the crisis. Following market analysis and consultations with associate agents that the firm cooperated with in Greece
column74: a feasibility study was presented by the chief executive officer and finance director to the board of directors. The decision was taken to expand with the formation of Eurofreight Hellas – a sister company where the majority shareholder is EFL-Cyprus. Minority shareholders include members of the top management team working for EFL Cyprus and Eurofreight Hellas. The new firm was to be used as a vehicle to save certain business accounts that were handled by a Greek agency
column75: UFS S.A.
column76: that was about to file for bankruptcy. The formation of the new firm was made easy due to the fact that Eurofreight Cyprus had been trading with UFS S.A. for some years and thus legally did a debt rollover. Moreover
column77:
they ‘cherry picked’ staff and customers.

\r\n

With the deepening of the economic crisis
column78: the establishment of EFL-Hellas (despite market risk) was imperative
column79: both for strategic and operational reasons. On the operational side
column80: there was a lot of red tape in mastering the freight procedures
column81: which called for a dedicated team to expedite matters
column82: but also to ensure trading partners were creditworthy
column83: given the lack of liquidity which was hampering many enterprises. On the strategic side
column84: given the prolonged macro-economic crisis there were market opportunities for Cyprus-based Eurofreight to expand with low-cost transportation solutions for Cyprus-based trading partners
column85:
but also to pick up more business from rival Greek firms struggling to cope with the repercussions of the recession.

\r\n

The company is now seeking to offer these low-cost solutions to more clients sourcing their goods (such as spare parts or computers) from central Europe
column86: where lead times are secondary to economies of scale. Moreover
column87: there is an effort to synchronise the ordering of EFL’s representative offices in Cyprus and Greece in order to achieve economies of scale in terms of volume trade discounts and
column88: of course
column89:
to ensure lower transport costs.

\r\n

The project Eurofreight Hellas was launched in Athens in the early summer of 2010 and the formation of the new firm took about three months. Given the familiarity of the Greek market and rolling the operations of the struggling firm (UFS SA) into Eurofreight Hellas
column90:
the expansion of the new firm was orchestrated from Cyprus in order to keep the costs down.

\r\n

It involved regular trips by the chief executive officer to appoint the managing director who had to build the Greek team
column91:
which was based almost entirely on key members of the Greek firm that defaulted as a result of the recession.

\r\n

Overall
column92: it is estimated that about €60
column93: 000 has been invested in EFL-Hellas
column94: which basically involves a dedicated team of professionals
column95: operating from two offices
column96: and one in Athens and one in Thessaloniki. In the light of market uncertainty
column97: collapse of trading norms due to lack of liquidity
column98: and deteriorating trading relations
column99:
capital expenditure and offering trade credit was kept to a minimum.

\r\n

Moreover
column100: the formal strategic development business plan set out tactics to streamline operations and shed costs. Thus
column101: despite market declarations
column102: and the offer of integrated logistics solutions
column103: the firm also planned to outsource certain activities to other local service providers
column104: for example warehousing and transport. This was essential to manage risk but also in order to concentrate on the vital part of the logistics chain – bringing in new clients and ensuring they get customised
column105:
value-added solutions.

Challenges and constraints of restructuring

The development of Eurofreight Hellas was a risky venture given the economic climate in Greece
column106: but the project was able to capitalise on the availability of highly skilled staff that were rescued from the struggling Greek firm. The original team have been instrumental in guiding Eurofreight Hellas during this turmoil
column107:
in order to save the trading activities of EFL in Greece and of course to capture and build more niche business opportunities.

\r\n

There are
column108: of course
column109: a series of internal and external constraints hampering growth as part of restructuring. Historically
column110: the firm has been financing growth by retaining profits and borrowing from the banks. However
column111: local banks are now experiencing problems due to the Greek crisis (which has meant the hair-cut of Greek government bonds; and defaulting on loans to the private sector in Greece) which erodes their capital base and thus their lending power. Subsequently
column112: smaller companies with growth aspirations such as EFL are experiencing a finance gap. They have problems accessing growth capital in the form of long-term loans; their working capital
column113: in the form of overdrafts
column114:
is being rationed; and of course higher interest rates have further hit profitability.

\r\n

The crisis has hit the sector as trading volumes have fallen and rivals are engaged in price wars in their effort to sustain their performance. Since the company has grown organically (growth was financed with internal profits and external debt)
column115:
it was felt that that the firm had reached a stage where it was essential to bring in strategic partners to enable the enhancement of investment in the financial and human capital base.

\r\n

It is imperative to develop the business to the next stage in order to overcome some of the classic SME constraints that relate to the narrow resource base and inertia of owner/managers to radically address certain operational issues and strategic challenges in the context of the prolonged recession. The recapitalisation of the business and the strengthening of its top management team could enhance its strategic capability to master the ongoing organisational and market challenges and
column116: more importantly
column117:
to seize emerging opportunities in the growing logistics sector.

Restructuring advice and support

The executive management team
column118: which is dominated by owner/managers
column119: have prepared a feasibility study (with technical input from outside financial consultants and legal experts) which was presented to the board of directors
column120: which includes in addition to the four owner/managers
column121: three non-executives
column122:
including the chairperson. The Greek expansion was approved as a part of the strategic development plan to allow the necessary restructuring of operations to and from Greece.

Outcomes of restructuring

In the early days of the restructuring
column123: finance director Paris Papageorgiou and chief executive officer of Eurofreight Cyprus had to travel regularly to Athens to streamline Greek operations and offer an induction to the Athens team about the new regime; the operations are now managed by the newly appointed managing director
column124: Demetrios Nikitopoulos. There was limited impact on the Cyprus based team
column125:
simply because they have been dealing with the Greeks as UFS SA.

\r\n

The EFL Hellas operation resulted in the saving of nine jobs (two people working for UFS SA left the operation) and subsequently led to the establishment of some part-time
column126: pro-rata posts and business for associates. It is notable that the Demetrios Nikitopoulos and Paris Papageorgiou
column127: who have played a key role in the planning and implementation of this major restructuring event
column128:
have been awarded a small minority shareholding in EFL Hellas.

\r\n

Moreover
column129: the firm decided to pay the salaries and wages for the Greek team who remained unpaid for a two-month period during the default of UFS SA and the transition to the new firm. This ethically respected gesture has boosted the empathy between the Greek team and the new management
column130:
which has translated into good early operational results.

\r\n

More specifically
column131: the managing director who is accountable to the chief executive officer of EFL Cyprus
column132: in cooperation with the Athens team
column133:
took effective action on two fronts: to reduce costs – by reorganising operations and outsourcing more services; and classing clients in terms of creditworthiness and scope for cross-selling.

\r\n

In terms of operational efficiency
column134: it is notable that the new enterprise enjoys administration from Cyprus (ordering
column135: credit management
column136:
invoicing and handling management) as it is fully integrated in the IT system and financial function.

\r\n

In the early days
column137: business was heavily dependent on Cyprus-based firms using their services
column138: but gradually more and more new contracts were secured from new customers
column139: mainly Greek trading firms – especially those serving Greece
column140:
Cyprus and the nearby markets.

\r\n

Interestingly
column141: other large market players
column142: such as international courier companies
column143: have been lined up as partners of EFL
column144:
as they seek to use the European economy transport route via road and sea-freight option (which involves seven to nine days) for certain clients dealing with durable goods who want to lower their cost structures.

\r\n

The fact that about a third of the volume of trade that EFL Cyprus is handling is now associated with the Hellas operation is a testimony that the restructuring is offering a competitive advantage. EFL Hellas delivers value both to EFL and its partners but ironically also some of its direct and indirect competitors due to horizontal partnerships that are symptomatic of how logistics work.

\r\n

As a result of the expansion with the Hellas operation
column145: the firm managed to pick up very important clients such as ECCO shoes
column146: transporting volume from Poland to Greece on the road and then via sea-freight from Piraeus in Greece to Limassol in Cyprus. This route offers tremendous cost savings for ECCO and
column147: of course
column148:
expanding business for EFL.

\r\n

Now that the Hellas operation is integrated into the parent company
column149: the company can start to take advantage of the challenges from the economic crisis and to enjoy early growth. The managing director of Hellas EFL is also offering business development support to EFL-Cyprus. Indeed
column150: he has been instrumental in securing a few high-value contracts that leverage the market position of both operations. For example
column151: EFL now handles the operations of many Greek-based organisations such as Public
column152: Marinopoulos
column153:
and Eshop.

\r\n

In the context of mapping new growth avenues
column154: EFL has managed to get the contract to offer sophisticated logistics support to PHC which manages a chain of restaurants which include Pizza Hut
column155: KFC
column156:
and Hobo’s.

Commentary

This case study epitomises how restructuring can help SMEs to enhance their long-term development by seizing opportunities
column157: especially during the crisis. Basically
column158: EFL has engineered solutions including 3PL and 4PL and low-cost transport routes via Greece
column159:
for its trading partners searching for economies central to their sustainable competitiveness.

\r\n

According to the chief executive officer of EFL
column160:
George Papachristodoulou:

\r\n

\r\nIn the short run
column161: the crisis is proving traumatic
column162: but\r\nfor us
column163: given our robust business model built on partnering and offering value\r\nto our clients
column164:
this crisis is helping us to consolidate our future growth path. The shaking up of our market will get rid of cowboys that will not make it and smart firms naturally will embrace our professional ethos and practice. What we expect from the government is to cooperate with the banks and perhaps help out to channel growth capital in the context of a loan guarantee scheme.

Today
column165: EFL is on a mission to kick-start a new business model by offering sophisticated logistics for the food and pharmaceutical sectors (insulated from the macro-economic cycle). Thus
column166:
the next restructuring event is now on the horizon: expansion of its operation via building a purpose-built warehousing-distribution system to offer logistics but also high value-added services to food firms and restaurant chains.

\r\n

Moreover
column167:
the firm has growth capacity as it enjoys a unique capability platform which includes:

  • long-lasting relations with other prestigious logistics firms such as TNT
column168:
UPS; \r\n
  • a prime location
column169:
5–6 kilometres away from the new Larnaca International Airport;
  • state-of-the art warehousing (with plans to build more facilities in the free trade zone);
  • a network of partners in 120 nations;
  • sophisticated IT platform;
  • logistics expertise to handle standard and complex cargo.

    • EFL is ready to cater for any project in Cyprus (and offshore) which is an emerging hub for new energy and utilities projects to deal with gas
column170: radioactive materials
column171: telecom and electricity. Cyprus is proving to be one of the bridges between East and West
column172: North and South. Recent findings of sizeable gas reserves in the sea between Cyprus
column173:
Israel and Egypt has stimulated explorations for new projects that will boost the macro-economic multiplier effect and thus further boost trading in the region.

column1:
Europlan Engineering, Finland~"Europlan Engineering Ltd"~"

When the major client of Finnish project management company Europlan Engineering experienced business difficulties
column2: the company decided to look for new markets and to change its focus from planning and design towards the provision of turnkey solutions. It sold the design and planning side of its business
column3: which involved the transfer of 50 out of 80 employees. Shortly afterwards
column4: it acquired HN-Yhtiöt so that the company could have its own production. The two companies have been integrated to save costs and exploit synergies; however
column5:
this did involve the dismissal of administrative workers from HN-Yhtiöt.

"~"

 

\r\n

Organisational profile

\r\n

Europlan Engineering Ltd is a project management company offering turnkey solutions in shipbuilding
column6: industry and building construction. The company was established in 1990 from the remains of Wärtsilä Marine Ltd
column7: which went bankrupt in 1989. Europlan focused mainly on planning and design services for the marine industry up to the year 2010. At the end of the 1990s
column8: Europlan Engineering Ltd also started to provide turnkey solutions for new buildings and conversions in the shipbuilding industry. Nowadays
column9: the company offers complete turnkey solutions
column10: from planning and design to installations and post-delivery support
column11:
and it has widened its target sectors to three.

\r\n

The current Managing Director
column12: Jari Savola
column13: joined the company in 1996 after completing his studies in mechanical engineering. He worked in project management tasks and was responsible for the development of turnkey deliveries. He bought his first shares in the company in 1999 and in 2006 became the main owner. He served first as the chairman of the board
column14: but became managing director as well in 2008. Nowadays
column15: Jari Savola owns 92% and Financial Director Perttu Tuominen 8% of the company. The organisational structure is very flat. In addition to managing and financial directors
column16:
there are two other manager-level posts in the company: HR manager and network manager.

\r\n

Europlan Engineering Ltd employs about 30 employees and a further 30 employees work in Hermann’s Finland Ltd (former HN-Yhtiöt Ltd)
column17: the company bought by Europlan Engineering Ltd in 2010 (as part of the restructuring event described below). Hermann’s Finland Ltd is a production technology company specialising in interior solutions. Both companies operate in the same premises in Raisio
column18: Finland. The employees of Europlan Engineering Ltd are mainly clerical workers such as project managers
column19: project assistants
column20: designers and supervisors. At Hermann’s Finland Ltd
column21:
employees are more involved in production tasks. The educational background of employees varies from higher education to vocational degrees. Most of the employees have a technical education.

\r\n

The company was on a growth path from 2000 until 2010. The turnover of Europlan Engineering Ltd was about €10 million in 2005 and it rose to €60 million in 2008. In 2011 turnover fell to €5 million due to the difficult situation in the shipyard of Turku
column22:
Finland. A comprehensive restructuring was initiated.

\r\n

There is no works council in the company
column23: but there are shop stewards representing the employees. The shop steward serves as a local negotiator
column24:
conciliator and channel of communication between the employer and the employees. Shop stewards have been involved in the restructuring procedures related to dismissals as required by the Act on Cooperation within Undertakings (or YT Act) applied in all businesses with a regular staff of at least 20 employees in Finland. The company also has close relationships with the trade unions.

\r\n

Background to restructuring event

\r\n

During its history
column25: the company has been heavily dependent on the Turku shipyard. Ten big cruise vessels were built in the shipyard during 1999–2010 and the shipyard has been an important employer in the region. Basically
column26: the turnover of Europlan Engineering Ltd was derived from the shipyard and the company was able to grow organically as a network partner of the marine cluster. In 2010
column27: one large cruise ship was finalised in the shipyard. After that there were no big orders on their way and the shipyard lost a major order for a new cruise ship in February 2011. When the markets started to decline
column28: competition increased. Due to these structural changes in the shipbuilding industry during the global financial and economic crisis
column29: there were in practice almost no new orders received for a year and the turnover of the company started to decrease. To ensure its future survival
column30:
the company started to look for new markets and opportunities. Major restructuring was also required inside the company to get the business back on track.

\r\n

Restructuring processes

\r\n

Europlan Engineering Ltd had historically focused mostly on planning and design services
column31: but Jari Savola saw the future potential in turnkey deliveries. He saw that the sizes of cruise ships have reached their limit
column32: meaning that shipyard orders will get smaller in future. Therefore
column33: the focus on the turnkey solutions would be more profitable. In addition to new buildings
column34: Jari Savola also considered it necessary to operate more in conversion projects to be able to better compete in the markets. Europlan Engineering Ltd started to implement changes in its strategy in 2010
column35:
a year before Turku shipyard lost the major order.

\r\n

At first
column36: the company gave up their design and planning business. Due to its project-based nature
column37: Jari Savola had been thinking about selling out the business since he bought the company. The decision was finally made in spring 2010 when the order book was almost empty. At that time there were about 80 employees working at Europlan Engineering Ltd and about 50 of those were sold out to another company. Jari Savola states that it was not a proper acquisition but it was more like a business transfer as the employees moved to a temporary work agency owned by the former owner of Europlan Engineering Ltd. The process went smoothly as all the parties knew one another and the transferred employees were able to continue designing work. Some designers were left in Europlan Engineering Ltd
column38:
but the company designs nowadays only for their own purposes as a part of their turnkey services. The company also uses the services of their former employees in their projects.

\r\n

According to their new strategy focusing on turnkey deliveries and international markets
column39: the directors of Europlan Engineering Ltd considered it beneficial to have own production. This was the main motivation behind the acquisition of HN-Yhtiöt Ltd in the autumn 2010. Through the acquisition
column40: Europlan Engineering Ltd has been able to widen its business to new markets and fields and to offer turnkey services to the customers. HN-Yhtiöt Ltd had also offered turnkey deliveries in the maritime industry
column41: but the focus had been more on interior solutions. Now
column42: after the acquisition the focus of the company has been shifted more towards the Finnish construction industry
column43:
whereas Europlan Engineering operates internationally in the marine industry.

\r\n

Europlan Engineering Ltd had not made any systematic plans to acquire another company
column44: but Jari Savola got to know the CEO of HN-Yhtiöt Ltd
column45: when the idea of buying the company arose. The first contacts with HN-Yhtiöt Ltd were made at the turn of the year 2009–2010
column46: but the actual negotiations following the due diligence took place during summer 2010 and they lasted about three months. The negotiations were intense
column47: but went smoothly as both parties had the same interest. There was a timetable
column48: but no written
column49: formal plans set for the acquisition process. Jari Savola and financial director Perttu Tuominen carried out the due diligence by themselves. The lawyer was used only in drawing up the official contracts. The key persons – that is
column50:
the managers – in Europlan Engineering Ltd were informed about the plans to acquire HN-Yhtiöt Ltd and their opinions were sought.

\r\n

The acquisition was finalised at the end of 2010 when Europlan Engineering Ltd bought 51% of HN-Yhtiöt Ltd. The payment was made in cash. There were about 35 employees in HN-Yhtiöt Ltd at the time of the acquisition. The personnel of the two companies were informed when the deal had been finalised. A press release was issued to inform trade unions
column51:
customers and interest groups about the acquisition. HN-Yhtiöt Ltd was the bankrupted estate of Hermann’s Finland Ltd formed in 2009. Due to its good reputation the name was changed back to Hermann’s Finland Ltd in February 2011.

\r\n

The original plan was to have two separate companies operating in their own premises
column52: but after the lost cruise ship order the managing director made a quick decision to integrate the two companies to save costs and exploit synergies of the two companies
column53: for example by having a joint administration and data system. Jari Savola is the director of both companies
column54: but despite the joint administration the two companies have the same organisational structure they used to have. These changes happened within a month. Europlan Engineering Ltd sold their own premises and moved to the premises of Hermann’s Finland Ltd in Raisio in March 2011. Following this move
column55: administrative workers (about 10) from Hermann’s Finland Ltd were dismissed. As the CEO already knew the personnel in Europlan Engineering it was a rather straightforward decision for him to dismiss the personnel from Hermann’s Finland Ltd. The codetermination negotiations went rather smoothly and were conducted in a constructive atmosphere
column56:
insofar as that is possible in situations where painful decisions are made.

\r\n

Due to the poor order book in Turku shipyard
column57: Europlan Engineering Ltd has looked for new markets for their services abroad. This has required lots of travelling by the managing director who is responsible for negotiating the deals. However
column58:
the internationalisation and expansion of business has been done systematically. The company has selected five shipping companies with which it cooperates. The idea is to learn the customers’ way of working and build close relationship with them and this way to grow own business. The same kind of strategy was also applied in Turku shipyard.

\r\n

Challenges and constraints of restructuring

\r\n

According to Jari Savola
column59:
there were no major challenges related to the implementation of restructuring. The acquisition of HN-Yhtiöt Ltd went smoothly as the buyers were already familiar with the business type and sector. The only thing that the management would have done differently is related to the due diligence. After the acquisition the management realised they had relied too much on the good reputation and the long history of Hermann’s Finland Ltd and they should have paid more attention to its current deals and projects. The results of the current deals should have been evaluated in more detail and taken into account in the selling price as it was found out later that two of the projects of the company were unprofitable.

\r\n

Restructuring advice and support

\r\n

The managing director Jari Savola has had the main role in the restructuring implemented in the company and basically no external help has been used. He described the acquisition process as a challenging and interesting learning process. For him it was an obvious decision to carry out the process by himself together with the financial director and not to access any support: ‘When you do everything by yourself
column60:
you can be sure of what you are buying.’ Jari Savola can be defined as a serial and portfolio entrepreneur currently owning five or six companies. His previous experience in selling and buying companies has taught him a lot and was also helpful in the restructuring of Europlan Engineering Ltd.

\r\n

Financial support was not obtained for the actual restructuring events
column61: but Europlan Engineering Ltd has received support for activities carried out after the restructuring. Financing from Tekes (the Finnish Funding Agency for Technology and Innovation) and ELY Centre (Centre for Economic Development
column62:
Transport and the Environment) has been received for projects related to launching the services business and product development. These supports were considered important in terms of the internationalisation.

\r\n

Outcomes of restructuring

\r\n

The first reactions of employees towards the acquisition were varied. Some had a neutral reaction while some saw the changes in a more negative light. As Europlan Engineering Ltd moved to new facilities
column63: there was some resistance. While the distance between the old and new location is only about 15 kilometres
column64: for some employees the journey to work became longer; however
column65: on the other hand
column66:
for some people it got shorter.

\r\n

The split into two companies was evident in the beginning
column67: but after a year both sides are seeing the positive sides of the restructuring. The management has tried its best to create a good working atmosphere
column68:
for example by organising some joint events for the staff.

\r\n

Many types of cost savings have been used in the company. There have been some redundancies made in both of the companies among all employee groups. Also there was a one-week-long compulsory unpaid leave for all the workers. Typically the company offers a lot of training for their clerical workers
column69: but during the past few years the amount of training offered has been limited. Furthermore
column70: the board work has been disbanded
column71: meaning that currently there are no persons outside the company on the board who are involved with the development of the company. The idea is to have new members on the board and continue more active board work in the future. There has also been a break in management teamwork
column72: but it has been quite recently started again and the aim is to make it systematic. As a result of the integration
column73:
the responsibilities of administrative workers have been broadened.

\r\n

The integration has required a lot of energy from many workers
column74: but especially from management. The managing director needed to invest a great deal of his time in Hermann’s Finland in order to get to know the business and the way of working
column75: integrate all the systems and to change an unprofitable business into a profitable one. This meant that in 2011 Jari Savola was not able to put that much effort into Europlan Engineering Ltd and its turnover remained at lower level than it probably would have been in other circumstances. However
column76:
this paid off and the results of Hermann’s Finland Ltd were positive apart from the unprofitable old projects.

\r\n

The new internationalisation strategy was devised after the acquisition and the direction seems to be right. With its own production Europlan Engineering Ltd is able to take care of the project from beginning to end. This is seen as positive by the customers and more profitable for the company as there is no need to buy some of the services outside. Many employees of Europlan Engineering Ltd are currently working abroad and nowadays almost the entire turnover of the company is derived from international projects. International projects are viewed by employees as a pleasant change. However
column77: the whole process is slow: the seeds have just been sown
column78: but no fruits have yet been borne
column79:
according to the managing director.

\r\n

Commentary

\r\n

Jari Savola considers the commitment of the management and their ability to secure the support of the employees as the key factor for the successful implementation of the restructurings. In SME restructuring the role of the owner–manager is greater
column80: whereas in larger companies the owner is in a sense ‘faceless’. The board makes the decisions and the personal money of the directors is not involved. In SMEs
column81: management and employees have daily contact and emotions can be involved in these sensitive processes. Also
column82: it might be more difficult for the SMEs to acquire finance. On the other hand
column83:
in SMEs the decision-making process is often quicker.

\r\n

In terms of advice for SMEs buying another company
column84:
it was recommended to carry out the due diligence very carefully. Enough time must be invested in it in order to find all possible hidden costs. Tax inspection could be a useful tool in this process.

\r\n

Author

\r\n

Elisa Akola

column1:
Finchemics, Finland~"Finchemics Ltd"~"

Poor financial performance was behind the restructuring of Finnish chemical company Finchemics
column2: a family-run business. Restructuring began with a reformulation of business strategy
column3: which focussed on the development of a new product line. A succession process was instigated
column4: with the CEO moving to become chairman of the board while his son took over as CEO. A third aspect of restructuring was cost-cutting
column5: which involved two rounds of redundancies
column6: as well as temporary layoffs and salary cuts. The restructuring has been tough for the company
column7:
and the CEO feels that more should have been achieved.

"~"

Organisational profile

Finchemics Ltd is a Finnish family company operating in the chemical industry. Established in the early 1900s
column8: Finchemics has played a significant role in the development of the chemical industry in Finland. During its long history
column9: the Finchemics business has taken many forms. At the outset
column10: the company manufactured consumer goods
column11: but in the 1970s and 1980s the focus was on packaging. The 1990s again brought new changes as Finchemics moved into technical contract manufacturing. In the decade leading up to 2012
column12: Finchemics returned to its roots
column13: as consumer goods have become its main business again. In addition to manufacturing consumer goods
column14:
Finchemics also carries out some technical contract manufacturing.

\r\n

The basis for Finchemics’ operations is to design
column15: manufacture
column16:
market and deliver goods that satisfy the customer’s needs. The company has no direct rivals in the Finnish market but there are some companies with comparable products. Finchemics’ main business is in Finland but it also has international operations. Imports have accounted for 6% to 10% of Finchemics’ business.

\r\n

The company is located in southern Finland. Today
column17: the family enterprise is in its fourth generation. The last business transfer process took place in 2011 as the previous CEO stepped aside to be the chairman of the board and his son took his place as CEO. The ownership of Finchemics is divided among four family members. The chairman of the board has the biggest share of the company with an ownership of 35%. His son
column18: the current CEO
column19: owns 20.4% and the rest is divided between the CEO’s aunt and uncle
column20:
who are members of the board.

\r\n

Finchemics has been involved in different kinds of restructuring during the past few years. In 2011
column21: Finchemics went through a succession process and in 2012 part of the workforce was made redundant while some were temporarily laid off. A business strategy reformulation has also been taking place as Finchemics has been focusing increasingly on design products. The current CEO
column22: incumbent since 2011
column23: has devoted his whole career to Finchemics. He first started working at Finchemics when he was studying for an M.Sc. degree. Now in his thirties
column24:
he is in charge of the company. Succession planning was begun by the board of directors as there was a need to develop and renew the board’s work.

\r\n

There are 31 employees working at Finchemics. The number of employees fell by seven in spring 2012 and it was envisaged that two more employees would be made redundant in autumn 2012. About two-thirds of the employees are white-collar workers and the remaining one-third are blue-collar workers. Half of the employees in the office are women
column25: but only one-quarter of the employees in production are women. When it comes to the age structure
column26: the average age among white-collar workers is 40
column27: while in production among males it is 30–40 years and among females 50–60 years. Such diversity among employees is naturally reflected in the educational backgrounds of the employees: four people have a higher academic degree
column28:
some have a college education and some have only completed primary school.

\r\n

Finchemics is also a member of the industry association. There is no works council present in the company
column29: but there are shop stewards representing the employees. The shop stewards serve as local negotiators
column30: conciliators and channels of communication between the employer and the employees. Shop stewards have been involved in the restructuring procedures related to redundancies and layoffs
column31:
as required by the Act on Cooperation Within Undertakings (or YT Act) applied in all businesses with a regular staff of at least 20 employees in Finland. The relationship between the management and shop stewards was described as open and active. During the cooperation negotiations the management and shop stewards were in daily contact.

\r\n

Background to restructuring events

\r\n

The background to restructuring lies in the firm’s performance. The development of turnover has not been satisfactory according to the company management. The beginning of 2012 was a disappointment for Finchemics whose aim is to grow. Despite slight growth in recent years
column32: this was not sufficient to enable the company to move forward to achieve its goals. In the years 2005 to 2008
column33: company turnover varied from €4 to €4.65 million. However
column34: from 2009 to 2011 Finchemics’ turnover grew from €4.14 to €5.25 million. Despite the turnover remaining stable
column35: the results in certain financial periods have been poor and in 2009 some employees were temporarily laid off. As Finchemics faced new challenges
column36: it became apparent that the company could not go on making temporary savings with short-term layoffs. The decision to lay off part of the workforce was taken for reasons of economy and production. The renewal of the business strategy has been an attempt to improve the financial situation by targeting new markets both nationally and internationally with design products. However
column37: it takes time for the new strategy to start working. At the same time
column38: Finchemics has lost clients in technical manufacturing. There was a clear need to reorganise the cost structure
column39:
and redundancies and layoffs were seen as the only sensible solution to the situation.

\r\n

Restructuring processes

\r\n

Three kinds of internal restructuring took place in the company. The first one is related to the reformulation of the business strategy which was started in 2008–2009 and is ongoing. In conjunction with this
column40: it was seen as relevant to start the succession process
column41: the second restructuring
column42: which was implemented at the beginning of 2011. The third form of restructuring
column44: related to cost-cuttings
column45: including redundancies
column46:
in order to improve the financial situation of the company.

\r\n

Although improving the profitability of the company was the main trigger for the renewal of the business strategy
column47: environmental issues played a role. For example
column48:
the company was not able to compete with Chinese manufacturers due to higher production costs. The idea for reformulating the business strategy came from the board as there was a need to generate added value for consumers with other means than pricing. A new competitive advantage was seen in design products. It was clear that the products have to meet certain standards and appeal to the consumers.

\r\n

The new product line started with cooperation with a famous Finnish designer in 2008–2009. Finchemics contacted the designer and he was interested in the cooperation. At first
column49: only a few design products were launched and these received a positive reception among customers as well as the designers. Next Finchemics created partnerships with several Finnish designers
column50: who design products for Finchemics. Earlier Finchemics produced a wide range of consumer goods and carried out contract manufacturing. In the new business strategy the company has three product strands: 1) design products; 2) everyday household products; and 3) industrial contract manufacturing. With the design products
column51: Finchemics also aims to grow in international markets. When it comes to contract manufacturing
column52: Finchemics seeks to maintain profitable customers
column53:
while cutting the rest away.

\r\n

The succession process started as a result of a perceived need to develop the board work together with the formulation of the new strategy. There had been talk among the board members that sooner or later some changes would have to be made in order to improve and renew the course of action. In particular
column54: the need for developing the board work became even more topical as the future CEO attended a course called ‘Approved member of the Board’ in 2008. Following completion of the course and in line with the renewal of the business strategy
column55: a succession process took place whereby the CEO was changed at the beginning of 2011. Finchemics’ employees were informed of the succession process and changes in leadership only when the decisions had already been made. The employees’ reactions were hard to describe
column56: according to the CEO
column57:
but he concluded that the employees saw that change coming as he worked for the company already some years. Neither trade union nor other actors were informed about this decision but the Finnish business publication Talouselämä covered Finchemics’s leadership changes in a fairly neutral way.

\r\n

The CEO has not attended leadership training but he has had a tutor to encourage and help him out in different issues regarding leadership. Personal goals for management have been set
column58:
job descriptions have been redefined and lots of leadership tools and skills have been taught. Examples of these are the art of giving feedback and development discussions which the CEO has started among the employees.

\r\n

The third restructuring process at Finchemics related to cost-cutting measures which were necessary in order to save the company from bankruptcy. The board was involved in making the decision about the cost-cutting. In the spring of 2012
column59: the company carried out cooperation negotiations and as a result seven employees were made redundant. In addition
column60: savings were made with temporary layoffs and salary cuts for three employees. The cooperation negotiations
column61: in which the shop stewards were involved
column62: were constructively carried out and in general the employees understood well the situation of the company so the cost-cutting did not cause huge turmoil in the company. In addition to the redundancies and layoffs
column63: the company did not pay any additional holiday pay for the employees in summer 2012 – instead all employees had extra unpaid leave. These cost savings were
column64: however
column65: not sufficient and the company had a second round of cooperation negotiations in autumn 2012
column66:
aimed at making two employees redundant and temporarily laying off another two employees.

\r\n

The actual restructuring was not carried through with excessive planning and timetables. Naturally
column67: the new business strategy was written down
column68: but otherwise no written plans or schedules were made. This seems to be quite common for SMEs that are undertaking restructuring. There was no personnel strategy or social responsibility strategy. And although there were no written documents and no written schedules
column69: it is obvious that some planning had been done. There were some ideas on how the succession would be realised and the same applied to the redundancies. In addition
column70: the need for restructuring had been evident for a long time and many issues surrounding restructuring processes had been discussed. The need to make some staff redundant and lay off others was on the table even before the succession process started. When restructuring was undertaken
column71: other options were not considered too deeply
column72:
as it was seen that other options in the end would end up in closure and bankruptcy.

\r\n

Challenges and constraints of restructuring

\r\n

The restructurings
column73: especially the redundancies
column74: have undoubtedly been tough ones. Coming out of a challenging year and stepping into even a more challenging one
column75: the CEO has come to know what it takes to restructure. However
column76: it has also been a learning process. The greatest challenges and bottlenecks in implementing the restructuring have been lack of time and know-how. Progress has been much slower than the company expected and wished for
column77:
and the sheer volume of things to take care of has been overwhelming. It is easy to get buried in unfinished work and lose sight of what are the most crucial things to manage in restructurings. The CEO feels that many things have been done somewhat poorly as a result of these pressures.

\r\n

The succession and strategy restructuring processes themselves were followed through largely as planned but some deviations from the original plans have naturally occurred. For example
column78: when the ownership contract for the CEO was drafted
column79:
some things came up that had not been prepared for. These were related mainly to juridical issues. The restructurings have also required financing. The new CEO acquired his shares through a bank loan.

\r\n

Restructuring advice and support

\r\n

Finchemics received public support
column80: both in terms of advice and financial support
column81: in its restructuring. Among the supporting parties were Tekes (Finnish Funding Agency for Technology and Innovation) and the Centre for Economic Development
column82: Transport and the Environment. The CEO felt that there were many advisers but not many people he could really count on. He found that while board members were prepared to ‘get their hands dirty’
column83: consultants could sometimes be irritating as they do not necessarily understand what it is like to be in the actual battle. When it comes to financial support
column84: the CEO acknowledged that it was possible to apply for it and sometimes even get it
column85: but applying for different supports has its own costs as well. If a firm is serious about applying for financial support
column86:
it often means a great deal of bureaucracy and time spent in making the application.

\r\n

However
column87: public support has also been beneficial for Finchemics. Loans from Tekes for product development enabled the strategy reformulation and the formulation of mindsets. According to the CEO
column88:
the product development loans have been beneficial but the results achieved have not been as positive as he had hoped. The product development loan was received in 2010 to continue working on the new business strategy. The strategy has been in development for three years and still its impacts on company’s result are not as great as the company expected to be.

\r\n

Outcomes of restructuring

\r\n

As a result of the succession process
column89: the current CEO became the successor to his father
column90: as the father moved on to be the chairman of the board. The new CEO took the operational responsibility while the former CEO takes care of things on a broader basis. The succession process and strategy reformulation have so far had some welcome impact on the business of Finchemics: operations have been clarified and objectives have been set at an individual level among the persons in charge. Previously there were no detailed job descriptions available in the company
column91: but objectives and job descriptions have now been set down in detail. Greater attention has also been placed on giving feedback. Based on the feedback received from the employees
column92: job satisfaction has also increased. In addition to these improvements in 2011
column93:
both turnover and net return have also increased.

\r\n

The cost-cuttings – redundancies and layoffs – affected 10 employees in production. The planned redundancies and layoffs will affect the whole company
column94:
meaning that employees in marketing and sales might also be let go.

\r\n

The CEO has mixed feelings about the restructuring that has taken place so far. Finchemics has received positive feedback about new products
column95: new image and overall about the new direction the company is taking. However
column96: when it comes to the succession process and the hard numbers
column97: the CEO feels that more should have been achieved. However
column98:
no thorough estimations have been made about the influence of the succession process on Finchemics’ business.

\r\n

At first the employees reacted with suspicion to the strategic changes. Now they have adapted to these changes and overcome their suspicions
column99: but again as redundancies are announced
column100:
commitment and attitudes will naturally get worse again. The truth is that if a company is running out of money something must be done.

\r\n

Commentary

\r\n

The CEO of Finchemics has been guiding the company through turbulent waters ever since he took the job in 2011. First there was the succession process
column101: followed by the strategy change and then the workforce reduction. In the case of Finchemics
column102:
it is apparent that restructuring has had more to do with correcting the firm’s direction than preventing different threatening issues. The goal of these corrections was to get the company in a shape where it attracts more growth.

\r\n

At this point in the restructuring process
column103: some of the unpleasant realities of being an SME become evident. In an SME restructuring
column104: personal relationships are at stake. The SME boss who makes employees redundant is taking jobs away from people he knows
column105: and who know him. The human aspect is much more present in SME restructuring than in restructuring of larger enterprises. Managers in large companies can impose mass redundancies without coming face-to-face with the employees whose jobs are gone. However
column106: SMEs also have some advantages over larger enterprises. The CEO believes that if an SME has the right team leading it
column107:
then it can be more flexible and able to follow through restructuring on a shorter time scale. The truth seems to be that SMEs still struggle with inadequate resources and time in the midst of hectic circumstances and larger enterprises might have it better as they may have more adequate resources to do what has to be done.

\r\n

In the CEO’s experience the most important thing in managing restructurings is to have enough time to take the organisation through the change process. Know-how and experience are massive assets in restructuring situations. The more qualified the team is
column108: the fewer mistakes are made and the less time is wasted. Other issues that the CEO gives attention to are the need for planning
column109:
coming up with a realistic schedule and being serious about both budgeted expenses and expected returns.

\r\n

If the CEO had the chance to carry out the restructuring again
column110: he would do some things differently. Instead of trying to renew too many things at the same time
column111: he would focus on a few key issues instead. In other words
column112:
he would slow down the pace of restructuring and make sure that the basics were given enough time.

Authors’ note: Finchemics Ltd is not the real name of the company. The information related to the company has been made anonymous in this case study.

Authors
