column1:
First Credit, Ireland~"First Credit"~NULL~"

Organisational profile

John McGuire incorporated First Credit as a limited liability company
column2: FCMB Limited
column3: on 10 May 2002. He was the sole shareholder in the company and as Irish company law requires that a company should have two directors
column4: his father
column5: a school headmaster
column6:
was the second director. His father has no real involvement in the running of the company.

The first objective of FCMB Limited – which trades under the name of First Credit – was mortgages and life assurance.

John McGuire was 29 years old when he established First Credit. His first job on leaving secondary education was in a commercial insurance broker’s (a commercial insurance broker mainly sells insurance policies to businesses) but this only lasted four months as he was dismissed because his employer said he was not applying himself enough. He quickly found employment in another insurance broker’s but the episode had a major impact on his attitude to work.

Prior to establishing First Credit
column7: he spent a number of months researching ideas for a business before concluding that the provision of mortgages represented the best market opportunity. He set up the company with €40
column8: 000 in capital and a €20
column9: 000 overdraft. Between the ages of 19 and 28 years when John McGuire was working in insurance brokering
column10:
he was also involved in developing land and in purchasing property. He used the proceeds from the sale of one his properties to fund the establishment of First Credit.

\r\n

He was the company’s only employee in the initial period and it took some time for sales to build up before he needed to take on employees. Sales were initially slow because he had no prior experience of the mortgage brokering business and therefore had no customer base to draw upon. Word of mouth was an important means of spreading awareness of First Credit. John McGuire’s innovative marketing strategy in 2006 of offering fixed legal fees in respect of mortgages taken out by borrowers helped to attract customers at a time when legal costs were a significant burden for home purchasers.

\r\n

In the early years of First Credit
column11:
John McGuire relied heavily on the services of an external management accountant to guide him in relation to costs.

\r\n

First Credit initially started in a small office and then moved to a larger office nearby before John McGuire purchased as a private investment (that is separately from First Credit) the building in Upper Pembroke Street – close to Dublin’s city centre – in which First Credit and his other companies (see below) are now based.

\r\n

First Credit benefited from the boom in the Irish property sector and five years after incorporation was organising more than €130 million in mortgages a year and was making more than €1.4 million in gross profit. John McGuire took more or less everything out of the company including an annual salary of €300
column12: 000 and rental income of €200
column13:
000 due to him being the company’s landlord.

\r\n

Employment in First Credit grew rapidly and by 2007 18 people were employed in the company. The majority of employees were men in their early 20s
column14:
most of whom had a background in financial services. The two main staff categories were sales and administration. The employees were not members of any trade union.

\r\n

John McGuire took advantage of the profits generated by First Credit and the opportunities arising from the fast-growing Irish economy to invest in new businesses and in property. In his own words: ‘I had just invested in two new companies
column15:
I had a net worth of €10 million and I was making a decent year’s salary every month’.

\r\n

His first new business was Pembroke Insurances
column16: established in 2006. Its main business is the provision of insurances policies to the business sector. The second new business
column17: Quote Devil (www.quotedevil.ie)
column18:
was set up in 2007 to market insurance products via the web.

\r\n

He also invested in property including one site in Ballsbridge
column19:
an upmarket location close to the city centre. He purchased this investment – which had the potential to be used as his residence – without the aid of a bank loan; he used the proceeds from the sale of his holiday home in Dubai to fund it.

Background to restructuring event

First Credit’s main activity before the restructuring event was as a mortgage broker for first-time house buyers. The company facilitated borrowers to source mortgages from financial institutions and was a one-stop-shop advising on all the steps involved. Through a sub-brand
column20: Remortgage Plus
column21: it also assisted borrowers to re-mortgage their loans
column22: that is
column23:
to consolidate all their outstanding loans into one loan.

\r\n

During the period 2000–2008 (known as the ‘Irish property bubble’)
column24: the demand for mortgages in Ireland grew rapidly. However
column25: from 2007 onwards the mortgage broker industry was significantly – and negatively – impacted by a number of factors. A significant contributing factor was the extent of over-lending by Irish financial institutions to the property market which became apparent in 2007–2008 and ultimately resulted in the nationalisation of virtually all of the Irish-owned banks. Additionally
column26: the collapse of the US investment bank
column27: Lehman Brothers
column28:
in 2008 was a major shock to the international financial service sector and resulted in restrictions on wholesale bank lending – on which Irish financial institutions relied greatly as a source for funding.

\r\n

The decision of the banks in Ireland to scale back on their lending – and in particular lending to the property sector – had disastrous consequences for mortgage brokers such as First Credit. Mortgage brokers
column29: even if they had customers with good credit ratings
column30:
were unable to source mortgage finance from the banks.

\r\n

The collapse of the Irish property bubble had other complications. Falling property prices meant that thousands of new homeowners were now faced with the prospect of negative equity: mortgage debt exceeding the value of the property. This also stopped the mortgage refinancing market in its tracks.

\r\n

Additionally
column31: the property bubble had created thousands of jobs in the construction sector and with falling property prices
column32: activity in the sector ground to a halt and construction companies started to lay off staff. Furthermore
column33: as the government had been over-reliant on revenues generated from the sales of properties as a source of revenue
column34: when construction-related tax receipts fell
column35:
Ireland’s fiscal deficit widened significantly.

\r\n

Though initially the real culprit was the refusal of the banks to provide mortgages
column36: the recession also caused a decline in the demand for mortgages by consumers. In his book
column37: Sorted!
column38:
John McGuire describes the impact:

\r\n

\r\nI was shocked in October 2008 when
column39: along with many of\r\nyou
column40: I watched stock markets
column41: pension funds
column42: and everything else get\r\nannihilated. October 2008 was when the phone stopped ringing in my company
column43: but\r\nit was in 2009
column44: when it really hit the fan
column45:
that the business really stopped\r\nturning and the cash reserves started to run\r\nout.

At one stage during 2009
column46: John McGuire was putting €25
column47:
000 a month into the company to pay employees’ salaries. He continued to put his own money into the company during 2009 as he felt the downturn in the demand for mortgages was going to be temporary.

\r\n

In 2010
column48: he realised that the new economic conditions were not temporary
column49: but permanent. There would be no market for mortgages and
column50: as a result
column51:
the business model on which First Credit was based was obsolete.

Restructuring processes

During the initial stages of the restructuring process which started in late 2008
column52:
John McGuire put a considerable amount of his own cash into First Credit in order to pay the salaries of employees.

\r\n

Around this time too
column53: one of First Credit’s main competitors
column54: Rea Mortgages
column55: went into liquidation. John McGuire says that the owner of the Rea Mortgages had saved himself a lot of pain by going into liquidation early rather than enduring the slow
column56:
dragged-out death that other mortgage brokers experienced.

\r\n

John McGuire’s main challenge of the restructuring process was to deal with the declining market for mortgage brokering while at the same time take advantage of opportunities in other markets such as the sale of commercial and personal insurance policies. However
column57: his main focus during 2009 and 2010 was survival. His survival plan – an overall plan that was flexible to change depending on circumstances – involved gambling on his two new companies (Pembroke and Quote Devil) and two property sites that he knew would eventually be profitable. However
column58: he faced a double-bind: his main operating company
column59: First Credit
column60:
was losing money on a monthly basis while his new businesses were in the start-up phase with no revenues being generated.

\r\n

He needed the companies to be profitable so that they could pay him rent for the use of his building in Upper Pembroke Street. He needed this income to make his loan repayments – if he didn’t
column61: it would be all over. Realising that he had little prospect of finding a buyer if he were to put the property up for sale — there was even less property finance available for commercial land as the market had fallen 705–80% — and in an effort to generate additional rental income
column62: he decided to set up a café/bar in the basement of the building. The company
column63: Dax Café Bar
column64:
established to run the new venture was incorporated in 2009. He used the proceeds from the sale of his car and some of the money from the sale of his holiday home to finance the building works at Pembroke Street and at his property in Ballsbridge which cost over €1 million in total.

He had to decide if he should liquidate First Credit or keep going. He was conscious that First Credit had very loyal staff but he was equally aware that the company was losing more money than it was generating. He was dipping into his savings to pay for the shortfall in revenues.

First Credit’s employees were fully aware of the difficulties faced by the company: they could see that the banks were not lending money for mortgages and that consumers were becoming increasingly reluctant to borrow money for a major purchase such as a house at a time when unemployment was rising and interest rates were increasing. The employees also saw that First Credit had stopped advertising and that the company’s ranking on major search engines was falling.

During the restructuring process
column65: staff salaries within First Credit were cut (ultimately by 30%) and additionally
column66: because of the downturn in business
column67: none of the sales staff were receiving commissions. Employees experienced delays in getting their salaries. One by one
column68:
his staff resigned from the company; they left of their own accord – there were no redundancies.

\r\n

In his book
column69: John McGuire describes the relief when the very last employee left. It meant that he would not have to draw upon his savings to pay the employee’s monthly salary. For a short period during 2010
column70:
John McGuire was the only person working in First Credit.

\r\n

In hindsight
column71: John McGuire wonders whether it would have been more beneficial to have made employees redundant and thereby not have to work in the very tense and difficult atmosphere within the company. On the other hand
column72:
he says that jobs in the financial services sector were difficult to find and his employees might have had to face the dole for a couple of months before finding new employment. He says that it is easier to find a job if you are already in a job so the fact that First Credit kept the employees in employment may have made it easier for them to find work elsewhere.

\r\n

Consultation with employees was not a feature of First Credit’s modus operandi though it was obvious to the employees that the company was in trouble (firstly
column73: no bank was lending money for mortgages and
column74: secondly
column75: there was little demand for mortgages on the part of borrowers). Though it was not officially spoken about within the company
column76: staff became aware of the money John McGuire was personally putting into the company because their salary cheques came from his personal account. They knew too that First Credit’s advertising budget had been cut which
column77: as mentioned previously
column78: meant that the company’s ranking on search engines fell. Realising the very serious situation facing the company
column79: the employees participated in initiatives to reduce costs
column80: for example sourcing cheaper stationery items. As time progressed
column81:
it became evident to the employees that John McGuire’s entrepreneurial energies were being directed towards his other enterprises and not First Credit.

\r\n

In addition to his problems with First Credit
column82: John McGuire had to contend with difficulties in his other ventures. The bank that had lent him money to develop his Ballsbridge site pulled the funding
column83:
leaving him essentially with a large hole in the ground that was worth nothing. There were problems too obtaining planning permission to develop his new café/bar venture.

Challenges and constraints of restructuring

John McGuire says in his book that had he merely been an employee of First Credit rather than its owner he would have left the company much sooner – a mortgage broker fighting for survival was not the most pleasant place to be.

He debated whether he should make his staff redundant or try to hold onto them for as long as possible. In the end
column84:
his employees made the decision for him by resigning. One employee characterised the situation facing staff as being like a passenger on the Titanic (‘do I jump or do I stay on board?’).

\r\n

The main issue faced by First Credit and other mortgage brokers from 2008 onwards was the unwillingness of the banks to provide mortgage finance
column85: even in cases where the applicant had a good financial track record. Then
column86:
the full extent of the recession kicked in with the result that consumers scaled back their purchases of homes and property. The situation was compounded by tensions between the two government parties over how to respond to the economic and financial crisis.

\r\n

John McGuire initially took the view during 2007–2008 that the economic downturn was going to be temporary (he had even been considering an expansion path for First Credit). Then the full extent of the financial
column87:
economic and political meltdown in Ireland became apparent and was given full realisation with the signing of the bailout agreement in November 2010 between Ireland and the EU and International Monetary Fund. A general election held three months later in February 2011 resulted in a heavy defeat for the two government parties.

\r\n

It was only when it became apparent that not only was the downturn not temporary but in fact it was going to get much worse
column88: that John McGuire decided to run down First Credit and focus on his two new insurance-related ventures
column89: Pembroke Insurances and Quote Devil
column90: which had future potential and unlike the mortgage finance business were largely repeat business. He said that all his creative energy went into these two ventures because they represented his future. Both sold standard insurance products which
column91: unlike mortgages
column92: had to be renewed annually: that is
column93: they were repeat business products. His other investment
column94: Dax Café Bar
column95:
was also important to him as a source of rental income for his building.

Restructuring advice and support

John McGuire did not have access to state supports such as advice or financial assistance from Enterprise Ireland
column96:
the SME national support agency or any other agency. None of his other businesses have received support from state agencies.

\r\n

He said that he did not know where or to which organisation he could have turned to for help with his restructuring.

\r\n

In the early years of First Credit
column97: John McGuire relied on his management accountant for advice. However
column98: he was irked by the fact that during the post-2008 crisis
column99: even though First Credit was in decline
column100: his management accountant did not reduce his fees
column101:
and so he decided to dispense with his services.

\r\n

First Credit was involved in an industry group
column102: AMG Group
column103: set up in 2008 by independent mortgage brokers to respond to the banks’ decision to reduce the availability of mortgages. This group allowed for an exchange of ideas regarding the difficulties that mortgage brokers were experiencing at the time
column104:
particularly in relation to dealing with the banks. John McGuire participated in the group for approximately one year but left when he realised that there was no future for First Credit as a mortgage broker.

Outcomes of restructuring

The outcomes of the restructuring of First Credit are that it has considerably reduced its numbers of employees and it now no longer specialises in mortgages. First Credit currently has one full-time staff member who was recruited in late 2010 and who concentrates on the selling of life insurance policies; its trading name has been changed to First Credit Assurance. The company is generating a small profit
column105: primarily because it only has one salary to pay; however
column106:
it is still carrying forward substantial losses from previous years.

\r\n

John McGuire did not make any of his 18 staff in First Credit redundant. He decided he would make sure that there would be jobs for everyone who stuck with him; however
column107: in hindsight
column108:
he says he could have given them a cash lump sum and let them find alternative employment.

\r\n

A number of the staff who left First Credit found employment in other financial institutions while others are believed to have emigrated.

\r\n

Prior to the restructuring of First Credit
column109: John McGuire had established a commercial insurance brokerage
column110: Pembroke Insurances
column111: and an online low-cost car
column112: van
column113: home and health insurance business
column114: Quote Devil. The latter business now already has over 10
column115: 000 customers and is trading profitably. He has also opened a new bar
column116: Dax Café Bar
column117:
which is based in First Credit’s old boardroom.

\r\n

The property sites that he purchased during the property boom were completed and are now generating rental income for him.

\r\n

Through his new businesses
column118:
John McGuire now employs 40 people and expects that number to grow by an additional 25 jobs.

\r\n

It is important to point out that though First Credit now only employs one person and focuses on assurance products
column119: John McGuire is considering a project that might involve a return to the mortgage market. He believes this new project
column120: if brought to fruition
column121:
could have the potential to significantly transform the fortunes of First Credit.

Commentary

This is the case study of a company whose product simply disappeared overnight because of the refusal of the banks
column122: as a consequence of the financial markets crisis in 2008
column123: to provide mortgage finance. First Credit had grown from one employee to 18 by 2007 but as firstly the supply of mortgage finance dried up and secondly consumers scaled back on their demand for mortgages
column124: its sales declined. The owner of First Credit
column125: John McGuire
column126: continued to pay employee salaries from his own personal savings until
column127: one by one
column128:
they all left the company.

\r\n

The company now employs one full-time employee and its focus is on selling life insurance policies. John McGuire is considering a new venture that could see the return of First Credit to the mortgage market and has the potential to significantly transform the fortunes of the company.

\r\n

The company did not seek external help with its difficulties; in any case
column129:
John McGuire says he did not know who he could have turned to for assistance.

\r\n

Though he parted company during the crisis with the external management accountant he had relied upon during First Credit’s formative years
column130:
he believes it is important that enterprises facing a restructuring should have up-to-date information on their financial health.

\r\n

In retrospect
column131: he says he should have considered liquidating the company and making the employees redundant: this would have allowed him to safeguard his cash reserves for other opportunities. However
column132: the scale and intensity of the financial and economic crisis did not become apparent for some time; he
column133: along with other Irish entrepreneurs
column134: thought that the downturn was temporary (‘a blip’) but soon came to realise that not only was it permanent
column135:
it was likely to get even worse.

Tom Martin

\r\n

Interviews

\r\n

John McGuire

\r\n

column1:
GC, Romania~"GC"~"

When the construction bubble burst in 2009
column2: restructuring became unavoidable for this Romanian wholesaler and retailer of construction materials. A number of retail spaces were closed
column3: which led to almost 10% of the workforce having to either be relocated to other retail locations or production facilities or to be let go. For staff who were retained
column4: salaries were cut or frozen; some had to take unpaid leave for one or two weeks at a time. The best way to maintain motivation among the staff
column5: according to the owner-manager
column6:
was keeping them apprised of his efforts to avoid further staff reductions.

"~"

Organisational profile

The company GC is located in Ramnicu Valcea
column7: west of Bucharest. Its main activities are selling construction materials either wholesale or retail. The company was set up by ‘Mr P’ in 1999. It employs 100 people in different business areas
column8: the two main ones being retail and production. There is no works council. The management structure is very simple. Mr P is the final decision-maker on all costs and payment-related issues. There are heads of businesses and of teams but they cannot take decisions about finances
column9: hiring and firing
column10:
the suppliers of goods and services or prices of own goods and services.

\r\n

The business has developed by following market trends. For example
column11:
Mr P entered the construction business when he observed the booming construction sector.

\r\n

GC sells construction materials
column12: electrical appliances
column13: kitchen fixtures
column14: furniture
column15:
double-glazed windows and window frames.

\r\n

Mr P is 35 years old and has been an entrepreneur all his life. He started the company to meet a growing need in a bullish economy. It was a time when Romanians were making their first ventures into credit loans and when they wanted to own their houses. Building their own house was one of the preferred options.

\r\n

Mr P discovered this demand very early. At first the company sold fittings for kitchen and bathrooms. Then construction material and double-glazed windows and frames were added. As mentioned above
column16:
the dynamics of the company were dictated by the market dynamics. Mr P did not follow one single business line – it just went according to what was profitable at the time.

Background to restructuring events

Although Mr P was very good at spotting the development of the construction sector related to the development of the mortgage market
column17:
he was not able to predict the end of the boom. The 2009 recession found Mr P during an expansion phase as he was investing in new retail spots and hiring new personnel.

\r\n

The fall of the construction market for housing was swift and sharp. Even in 2012 the sector was still searching for the bottom.

\r\n

Another problem was the concentration of the business on only one market: housing and house remodelling. Thus Mr P had to react very fast to the changing realities of his business
column18: especially as close to 100 people were depending on him. Unfortunately
column19:
there was no way to avoid the introduction of a tough restructuring programme.

Restructuring processes

All the investment decisions and programmes that were decided in 2008 had to be revised. The restructuring plans were divided into two: measures that could be implemented immediately and measures that would be implemented throughout 2009 and maybe 2010.

It was obvious at the beginning of 2009 that some of the investment plans had to stop immediately. Mr P first tried to exit rent contracts for new retail spaces that were not yet developed. Then he looked at his inventories and made a plan to identify if any of the materials could be sold to a market like Turkey
column20:
where the construction market was still growing.

\r\n

At the same time Mr P looked at his retail spaces that were already established. Together with his senior management
column21: he chose which of them they would keep and decided to close the others. To make this decision
column22: he looked at overall profitability of individual location
column23: number of employees
column24: proximity to main shopping areas and
column25: probably most importantly
column26:
the cost of renting. This decision led to almost 10% of his workforce having to either be relocated to other retail locations or production facilities or to be let go.

\r\n

To decide on which personnel to be made redundant
column27: Mr P looked at the most profitable locations and identified which ones could accommodate one or two more employees. He determined that around 15 people from production who were supposed to leave could be employed in other parts of the company. For the other five people
column28: Mr P negotiated a severance package comprising
column29: from case to case
column30: depending on experience and years within the company
column31:
one or two months’ salary above the one month salary required by the law.

\r\n

At the same time Mr P was trying to find places for the people working in the retail stores in other departments of the company. Of course
column32: not all staff could be saved
column33:
and some of the personnel were dismissed with a severance package.

\r\n

The employees who had to move to other areas of the company were informed by their immediate superior. However
column34:
Mr P said that he personally informed the people who had to be fired.

\r\n

For the reassigned staff
column35:
there was a short half-day training regarding the products that they would sell in the retail stores.

\r\n

As the fall of the construction market was so dramatic
column36: more had to be done to keep the company profitable in the long run. Mr P had to freeze and cut some salaries for the rest of the employees. At first he froze salaries for the second part of 2009 but
column37: as this was not enough
column38: he negotiated a 15% salary reduction for the whole of 2010. In some cases
column39: especially during the winter period
column40: the people working on the side of the business connected to the construction sector had to take unpaid leave for one or two weeks at a time. There were 45 employees in this unpaid leave programme. At the same time
column41: Mr P renegotiated the acquisition prices for his inventories and new products
column42:
and also asked for a longer period to pay the suppliers. Negotiating lower prices and costs is tough but Mr P felt that during 2010 all these adjustments were easier to implement. He felt that the counterparties also had an active interest in keeping him as a client and were more willing to accept worse conditions than previously agreed.

Mr P explained that he felt 2009–2010 was a period of just cutting and negotiating. And even then it would not be enough to make the company profitable.

Challenges and constraints of restructuring

Throughout the restructuring process
column43: Mr P had to ensure that his staff remained motivated and that he made the payments to his creditors and suppliers. When asked about what he did differently to motivate his people during the crisis
column44: Mr P replied that he didn’t do too much. He had to keep paying the salaries in time
column45: added a few more meetings with his senior staff to update them on the new contracts or upcoming deals and asked them to pass the information as soon as possible to the rest of the workers. The best motivation came from his efforts to keep the jobs in place and not to be forced to further reduce the number of his employees. He made sure that this message reached the employees constantly. Also
column46:
getting out of lease contracts for retail spaces proved almost impossible in those times and it came at a cost. The situation improved from his point of view for contracts in the latter part of 2009 and throughout 2010 when it was obvious that the construction and real estate market would not recover any time soon.

\r\n

To this cost was added also the cost of severance packages for the people he could not retain. To pay for the severance package
column47: Mr P contracted a short-term loan from a local bank
column48: which he paid back in 2011. To get the loan Mr P met with five banks
column49: all of them ranked among the top 10 banks in Romania by asset size. Unfortunately
column50: none of them was able to give him a deal that he could afford. In fact
column51: four out of the five banks did not present an offer as his company was seen as a risky one due to its reliance on the construction sector. In the end
column52:
it was the sixth bank that gave him the loan. It was a small bank used to dealing with SMEs similar to GC.

\r\n

Finally
column53: another constraint was the high inventory
column54: construction materials and fixtures that he had accumulated in 2008
column55:
based on the 2008 turnover numbers. Unfortunately some of the inventory is still there today but Mr P had to pay for it in 2009.

\r\n

However
column56:
in the last months of 2011 and at the beginning of 2012 Mr P sold 80% of the old inventory.

Restructuring advice and support

Mr P did not use any restructuring advice or support. Mr P said that he could not afford the advice of a consultant. He also said that he does not see the point
column57: as at first he would have had to explain his business to the consultant
column58: which would have taken time. In his view
column59: it was better for the company if he used this time to solve the problems himself. Also
column60:
he does not think that he will use outside help in the future if a similar situation will arise.

Outcomes of restructuring

GC saw the same meteoric rise as the other companies in the construction business. The restructuring has been long and in some respects it is still continuing today.

But as other similar companies disappeared
column61:
Mr P managed to turn his company around in 2011 after two really tough years. In 2011 he managed to increase salaries again and registered a profit. The turnover is not at the 2008 level but Mr P is expecting it to be at that level in a few years.

Commentary

Mr P’s management style resembles the style of the majority of managers in Romania
column62: in both small and large companies. As this business was not his lifelong dream
column63: Mr P was always guided by the market. Thus
column64: when business was good
column65: Mr P hired more people than he actually needed as he was hiring for his future plans not current needs. However
column66:
when things slowed down he did not shy away from restructuring personnel or from shifting staff within the company.

The restructuring process was long and complicated for a small company but Mr P was more than capable of managing it. It is also interesting to see that he did not have any problems with the staff he let go and those that were relocated were more than happy to just keep their jobs.

Mr P shows that even without formal training the survival instinct led him to the right decisions for his company and employees.

Czech textile firm H&D decided to offshore production to China because of increasingly high labour costs in the Czech Republic

which made the firm less competitive. This way of optimising costs was sought as it was assumed that the competition in the industry will further increase due to the introduction of vertical production chains and the weaker negotiation power of SMEs (compared with larger firms) towards suppliers.

column5: who is the company’s current director

column9:
all the shops of the two above-mentioned companies were sold out as a consequence of declining sales.

As far as the manufacture of clothing is concerned
column10: between 1995 and 1997 the company had eight separate operations with approximately 40 employees each. In 2012

column15:
the company runs its own guest house in the Jeseník Mountains.

When it was first established

column22: not on their production)
column23: the creative division
column24: the furniture and textile warehouse
column25: and the accounting department. Other than the designers and top management
column26: who have university degrees

the majority of the employees have completed a vocational education. The company does not have a documented human resource development strategy or a social responsibility strategy. There are no works council and no trade union in the company.

Ivo Havel
column28: who is a qualified engineer

column31:
he was the director of the state-owned Gala Company for a short time.

Mr Havel classifies the company as an international enterprise

column34: which is represented in the European Union
column35: the Ukraine
column36: Kazakhstan
column37: Greece
column38: Romania
column39: Serbia
column40: Bulgaria and Hungary

is the main export intermediary. The company exports 40% of its total production volume through this chain. Only a minimum of production output is purchased locally.

Starting in about 2000
column42: the company’s annual turnover was approximately CZK 200 million (€8 million). The maximum turnover was achieved in 2008

column44: CZK 98 million (€3.9 million) in 2010

column47:
including VAT).

Background to restructuring events

The main initiating factor behind the restructuring changes that required the offshoring of production to China is the high cost of labour for line production. As an example
column48: Mr Havel described the situation of the Czech Republic
column49: when in 2004 the personnel costs for one employee were approximately USD 200 (€160) per month. Due to increasing wages and the weakening of the dollar in relation to the Czech crown
column50: these costs have increased to USD 600 (€490). As a result
column51: the workforce lost its competitive strength in comparison to countries such as China. The company began outsourcing the production of its products to China in 1994 and all of its production operations have gradually transferred there. In Prostějov
column52: where the company is situated
column53:
their products are only designed.

\r\n

Although the company had a record turnover in 2008
column54: the management was certain that the competition in the textile industry would continue to intensify
column55: particularly due to the arrival of vertical production chains – international chains that sell their products in their own international retail networks
column56: but do not purchase their product portfolio but produce it themselves in countries with lower labour costs
column57: for example H&M
column58: Kik
column59: C&A
column60: and Inditex
column61: which operates stores such as Berschka
column62: Massimo Dutti and others – in the Czech Republic. When ordering production in Asia
column63: medium-sized enterprises do not have as strong a negotiating position as large companies and thus cannot attain the same level of quantity discounts. According to Mr Havel
column64: China is currently also becoming expensive and Mr Havel is looking for somewhere else to relocate his sewing shops
column65:
possibly to Bangladesh.

\r\n

2010 was the most difficult year in H&D’s history due to the confluence of several negative factors. In addition to the overall global crisis
column66: which was reflected in a decrease in consumption and consequently in the demand for the company’s products and reduced deliveries to hypermarkets
column67: other negative trends also started to appear. The first was a continual increase in the price of cotton on the world’s markets. The company
column68: as a manufacturer of leisure clothing
column69:
uses primarily cotton or cotton blend materials. Another negative factor was the increase in costs associated with production in China due to the reduction in subsidies provided by the Chinese government for the export of textiles. This was combined with an increase in the wages paid to workers in this industry. All of the above were reflected in increased costs associated with the manufacture of clothing.

\r\n

As a reaction to the decreasing sales in clothing
column70: due to the very capable and experienced employees in the import section (they have language skills
column71: knowledge about corresponding legislation
column72: established contacts)
column73:
Mr Havel decided to look for new import opportunities in order to diversify the production of the company.

Restructuring processes

As a result of various influences on the competitiveness mentioned above
column74: in 2010 the company was forced to implement measures aimed at creating internal sources of cost savings. These measures included increasing the effectiveness of production outsourcing management
column75:
primarily in the phase during which all of the components required for the manufacturing process are ordered and completed.

\r\n

Another measure used to counterbalance the pressure in the textile industry was to gradually diversify production and to shift from the manufacture of clothing to the manufacture of furniture and home accessories. For these reasons
column76: the company has been undergoing an internal restructuring process since the autumn of 2008 in relation to the portfolio of products it manufactures. The company is gradually changing its focus and is shifting to the manufacture of home accessories and furniture manufactured under the H&D Home Design brand. The competition is not as stiff within this particular segment as it is in the clothing industry – in 2011 the sales of furniture and home furnishings accounted for a turnover of CZK 15 million (€600
column78: as compared to CZK 7 million (€280
column79: 000) in 2010. The original focus on retail sales of this particular group of products has thus far not generated any significant results. For this reason
column80: the company would like to become a supplier for hotels
column81: restaurants
column82: golf clubs
column83:
spas and bakeries.

\r\n

In addition to changing its product portfolio
column84:
the company also attempted to decrease its overhead costs. It installed more energy-efficient lighting and other measures to decrease the overall use of energy.

\r\n

As far as the restructuring period is concerned
column85: according to Mr Havel it is still underway. The share contributed to turnover by furniture has been increasing continually since 2008
column86: to the detriment of clothing. In the case of off-the-rack clothing
column87:
the volume is becoming lower and lower and the company recently abandoned the manufacture of women’s off-the-rack clothing because of weak demand. The volume of clothing produced develops according to demands of clients of the company. In a case of urgent demand for clothing the company is prepared to increase its production.

\r\n

The company has never had – and still does not have – any cohesive restructuring plan. However
column88: for the purpose of receiving bank credit
column89: it must prepare two-year business plans. According to Mr Havel
column90: these two-year plans are sufficient. He claims that
column91: within the textile industry
column92: it is not worthwhile to plan for a longer timeframe due to the rapid ageing of production. The situation with furniture is different – it has a longer physical and functional useful life. In addition to Mr Havel
column93:
the company’s sales director and financial analyst also participate in decision-making about restructuring issues.

\r\n

The business strategy to move to a different product portfolio originated gradually. At various trade fairs that Mr Havel visited in Southeast Asia (Shanghai
column94: Canton
column95: Djakarta
column96: Singapore
column97: New Delhi
column98: Dhaka and Taipei)
column99: he established contacts with furniture manufacturers. Within the company itself

This was easy because the main principles of their work remain the same and only the object of business has changed. The retraining was announced to employees just at the beginning of this restructuring process. column102: which threatened their jobs. The creative division changed its focus from fashion to furniture and home accessories. In the case of the internet shops

the company hired software specialists.

Approximately 135 employees have been made redundant since 1994 as a consequence of outsourcing the production to China. In the period of internal restructuring (2008–2012) the number of employees decreased by 30; however

The selection of employees who became unemployed was made according to the needs of company as the effectiveness of the production had to be maintained. However
column105:
Mr Havel maintained the jobs of hardworking lone parents whose redundancies would have exposed them to a very difficult situation. The dismissal was announced to all relevant workers in advance. All the dismissed workers got severance pay according to law.

The restructuring steps were financed from the company’s own resources and with the use of the company’s existing revolving credit account (the limit is CZK 10 million (approximately €400

column108:
000)).

Challenges and constraints of restructuring

When evaluating restructuring activities from the perspective of small and medium-sized enterprises
column109: Mr Havel believes that the restructuring of the product portfolio is more complex than the restructuring of other areas
column110: mainly because it requires great support in the form of human resources

column112: this was especially valid concerning the transformation of the company’s product portfolio. This transformation required especially capable designers and it was hard to find them. If Mr Havel could turn back the clock and perform the restructuring process again

column115: a high-quality workforce plays a decisive role in the success of every company. In this respect
column116: Mr Havel draws attention to the weak position of small and medium-sized enterprises
column117:
which cannot afford to pay for ads on the large job portals such as www.jobs.cz.

\r\n

On the other hand
column118: small and medium-sized enterprises are more flexible but
column119: at the same time
column120: also place greater demands on a flexible workforce. As an example

column122:
he changed the job descriptions of two or three people every month.

Restructuring advice and support

Mr Havel did not feel the need to receive any significant level of support during the restructuring process. He continues to feel this way even looking back in retrospect.

Outcomes of restructuring

Mr Havel hopes that the restructuring is going smoothly – as the restructuring is not yet complete

column124: in due course

and the annual recertification requirement provides the initiative to evaluate production processes and redefine them as required.

\r\n

The impact of internal restructuring on employment is not clear as it is hard to distinguish it from the impact on employment associated with the offshoring of clothing production to China. This kind of restructuring

column131: 45 in 2012). Concerning the period of the internal restructuring (approximately 2008–2012)

column133: or by restructuring the operation of boiling room. However
column134: most of the redundancies were made in the clothing and furniture warehouse. The company’s employee headcount also reduced naturally to a large degree as employees retired. Mr Havel estimates that the share of those who left voluntarily was about 50% of the total number of employees who were made redundant. There were no redundancies in the business department
column135: which is very important as a support for the import activities. The company did not hire any new production workers for six years. If any were hired
column136:
it was only for a limited period of time.

\r\n

The dismissal preceded redeployment. Mr Havel specified that during the restructuring period
column137:
he changed the job descriptions of two or three people every month and by some of them even repeatedly (therefore it is hard to give a concrete number for employees redeployed). Such frequent changes naturally annoyed employees; they felt uncertainty and needed to struggle with new tasks. However they tried to adapt to such changes in order to maintain their jobs in a region where the unemployment rate was 9.8% at the end of 2012.

Taking into account the fact that the importance of the production operations is already minimal in Prostějov

especially with respect to unstable exchange rates of dollar and euro.

\r\n

From the perspective of the company’s employees

has already shut down) place a higher value on their jobs.

\r\n

As far as the company’s turnover is concerned
column147: thus far the restructuring measures have not yet brought the desired key effect with regard to increasing turnover. On the other hand
column148: the reduction in turnover from the clothing line is gradually being replaced by increased turnover from the furniture and home accessory product lines. This is another key objective for the future – to expand trading with household textiles
column149:
home accessories and furniture (currently the share held by furniture is growing by approximately 30% annually).

\r\n

Mrs Kolářová has experienced both the company’s good year in 2008 as well as the subsequent decrease in production. For this reason she was able to evaluate the changes that were made at the company. According to her

000) in 2010 and in 2012 it will be a ‘positive’ zero.

Commentary

Background to restructuring event

Restructuring processes

The production component of the restructuring included: diversification of the electrical equipment produced

expansion of business relations with partners in neighbouring countries. All these activities were developed in a period of one to two years as a step-by-step process.

\r\n

The management informed and involved the employees during the different stages of the restructuring and considered that this was one of the main reasons for the success of the restructuring process. The good organisation on the part of management and close involvement with the employees led to a smooth restructuring process.

\r\n

This opinion on the part of management was confirmed in an interview with an employee in the trade department
column50:
who expressed also the opinion that the employees had benefited from the way the restructuring was implemented and its results: no one was laid off and payments and benefits were preserved. Both management and employees agreed that the flexibility of small firms is the reason for better planning and implementation of restructuring in comparison with large firms.

Challenges and constraints of restructuring

Difficulties and problems experienced during planning and implementation of the restructuring process included:

  • Lack of cash in-flow.
  • Delays in deliveries of equipment from European firms
column51:
resulting in working conditions where the company could not fulfill its obligations to third parties.
  • Delays in payments from customers. This is among the most serious constraints faced by Bulgarian businesses (SMEs in particular). According to the biggest Bulgarian business association (Bulgarian Industrial Association)
column52:
inter-company indebtedness is actually the biggest problem for the Bulgarian economy. Estimates are that it amounts to BGN 100 billion (€50 billion). Many Bulgarian firms are simply not paying for goods or services they order.

All of these factors affected the work of the company very badly because they prevented it from managing its financial operations properly.

Restructuring advice and support

The whole process of restructuring took place without any support from public bodies. The company needed financial support for some construction activities but it was not delivered by the banks. In reality some indirect support was delivered by their Polish partners
column53: who
column54: after long negotiations
column55: rescheduled the payments from Intercomplex Ltd.for some of the supplies. Thus
column56:
they decreased the financial pressure on Intercomplex Ltd.

Outcomes of restructuring

The restructuring took place according to the adjusted plans of the company. The restructuring resulted in the planned outcomes for the company
column57: but it happened at the expense of company profit. In general
column58: the employment effect was positive
column59: although at certain periods some of the workers were on paid leave (this is a regime allowed by the labour legislation in Bulgaria and is commonly used during crisis periods). The management also put the emphasis on hiring young people. The management considers as a success the fact that they have kept their qualified personnel
column60: a very difficult task nowadays in the Bulgarian economy. The business performance of the company was kept at an acceptable level
column61:
too.

\r\n

Future plans of Intercomplex Ltd. include investment of around €1 million for a second production base in the town of Septemvri
column62: thus creating 50 new jobs. The development of these plans depends very much on the overall economic development of Bulgaria
column63:
the situation in this sector and the financial situation of the firm. The future plans also include better cooperation with their German partners.

\r\n

The economic situation of the company improved more quickly than expected. In general
column64:
the restructuring process was not easy.

Commentary

Some of the lessons learnt were that:

  • the banks should increase access to credits for firms during crisis;
  • less availability of investments leads to losses in firms in a period of crisis;
  • economic and financial crisis showed the necessity of being realistic;
  • it is better to stay relatively small – this allows for easy restructuring
column65:
organisation and management of the firm.

Important success factors were:

  • restructuring of the financial funds has to be constantly under consideration during the restructuring process;
  • the process of negotiations with banks has positive learning effects and hopefully will help the management with their relations with banks and other investors in the near future. Some of the lessons include: better understanding how to negotiate with banks; improved knowledge about internationalisation and interconnection between different firms; best practice of how to develop business; organisational behaviour of the firm during crisis period
column66: not only within the branch or the region
column67:
but throughout the country and\r\nEU.;\r\n
  • during the long period of crisis
column68:
management always has to be ready to react to the current and future situations;
  • it is very important to convene strategic suppliers to agree to delay the date of the payment;
  • open communication with the banks
column69:
suppliers and employees is required for smooth restructuring of the company;

The crisis situation has to be seen as a chance to improve all aspects of business performance of the company.

Lito Balkan,Bulgaria~"Lito Balkan"~"

When confronted with the effects of the global economic crisis
column2: increasing competition and decreasing demand for the current production
column3: the management of the Bulgarian company Lito Balkan decided to expand and diversify by acquiring machinery to make new products. This resulted in access to new clients
column4:
a widening of their market and an increase in profits.

"~"

Organisational profile

Lito Balkan was founded in October 1997 as a joint stock company of 100% private capital in the printing and publishing sector. The 60 shareholders of the company include some of its staff or natural persons
column5: owners of companies acting as clients to the printing house
column6:
such as advertising agencies and publishers. The five members of the management team have all completed higher education in the printing and publishing fields and have each more than 20 years of specialised work experience.

\r\n

Boris Dimitrov has been executive director of the firm since 1999. He has a Masters degree from the Polygraphic Institute and has worked in the field of printing and publishing for 40 years. Over the past 30 years
column7:
he has worked as deputy director or director of different printing companies. He is the founder and co-owner of Lito Balkan. Mr Dimitrov has experience in the restructuring of firms. His motto is ‘Do not run! You should have started on time!’

\r\n

The firm has 89 employees
column8: most of them graduates of vocational schools of printing. Almost 50% are women
column9:
and the average age of the employees is 40.

There is no works council or trade union branch in the company (similar to almost all SMEs in Bulgaria).

Lito Balkan has an HR development programme which includes the continuous improvement of workers’ qualifications. This is a major reason for the limited staff turnover in the company.

Since 2004
column10: at the request of Disney America
column11: an annual international social audit has been carried out to ensure compliance with health and safety requirements and the local labour legislation
column12:
which the company has successfully passed.

The main competing tools of the company are high quality and short terms of the contract implementation. The company’s basic operational channels are: magazines and albums – 30% of the total volume; advertising – 30%; labels – 30%; books (paperback and hard cover) – 10%.

The company was awarded an ISO 9001-2000 certificate by TUF Rheinland InterCert.

The annual volume growth is between 10 and 25%. The profit in 2010 was low and in 2009 very low. Both sales and profits rose in 2011 in comparison with 2010.

Lito Balkan’s main clients are: Carlsberg Bulgaria; Coca-Cola Bulgaria; Egmont Bulgaria (a Walt Disney division for children’s literature)
column13:
as well as a number of publishers and magazines in Bulgaria.

\r\n

About 15% of the produce is intended for export to Russia
column14: Greece
column15: France
column16:
Italy and Switzerland.

\r\n

The technical equipment is as follows: a violet laser; sheet offset presses; binding machines; three folding machines
column17: two straight binding cutters
column18:
and two label die-cutting machines.

\r\n

The company operates a full in-house production cycle. The availability of the equipment allows for the operation of a full technological cycle with sufficient flexibility. Lito Balkan printing house is the only one in Bulgaria with installed production line for multiple sheet spiral bound calendars. Additional customised binding machines are also available.

\r\n

The company has a successful investment programme. In 2000 it bought the Sts. Cyril and Methodius printing house from the Bulgarian Ministry of Finance in Sofia and over the past five years
column19: using various forms of financing (leasing
column20: internal credits
column21: etc.)
column22:
it managed to install and bring to full functionality equipment worth more than €3.5 million.

\r\n

The latest big investment of the company in the amount of €2.5 million is in the framework of its Investment Programme for Modernisation
column23:
which is the restructuring event described below. It was cofinanced by the Operative Programme ‘Development of Competitiveness of Bulgarian Economy 2007–2013’ and includes a new state of the art machine for labels and binding: the Gallus RC 430. This puts Lito Balkan in a leading position in this area in the whole of eastern Europe.

Background to restructuring event

The reason for the company restructuring was the need to find new clients
column24: to enter the new markets of labels and folding
column25:
and to improve the quality of production.

\r\n

In fact
column26: the start of the restructuring coincided with the beginning of the economic crisis. New developments included: the increasing competition in the branch
column27:
the decline in demand for the current production and an active motivation of owners and managers to expand and diversify.

\r\n

The restructuring was planned in advance
column28: on an annual basis
column29:
and the decision to restructure was taken by the board of directors of the company one year before the restructuring event. No other options for restructuring were considered because it was clear to the management that the introduction of a new printing machine was the only possibility for business expansion. The organisational stage of the preparation of the project was about six months.

The restructuring concept and the measures planned were developed by the company’s management on the basis of their long experience of dealing with the strengths and weaknesses of the company.

Restructuring processes

The restructuring event took the form of business expansion – more specifically
column30: the acquisition of a new printing machine for labels folding/binding
column31: which brought new clients
column32:
widening the market and increasing profit. The restructuring process started in June 2009 and ended December 2009.

\r\n

The restructuring plan was implemented through drafting the project for cofinancing from the ‘Competitiveness’ Operational Programme. Unfortunately
column33: the time schedule for the restructuring event was delayed by seven months
column34: because of a delay in the selection procedure of the proposed projects. This delay created some problems for the firm and postponed the plans for development. After the approval of the project the process went smoothly – finalisation of negotiations and dealing with the sellers of the printing machine
column35: installation of the machine
column36: training of employees
column37: testing of the production process. The financing of the restructuring was 80% own funds of the firm
column38:
and 20% from the Operational Programme.

\r\n

The whole process was supported by the workforce because they understood that the restructuring would save or even increase jobs.

\r\n

Interviews with employees confirmed the opinion of the management that one of the biggest success factors of restructuring was the lack of labour turnover. The organisational restructuring of the firm
column39: after the acquisition of a new machine
column40: led to a reduction in the number of workers in some departments. These workers were transferred to work with the new label and folding machine. The transfer concerned about 10 workers
column41: who accepted the change of work station and did it voluntarily; thus no redundancy was observed. Obviously they took into account the worsening economic situation at that moment. The management organised good information sessions on the forthcoming changes. The reaction of the employees was very positive – they understand very well the need for transformation of the business. Obviously they preferred transformation to losing their jobs. The prevailing opinion is that small firms have advantages in planning and implementing restructuring in comparison with larger companies. The advantages of SMEs include flexible HR
column42: better adaptability
column43: easier management
column44: less formal organisational process
column45:
and so on.

Challenges and constraints of restructuring

During the planning and implementation of the restructuring event
column46: no serious difficulties or problems were observed
column47: except the already mentioned delay by seven months for approval of the project. Otherwise
column48:
the process of applying and approval of the project went smoothly.

Restructuring advice and support

Financial support for buying the new machine came through the ‘Competitiveness’ Operational Programme
column49: which is focused on provision of support to Bulgarian business
column50: in particular SMEs. Apart from the co-financing support by the Operational Programme
column51: the company did not receive any advice or support from the state authorities
column52: banks or media. The management of Lito Balkan tried to explore all these possibilities
column53: but failed. In the past few years the importance of the Operational Programmes for Bulgarian business has increased because of the lack of funding from other financial sources. The combination of EU funds and national budget cofinancing proved to be successful. The fact that firms could not count on banks’ financing
column54: unlike in previous years
column55:
pushed enterprises to be more active in applying for projects for funding from the Operational Programmes.

Technical support through experts and training (financed by the project) was provided when the new machinery was put into operation.

Outcomes of restructuring

In general
column56: the restructuring
column57: although somewhat delayed
column58:
took place according to plan. The employment effect was the preservation of the number of employees during the period of economic crisis. The firm prepared for a long time for this investment and mobilised all of its financial resources to purchase the new machine. The pay and benefits of the employees were preserved and during the last two years even increased.

\r\n

The purchase of a new machine was for the purpose of closing the production cycle
column59:
which has led to a complete organisational change in the firm.

\r\n

Various organisational adjustments were made: a new structure was approved and enforced
column60: new departments developed their activities
column61: the organisational chain in every department was streamlined
column62: and the functions of all employees were described in more detailed manner. The restructuring is having a positive effect on the business performance of the company in terms of an increase in profit
column63: retaining staff
column64: closing the production cycle
column65: diversification of products
column66:
and an improvement in the quality of printing materials.

\r\n

The overall outcome of the restructuring was considered positive by both the management and the employees. For the time being
column67:
management has no future plans regarding the business strategy of the firm.

Commentary

The following lessons were learned:

  • During a period of crisis SMEs have to diversify their activities.
  • It is very important to invest in new products in a timely manner.
  • SMEs have advantages over larger companies in planning and implementing restructuring because they are more flexible in production and management.
  • During an economic crisis
column68: state institutions have to\r\ndevelop a new policy and instruments for support of SMEs
column69: such as easier credit\r\nfor SMEs
column70: improvement of the business environment
column71:
decrease of administrative burden.
  • The ‘grey’ sector is a real threat to the development of SMEs
column72:
which are following the rules of the game especially during a time of crisis.
  • Success is possible with a high level of work input and personal engagement
column73:
both by the management and the staff.

The main success factors identified were:

  • A clear concept for restructuring is not enough for success: a huge amount of organisational work and self-help activities have to be done in order to achieve success.
  • During the period of restructuring
column74:
the company has to\r\nprepare and adapt the internal structure for further growth.\r\n
  • All players – owners
column75: management
column76:
employees – have to recognise that they all have to bear the negative consequences of the crisis and its influence on the company.
  • It is very important for the management to do its best to let the workers know that employers
column77: by taking different measures
column78:
are trying to maintain the highest possible number of jobs in the firm.
  • Lack of information concerning the upcoming changes in the firm often leads to rumours or fears or even a mistrustful atmosphere in the company
column79: which always slows down the restructuring process (fortunately
column80:
this company did not experience such a situation).

column1: MERET, Slovakia~"MERET
column2:
