"~"

Organisational profile

Omega Dairy Products Ltd is a company operating in the dairy manufacturing sector in Cyprus
column4: producing traditional dairy products such as halloumi (a semi-hard
column5: unripened brined cheese)
column6: anari (a soft Ricotta-like cheese made from whey)
column7: and yoghurt. It should be noted that Omega is an assumed name
column8:
and the actual names of the company and persons mentioned in this report are not disclosed at the request of the owner/managers.

\r\n

The company was founded in 1960. The shareholders are two brothers
column9: having equal ownership. They acquired Omega Dairies in 1980
column10: a company that was owned and managed by a different family. The brothers decided to acquire Omega because their parents were engaged in the domestic
column11:
small-scale production of dairy products and they were used to this kind of work. They had always wanted to have their own business in producing traditional Cypriot dairy products and to keep alive their family tradition. Acquiring Omega (as opposed to establishing a new business) offered a means to capitalise on a business that already had an established reputation and access to retail channels.

\r\n

The general manager of the company is one of the brothers
column12: who has a mechanical engineering background and who had previously been in charge of a major paper product manufacturer. This is a first-generation family business
column13: involving both its senior and the junior generations. One brother has a son who is in charge of production
column14:
while the other has a daughter and a son that are involved in sales.

\r\n

The organisational structure of Omega Dairies Ltd is that
column15: at the top of the hierarchy is one of the brothers
column16: the general manager
column17: who also is the quality manager. Other key company managers include the production manager (son of the general manager)
column18: the head of the maintenance department
column19:
and the sales and marketing manager (the other brother). Another key department is the accounting department.

\r\n

The company employs 35 individuals
column20: mainly semi-skilled
column21: the majority being female (around 60%). The employees are not represented by any works council or trade union. The company has a production capacity of around six million litres of milk annually
column22: aiming to increase this by greater expansion into markets within the EU. Omega is an international company
column23: with 70% of total production being exported. Markets abroad currently being served include the United Kingdom
column24: Germany
column25: Sweden
column26: Greece
column27: Finland
column28:
and Estonia.

\r\n

Cyprus’ accession to the EU in 2004
column29: as well as the efforts of the management to facilitate further company growth
column30:
led to a number of changes being introduced. These included:

• establishing a new factory in the late 1990s;

• reengineering key processes and systems as part of the harmonisation with respective EU regulations in 2003;

• the acquisition of new machinery and the expansion of production capacity in 2005 due to the initiation of exports

• the decision to subcontract a part of product distribution in 2010.

Since 2005
column31: when the company started exporting
column32: there has been an impressive growth in company revenues. While in 2005 total revenues were €2 million
column33: in 2011 annual revenues reached €5.5 million. This is translated into a 16.7% average annual growth in revenues between 2005 and 2011. As for the profitability
column34: between 2005 and 2010
column35: the company had a 3% average annual growth in net profits. 2011
column36: however
column37: was the first year that the company recorded losses. There was a 1% net loss
column38: partly due to the financial crisis
column39:
the unsuccessful restructuring that the company undertook (described later) and the fact that the company invested in new machinery and equipment acquisition during 2011.

\r\n

Background to restructuring event

\r\n

In January 2010
column40: the company decided to outsource a part of its product distribution to an external provider. The agreement established between the two parties allowed Epsilon Ltd (an assumed name) to distribute and sell Omega’s dairy products to retail outlets around the country. Omega
column41: though
column42: kept the distribution and sales of its products to other clients
column43: mainly wholesalers
column44:
including exports abroad. This meant that approximately 50% of total distribution on a local basis would be facilitated by Epsilon.

\r\n

The company decided to outsource the retail distribution function as a means of avoiding the excessive costs associated with maintaining an extensive distribution network and concentrating efforts in key practices such as production and export. In this way
column45: the company would be able to realise its dual aim of both cost minimisation (that is efficiency) and further company growth. Another reason for this decision was the credit crunch
column46: which started becoming evident during 2009. This led to a number of retailers not paying on time
column47:
with many major retail chains paying six months after they received products from manufacturers.

\r\n

As part of this restructuring event
column48: the two parties agreed that Epsilon would buy the products at a discounted rate from Omega
column49: while paying the manufacturer within 75 days. In this way
column50:
Omega was aspiring to solve the problem of late payments and have a healthier cash flow to run the company.

\r\n

Restructuring processes

\r\n

The agreement between Omega and Epsilon needed three months
column51: in total
column52: to be finalised. The restructuring process started in January 2010 and ended in March 2010. The decision to outsource retail distribution was made with little planning. As emphasised by the owner/manager being interviewed
column53: while this decision was on the table for a period of time
column54: the decision to outsource was mainly driven by the increasing pressure of late payments in the market and the restrictions that this created in facilitating further company growth. It was just a month before the actual negotiations with the provider
column55:
that Omega’s management decided to outsource retail distribution.

\r\n

The choice of outsourcing distribution had been considered by the management for some years. The idea was that this would help the company in focusing on more core activities that was the production of dairy products and further company expansion through exports abroad. According to the general manager
column56: some companies had previously approached Omega with offers to take over the retail distribution of their products. However
column57: as he emphasised
column58: it was after getting exposed in the credit pressures of the market during 2009 that they actually started thinking seriously about this option. During this year
column59: Omega was approached by Epsilon
column60: a newly established business. Epsilon was set up as a company for the purpose of being a mediator between manufacturers and retailers. Taking advantage of the upcoming crisis
column61: Epsilon targeted a number of manufacturers that it felt would be willing to outsource their retail distribution function. To induce them to cooperate
column62: Epsilon promised it could help manufacturers receive money on time for their sales. Omega
column63: which at that time was receiving money from retailers 180–200 days after delivery
column64:
was persuaded to collaborate by Epsilon who assured that payments would be received within 75 days.

\r\n

The agreement between Omega and Epsilon came about as a result of negotiations between the management of the two companies. The person in charge of the negotiations on behalf of Omega was the general manager
column65: who was engaged in the needed discussions with Epsilon for the finalisation of the outsourcing agreement. Both sides put on the table their requirements
column66: which were thoroughly discussed for reaching common points of agreement. Omega went to the negotiations with a concern around late payments
column67: aiming to establish an agreement that would allow them to receive money from the sales of their products within 60 days. On the other hand
column68: Epsilon was looking into an agreement that would allow them a satisfactory profit margin from Omega sales. The end of the negotiations led both parties in satisfying their concerns. Under the agreement between the two parties
column69:
Omega would receive payments within 75 days and Epsilon was satisfied by the prices offered by Omega on their products.

\r\n

No formal plans were in place to accompany the restructuring event. The only formal aspect of the whole restructuring process was the contract that was decided and signed between the two parties. Omega’s management did not engage in any formal planning that would accompany the implementation of the restructuring event. This was primarily informal. Problems and complexities were mostly tackled on a reactive basis. However
column70: as it was emphasised in the interviews
column71:
no major difficulties were met throughout the restructuring process.

\r\n

Employees were informed about the outsourcing after the finalisation of the agreement
column72: during an intra-company training session where all employees were involved. There was no particular reaction on the part of employees
column73: who showed no resistance to the decision of the owners to outsource the retail distribution. The fact that the business managed this change with extra care was a reason for not experiencing any reaction. According to the general manager
column74: the employees were reassured constantly that no changes would affect the way each person carried out their  tasks. However
column75: three employees were laid off as a result of the restructuring and one employee that had to be moved to  production. All these individuals had been  occupied in product distribution to retail channels. Though a sensitive issue
column76: the company managed to deal with this successfully. Financial compensation was provided to those employees laid off
column77: and successful efforts were made to secure employment for them in other businesses. During the interviews
column78: the general manager mentioned that these employees seemed to have understood the situation and the reasons behind the termination of their employment. The management of the company had discussions with each of these employees separately
column79:
explaining the situation in detail and assuring them they would provide all the necessary financial and other support. This extra care helped avoid any reaction from other employees.

\r\n

Employees were excluded from the restructuring process and relevant decisions within. No consultation with employees took place as part of this process. The three employees laid off were informed after the finalisation of the agreement with Epsilon
column80:
and after careful discussion between the company’s managers. All three employees were given a month’s notice prior to terminating their employment.

Challenges and constraints of restructuring

Difficulties in the course of the restructuring process were mainly financially related. The first thing the company needed to secure during this process was the bank guarantees of the agreement. This took time
column81: since Omega wanted to obtain bank guarantees from the contracting party (that is
column82: Epsilon) prior of finalising the agreement. This was to make sure that Epsilon would fulfil its obligations as a contracting party and to insure Omega from loss or damage due to non-performance by Epsilon. As emphasised by the owner–manager interviewed
column83: such guarantees are essential at the early start of an agreement
column84: and it is through time that trust between contracting parties is built. In this way
column85:
Omega felt sure that the subcontractor would be able to fulfil its contractual obligations.

\r\n

Restructuring advice and support

\r\n

Omega’s management received no particular financial or non-financial support in its efforts to finalise the outsourcing agreement. In fact
column86: all negotiations and decisions were made by the general manager
column87: while consulting other members of the owning family such as his brother and their children involved in business. The fact that all the family was supporting the general manager and was embracing all his choices was very important in taking the final decision to outsource the retail distribution function of the business. This made the general feel more confident in taking actions on this matter. However
column88: he mentioned the drawback that the family had no specialised knowledge of outsourcing issues. As a result
column89:
much of the support that he was getting from other family members was mainly psychological.

\r\n

The costs of outsourcing were covered in full by the contracting parties. In fact
column90: Omega did not have any significant costs
column91:
since no investments were necessary. The only costs involved related to compensation for the employees that were laid off.

\r\n

No governmental or EU schemes were available
column92: at that time
column93: to support such a restructuring. The owner–manager mentioned that their needs were of a financial nature
column94:
but that there was a need for proper advice and consultancy support for making sure that restructuring would be conducted the right way.

\r\n

Restructuring advice was desirable at the time of the negotiations and the whole restructuring process. However
column95: while it was acknowledged that external support from specialist consultants would be particularly useful in managing the whole process
column96:
the management decided against this option as it wanted to minimise costs.

\r\n

Outcomes of restructuring

\r\n

Prior to outsourcing
column97: the company received money owed by clients within 180 to 200 days. The aim of the company was that the contractual agreement with Epsilon would allow Omega to collect money within 75 days. However
column98: the outcomes of the restructuring were not as expected. As emphasised by the general manager
column99: cash was hardly ever received within 75 days
column100: since the subcontractor was also facing a lot of difficulties in receiving money on time. As a result
column101: the planned financial gains for the company were never met
column102: and indeed the decision to outsource the retail distribution brought additional problems for Omega
column103: such as further cash flow problems and reduced profitability. While the managers expected to collect receivables much earlier (that is
column104: within 75 days)
column105: they found themselves in a similar situation to the pre-restructuring period
column106: collecting cash after 150 days. However
column107: the fact that products were now supplied at a lower price to the subcontractor meant that the company faced an additional financial burden as revenues and profits were lower than before. In fact
column108: the performance of the company was influenced negatively
column109: and this was one of the reasons for the net loss that the company exhibited for the first time since 1980. The company was facing a dilemma at the time of the interviews
column110: looking into various options that would help remedy the situation. The general manager mentioned that returning back to wholly controlled retail distribution would not solve this problem
column111:
emphasising that they were in such a difficult financial situation that they might also start considering selling the business.

\r\n

The restructuring event brought changes to employee structure and staffing. As mentioned
column112: three people were laid off. These included individuals employed in  distribution
column113: which was outsourced. At the same time
column114: a fourth person was relocated to the production department
column115: as a result of the company’s efforts to strengthen this division. No negative consequences resulted for the business as a result of the need to lay off employees. Since the business provided financial compensations to these employees and exhibited a willingness to help them find employment elsewhere
column116: this was seen positively not only by the affected individuals but from all the company employees.. Indeed
column117: the Omega management persuaded Epsilon to recruit one of these three individuals while
column118: after communication with companies in Omega’s network
column119:
jobs were secured for the other two.

\r\n

The general manager acknowledged that a number of lessons were learnt from this restructuring. In fact
column120: he presented this event as a failure that has to be the driving force of future actions. The management team
column121: in fact
column122: failed to realise the planned scenario of collecting receivables within 75 days and this led to a further worsening of the financial condition of the company. He mentioned that this ‘failure’ led him to reflect on the mistakes that were made in the course of the outsourcing decision and the agreement with Epsilon. He emphasised that next time around he would formally plan such actions
column123: while asking for the support of specialist consultants in undertaking a formal evaluation prior to the event
column124:
and in participating in the actual negotiations. This would help to minimise pitfalls after the implementation of the agreement.

\r\n

Commentary

\r\n

This case study provides useful lessons that can be considered by businesses during restructuring events. While Omega’s management was aspiring to obtain faster payments and thus better cash flow management through outsourcing the retail distribution function
column125: things did not go as planned. One reason for the failure to facilitate changes that would help to improve competitiveness appears to be that the management failed to appreciate the complexities involved in the particular restructuring event. Reflecting on the agreement made with the subcontractor and the process that they went through to materialise this restructuring
column126:
the management admitted that the idea to outsource might have been a big mistake.

\r\n

The failure of Omega’s management reveals major issues that need to be considered during business restructuring. The first was the hasty decision to move on with business restructuring without proper preparation. Omega’s management appeared to have undervalued the significance of preparation prior to negotiations. Such preparation could have included a feasibility study
column127: due diligence for a thorough investigation of the contracting party
column128: and proper planning that would help set the foundations for the effective implementation of restructuring and the management of change. Simulation and sensitivity analysis would again help obtain a complete understanding of different scenarios in the agreement
column129: prior to its enforcement. These tools could help management to gain a thorough understanding of the situation and decide: first
column130: whether restructuring would be wise and
column131: second
column132:
how this process could ideally be managed.

\r\n

The second major issue that stems from the case is the fact that formal agreements may not necessarily bind two parties in a mutually acceptable performance. While there was agreement on behalf of Epsilon to pay within 75 days
column133: this clause was never met and this was one of the reasons for Omega experiencing losses after the restructuring. An option for Omega was to terminate the contract with Epsilon. But the general manager did not see this as viable since the company would need to invest in reorganising product distribution. As a result
column134: the company chose to do nothing and therefore experienced losses and cash flow problems as a result of the late payments by Epsilon. This could have been avoided
column135: however
column136:
if Omega’s management had fully understood the decision to outsource and the risks associated with it. One option to avoid this would have been for the company to have had a back-up or reaction plan in the event that the subcontractor would not meet the terms of the initial agreement.

\r\n

As emphasised by the general manager during the interviews
column137: Omega asked from Epsilon certain bank guarantees prior to the agreement. While these were met
column138: Omega did not exercise the right to claim money as a result of the unsatisfactory performance by the subcontractor. This was not made on due to fears about the uncertainly that would unfold in the case of the termination of the agreement with Epsilon. A back-up plan
column139: however
column140: could have outlined the next steps in case of such a scenario and would have helped the Omega’s management to take the necessary steps to minimise potential losses for the company. In this case
column141:
it could perhaps have been wise for Omega’s management to ask for the help of an experienced consultant in order to avoid the risks of such a negative scenario.

Background to restructuring event

The holding company was in no way involved in the restructuring process

Challenges and constraints of restructuring

Due to the considerable changes the expansion/innovation brought about for nearly all jobs

The recruitment of the additional staff required because of the expansion was a challenge as it is difficult to make a decision suitable for both sides solely on the basis of written documents (CV) and one or few job interviews. The lack of skilled workers is a problem

Another challenge has been the time required for the application for public financial support

Restructuring advice and support

Due to the innovative character of the planned production plant

Outcomes of restructuring

The company has expanded because it now has a new production plant as well as its original one. The new technology

The management estimates that

column112:

The management considers the restructuring not only as a means of expanding its product portfolio

\r\n

The whole process of restructuring was funded by firm’s own financial resources. For example
column49:
in 2005–2007 almost all profit was directed toward investments in restructuring.

\r\n

The workers were informed about the restructuring process and most of them showed high commitment during the whole restructuring period. They well understood the need for modernisation during a time of crisis. To some extent
column50: the crisis triggered the restructuring
column51:
but the process was also a part of the continuous efforts of the owners and management to improve the work of the firm.

Challenges and constraints of restructuring

The main challenge experienced by the firm during the planning and implementation of restructuring was the long and complicated process of licensing new products – mostly veterinary drugs – as well as licensing products for selling in other countries (which can take at least two to three years). These long delays have a negative impact on the whole firm’s activity
column52: especially in the field of exports
column53:
because it prevents the firm from being able to service the requests of international partners.

Restructuring advice and support

The firm managed to carry out the restructuring without any advice or support. They relied entirely on their and their business partners’ (suppliers and customers) professional resources. This required a good understanding of the temporary constraints and breach of contractual obligations
column54: business advice and counselling. Access to bank loans was very difficult
column55:
so the company decided to apply for finance from European funds.

\r\n

Unfortunately their proposal for the project for the Operational Programme ‘Competitiveness’ was rejected on the grounds of what they consider to be ‘formal reasons’. Therefore the firm had to develop new products by using their own funds. Management feel the Bulgarian administration is still not prepared to support and help Bulgarian business
column56:
especially during a crisis.

Outcomes of restructuring

On the whole
column57: the restructuring process took place according to the management’s initial plans for the firm’s business development
column58:
and the planned outcomes were achieved.

  • Employees were encouraged
column59: through a series of meetings
column60:
to participate in the restructuring plans. These led to better understanding of the process of restructuring and active participation in it.
  • The number of employees increased from 25 to 45 because of the business development of the firm. All newly recruited employees had the required professional training
column61:
selected according to the firm’s standard procedures.
  • The working conditions improved (most of the staff are working in the new building with improved health and safety conditions
column62: and new
column63:
\r\nmodern equipment was introduced).\r\n
  • Due to the improvement of the production process
column64: \r\nintroduction of new technologies and the new organisational structure
column65:
the quality of the production was improved and the range of the vet products was expanded.
  • Exports increased.
  • Employees’ salaries increased and are now above the Bulgarian average.
  • The introduction of the new organisational structure proved to be successful.

    • The general reaction of the employees was very positive. This opinion of the management was confirmed by an interview with one staff member of the commercial department. She considers that the changes made in the firm during the last ten years have benefited both employees and the business of the company. The changes were especially successful in finding new foreign markets
column66:
which resulted in better economic results for the company during the last few years. That was reflected by an increase of wages for staff.

Primavet-Sofia Ltd. plans to continue to focus on innovation and better business performance.

Commentary

The major success factors of the restructuring process were identified as:

  • a pro-active and strategic approach;
  • close personal engagement and initiative by the manager and owners;
  • economic and commercial expertise;
  • development of a sense of taking responsibility by the management and the majority of staff;
  • timely implementation of tasks;
  • concentration on the core competences of the firm;
  • organising a more active form of sales;
  • an honest attitude towards employees;
  • the willingness of most employees to adapt to the speed of the changes.

Management also feels that their staff understands that an increase in wages and the hiring of extra staff during a crisis is a sign of a good management. However
column67: management would like to see an improvement in the bureaucracy of state administration
column68:
which they think is a prerequisite for better business performance. Management also feels that constant restructuring is the key to success in the 21st century – overcoming the status quo is a permanent job.

Royal Tsatsoulis Bros, Greece~"Royal Tsatsoulis Bros"~"

The case of Greek food processing company RTB highlights a successful SME restructuring event where family control and entrepreneurial skills played a major role. The owners–managers were free to plan and execute their ideas
column2: and also to adapt the restructuring process at all stages
column3:
leading ultimately to a growth in turnover and satisfactory profitability. There was also very direct and efficient communication with employees during the process.

"~"

Organisational profile

Royal Tsatsoulis Bros (RTB) is located in the industrial area of Xanthi in north-eastern Greece
column4: and has a strong international presence. The company business is the food and beverages sector
column5: particularly the processing of fresh vegetables
column6: such as peppers
column7: olives
column8:
tomatoes and pickled vegetables.

\r\n

RTB is a family-owned business founded in 1925 by the current owners’ grandfather in Kavala (35 km from its current location). The two owners succeeded their father as owners and managers. The company started by selling pickles in large volumes for the Greek market and has now expanded into new markets and products. In 1967 RTB initiated exporting to Germany
column9:
taking advantage of the strong presence of Greek immigrants there. The company’s first foray into exporting had been in 1936 by the current owners’ grandfather who reached an agreement to export pickled vegetables stored in wooden barrels to England. It was not until 1986 that the company decided to start packaging its products in jars under the company’s label.

\r\n

This decision was further fostered by the company’s relocation to Xanthi in 1998
column10: where two main advantages were evident: first
column11: the opportunity to use a biological system of cleaning of waste water and
column12: second
column13: the opportunity to expand the processing system by importing new technology (machines) that would allow the company to offer new products in labelled jars and other packages. Following relocation
column14: RTB was able to take make economies of scale and promote products to large retailers
column15: such as supermarkets. The company was soon able to enter additional foreign markets
column16: such as Saudi Arabia
column17: while continuously expanding its production process and its variety of products (such as vegetables stuffed with cheese and other delicatessen items). Nowadays
column18: the company exports to 28 different countries
column19: ranging from America to the Ukraine
column20: Finland and Africa. Exports represent almost 80% of annual sales. The company sells to all major supermarkets
column21: and can offer customers own-brand labelling
column22:
thus very often producing customised products in terms of the product and packaging.

\r\n

One of the company’s current owners
column23: who has also been the general manager since 1995
column24: studied at the Aristotle University of Thessaloniki and holds a graduate degree in Agricultural Engineering
column25: and a master’s degree in Food Technology and Control. He has worked in the company from an early age and is aware of the different procedures and tasks performed in all departments of RTB. Nowadays
column26: he is mainly responsible for the management
column27:
while he is also engaged in the research and development Department and quality control. His brother is in charge of the production department.

\r\n

RTB’s annual turnover exceeded €13 million in 2011
column28: illustrating a stable growth pattern over the past few years. There are 75 people employed throughout the year in the Greek company
column29: with 50 more employed on a seasonal basis
column30: during the harvest period. Owing to the family nature of the business
column31:
the personnel have remained stable throughout the company’s history. There is no collective representation of employees or a works council.

Background to restructuring event

Back in 2003
column32: the company owners decided to expand sales in order to respond to the growing demand for pickled vegetables and similar products
column33: mainly from abroad. However
column34: there seemed to be a major barrier
column35: related to the low volume of fresh vegetable production in Greece. As a result
column36: RTB was unable to produce the needed volume in order to cover the growing demand. At first
column37: a solution was reached by importing additional vegetables from neighbouring countries
column38: such as Bulgaria
column39: Macedonia and Turkey. At the same time
column40: though
column41: the owners faced another major problem
column42: with pricing agreements
column43: since there was a strong fluctuation in the volumes the major suppliers could offer
column44: which in turn affected price levels and
column45: ultimately
column46: the company’s ability to negotiate with foreign customers. Specifically
column47: as mentioned in our interview
column48: suppliers are not always capable of meeting the contract specifications
column49: as far as order volumes are concerned. This affects the company’s ability to negotiate with foreign customers
column50:
given that price is usually associated with discounts for large orders.

\r\n

The volume of fresh vegetables produced in the local market (northern Greece) is not enough to cover the demand of the company alone
column51: which exceeds 5
column52: 000 tonnes per year. Moreover
column53: the company faced enormous difficulties in order to ensure that contract terms with the farmers would be met
column54: given that both the volumes produced and the agreed prices were not always fixed. Generally
column55: according to the general manager
column56: the farmers would offer part of their production to other firms
column57: where higher prices are offered
column58: despite the fact that a signed contract exists between them and RTB. Thus
column59: even though several agreements were evident
column60: they could not ensure access to raw materials
column61: fresh vegetables
column62: and as a result the company faced a limited capacity problem
column63: given the large orders
column64:
especially from abroad.

\r\n

Access to fresh vegetables constituted the major barrier to growth
column65: with plant capacity and price competitiveness second and third. The owners considered alternatives to overcome this situation. At first
column66: they considered investing in a new plant in Bulgaria
column67: given that many Greek firms had moved or expanded their activities there and
column68: thus
column69: an intensive foreign direct investment activity was observed
column70: especially in northern Bulgaria. However
column71: they soon realised that production of fresh vegetables in the Bulgarian market was even lower than in Greece
column72: while costs per unit would not be significantly lower. Another alternative
column73: the expansion of the production process to India
column74: was assessed. However
column75: this solution was soon rejected as well
column76: given that
column77: although labour costs would be significantly lower
column78:
distance and language could hinder RTB’s growth.

\r\n

Then the owners realised the potential of the market in Turkey
column79: which presented some crucial advantages. First
column80: the volume of fresh vegetable production is one of the highest in Europe: the country produces more than 130
column81: 000 tonnes of Florina peppers annually. Added to that
column82: the quality of fresh vegetables is exceptionally high
column83: owing to the climate and the environmental conditions in Turkey. Moreover
column84: significant reductions in unit costs could be achieved
column85: primarily due to differences in labour costs. In addition
column86: the business environment in Turkey appeared to be another motivating factor
column87: since there are important benefits for direct investments there (for example
column88: export subsidies
column89: and the financing of mechanical equipment upgrades) and a supportive legal and financial framework for exporting companies. The new plant in Turkey enabled access to an extensive labour pool and raw materials and the owners decided to proceed with this alternative
column90: while maintaining the company’s operation in Greece
column91:
given the growing demand from large trading companies.

Restructuring processes

The restructuring process was planned during 2003
column92: while the construction of a new plant took place in the Çanakkale Province
column93: on the southern (Asian) coast of the Dardanelles in Turkey during 2004. The new company (Royal Foods AS) started operations in 2005
column94: and the plant reached full capacity two years later
column95: following extensions to the building. The owners contributed 95% of the new company’s capital
column96: while the remaining 5% is owned by a Turkish partner
column97: who is employed as the general manager. However
column98: the ownership and the management structure are centralised
column99:
given that the Greek owners are in essence entirely responsible for all activities that take place there.

\r\n

This process was mainly planned and executed by the current owners and their father in 2003. However
column100: given that a new company was to be established
column101: the three men thought that it would be in their best interests to cooperate with a partner they had in Turkey through their previous exporting activities. This man was mainly responsible for assisting in the location selection and negotiating with the Turkish authorities and the construction company
column102: in order to act as an intermediary for the Greek entrepreneurs. As our interlocutor mentioned
column103: apart from being the general manager of the new company
column104: they decided to offer him the opportunity to contribute to the company’s capital
column105: to obtain a higher level of commitment. Thus
column106: an agreement was reached and the Turkish partner was also engaged in the planning process and the administrative issues that arose (for example
column107:
hiring new personnel).

\r\n

There are 35 persons permanently employed in the Turkish company
column108: while 300 more are employed on a seasonal basis
column109: during harvest time. The Turkish partner is mainly responsible for recruitment
column110: although the existence of ‘local brokers’ is also evident. Labour costs include not only employee wages
column111: but
column112: in certain cases
column113: also their transfer from their areas of residence
column114:
as well as food provided during breaks.

\r\n

During the early stages of restructuring
column115: a general plan was set out by the Greek owners
column116: even though
column117: according to the general manager
column118: it was not easy to define all related terms and milestones
column119: or to specify a strict timetable
column120: given the ‘greenfield’ character of the investment. Hence
column121: the event could be characterised as a type of ‘informal implementation’
column122: which lasted more than three years. As a result
column123: personal monitoring of the process was essential
column124: especially during the first year
column125: which involved commuting on a weekly basis (four hours’ distance) for the owners and two or three other persons
column126: mainly technical staff. The owners were fully responsible for restructuring
column127: and no formal efforts were made to inform the Greek workforce since
column128: given the family nature of the business
column129: most were already aware of the owners’ intentions to expand operations and the production process in another country. Specifically
column130: as mentioned before
column131: the company has a large experience of exporting and cooperation with foreign customers (wholesalers and retailers). These activities had enhanced the workforce's ability to cooperate on an international level and
column132: thus
column133: it was obvious for most of them that the neighbouring markets presented specific advantages. As a result
column134: the owners' decision to expand their production process in Turkey appeared as a rational solution to most employees
column135:
who realised this shift would assist the company to overcome the limitations that the Greek market presented.

\r\n

The major problems that occurred during planning and implementation related to RTB’s ability to ‘stick to the plan’. This refers to the owners’ skills and experience regarding restructuring
column136: since it was the first time the company had undertaken such a radical change. However
column137: they were able to handle the situation due to its ‘informal’ character
column138: which enabled modifications to the plan or
column139: in other words
column140: owing to the greater flexibility a small company can enjoy regarding restructuring. At the same time
column141: close monitoring of the restructuring event was essential at all stages
column142: which was ensured by the weekly commute
column143:
given the relatively short distance between the company’s headquarters in Greece and the new plant in Turkey.

Challenges and constraints of restructuring

The most important challenge the managers faced was to familiarise themselves with a different legal framework and entrepreneurial mentality. However
column144: this barrier proved to be of minor importance
column145: given the experience gained through international collaborations in the past
column146: involving the exporting operations the company had been engaged in for a long time. Another major challenge concerned the long-standing political and religious disputes between Greece and Turkey. It is worth mentioning here
column147: however
column148: that the company owners and their employees presented a greater sense of realism and proved to be more open-minded than the majority of the politicians on this issue. There was no significant reaction by employees or customers
column149: and no major implications for them
column150: as long as production on the Greek side of the border continued. Moreover
column151: the owners did not seek to take advantage of any possible assistance from the Greek State
column152: in order to avoid criticism of the local society. It is useful to note here that a sizeable percentage of the Turkish minority in Greece resides in the Prefecture of Xanthi
column153: where the company is located. As the sales manager reported
column154: an effective communication link between the company and customers was set up through the company's website
column155: e-mail and telephone
column156: which proved to be of crucial importance providing the necessary details on this move. The main argument was that the company would not discontinue its production in Greece
column157:
while the same quality control would be maintained for production in Turkey.

\r\n

Moreover
column158: allowing the Turkish manager to take a financial share in the new company assisted the Greek owners’ efforts to become familiar with the legal framework in Turkey. The Greek owners’ visits to the plant very often enhanced implementation of this process. Moreover
column159: the Turkish partner
column160: in addition to a translator employed to participate in the meetings
column161:
helped the owners to overcome the linguistic and communication problems that arose and ensured that this constraint would not constitute a threat towards successful implementation of restructuring.

\r\n

Finance for investment was another constraint. It was not an easy task to define the size of the plant and acquire the necessary funds. However
column162: the owners decided to rely on their private funds
column163: while a relatively small share of the investment was funded through bank loans
column164: given the dearth of any other financial support mechanism
column165: as will be discussed later. Moreover
column166: the owners soon realised that they had to reconsider the size of the new plant
column167: given that the market in Turkey presented some peculiarities. Significantly higher production volumes could be achieved there
column168: given easier access to raw materials
column169: while exporting subsidies from the State were also available. Thus
column170: an alteration was decided regarding the size of the investment
column171: which could allow the company to enjoy higher economies of scale and annual turnover. This was achieved through building extensions to the new plant
column172:
which lengthened the restructuring event but presented significant advantages for RTB’s growth.

Restructuring advice and support

The owner of RTB pointed to the dearth of public support instruments regarding SME restructuring in Greece. As a result
column173: the company did not participate in any related programme
column174: while the owners decided to rely solely on their own strengths in order to expand the company’s production process abroad. The same is true regarding assistance from the private sector
column175: since the company did not receive any type of assistance
column177: the company owner holds a negative view of public actors engaged in consulting services or financial support mechanisms
column178: even though he happens to be president of the local chamber of commerce and industry. He believes the Greek state presents a rather centralised and bureaucratic administrative system
column181: to take advantage of assistance. Hence
column182:
he did not look for any public support during restructuring.

\r\n

During the planning process
column183: and before the owners decided to establish the plant in Turkey
column184: the owners discussed their plans with a friend
column186: who had relocated to Bulgaria. This fact indicates the procedures undertaken at the small firm level in Greece
column188:
this type of restructuring.

\r\n

RTB’s owners soon realised that a more favourable business environment was evident in Turkey
column189: especially for companies exporting high value-added products from Turkey. The company faced no significant bureaucratic barriers or problems related to the legal framework. They were also able to take advantage of specific measures (such as export subsidies or financial assistance for machinery upgrades) in Turkey
column190:
which proved to be of crucial importance for the company’s smooth operation.

Outcomes of restructuring

The outcomes of restructuring are considered to be positive so far
column191: according to both the owners and the sales manager
column192: given that there has been no reduction in the number of employees in the Greek company. Business expansion to Turkey enabled higher production volumes with lower per unit costs
column193: and ensured the survival of the ‘parent’ firm in Greece
column194: since a significant part of the raw materials acquired through the Turkish market are further processed in the Greek plant. At the same time
column195: RTB gained easier access to the significantly larger neighbouring market
column196: while its exporting activities were further strengthened by higher production volumes that can meet international demand at competitive prices. Thus
column197:
the primary goals of this restructuring effort have been met.

\r\n

The company has been able to overcome barriers by taking advantage of the flexibility common to smaller firms. This
column198: combined with the short distance between the company’s headquarters in Greece and the production unit in Turkey
column199: enabled close monitoring of the whole process
column200:
while maintaining overall control and the ability to find suitable solutions to emerging problems.

\r\n

Even though the general manager does not believe that all goals have been completely met
column203: to have been a reasonable success. Moreover
column204: the owners did not face additional pressures from external shareholders or a trade union
column205: which is more generally the case in larger enterprises. This is considered to be another critical success factor
column206: which enabled alteration of the restructuring plan without further problems
column207:
as the extension of the production unit at a later stage of the restructuring process demonstrates.

\r\n

Interestingly
column208: even though restructuring generated additional workload pressures for managerial staff
column209: these were faced primarily as a challenge and not as a negative aspect of the whole process. Moreover
column210: the family nature of the business ensured that no particular efforts were necessary to communicate the ‘message of change’ to other employees
column211:
who were able to appreciate business expansion as a means to ensure long-term company survival and growth.

\r\n

The company owners are convinced that they have taken the right decision at the right moment
column212: since they would have been less able to execute this plan today
column213: owing to the economic recession during 2011–2012. From a personal point of view
column214: he realises that this ‘shift in the company’s history’ has created enormous benefits
column215:
such as a better understanding of production and trade on a global scale and improvement of his managerial skills.

\r\n

RTB has enjoyed a growing turnover and satisfactory profitability
column216: which can ensure that the next generation will be left with a profitable business. According to the owners
column217: this would not have been possible if they had not decided to expand their activities to Turkey
column218:
while maintaining a good part of production and sales activities in Greece.

Commentary

The case of RTB demonstrates a successful SME restructuring event. Given the family nature of the business and its size
column219: this company constitutes a typical example of a Greek SME. Moreover
column220: it confirms the dominance of a rather centralised governance structure in which the company owners appear to hold a preeminent role
column225: educational level) and entrepreneurial mentality can define the success or failure of most Greek SMEs
column226:
as the case of RTB illustrates.

\r\n

Moreover
column227: this case highlights the significance of flexibility in Greek SMEs. Given
column229: the absence of shareholders or collective employee representation
column230: the owners–managers in these cases are more able to freely plan and execute their ideas
column231: but also alter a restructuring process
column232: even at later stages. Owners can also easily establish more direct and efficient communication links with employees compared with the case of large-scale enterprises
column233:
which can also foster successful implementation of a restructuring event.

\r\n

At the same time
column234: the findings confirm that the main motives for a Greek SME to expand in a foreign country are related to lower per unit costs and access to new markets
column235: which constitute a means to ensure the survival of the firm and its future growth. Thus
column236: restructuring events of this type represent one of the few alternatives for small firms to internationalise their activities and increase sales volumes. Hence
column237: one could expect this phenomenon to increase during times of financial recession
column238:
such as the one Greece faces today.

\r\n

The list of critical success factors in the case of Greek SMEs’ expansion in foreign countries processes includes geographical proximity (which is particularly true for RTB given that is located in northern Greece)
column239: as close monitoring of the whole process seems to be essential
column241:
and can also ensure better communication and higher levels of trust. This argument was clearly confirmed by the case study presented above.

\r\n

Lastly
column242: it is worth mentioning that both the general manager and the sales manager feel they have been successful in ensuring a smooth transition in the company’s history
column243: while most major goals were also met
column244: concerning faster and cheaper access to raw materials. At the same time
column245: access to new markets was also facilitated
column247: which rendered export products more competitive in international markets. Thus
column248: the company is nowadays able to face
column249: in a more efficient way than many of its Greek competitors
column250:
the impacts of the current economic downturn.

column1:
Solar panel company, France~"Solar panel company"~"

Changes in legislation led a French distributor and installer of photovoltaic solar panels to close regional offices and concentrate activities in one region. Some 10–15 staff were dismissed and others left voluntarily. The company has adopted a new business strategy
column2: diversifying into other renewable-energy products to offset falling demand for photovoltaic products. It created 44 new call centre jobs in 2010
column3:
bringing staff numbers to 160 and has plans to expand into other regions once again and to hire many more staff.

"~"

Organisational profile

The company is a French supplier of solar panels produced in Germany and Switzerland. It specialises in both the distribution and installation of solar panels and other energy-efficient products. The company was set up in the 2000s and gradually expanded to its current (spring 2011) 160 employees.

By the end of 2010
column4: the company had several regional sites across France. Following a change in the legislation on PV (photovoltaic) systems
column5: the company decided to concentrate all activities in one region and close the other regional sites. All employees at the affected sites were offered relocation to other company sites. This restructuring plan resulted in the dismissal of between 10 and 15 employees; additional workers left the company on a voluntary basis. Mainly administrative staffs were affected
column6: while sales and technical jobs were kept. At that time
column7:
the aim was to reduce administrative overheads/ costs.

\r\n

The company owner and managing director carried out technical and business administration studies and has considerable work experience in the sector
column8:
not only in France but also abroad.

\r\n

In terms of workforce composition
column9: the average age of employees is 30–35 years. There are very few employees older than 50 years or younger than 30. On the whole
column10: the company employs more women than men; however
column11:
it depends on the posts. There are more women working in the call centres (80% of the call centre staff are women) whereas only men are employed as skilled technicians and male employees tend to predominate in sales jobs. One company objective is to achieve a better gender balance in the workforce composition.

\r\n

There are four employee representatives within the company. Only the call centre staff are represented by the French Democratic Confederation of Labour (Confédération française démocratique du travail
column12: CFDT). Administrative staff and technicians are not unionised
column13:
by their own choice. The managing director regularly informs his staff directly about relevant issues.

Background to restructuring events

The recent expansion of the business was partly facilitated by a favourable economic climate as the company is located in a region that has been less affected by the recent recession than other parts of France. There was no decline in orders during the crisis. Nevertheless
column14:
the impression is that nowadays the clients are somehow less receptive and more efforts are needed to achieve results compared to previous years.

\r\n

The company plans to expand in the region and eventually to reopen other sites across the country. In 2011 the company launched a new business strategy based on product diversification covering a wider range of renewable energy-related products (that is
column15: heating systems
column16: thermal insulation
column17:
etc.). This strategy is deemed necessary due to the fact that the PV (photovoltaic) products do not sell as they used to – this requires a reorganisation to adjust to a more diversified and changing market.

\r\n

As part of this strategy
column18: the company envisages consolidating its position in France and expanding outside Europe. To this end
column19:
the company is now seeking to consolidate business relations with companies in North Africa and the United States. The long-term plan is to engage in production and cover the full chain from production to distribution and installation of energy-efficient products.

Restructuring processes

In late 2010
column20: the company created 44 new jobs for a new call centre
column21: bringing the workforce up to 160 employees. The company received some subsidies from a large multinational which
column22: after dismissing a large number of workers
column23: reached an agreement with the local authorities to launch a so-called ‘revitalisation’ plan involving economic incentives for new businesses willing to invest in the area. At the time of the interview
column24: the company was also likely to receive some public subsidies. The recruitment of the 44 employees at the call centre was completed by spring 2011. In 2010 the company achieved a turnover of €15 million
column25: an increase of 20%. Following these positive results
column26: in early 2011 the company announced the creation of 60 new administrative and sales jobs. However
column27:
the shortage of skilled labour is a major problem in the recruitment process. There are still 30 sales positions to fill. The new diversification strategy launched in 2011 entails the creation of 40 new jobs by the end of 2011 and another 200 new jobs with the opening of new sites across the country by 2013–2014.

\r\n

The new strategy based on diversification was planned carefully before entering the implementation phase. This started with the analysis of the existing business process and workflow and subsequently the definition of a business plan. Different stages of the workflow were identified. The first stage involves the call centre employees who set the appointments with potential clients. In a second stage
column28:
these calls are followed up by the sales people who meet the clients to sell the products. The third stage consists of the administrative paperwork (opening and management of the client file) and the final stage is the installation of the panels and closure of the client file. The company monitors the share of successful contacts at each stage to ensure that the number of employees needed (in particular sales persons) are in place at later stages.

\r\n

No consulting companies have been involved in the process of setting out and implementing the new business strategy: this would require additional financial resources that are not available. Also
column29: more importance is attached to the opinion and expertise of the staff who are involved in the day-to-day activities. Communication and consultation with the staff is a key element of the organisational culture within the company. All staff are informed about the changes that will occur
column30:
and they are all provided with opportunities to grow and develop in the company.

Challenges and constraints of restructuring

The most pressing issue is to find funding for the injection of funds to improve the cash flow. It is estimated that €2–3 million are necessary to grow and continue the business successfully. One of the problems is that the loan guarantees and credits provided by public authorities are too limited: an SME needs a bigger buffer of money to survive.

The recent support measures for SMEs introduced by the French government target mainly innovative SMEs
column31:
and SMEs that produce and/or export. SMEs operating in the service sector are not covered by these support measures. The net should be thrown as wide as possible to cover a larger number and wider typology of SMEs. Instruments and measures provided through the French state-backed investment fund FSI (Fonds stratégique d’investissement) and OSEO (support agency for the development of French SMEs) for the injection of funds are not effective because the eligibility criteria are often too restrictive.

\r\n

To deal with this issue of lack of funds
column32:
the plan is to sell off a portion of the company to increase the shareholder equity/capital and have a bigger free floating cash reserve to prepare future investments.

Restructuring advice and support

The company obtained some subsidies from a multinational company for the creation of the call centre. They also received an OSEO loan guarantee for €250
column33:
000. The company also sought additional subsidies from the general local council but without success.

\r\n

The recent business expansion has been conducted without the support of any consultancy companies. There are not enough resources for this
column34: so the company is obliged to do everything on its own. With regard to the diversification strategy
column35:
there is generally some reluctance to seek the support of consultancies and the company relies mainly on in-house expertise.

Outcomes of restructuring

There is a clear and explicit HR strategy which was introduced in 2011. The main element of this strategy is continuous vocational training for all employees. The company started with the employees responsible for sales and will then target employees in the call centres and administrative staff. Technicians receive training on a regular basis. All training is provided by (local) accredited training providers. Also
column36:
a quality control system has been put in place to ensure that the HR strategy is effective.

\r\n

Organisational adjustments are frequent in the company. However this continuous change is positive in many ways (that is
column37: possibilities for promotion
column38: salary increases
column39: post upgrades
column40: etc.). It is left up to each employee whether they want to progress in the company or continue with the same job. As a result of the business expansion
column41: some employees have been promoted and posts upgraded. To cope with the rapid pace of change
column42:
continuous vocational training is part and parcel of the company’s HR strategy. The company’s responsibility is to ensure that all employees are provided with training opportunities.

\r\n

In spite of this approach
column43: which is firmly oriented towards the enhancement of employee skill sets
column44: there is a relatively high staff turnover within the company. Many sales staff have recently left the company because they felt that their skills were not in line with the new business strategy. Even in the context of business expansion
column45:
employees are generally concerned about the impact of the forthcoming changes on their job.

Commentary

As the company is not an innovative SME but rather driven by the need to respond to market demands
column46: continuous change and adjustment of the business strategy is not an option but a must. This requires the company to be vigilant at all times
column47: receptive and ready to adjust quickly. For example the company is certified ISO 9-2001; however
column48:
the company will have to apply for ISO certification again soon because the market changes continuously and there is a need to keep up to date in order to retain the business.

The recent growth of the company partly results from the continuous efforts to meet client demands which at times may put extra pressure on some employees.

Author

Sara Riso
