column1:
CAM, Italy~"CAM"~"

CAM
column2: a manufacturer of hydraulic and pneumatic components
column3: started to lose orders as many of its clients began internalising activities that they had been outsourcing to CAM. As production fell
column4: the company launched a restructuring process
column5: one highly dependent on state income support to compensate staff for their reduced working hours. In the meantime
column6: the company launched the development of a new product
column7: investing its own funds in product development
column8: and in training employees in its manufacture. Developed through ongoing social dialogue
column9: the restructuring meant that the company was able to maintain the level of employment and to develop a new product
column10:
one that attracted orders before development was finished.

"~"

Organisational profile

\r\n

CAM is a crafts company mainly engaged in hydraulic and pneumatic components manufacturing
column11: in particular the manufacture of components for the hydroelectric and hydrothermal manufacturing sectors. The company was founded on 14 February 1990
column12: when the owner was only 17 years of age
column13: and its main activity was to operate as a process manufacturer in the fittings manufacturing sector. The business idea was somewhat inspired by the owner’s father
column14: who in 1957
column15: while working as a manger for a company
column16: decided to establish an assembly company to provide assembling services for the company he was employed in. When the owner decided to establish its activity
column17:
his father had already decided to retire and close his business. CAM’s owner opted to give 5% of ownership to his father.

\r\n

Ownership and management are concentrated and the company is run as a family business.

\r\n

At the beginning
column18: the company operated in the fittings sector
column19: and then came to specialise as a process manufacturer in the hydraulic fitting sector. At the present time
column20: the company still supplies assembling services for other companies operating in the hydrothermal sector; however
column21: CAM is in the process of developing a flow measurement fitting
column22:
and it aims in the near future to specialise in the manufacture of flow measurement fittings.

\r\n

The company started in 1990 with three employees
column23: and by the end of the year had seven employees. Between 1997 and 2002 the company hired a further 12 employees
column24: making a total of 19 employees
column25:
which has since then remained unchanged.

\r\n

The 19 employees are aged between 30 and 45
column26: with 17 female and two male employees – one in quality control and the other in the technical department. All members of staff are employed on a permanent contract. The company has also availed of four external consultants
column27:
who are mainly technicians involved in assembling.

\r\n

There is no work council within the company. However
column28: when the company had to implement a first restructuring process in 2007 and benefit from social shock absorbers
column29:
the agreement and social dialogue as prescribed by Italian Law was done with the CGIL trade union.

\r\n

The company is located in a very small village and it is highly embedded in the local community. All employees live a maximum 10 to 15 km from the site of the company and the owner
column30: originally from the village of Mura
column31:
now lives only 30 km away.

\r\n

The company does not have a written human resources strategy. Human resources management is administered internally to the company by the owner/manager. However
column32: with future prospects of business expansion in the flow measurement fittings manufacturing sector
column33:
the owner foresees that a human resources department and a written human resources strategy and development strategy will have to be established and developed.

\r\n

Background to restructuring events

\r\n

The activity grew continuously until 2007
column34: the company working with three main clients until then
column35:
with an additional two clients in periods of high demand. It enjoyed an average turnover of up to €3 billion per year (of which €2 billion from business with one specific client).

\r\n

However in 2007
column36: due to economic difficulties
column37: the company started to lose most of its orders
column38: as many of its clients started to internalise those activities that were outsourced up to then. Furthermore one of CAM’s main client
column39: which owed CAM €270
column41: was declared bankrupt
column42: and CAM lost the amount it was owed. At that particular time
column43: the company had also financed the construction of a new site which had cost €1.800
column44: 000. The loss of the money owed from the bankrupt client and the high costs of the new productive site resulted in very difficult economic conditions
column45:
forcing the company to implement a restructuring process.

\r\n

Restructuring processes

\r\n

Small companies operating in crafts sector do not have the same access to social shock absorbers as larger companies in industry. However
column46: these crafts companies can also benefit from the support of bilateral bodies
column47: which are jointly managed by social partners
column48: and which pay specific subsidies
column49: as part of the unemployment benefit
column50: to workers in the event of a reduction in working hours or suspension
column51: from the contribution of the Employment Fund managed by the Italian Ministry of Labour and Social Policies (see also Eurofound
column52:
2010)

\r\n

Therefore
column53: at the beginning of the restructuring process
column54: the management got the support of the bilateral body for arts and crafts (EBNA – ente bilaterale nazionale artigianato) which provided income support to the 17 female employees while production was temporarily stopped for three months. However
column55: after these three months
column56: and due to the increasing demand for support to the bilateral bodies caused by the economic crisis
column57: these bodies were unable to provide support to all its members and the company implemented restructuring via the support of the ordinary wage guarantee fund ( CIGO – cassa integrazione ordinaria CIGO
column58: see also Eurofound
column59: 2010). Under this arrangement on a rotation base three to four employees at a time among the 17 female employees
column60: were not working
column61: while receiving a 80% of their normal salary (cassa integrazione guadagni ordinaria a zero ore). The two male staff
column62: employed in the quality control and technical department
column63:
due to their occupational tasks were not affected by the restructuring.

\r\n

Moreover
column65: due to a decrease in turnover of more than 65%
column66: at times the entire production was temporarily stopped and all of the 17 female employees benefited from the CIGO and from the extraordinary wage guarantee fund (CIGS – cassa integrazione straordinaria see also Eurofound
column68: which envisaged the stop of production (CIGS zero ore). Under this scheme employees work reduced hours up to zero hours worked
column69:
while receiving income support equal to 80% of their last salary.

\r\n

Due to persisting negative developments
column70: in 2011 the company continued the CIGS zero ore for seven of the 17 employees
column71: meaning that on a rotation base seven employees would not work at all for a specific period of time – three months in this restructuring case – while receiving CIGS income support
column72: while for the remaining ten employees the company introduced a solidarity contract (contratto di solidarietà
column73: see also Eurofound
column75: a social shock absorber which provides for short-time working of equal measure for the whole workforce
column76: while employees benefit of income support. In this specific case
column77: the ten affected employees reduced working hours
column78:
but production was not been stopped.

\r\n

However
column79: during the three months when they were not working and benefiting from CIGS
column80:
the seven employees were engaged in training courses organised by the trade union CGIL. In this specific case the seven employees attended a training course on ICT.

\r\n

Moreover
column81: since 2007
column82: the manager started to develop a new idea to launch a new product on the market: a flow measurement fitting. After analysing and assessing in detail the hydrothermal market
column83: management realised there was a vacuum in this sector. Indeed
column84: such product was developed in Europe by one only company which had a monopoly in the entire market. The management of CAM noted that this Swiss company produced only flow measurement fittings which were standard and for this reason each client had to adjust these for their products. CAM started to research and study a method to develop a flow measurement fitting which can work with a universal adaptor. In 2011
column85: the company registered their industrial design for their own flow measurement fitting which is enabled with a universal adaptor. In this way
column86:
CAM’s flow measurement fittings can be installed on any hydrothermal product.

\r\n

CAM planned to launch their brand new flow measurement fitting in February 2012
column87: with an investment of €400
column88: 000. The company will produce the fitting
column89: while the molding of the specific fitting will be outsourced to a partner company operating in the thermal manufacturing sector
column90: a former client of CAM. This partner company had outsourced the production of flow measurement fittings in China; however
column91:
due to the unsatisfactory quality of the production outsourced it became interested in CAM’s idea and decided to invest in it. The costs of the molding activity will be borne on a 50% base by CAM and by the partner company. The partner company has also the technical capacity in-house to provide technical consultancy for the development of the new product.

\r\n

Due to the development on this new product
column92: the company has implemented extensive training for its staff on a solidarity contract in order to train them for this new production. In particular
column93: four of these ten employees are attending a training course on quality control
column94:
organised by an external provider.

\r\n

The CIGS will last until the end of December 2011
column95: however as the production for the new product will start only in February 2012
column96: the management believes that CIGS will be renewed at least for the first quarter of 2012
column97: and once the new production has started
column98: they will assess how the market is responding to this new product and they will then re-assess the situation of the company in light of the outcome of the new production
column99:
and the relevant steps will be then taken.

\r\n

The company has already received requests for their own flow measurement fittings
column100: therefore future prospects seem positive. Indeed
column101:
the partner company has already ordered 250 flow measurement fittings.

Challenges and constraints of restructuring

The main challenges the company encountered related to the great uncertainty regarding the prospect of orders from clients. This implied a high degree of uncertainty on how to manage the restructuring process as well as high costs incurred both for financing and developing the new product (also including training costs) – which has been all private capital of the owner and then private money of the partner company who invested in the molding activity of the new flow measurement fitting – and for anticipating the income support treatments from the Italian National Social Security Institute (INPS).

In fact
column102: despite the fact that the restructuring was financed by the social shock absorbers (this is financed via a contribution that each enterprise pays
column103: in a sort of insurance mechanism)
column104: the procedure requires that the income support is anticipated by the company
column105: which will then be reimbursed by INPS. This reimbursement
column106: however
column107: can be paid several months after the treatment. This can result in a large burden for companies which are already in difficult situations. In the specific case
column108: by July 2009 the company had anticipated €200
column109:
000 of income support.

\r\n

The employees were informed immediately via the manager of the necessity to implement restructuring. However
column110: given the limited size of the company
column111: and the high level of trust
column112: loyalty and even friendship between the employees and the employer
column113: all employees were quite positive during the restructuring. While at the beginning the events were received with some feelings of worry and uncertainty
column114: these have diminished during the ongoing process
column115:
as the company showed a sincere interest in its employees and future prospects seems quite positive thanks to the development of the new product.

\r\n

The manager started the company when he was only 17 years age
column116: and therefore CAM represents his lifetime project. The manager is also very fond of his employees
column117: and even if the impact on wages has not been dramatic
column118: thanks to the supply of the social shock absorber
column119:
the decision to result to this tool has been emotionally very difficult.

\r\n

Restructuring advice and support

\r\n

The company has been supported in its restructuring process by the bilateral body EBNA
column120: which provided advice and information especially on the social shock absorbers
column121: its procedures and the social dialogue with the other involved actors. Indeed
column122:
the restructuring processes and the different options were discussed with EBNA which provided valuable advice.

\r\n

Moreover
column123: the company stresses that social dialogue has been very fair
column124: and the CGIL trade union has been extremely fair and supportive to the company as well as the employees. All decisions have been the result of an agreement between the trade union
column125:
the employees and the company.

\r\n

An external company
column126: which is also financing 50% of the costs of the molding activity of the new flow measurement fitting
column127:
provided the technical consultancy for the development of this new product.

\r\n

The company benefited from the economic support provided by the social shock absorbers which
column128: however
column129: are based on an insurance mechanism and are therefore financed by companies. According to the company
column130:
this support has proved vital to the survival of the company during times of uncertainty.

\r\n

However
column131:
the additional economic support to finance the restructuring in terms of costs for the specific training for the four employees for the new flow measurement fitting designed by CAM have been entirely borne by the company. It must be highlighted that the company regarded the training as very satisfactory and deemed it indispensable for a fruitful development of its activities.

\r\n

Outcomes of restructuring

\r\n

The restructuring had a positive outcome
column132: as it enabled the company to face the decline in orders
column133:
turnover and profits due to the economic crisis and it has also enabled the company to develop its own new product which might help it to expand his business.

\r\n

All the social shock absorbers implemented have proved to be indispensable in order to implement the necessary employment adjustments
column134:
while safeguarding the employment levels.

\r\n

The restructuring process was continuously developed
column135: through ongoing social dialogue based on the specific economic contingencies of the company. This implies that the company assessed the different restructuring tools on offer
column136: it implemented those which seemed the most appropriate and it re-assessed them according to the market reactions. In any event
column137: the restructuring reached the intended outcomes
column138:
as the company was able to maintain the level of employment and even to develop a new product.

\r\n

The restructuring also impacted on the management
column139: in monetary terms as he invested a lot of personal resources in the process
column140: but most importantly in terms of personal effects
column141: such as stress
column142: insecurity
column143: fear of having to close the company. However
column144: the owner firmly believes and stands behind the reasons for restructuring
column145: as after assessing all viable options
column146: he agreed that the specific restructuring implemented was the only feasible process which would have guaranteed the survival of the company. This choice has been excruciating at times but essential. In particular
column147:
recent developments show that these difficult decisions were well worth taking as first reactions to the new product developed are quite positive.

\r\n

In terms of staff
column148: even when out of working all employees affected by the restructuring have been engaged in different training courses
column149: even considering the slight decrease in wages foreseen by the social shock absorbers
column150:
outcomes on staff can be considered somehow positive.

\r\n

The restructuring process has not been formally evaluated
column151: neither internally or externally. However
column152: the company strongly argues that
column153: notwithstanding the associated difficulties
column154:
the restructuring process has been positive. CAM is also very positive on the future outlook of the company and is very confident on its new flow measurement product.

\r\n

Commentary

\r\n

The restructuring event was deemed positive by the company
column155: which has declared it would implement the exact same restructuring process if it could go back in time
column156: but it would implement it quicker. Indeed
column157:
the support of the social shock absorbers were deemed essential to implement the restructuring and to provide for the company survival during uncertain times.

\r\n

The company also declared that the support of EBNA and in particular the positive and fruitful social dialogue with CGIL which resulted in the restructuring agreement
column158: have been positively contributing to the successful outcome of the restructuring. The fair process of social dialogue
column159: as well as the loyalty and trust between the employees and employer
column160: has also encouraged a calm and polite environment within the company and in the relations with the management. Indeed while at the beginning affected employees were understandably worried about their uncertain prospects
column161:
with time they have understood and supported the reasons for restructuring. According to the company the supportive behavior of CIGL was essential to ensure a smooth restructuring.

\r\n

CAM stressed also that the great uncertainty on the outlook of orders received by clients resulted in a high degree of uncertainty on how to manage the restructuring process. Furthermore
column162: the high costs incurred both for financing and developing the new product (also including training costs) and for anticipating the income support treatments from INPS imposes a burden on companies needing to implement process of restructuring. This is particularly negative
column163: as it affects companies already negatively affected by difficult economic conditions. This is of great concern for SMEs
column164: which generally face more constrains to capital access than their larger counterparts
column165: due to size concerns. This is even more dramatic during times of crisis
column166:
when funding opportunities are extremely limited.

column1:
Cinoco Group, Belgium~"Cinoco Group"~"

Belgian drinks company Cinoco group acquired a competing company
column2: Le Palais du Vin
column3: in a business expansion. Potential synergies were identified between the two companies
column4: mostly in the back office operations – accounting
column5: financial services and IT services. Insofar as confidentiality permitted

column7: clients and suppliers

column10:
any reduction in head count coming from retirements and one resignation. Remuneration was left untouched for both companies.

"~"

Organisational profile

Background information on the company

The C.I. Nolet & Co. Group (Cinoco Group) is a family business originating in 1691
column11: the date of the foundation of the Nolet distillery in Schiedam
column12: the Netherlands. In the 19th century
column13: Charles-Hubert Nolet de Brauwere
column14: the family member in charge of the distillery
column15: moved to Belgium where a part of the Nolet de Brauwere family settled. His son
column16: Charles Nolet
column17: extended the activities of the distillery to the distribution and representation of French wines and champagnes in the early part of the 20th century. In the aftermath of the Second World War
column18:
the Cinoco S.A. company was incorporated in Brussels (1958).

\r\n

Today
column19: the Cinoco Group owns five companies: Cinoco S.A.
column20: Le Palais du Vin S.A.
column21: Bodega
column22: FX de Beukelaer and a Luxembourg subsidiary
column23: Maxivins Lux. The consolidated turnover of the Cinoco Group is
column24: on average
column25: around €32 Mio. The current total number of employees is 60. The two most important entities of the group
column26: Cinoco S.A. and the Palais du Vin S.A.
column27: are two separate companies
column28:
with two different names and having two separate and independent sales and marketing departments. This dual legal entity is due to the specificities of the industry: it is not allowed to put competing brands under the same flag. Synergies occur mainly at the level of back office.

\r\n

The Cinoco Group is active in the sector of wines and spirits wholesale trade
column29: with a focus on distribution in Belgium. Cinoco offers to the market Grands Crus and other brands of wine
column30: spirits and liquors as well as supporting services. 95% of the clients are based in Belgium
column31: including specialists
column32: wholesalers
column33: the hotel and restaurants sector
column34: supermarkets
column35: catering and other companies and private persons. Over the last three years
column36:
the turnover more than doubled: rising from €15 to €32 Mio.

\r\n

In 2004
column37: Gilles Nolet de Brauwere van Steeland (tenth generation) takes over the general management of Cinoco Group. Mr Nolet had prior professional experience as a Business and Development Director – hence in restructuring – in international large companies. Back then
column38: the company had around 40 employees and a turnover of around €150 Mio. In 2008
column39: Cinoco S.A. bought Le Palais du Vin S.A. for a price of €14 Mio
column40:
which is the restructuring event for the purpose of this case study. This acquisition almost doubled the size of the company and its turnover.

\r\n

The average age of employees is 46 years old. A few employees keep on working (on special arrangement) after retirement. Women account for only 18% of all employees. Around ten persons have a university degree
column41: including a couple with a master’s degree. Around 20% of workers have a vocational training diploma. The rest of the workforce has no higher degree
column42:
in some cases no degree at all. A third of employees are blue-collar workers.

\r\n

The Nolet de Brauwere family owns 65% of the group. The French family company Bollinger owns 10% of the group while French group Marie Brizard (MB) owns 25%. It should be noted that MB purchased its share in Cinoco Group in 1995 when MB still qualified as a family-owned company: as Marie Brizard has a 25% share in Cinoco Group
column43:
the two companies must be considered as partner enterprises. Therefore 25% of Marie Brizard’s turnover (which is around € 300 Mio a year) should be added to that of the Cinoco Group to calculate the company’s group as defined under Recommendation of 5 May 2005.

\r\n

This means that
column44: theoretically and legally
column45: the Cinoco Group does not qualify as an SME
column46:
while the family holds owns 65% of the shares and has four out of six seats at the Board of Directors.

\r\n

Half of the family holding is controlled by Mr Nolet and the other half by his older brother – who is also the manager of liqueur company FX de Beukelaer. Mr Nolet and his brother have regular conversations on general management matters
column47:
but neither brother interferes in the management matters of each other.

\r\n

Finally
column48:
there is no works council at Cinoco Group as legal thresholds for a works council obligation within Cinoco S.A. and within Le Palais du Vin S.A. are not met.

Background information on interviewees

The educational and professional background of Mr Gilles Nolet de Brauwere is interesting as it certainly had an impact on the restructuring event itself and on how it was carried out (as shown below).

Mr Nolet has two university degrees that he obtained in parallel: a degree in law and a degree in economic sciences. While he has never practiced as a lawyer
column49: his knowledge of the law allows him to understand and master legal issues companies commonly face
column50: including when restructuring (legal structure of financial relationship with banks
column51: legal framework applicable to mergers and acquisitions
column52:
and so on).

\r\n

Mr Nolet’s main professional experience before joining the Cinoco Group is in IT
column53: finance
column54: general management and in business and development
column55: including several positions as Business and Development Director
column56: thus in mergers and acquisitions
column57: which is the precise nature of the restructuring in the present case study. Mr Nolet has almost ten years of international professional experience abroad
column58: including in Germany (Frankfurt and Hamburg) and in London. He also has some experience in the banking and finance sector
column59: as Business Development Director for a subsidiary of the Deutsche Bank Group
column60: ALD GmbH
column61:
in Hamburg.

\r\n

Besides his law degree
column62: Mr Nolet has additional degrees/diplomas: an Executive Masters in Management from the Solvay-ULB Management School of Brussels
column63: a diploma in Finance Management from the Vlaamse economische Hogeschool Brussels
column64:
and a diploma in company law from the Vrij Universiteit Brussels.

\r\n

The interviewed employee
column65: Fanny Vigneron
column66: is 34 years old. She has been working for the Cinoco Group for over three years and a half
column67: as Customer Services Manager. Beforehand
column68:
she worked in a large company active in the transport sector. She is a graduate in law and literature.

Background to restructuring event

The type of restructuring event is the acquisition of a competing company
column69: Le Palais du Vin
column70: which at the same time
column71: corresponds to a business expansion. Mr Nolet identified several triggers to this event
column72:
including:

  • Personal preferences resulting from his background in finances and in business development
column73: including his personal vision
column74: his own\r\nopenness to identify and grab such an opportunity<i>
column75:
and his own passion to accomplish the restructuring process;
  • to expand externally by doubling the company size;
  • The ‘once-in-a-lifetime’ aspect of the transaction
column76:
resulting essentially from the fact that the acquired company was located close to the seat of Cinoco S.A. and from the fact that the premises of Cinoco S.A. were sufficiently large to accommodate Le Palais du Vin’s own stock.

Restructuring processes

The restructuring process went from the end of 2007 until the end of 2009 and beyond
column77:
and includes the following steps:

  • November 2007: management was informed of the bid to acquire Le Palais du Vin and focused its attention on this specific issue. Cinoco then issued a letter of intent;
  • From January 2008: negotiations with counterparties and banks
column78: which
column79: according to Mr Nolet
column80:
went quite well (due to the excellent reputation of the company and of Mr Nolet and the excellent track records of Cinoco Group for the years 2004–2008);
  • July 2008: finalisation of the transaction;
  • Early 2009: arrival of Fanny Vigneron
column81: external to both\r\ncompanies
column82: as an employee responsible for customer services
column83:
notably in charge of integrating activities;
  • February 2009: arrival of La Maison du Vin’s employees at Cinoco’s premises;
  • From May 2009: launch of integration process.

    • Mr Nolet explains that the restructuring process followed a well-defined structure. First
column84: Mr Nolet started to openly look for external growth. When the opportunity arose
column85: the negotiation process followed a structure that is commonly followed in merger and acquisition processes (letter of intent
column86: due diligence
column87: parallel negotiations with banks
column88: etc.). Mr Nolet’s own international experience proved very useful to carry out such a process
column89: notably with respect to the identification of potential synergies between the two companies. Synergies occurred mostly at the level of back-up office
column90: namely accounting
column91: financial services and IT services. In this respect
column92: Ms Vigneron explained that the synergies between the two IT system was a delicate and important issue that took months to be completed. One facilitating factor for this completion was the fact that both companies used the same IT system
column93:
albeit at different level of implementation. The merger of the system resulted in increased efficiency/return.

\r\n

External and internal communication was also structured. The management was transparent towards employees as soon as confidentiality of negotiations was alleviated
column94: notably by organising internal information meetings on a regular basis. Communication with partners
column95: clients and suppliers occurred after confidentiality of the transaction was levied
column96: by way of a few press releases and
column97: most importantly according to Mr Nolet
column98: by way of individual letters addressed to each external party
column99:
cosigned by Cinoco and Le Palais du Vin.

\r\n

No social negotiations took place during the process due to the absence of a work council. Numerous legal obligations applicable to transfer of activities (transfert de branche d’activité) under Belgian company law had to be followed
column100: such as announcements and letters to all employees
column101: for example (or the announcement of the transaction in the <i>Belgian Gazette
column102:
for example). This was well done through an open and transparent communication to all workers of both companies right from the start. This direct and open communication played a positive role in the restructuring process.

\r\n

Ms Vigneron joined the group at a critical point during the restructuring process. She was chosen for the position as she was neutral towards both companies. One of her mission regarding the restructuring process was to ‘erase borders’ between the two companies
column103: to make sure employees from both sides developed a common company culture. As both companies were ‘old’ companies with established and long-lasting reputation
column104: this was seen as a challenge back then. She was deeply involved in managing human resources and teams during the acquisition deployment
column105:
so she was in a position to report on the impact of the acquisition on the workforce.

\r\n

Mr Nolet insisted that the small size of the firm facilitated the whole process: the small size allowed for a rapid gathering of company-related information when needed as well as a rapid diffusion of information. The absence of strict and formal reporting lines – besides reporting to the Board of Directors of course
column106:
is viewed as a facilitating factor.

Challenges and constraints of restructuring

Overall
column107: Mr Nolet believes the restructuring process went well. He does not report any specific issue
column108:
beside the elements that are SME-specific identified in this report.

\r\n

Ms Vigneron confirms that the restructuring process was well implemented; and that the management implemented change in a ‘delicate’ and humane way. The working atmosphere before and after restructuring was excellent and employees are highly motivated
column109: according to her. She sees a positive factor between this and the productivity of the company
column110: which she regards as being high. Today
column111: employees have the feeling of working for a common cause and being part of the same family. The Managing Director
column112: Mr Nolet
column113:
is well respected among the workforce.

Restructuring advice and support

The acquisition of Le Palais du Vin was done on the basis of own resources and on the basis of a loan
column114: granted by two banks. The prior experience of Mr Nolet with business and development and with the financial and banking sector
column115: as well as additional skills (such as negotiation skills)
column116: greatly contributed to the success of relationship with banks. The reputation of the company
column117: that of the family and the personal and professional track record of Mr Nolet himself
column118: including subsequent reputation
column119: also contributed positively. Moreover
column120: since his arrival at the top of the company in 2004
column121: Mr Nolet had made a substantial work on improving the company’s financial situation
column122:
which also is viewed as a positive factor.

\r\n

It appears from the interview that the personal and professional skills of the Managing Director greatly contributed to the success of the process. Mr Nolet was furthermore supported by two experts
column123: one lawyer and one auditor
column124: who are both close acquaintances of Mr Nolet. Thanks to these personal ties
column125: Mr Nolet benefited from preferential fees. Mr Nolet explained that the rates of external experts (M&A lawyers
column126: financial counsels
column127:
etc.) are usually prohibitive for SMEs. He further stated that SMEs commonly lack the human and technical expertise for carrying out restructuring procedures.

Outcomes of the restructuring

The outcome of the restructuring is viewed as positive as it allowed for a substantial increase of the group’s turnover and workforce. The remuneration of the owners also increased
column128: but Mr Nolet highlighted that
column129: following conditions imposed by banks (mentioned above)
column130: the company dividends were reduced by a third. Mr Nolet views this as a specific feature of SMEs
column131:
which does not occur in larger ones.

\r\n

The restructuring went according to the plan and was in line with Mr Nolet’s own experience of business development.

\r\n

As far as employees are concerned
column132: they too benefited from the acquisition as new positions were defined
column133: training was offered to those in need of it
column134:
and so on. The definition and the allocation of employee tasks was one of the specific mission allocated to Ms Vigneron: she had to work with every employee to identify and define work and assess where change could be implemented in order to benefit from synergies.

\r\n

Moreover
column135: there was not a single lay-off. In the aftermath of the restructuring
column136: there was a downward adjusting of ten working units
column137:
but these resulted from several retirements and one termination of function upon common agreement. Remuneration was left untouched for both companies.

Commentary

As mentioned above
column138: Mr Nolet identifies numerous elements that are specific to SMEs when restructuring
column139: some of which are positive
column140: while others are negative
column141:
including:

  • Impact of personality and professional background of the Managing Director on the success and/or failure of restructuring processes;
  • Absence of social negotiations for those SMEs not fulfilling thresholds under social laws;
  • Personal ties;
  • Lack of access to human resources and expertise;
  • Reduced reporting lines;
  • Facilitation of information circulation to both communicate information and retrieve relevant information that is necessary for carrying out the restructuring process;
  • Heavy and counter-producing administrative requirements
column142:
including when restructuring.

Moreover
column143: the human factor is important for SMEs undergoing a restructuring process. According to him
column144: there is a lot of bi- and multi-lateral work (communication) to generate trust among the workforce
column145: which is less true for larger corporations. Retaining talents is also a challenge
column146: especially for SMEs
column147:
who suffer from issues of under-valued work in general and in comparison to larger companies.

Mr Nolet puts forward several recommendations for the attention of policy-makers:

  • Reducing administrative burden as much as possible: resources in SMEs are limited and time and resources are wasted on administrative paper work on a regular basis
column148:
but also during restructuring process. Some useless administrative requirements may be particularly burdensome for SMEs.
  • Thresholds for being subject to heavy social obligations (work councils
column149:
etc.) should not be lowered at all costs. This would bring no benefits and hinders/prevents the open and direct communication existing in SMEs.

Ms Vigneron identifies the following SME-specific elements regarding the restructuring process:

  • The importance of the human factor: a large number of employees are reluctant to change and show fear and defiance regarding the process. Management needs to make extra efforts to communicate with them and to reassure them. She confirms that Mr Nolet and the management were transparent. Moreover
column150: they announced a process at the first opportunity
column151: which was then\r\nfollowed and respected
column152:
and this generated trust and respect towards management.\r\n\r\n
  • SMEs require people to be multi-skilled
column153: not limited to\r\none’s job description. People need to be flexible
column154:
especially during\r\nreorganisation of work that follows restructuring events. \r\n
  • Restructuring events have a positive impact on employees
column155:
as those who face the event and successive changes and subsequently adapt to
them see their self-confidence increasing. She provides the specific example of
her own assistant
column156: the Assistant to the Customer Services Manager. In the past
column157: \r\nthis person had limited responsibilities if no responsibilities at all.\r\nFollowing work-reorganisation this person took over new tasks
column158: then\r\nresponsibilities. The progresses made by this person were so important that this\r\nperson is now able to work as a back-up to her when needed. She
column159: herself
column160:
benefitted from the process.
  • Restructuring impacts on employees in several ways. For instance
column161: some are delocalised
column162:
and this can impact on their daily lives.
  • Keeping talents in the company is a challenge for SMEs. SMEs need every member of staff and the loss of people
column163: especially good ones
column164:
can be costly for the company.

Ms Vigneron explained that there was no real social element during the process. The process went smoothly
column165: employees were well informed
column166: there were no lay-offs
column167:
so there was no issue in this respect.

column1:
Construction Company, Belgium~"Construction company"~"

The departure of two directors
column2: and the assumption of the role by a new director not qualified for it increased the company’s financial problems at the same time as the economic crisis affected the construction industry. In order to save the company
column3: the general manager agreed with a successor who would take over the company to restructure it
column4: on condition that the successor guaranteed the restructuring of the company
column5:
and agreed to retain the company’s workers. The construction company is now continuing operations under the same name.

"~"

In this company case study
column6: only the change of ownership/management process is described
column7:
not subsequent events.

Organisational profile

Construction Company is a company active in the construction and renovation of residential and non-residential buildings as well as in carpentry. Until the 1980s
column8: Construction Company could complete entire projects without needing to subcontract parts of the construction to other companies. It handled the following aspects: basic construction
column9: installation of electricity
column10: heating
column11: sanitary fittings
column12: windows
column13: roof
column14: and so on. Over the last 20 years
column15:
the company has been concentrating on building carcasses and carpentry and subcontracts in other construction activities.

\r\n

Construction Company’s premises are located in a sparsely-populated region nearby the border of a neighbouring state. Consequently
column16:
the cross-border influences (both opportunities and threats) have been and still are important for the company.

\r\n

During the last 40 years
column17: the General Manager has been assisted and supported by his wife
column18:
but generally speaking Construction Company has always been a company controlled by one person: the General Manager.

\r\n

Up to August 2011
column19: the shares of the company were always held by the General Manager and members of his family. Until 2009
column20: the administrative board of directors was composed of the General Manager and members of his family. In 2011
column21: the General Manager sold 90% of the shares of the company to Company A
column22: of which the Successor is a significant shareholder. Since September 2011
column23: the administrative board of directors is composed of the General Manager
column24:
the Successor and Company A.

\r\n

While in the 1970s and 1980s
column25: the most prosperous period for general construction companies in this region
column26: Construction Company counted between 150 and 180 employees
column27:
since 2005 the company has included between 30 and 40 employees. This reduction of business size was due to personal factors – such as a tragic accident involving the General Manager’s family and the sudden death of the administrative director – as well as business factors: the concentration of activities as explained above.

\r\n

At the end of 2011
column28: Construction Company counted on average 30 full-time employees and five employees working on a part-time basis
column29: mainly blue-collar workers. None of the workforce has a higher vocational diploma. About 10 to 15 workers are carpenters based either in the workshop or at clients’ premises. Under the General Manager’s supervisory control
column30:
the company has been managed by one administrative director and one technical director.

\r\n

Under the General Manager
column31:
the company’s activities were almost entirely carried out on a local and/or national basis.

\r\n

The company has no corporate charter
column32:
no union delegation and no works council. General communications that had to be made to all members of the company were traditionally made by the General Manager in front of the workforce.

\r\n

While the company seemed to be progressively improving between 2005 and 2008 by constant growth in the gross operating margin and reducing the deferred losses
column33: there was a cut in 2009 when the gross operating margin decreased and the deferred losses increased considerably. The reasons for this negative development will be analysed in the section below
column34: ‘Background to restructuring events’. The restructuring of the company
column35: started in 2011 by the Successor
column36: was a necessary step. Thanks to several capital increases and reductions
column37:
the balance sheet situation was stabilised in 2011 and the latest figures show a promising direction.

Background to restructuring event

The main reason for the restructuring of Construction Company was not a single event but generally speaking the ageing of the General Manager. However
column38:
this was accompanied by other circumstances that made the restructuring necessary.

\r\n

As in the most family-owned companies
column39: the General Manager also wished from the beginning that the company would be taken over by one of his sons. However
column40: for almost ten years
column41: it seemed clear that his eldest son would not take over the company as he decided to go his own way in the private sector. Nevertheless
column42: he was a member of the administrative board of Directors until 2011 in order to assist and support his father in the decision-making progress. The second eldest son worked for several years in the company
column43: but
column44: on the one hand
column45: the General Manager considered him too young to take over the company
column46: and on the other hand
column47: an illness prevented him from accomplishing his tasks. Moreover
column48: as we will explain below
column49:
the economic risk with respect to the take-over of the company was considerable.

\r\n

Despite the General Manager’s wish that the company would be taken over by his sons
column50: he was aware that everything had to be right for this to happen
column51: which is very rarely the case. Indeed
column52: according to the General Manager
column53: only 25% of family businesses are taken over by the children and only few of these family businesses are successful afterwards. According to the General Manager
column54: the main reasons for these difficulties are the following: the founder does not want to leave the company
column55: the successor feels permanently observed
column56: the successor does not put the necessary energy into the business
column57: etc. Generally speaking
column58: according to the General Manager
column59: it is difficult to establish a company
column60:
but it is even more difficult to take over an existing company.

\r\n

In 2008
column61: the technical director had to leave the company because of his wife’s illness. This person worked for almost 30 years in the company and invested enormous energy into the company and worked day and night. It was impossible to replace him. Moreover
column62:
it was extremely difficult to find persons that were technically qualified for his functions. All published job offers were unsuccessful and competition with foreign job offers was too high.

\r\n

Therefore
column63: a solution had to be found within the company. The staff member already employed by the company who took over the functions of the technical director was not the best solution. The new director knew that sooner or later the General Manager had to sell the company. He was personally interested in taking over the company
column64: but did not have the financial resources to accept the General Manager’s offer. Consequently
column65: he was not interested in improving the situation of the company but
column66: on the contrary
column67: sought the deterioration of the situation in order to reduce the value of the company. Moreover
column68:
he did not win the confidence of the workforce.

\r\n

Hence
column69: the important decrease of the gross operating margin and the huge increase in the deferred losses between 2009 and 2011 was related to the leave of the two directors and the promotion of the new director
column70:
who was not qualified for the job.

\r\n

In addition to the uncomfortable situation with the new director described above
column71: the General Manager was the victim of a serious accident in 2010 that prevented him from actively taking part in the company for several months. He never fully recovered from the accident. In the aftermath of the accident
column72: important decisions had to be taken by the General Manager’s family within the administrative board of directors. The new director gained even more power as he was the only active person having the experience and the technical skills to lead the company. In 2010
column73:
the administrative board of directors took the decision to fire the new director because of his poor leadership of the company.

\r\n

Even if in the construction sector the impact of economic crisis is generally felt later than in other sectors
column74: the slump in 2009 was certainly also due to the economic crisis. However
column75:
we understand that the crisis was not the main reason for the bad figures.

\r\n

In 2011
column76: the need for restructuring was obvious. In the past
column77: such restructuring has always been carried out successfully. As an example
column78: in the 1980s Construction Company’s activity was based 90% on public turnkey construction contracts. Because of the decrease of the public offers
column79:
Construction Company had to reorient towards private contracts and concentrated its activity.

\r\n

In recent years
column80: the General Manager was also looking for other solutions with respect to restructuring the company. Expansion of the business activity into the neighbour country has always been an option and in the past Construction Company has been internationally active. However
column81: the foreign clients were small ones and often poor payers. Construction Company would have needed a real business unit in this country
column82: with domestic foremen and workers in order to succeed in establishing a strong position in these markets. Indeed
column83: according to the General Manager
column84: the different technical regulations and legal frameworks in the neighbour country do not allow a middle-sized Belgian construction company
column85: such as Construction Company
column86:
to gain important market shares in this state without installing fixed business units.

\r\n

In each and every case
column87: Construction Company would have needed bank credit to realise the restructuring. The banks would only have granted the credits if the General Manager had accepted personal guarantees. In view of the age of the General Manager
column88:
the financial risk and the necessary energy were too high to consider the restructuring of the company by himself as a real option.

\r\n

Consequently
column89: the search for an external investor was the sole possibility. While in the 1980s
column90: this was very easy
column91: as a lot of foreign companies were acquiring small and medium-sized enterprises in this region
column92: it became much more difficult in the last 20 years. As the General Manager has a young family
column93: he could not have considered selling his company in the 1980s. The General Manager always learned about persons who are possibly interested in acquiring his company by word-of-mouth communication. In the same way
column94: he learned that the Successor
column95: whose parents are friends of the General Manager
column96: was potentially interested in acquiring a Construction Company even one with financial problems
column97:
provided that it still had a good reputation.

\r\n

In conclusion
column98: the General Manager stated during the interview that there were three possible solutions in 2011 before meeting the Successor: to declare bankruptcy
column99:
to liquidate the company or to find a new investor.

Restructuring processes

In this particular case
column100: the restructuring process was a very short one. As already stated above
column101: the General Manager learned that the Successor was interested in acquiring a Construction Company in order to restructure it. Earlier
column102: the Successor had been partner of a venture capital company that dealt with structuring and due diligence supervision. Later
column103: as financial manager in a company active in the façade industry
column104: he faced the challenges of building companies. Consequently
column105:
he had the necessary technical skills to organise the continuation of Construction Company.

\r\n

For the General Manager
column106:
the following conditions were important with respect to the acquisition of Construction Company by a new investor:

  • the successor had to guarantee the restructuring of the company;
  • the successor had to retain Construction Company’s workers;
  • the General Manager wanted to follow the evolution of the company.

At the end of summer 2011
column107: the General Manager and the Successor discussed all items concerning the functioning/structure of Construction Company
column108:
the modalities of the change of ownership and prepared all required formalities. The General Manager was keen to finalise the change of ownership in the short term in order to avoid rumours regarding the closure of the business.

\r\n

In September 2011
column109: Company A acquired 90% of the shares of Construction Company. In return for the liquid funds that were in Construction Company
column110: the General Manager kept 10% of the shares and agreed to stay on as a member of the administrative board of directors. Company A guaranteed the company restructuring and to retain the workforce. Consequently
column111:
all of the abovementioned conditions were fulfilled with respect to the acquisition by Company A. Construction Company is now continuing operations under the same name.

The change of ownership was communicated by the General Manager to the workforce shortly after the finalisation of the agreement during a general meeting. The details of the change were announced at the company’s traditional dinner before the winter break in the presence of the Successor. The workforce’s reaction was unanimously favourable as they were aware of the company’s financial difficulties. They were grateful that the General Manager and the Successor found this solution.

The change of ownership was communicated to suppliers by letters and personal visits in order to introduce the Successor. The suppliers also reacted in a positive manner and gave the Successor the same good terms and conditions that they already gave the General Manager.

Most of the clients have not been informed about the change of ownership. Indeed
column112: Construction Company continued working under the same name and finished all projects in accordance with the agreements in place. According to the General Manager
column113:
there are still some clients that are not aware of the change of ownership.

Challenges and constraints of restructuring

In this particular case
column114: from the point of view of the General Manager
column115:
there were no real challenges and constraints in the restructuring procedure.

\r\n

From the point of view of the Successor
column116:
the main difficulty was to estimate the time and human and financial resources necessary to manage current difficulties and obviously (re) develop the business.

\r\n

Most blue-collar employees were laid off and the company encountered a dramatic deterioration in the order book. Moreover
column117: as already explained
column118: the process of restructuring was quite short and consequently the due diligence process that sometimes allow dubious liabilities to be highlighted was also restrained. So the risks arising from the transaction
column119: from the point of view of the investors
column120: were very high
column121:
as Company A had to guarantee the financing of the restructuration. This would not have been possible without the confidence from the Successor to the General Manager on the situation of the Company.

Restructuring advice and support

As already mentioned above
column122: the banks were only willing to grant credit if the General Manager would personally guarantee the repayment. Given his age
column123: this option was not feasible. Regarding other possibilities of financial support
column124: by public funds or venture capital companies
column125: the General Manager has always been very cautious. He is against public funds as he thinks that they create discrimination between companies. Moreover
column126: with respect to financial support by venture capital companies
column127: the General Manager always feared the interference of these companies in the decision-making process within his company. Therefore
column128:
Construction Company has never been financially supported.

\r\n

The new investors came with an excellent track record with the bank sector. As the building sector is very cash-consuming due to long payment delays and a seasonal activity
column129:
the confidence from bankers was fundamental to finance part of the company’s restructuring. Investors had to finance accumulated arrears (and loss) and banks had to finance the short term needs for the new expansion of the business.

\r\n

Due to the good reputation of the successor
column130:
suppliers also agreed to delay the payment of some accounts.

\r\n

During the years before the transfer of the shares
column131: the General Manager has always been assisted and supported by the members of this family. All possible solutions have been discussed within the family
column132:
in the broad sense of the term. The decision to sell the company to Company A has also been discussed and taken within the family.

Outcomes of restructuring

The acquisition of the company was fully successful. The situation of Construction Company’s workers has not been negatively influenced by the acquisition. On the contrary
column133: the secured continuation of the business as well as the restructuring of the company have been very well accepted by the workforce. Moreover
column134: by continuing to use the same company name
column135:
Construction Company kept its former clients and can seize the new opportunities created by the new investor. The General Manager thinks that Construction Company is looking forward to a good future.

\r\n

Personally
column136: the General Manager did not take directly financial advantage from the sales of shares. However
column137: the General Manager still holds 10% of the shares and owns the land on which Construction Company is established. Thus
column138: he collects rents from Construction Company. Moreover
column139:
it was very important for the General Manager to keep up a good image. The bankruptcy of Construction Company would have cast a negative shadow on his life work as well as on his children’s present and future careers.

Commentary

The General Manager is very satisfied with the solution that has finally been found. The General Manager is also aware that the situation would have been much worse – in fact
column140:
the business would probably have closed – if the Successor had not have acquired Construction Company.

\r\n

Generally speaking
column141: he believes that flexibility is very important for companies in the construction sector
column142: as some of the workers have to be paid during the winter season even if there is no workload. He also thinks that the business environment changed very much in the last 50 years. Whereas in the past
column143: the engagement of workforce was profitable for companies as the added value by the workforce exceeded the costs
column144: nowadays he thinks that it is very difficult for small and middle-sized companies to be profitable. He feels that two or single-person enterprises are in a much more comfortable situation than middle-sized companies with respect to profitability
column145:
flexibility and risk exposure.

\r\n

Finally
column146:
the General Manager believes that the support and assistance of one’s spouse is always crucial in small and middle-sized family businesses.

For this case study
column28:
the Managing Director (MD) and the Development Director (DD) of the company were interviewed.

\r\n

The MD first joined the company in 2004 as its Commercial Director and has been the MD since 2005. He is the coowner and the major shareholder with around 60% of shares. The company has private investors alongside shares allocated for three Executive Directors.

\r\n

The MD has two degrees: a joint degree in Computer Science and Mathematics
column29: and a Masters degree in Philosophy
column30: Public Policy and Economic Development. He has gained experience in all areas of economic and social regeneration during his 20 year long career in public service provision. He has operated programmes aimed at young people
column31: business support
column32: social enterprise development
column33:
and work-based learning.

\r\n

Since joining the consultancy firm
column34: the MD has actively reshaped the company
column35: moving it into new areas such as brokerage
column36: combining skills and employment
column37:
and developing deeper and broader partnerships and regional services in the Midlands and the South East of England.

\r\n

During his career
column38:
the MD has been involved in restructuring in one way or another about every two years. This is inevitable when working as a service provider for ever changing public sector where programmes regularly emerge and disappear with changes of Government.

\r\n

The Development Director has been with the company since 2003. During this time
column39: he has progressed from various roles of Assistant Director into Director of Skills
column40: Director of Skills and Employability
column41: and Director of Operations. The role of the DD is to develop and win new business
column42: generating income for the company to deliver. Moreover
column43: he ensures that the transition from being successful with a new tender to making it operational is smooth. During his 12-year long career in this industry
column44: the DD was involved in a number of small and major restructurings. He previously worked in multi-media design and IT training
column45: owned a design company
column46:
and had also run a number of bars and restaurants. He originally trained as an architect.

\r\n

The company has undergone a major change in terms of its service portfolio in recent years. From 2004 to 2007
column47: public money for certain programmes dried up. At the same time
column48: the organisations that they would previously help receive money or develop products for found it difficult to deliver and increasingly asked them to help deliver outcomes rather than design programmes that deliver outcomes. Above all
column49: the money that was available for businesses doing contracts moved from programme evaluation and design
column50: which are not outcome focused
column51: to programmes that are entirely outcome focused. The company has therefore moved from providing design and evaluation services into delivery
column52: reflecting the government agenda. Consequently
column53: 95% of their services consist of delivery of outcomes in relation to jobs
column54: apprenticeships
column55: NVQs and business support
column56:
and the remaining 5% is evaluation work.

There is no works council and the company has no relationships with trade unions.

Background to restructuring events

The company has undergone two restructurings in recent years. The first
column58:
was due to a combination of a management buyout and regional expansion which did not bring a commercial return and the company retrenched to London and their home markets. This was in part due to changes in government policy in the training and business support markets.

\r\n

The focus of this case study is the second restructuring
column60:
which was due to inefficiencies in the business and the key management not being capable to execute the new work that the company had won in new markets.

\r\n

As the company entered new markets and changed its service portfolio from programme design to delivery
column61: the existing personnel became less suited for the required work. According to the MD
column62: this was not due to lack of skills or inability of staff to carry out the work; however
column63: they were not necessarily the right team for driving and delivering outcomes. As a consequence
column64:
the company started to experience two negative trends: not reaching its potential in terms of turnover and profit and losing contracts value from funders.

\r\n

At the same time
column65: the company entered new markets in the post- 2010 general election period when competition was tough
column66: market share was smaller and the money coming into the system was much smaller. As a result
column67: larger firms in the industry were entering new markets because there was no work coming in from their usual streams. The present company
column68: likewise
column69: found it difficult to find contract value that was sufficient enough to keep the business going. And the contract value they had was not performing
column70: partly due to the nature of the programmes
column71:
but also because they did not have the right team to drive performance in those areas.

\r\n

In March 2011
column72: the present DD moved a position and became the Operations Director (OD) to try and re-set some of the deliverables. Both the MD and the DD had a solid reputation. They had the organisational intelligence and market knowledge and so the MD took a chance at the time and promoted the current DD to OD. This however was going to be a short- to medium-term measure. The role of the OD was to manage staff and ensure smooth running of programmes. However
column73: this did not work and from around September 2011
column74: the MD started to feel that something was wrong with the positions of the OD and the Assistant Directors. At the time
column75: the management structure of the company consisted of the MD
column76: the OD
column77: the DD
column78: and Finance Director. Below the senior level
column79: they also had three Assistant Directors in marketing
column80:
skills and employment.

Restructuring processes

In October 2011
column81: the company appointed a new chief operating officer (COO)
column82: recruited from outside
column83: with a background in programme delivery. Subsequently
column84: the new COO and the MD looked closely at the business and decided to strip out the positions of Assistant Directors and restructure the company. The decision to restructure was taken by the MD in consultation with the Board and investors
column85: with the aim to better adapt to their new markets and focus on outcome delivery. The restructuring
column86: including planning
column87: consultations with the Board
column88: and implementation phase
column89:
took about two to three months to complete. The management developed a restructuring plan which was approved by the Board.

\r\n

The Board consists of several members: the MD
column90: two investors
column91: and an independent chairman with no stake in the business to ensure that everything goes by the book. Besides the Board
column92: they have an Observer who scrutinises their finances. According to the MD
column93: there was some resistance from Board members during negotiations. There was some concern that the company was restructuring again and there was also nervousness about whether it would work. Moreover
column94: there was certain nervousness and differences of opinion about retaining particular employees. Board members not involved in the daily running of the company had different views
column95: as opposed to the MD who thought over how they can actually use existing human resources. In the end
column96:
the board came to an agreement. An alternative to restructuring would have been closure.

\r\n

The restructuring event was about changing the way the business operates for the sake of the business. The company needed a new structure which had inevitable consequences for employment as seven posts were made redundant
column97: including the three Assistant Directors. The company informed all employees by circulating letters on 23 December. This was clearly quite distressing
column98:
given that employees learned about the decision just before the Christmas break.

\r\n

The company followed employment law and their own due process for handling redundancies; this involved consultations with the employees. According to the MD
column99: some employees saw it coming but resisted and appealed against the decision. Eventually
column100:
the company signed a compromise agreement with all three employees. This was not a pleasant time for the company but it was necessary.

\r\n

At the same time as making redundancies
column101: new roles were being created through an open and transparent internal and external recruitment process. The redundant employees had the opportunity to apply for the new roles. One employee chose to apply and continues working at the company
column102:
two left and three employees were made redundant.

\r\n

The new company structure includes two new Senior Operations Managers and a dedicated marketing division. The sales were moved directly under the operations management so there is a direct link into the delivery machine that then turns out the outputs as per contract requirements. The company increased the proportion of delivery done internally rather than externally through partnerships. By internalising delivery work
column103: the headcount of frontline employees to management has shifted significantly. As a result of company reorganisation
column104:
they recruited twelve new staff who all received informal briefing sessions when they first joined.

\r\n

Besides the mentioned negotiations
column105:
the MD and the newly appointed COO had a conversation with the OD about his role and decided to make that post redundant too. The MD thought that this employee had value for the business on the development side and was therefore offered the new position of the Development Director as he had the knowledge and experience required for the role.

\r\n

According to the MD
column106: as a small business
column107:
it is important that you have an approach to people and what they might bring to the business even if what they are doing at that time is not particularly useful. The company has tried to compromise and retain staff during this and past restructurings where a post became redundant but it was thought that an employee could bring a value into other parts of the business.

\r\n

The cost of restructuring
column108: including redundancy payments and compromise agreements
column109: was around £20
column110: 000 (approximately €25
column112:
funded from the cash reserves of the company.

Challenges and constraints of restructuring

The MD notes that small businesses face problems when it comes to recruiting the right people. Some people want to see a progression fast or they join a bigger business. The family atmosphere in the small business with 50-60 staff is not for everyone
column113: some people prefer a corporate environment and the company has to try and accommodate that. Recruiting the right people has been a great challenge. The company had been looking for a person with strong background and experience of delivery for about three years. They spent around £20
column115: 000 (approximately €25
column117: 000) on recruitment fees trying to recruit an Operations Director three times but failed because they could not find the right person. The company had to compromise on what they were really looking for. Besides the senior positions
column118:
they did not have the right team in place to drive delivery.

\r\n

One of the challenges the company faced during restructuring were human emotions. There was a degree of employee resistance
column119: anxiety and sadness. Communicating with staff throughout the process has been very important for the company. They held 1-2-1 sessions
column120: regular briefings
column121:
team meetings and full staff meetings. They also had to think about how best to communicate to the market the changes made; what to say to partners and to funders. The MD addressed this by initiating a number of briefing sessions with major funders to explain that the company is now in the business of delivery and has therefore moved their teams to ensure that funders get what they want in return for their money.

\r\n

The change of employment dynamics has created some tension between the culture that the new COO brought into the company – the crew of people he used to work with in previous organisations – and the pre-existing culture. To address this tension
column122: they have done some work around certain ideas and preconceptions in order to bring people together. This involved a company quiz
column123: role swap
column124: IIP (Investors in People) implementation
column125: old staff peer to peer with new staff
column126:
team away days and culture days.

Restructuring advice and support

Outcomes of restructuring

The restructuring of the company changed the way that the operations division was structured in terms of the teams
column127: line management
column128: and the resources assigned between programme delivery and management coordination. As a result
column129: 90% of senior managers exited and a new team was put in place. The company now has more frontline staff and fewer in managerial roles. The new structure is made up of a Managing Director
column130: Chief Operating Officer
column131: Finance Director
column132: and a Business Development Director. They have Senior Office Managers who take care of day-to-day delivery
column133:
and more frontline staff such as business advisers and guidance workers.

\r\n

In May 2012
column134: five months into the reorganisation
column135: there has been an increase in performance in some areas
column136:
but it is early days to evaluate the outcome fully. There is a degree of uncertainty as some promises of where the company would be by this time have not been fulfilled. Moving the current DD from operations into business development has been beneficial; they have since won an £8m (€10.2m) contract in March 2012.The DD was instrumental in making it work and driving performance.

\r\n

Both restructuring events in 2008 and 2011 resulted in staff reductions.During that period the employment number fluctuated depending on the contract value and changes to the market but the company was able to retain between 35-45 employees. As a result of the recent restructuring
column137: two people left
column138: three employees were made redundant
column139:
one re-applied for a different position and remained with the company and one was offered a different position. Some of the existing employees are still evaluating the recent changes and whether company aims will come to fruition. Time will show if they remain committed.

\r\n

There is some cultural tension between the pre-existing employees and the twelve new staff that joined the company. The management have addressed this by organising quiz events
column140:
team away days and one-to-one sessions to bring staff together.

\r\n

Turnover dropped initially by £2m (approximately €2.6m)
column141: and profit in the same proportion
column142:
but they are more stable in 2012. The company confirmed turnover of £5m (€6.4m) for the next three years and is in a healthier position. The MD predicts that in 2013 they have the potential to do very well; it will probably be their best year ever in the life of the company.

\r\n

Overall
column143:
the MD concludes that restructuring was painful but necessary and as a result the company is in a much healthier position to face the markets in which they operate.

Commentary

The restructuring event described in this case study is an example of how a change in product markets can push a small company into restructuring. The cutbacks in government expenditure that have been implemented to cope with the deficit since 2010 have had a major impact on small company providers of public services such as this consultancy firm. With less money available and tougher competition
column144:
the company had to enter new markets.

\r\n

Restructuring was a necessary reaction to changing markets. Entering new markets and adapting to the new requirements rapidly meant that the company survived and continues to grow. As a small company
column145: the consultancy firm was able to benefit from their ability to adapt quickly
column146:
unlike many companies in their markets that closed in recent years.

\r\n

With hindsight
column147: the MD thinks that they should have implemented changes earlier when they crept into doing delivery. Instead
column148: they decided to remain focused on their existing strengths which together did not work in the end. Despite this
column149: the MD does not have any regrets about what they did and the processes followed. There are two important aspects to mention. First
column150: the emotional response of human beings directly affected by the changes; and second
column151: in the aftermath
column152: the importance of linking people left behind
column153: who go through a sort of grieving process
column154:
together with the new people who join the company.

\r\n

This restructuring affected the DD more than any previous restructuring events due to the non-performance to the required level in his previous role as the OD. Appointing him to that role was a compromise not only for the company but for him personally. At the time
column155: he was not 100% confident that the role was right for him; he feared that it was not really what he should have been doing. His strengths are in business development which is where he moved eventually and has been successful since. The DD notes that restructuring is a necessity. Markets are never stagnant
column156: they change
column157:
and SMEs therefore need to react and find new markets. Market change drives restructuring and SMEs arguably need to restructure more often than large businesses. Even minor restructuring can have a greater impact within an SME but SMEs should not be frightened of it and should seek external advice and guidance if they do not have previous experience of restructuring.

\r\n

As time moved on and there was a greater demand for programme delivery
column158: the consultancy firm also had to move on and therefore the structure of their business had to change. Within that structure
column159: changes were made which inevitably had implications for employment at managerial and other occupational levels. A number of staff left
column160: some moved into different positions and some were made redundant. At the same time
column161: the company recruited new staff with skills and experience that would match the new focus on delivery. In that process
column162: they lost the intelligence
column163: knowledge and experience of people who had worked at the company for years. There has been a change in company culture as a result of tensions between incumbent employees and new staff; however
column164:
the company is putting time and effort into trying to bring people together and ensuring that people know the company culture.

Outcomes of restructuring

column150: the implementation of preventive measures and technologies that allowed for a textile waste reduction of approximately 27% as a whole
column151: and of 50% of the sludge

column153:
energy and products and a decrease in the overall waste level.
