At the management level
column154: a training plan was established for workers to internalise the company's waste minimisation policy as being a key issue and a priority for the company due to economic
column155: environmental and corporate factors. Part of the strategy also included informing consumers about the company's environmental policy
column156: in order to improve financial performance
column157: by reducing costs and increasing sales and turnover. There was an increase after the process and the same happened with the employment levels
column158: as it was possible to contract more employees due to the expansion of sales and production
column159:
by adding value to the products and making better use of the resources and achieving an increased competitiveness.

Through this methodology Fitecom was able to reduce costs
column160:
increase environmental awareness in-house and with clients and other stakeholders level and decrease time waste.

An additional outcome of the process at Fitecom was the development of an integrated management system that created policies geared towards improved hygiene
column161: health and safety applied to all workers
column162:
in order to avoid professional accidents derived from the new practices and increase competitiveness.

\r\n

Among the fundamental principles of this policy were the identification
column163: evaluation and prevention of risks to safety and promotion of health in the workplace (physical
column164: chemical and biological)
column165: the preventive/corrective planning of programmes and their risk assessment measures for all the company's activities
column166: as well as for occupational hazards in general
column167: the information and training on risks to health and safety
column168:
as well as protection and prevention on measures and the planning of appropriate monitoring programmes.

Commentary

The new environmental innovation cycle pursued by the company allied with new practices of human resources management focused on the development of skills and competences required at this
column169: made it possible to reposition Fitecom competively as a leading SME in the field

column172: environmental and energy waste reduction issues. Waste prevention can be achieved through innovative changes in products
column173:
processes and operations.

The firm implemented several restructuring measures
column174: such as changes in procedures and management
column178:
changes in the composition or product packaging and the reuse of waste generated in the company.

\r\n

The employees were positively affected and motivated through the involvement in the changing mission of the company
column179: such as the constant training in the areas of expertise and in environmental practices
column180: the hiring of new workers and the expansion of the business
column181:
characterised by parameters targeted at high levels of quality and safety. The restructuring process altered the entire modus operandi of the company concernig environmental practices in the production process.

\r\n

This demonstrates that the residuals prevention must be part of a plan and must be understood by the firm as a whole. Furthermore
column184:
economic and social) of the company depends upon the minimization of wastes and residuals and the maximization of efficiency in processes and operations.

\r\n

In order to achieve the success planned from the goals previously defined

column1:
Foodstuff Company, Belgium~"Foodstuff company"~NULL~"

Organisational profile

Foodstuff Company is a company active in the processing
column2: wholesale and retail trade of food. Foodstuff Company was founded in 1984 by the current Board Member and former CEO
column3: as a means to diversify his agricultural activities. At the outset
column4: the company was breeding a small stock of animals for the benefit of a French company but
column5: following the bankruptcy of the latter
column6:
it was decided to start breeding animal stock for Foodstuff Company’s own activities.

\r\n

Foodstuff Company rapidly developed a sales network
column7: followed by the opening up of franchised shops and restaurants/tables d’hôtes. In 1996
column8: Foodstuff Company started offering their products in the Belgian supermarket chain
column9: Delhaize Group SA
column10: as well as to the Belgian supermarket chain Colruyt NV. Between 2005 and 2010
column11:
Foodstuff Company took over three companies:

\r\n

• Company A (2005)
column12:
a Brussels-based company specialised in the processing of food;

\r\n

• Company B (2007)
column13: based in Flanders
column14:
delivering food to restaurants; and

\r\n

• Company C (2010)
column15: a company based in the German speaking part of Belgium
column16:
specialised in food production and sales.

\r\n

The takeover of these three companies is the ‘restructuring event’ for the purpose of the present case study.

\r\n

The shareholding of Foodstuff Company has been exclusively family-owned from the date of creation of the company until May 2012. So
column17: for the period of restructuring
column18: that is from 2005 to 2009
column19:
the capital was family-owned exclusively.

\r\n

In early 2012
column20: 20% of Foodstuff Company’s activities qualified as ’international‘
column21: that is exports to the Netherlands
column22: the Grand Duchy of Luxembourg
column23: to Hong Kong
column24:
Mexico and Japan.

\r\n

In early 2012
column25: Foodstuff Company had 42 employees working on site in the historical centre of the company
column26: the family farm. In addition
column27: approximately 40 employees worked outside
column28: notably in the franchised restaurants/shops
column29: and these are all employed by Foodstuff Company. Foodstuff Company’s employees are equally divided between men and women. There is a high level of employee loyalty as some families have worked for two generations within the company. The employee population counts more blue-collar than white-collar workers. Most employees have no diploma at all
column30: whereas some hold a vocational training certificate and four have a university degree. Half of the employees have never had another employer than Foodstuff Company. There is no human resources charter at Foodstuff Company
column31: but the company’s values – mutual respect
column32: availability and flexibility – are strong within the company. There is no works council at Foodstuff Company
column33:
the legal thresholds for such a body not being fulfilled.

\r\n

Over the last five years
column34: Foodstuff Company’s turnover steadily increased by 20% each year. In 2011
column35:
the turnover was €12 million.

\r\n

At the outset
column36:
the current general manager was a farmer. His wish to diversify his farming activities rapidly made him responsible for large fruit orchards in Belgium and abroad. He holds a secondary education certificate in Latin and classical Greek. He dropped out of university to start working as a farmer.

\r\n

The employee interviewed for the case study has a vocational training certificate in the field of hospitality business gained in 1993. He worked in the hospitality business sector for seven years before joining Foodstuff Company in 2000. At Foodstuff Company
column37:
he started as a white collar worker assigned to the production chain for a couple of years. He then became responsible for production for five years. He is currently a purchasing manager responsible for buying or approving the acquisition of approximately 650 goods needed by the company.

Background to restructuring event

The cause of the restructuring event is the aspiration of Foodstuff Company’s manager to grow externally and to diversify his activities
column38: combined with his personal knowledge of the market
column39:
including personal/professional relationships with general managers of other companies/competitors:

\r\n

• With the takeovers of Company A and of Company C
column40:
Mr General Manager saw an opportunity and was willing to expand and diversify his portfolio of food offered.

\r\n

• With the takeover of Company B
column41: Mr Employee was willing to expand his customer base
column42:
by notably having access to restaurants.

\r\n

The restructuring process was quite simple
column43:
mostly based on personal contacts with the managers of the purchased companies and knowledge of these companies’ activities.

Restructuring processes

The restructuring process was relatively informal. The general manager
column44: due to his long involvement in the industry and his proactivity
column45: knew of the existence of potential companies to be purchased and took time to get to know these companies’ managers better. He thus first made informal contact with the potential companies to be purchased. After some time elapsed
column46: the managers eventually agreed to the purchase and the purchase was structured
column47: with limited external support
column48: that is basic legal advice from a local law firm and support from the company’s external accountant/auditor. After the purchase was executed
column49: for approximately six months nothing was changed in the daily running of either of the purchased company
column50: spending time observing the daily management
column51: asking questions to the management and the staff. Once the learning curve was over
column52: change was implemented
column53: for example replacing inefficient processes by more efficient ones (replacement of one packaging process by another one
column54:
for example).

\r\n

The takeover of Company A was unplanned; it was an opportunity that emerged out of the blue. Company A was located in Brussels and it was decided not to use the premises of Brussels
column55: but to relocate all activities to the family farm
column56: approximately sixty kilometres away. The takeovers of Company C and of Company B were more planned; the general manager was actively on the lookout for external growth and activity diversification. According to him
column57: being ‘out there’ looking for opportunities was made possible thanks to the efficient support of some employees and
column58: more importantly
column59:
his wife. This support allowed him to delegate the day-to-day management and to concentrate on strategies and on exploring the market. All three purchased activities/companies were relocated to the family farm or the vicinities of it due to the wish to keep activities close to the family farm.

\r\n

The employees were never consulted before or during the transaction. Employees were informed once the transaction was executed
column60: during a single meeting in the cafeteria. Employees were presented with the ‘fait accompli’
column61: that is
column62:
informed only afterwards about the deal.

Challenges and constraints of restructuring

According to the general manager
column63: the restructuring events went smoothly and quickly
column64: without any major difficulty. External financing by banks was necessary for all three purchases
column65: but
column66: the debt proportion was low/reasonable at each time and the track record of the company was excellent
column67: which made things relatively easy except for the following: Access to external financing was an issue for the takeover of Company A
column68: where the debt level of the company was relatively high
column69: following the withdrawal of a historical shareholder
column70: whose shares were taken over by the company. Banks were difficult
column71: requiring bank guarantees
column72: which represented a financial burden for the company. The company managed to obtain the bank guarantee and
column73: in the end
column74: they were never executed
column75:
which is seen by the company to demonstrate that banks tend to be difficult with SMEs when it comes to allowing funding.

\r\n

Moreover
column76: the heavy red tape surrounding access to financing
column77: notably for restructuring purposes
column78: was seen as a negative factor
column79:
and simplification of administrative process should be considered.

\r\n

According to the interviewed employee
column80: more information could improve employees’ acceptance of the restructuring event. He points out a specific fear of employees regarding the impact of the restructuring event on the quality of work. As the sector is seasonal
column81: work becomes very intense from early October until the end of the Christmas/New Year period; taking into account that the activities of Foodstuff Company almost doubled over the considered period of time/restructuring period – as explained below
column82: employees legitimately feared a concomitant increase of workload
column83: which
column84: in the end
column85: did not really occur. More information could ease such types of fears
column86:
the interviewed employee believes.

Restructuring advice and support

Foodstuff Company did not benefit from external financial support for the three acquisitions
column87: apart from the financing from the banks
column88: mentioned above. Both the lawyer and the accountant who provided external technical support were personal acquaintances of the general manager
column89:
so it was not an issue for him to find such external support.

Outcomes of restructuring

The outcomes of the restructuring event are positive from the company perspective:

• Steady increase of the yearly turnover of 20% since 2007;

• Increased competitiveness due to the diversification of supply sources;

• Increased market shares;

• Increased profitability;

• Diversification of production chain; and

• Modernisation of processes and distribution methods.

This is confirmed by the interviewed employee who notes that
column90: following the restructuring event
column91: Foodstuff Company improved the purchase management. Generally speaking
column92:
Foodstuff Company became more efficient.

\r\n

Following the takeover of Company A
column93: numerous employees of the purchased company eventually left on a voluntary basis. Out of the 23 former employees
column94: five are still working within Foodstuff Company today. The interviewed employee explains this by the fact that these employees did not like the fact that they had to drive to their relocated workplace on a daily basis without further financial compensation. It needs to be noted
column95: though
column96: that no one had to be fired: people left on a voluntary basis or retired
column97:
and were not replaced afterwards.

\r\n

The restructuring event did not lead to important changes in work arrangements
column98: such as conversion of full-time jobs into part-time jobs or conversely. Likewise
column99:
social packages/employment contracts were not modified.

\r\n

Following the restructuring event
column100: work organisation has changed for some employees
column101: as reported by the interviewed employee. He explains that
column102: for his part
column103: the diversification of the production chain and the subsequent merger of two different activities generated a lot of work as well as the learning of new tasks and processes (new machines and the like)
column104: which employees have learnt to manage (increase of work) and develop (new tasks/skills/processes) ‘on-the-spot’
column105: that is
column106:
without external training. He says he gained new skills/competences and knowledge following the restructuring event.

The outcome of the restructuring event on the general manager’s own assets/estate was positive as well.

Commentary

The general manager sees some advantages that SMEs have over larger companies in restructuring
column107: notably flexibility and speed; and the fact that decisions are taken by a handful of people
column108: without having to go through extensive reporting lines
column109: which gives a clear competitive advantage over larger competitors. The interviewed employee confirms this. He moreover notes that task allocation in SMEs is less clear than in larger companies
column110: also during/following restructuring
column111:
but he does not identify this as being either a negative or a positive aspect.

\r\n

One drawback in SME restructuring is the lack of human
column112:
technical and financial resources.

\r\n

Moreover
column113: high taxes in Belgium following a restructuring event and/or in general are an issue for SMEs. He explains that high taxes lower Belgian SMEs’ profitability
column114:
which forces some of them to eventually go out of business or sell out their activities.

column1:
Furniture Company, Italy~"Furniture company"~"

This Italian furniture company was compelled to restructure when faced with falling orders
column2: turnover and profits. The company implemented the CIGO measure
column3: under which part of its workforce reduced their working hours while receiving 80% of their normal salary. At the end of the CIGO
column4: the company implemented a solidarity contract for some employees
column5: who reduced their working hours by 20% while receiving 80% of the lost salary for the non-worked hours. Employees at the company’s smaller production site were laid off under a mobility procedure. The restructuring process has required continuous organisational adjustments
column6:
both in terms of tasks and roles.

"~"

Organisational profile

The group is composed of three branches: the manufacturing of furniture accessories and decorative hardware
column7:
and industrial design.

\r\n

The company was founded in the 1950s and has been run since then as a family business
column8:
and it is now in its third generation. Ownership and management are concentrated in the same hands.

\r\n

Since its foundation
column9: the company has invested in a strong design discipline and manufacturing expertise. In order to respond to the emergence of new trends in the 1970s
column10: a second company was founded in the plastics sector to offer plastic with conscious
column11: intrinsic value as a material that is strongly expressive as well as being technically versatile and highly functional. In addition
column12: a third brand was introduced to renew classic taste
column13:
mixing it with the modern aspects of design. This brand introduces a new era in which industrial product is enhanced with elegance and optimum quality.

\r\n

The company has two production sites. The main site is adjacent to the main offices and it is where they manufacture and cast products in zamak. A second smaller unit
column14: located in a nearby village
column15:
is engaged in molding processes.

\r\n

The company has 74 employees; of these 38 are women and four non-nationals. In terms of educational profiles among the staff
column16: five hold tertiary degrees
column17: 17 have an upper secondary education
column18: 45 have secondary education and three have primary education qualifications. The company has no information on the educational profile of the four foreign members of the staff. Seven employees (of whom four part-time workers) are employed in the second productive unit of the company
column19:
while the remainder 67 staff are employed in the main offices and main production site.

\r\n

Despite the fact that the number of employees has diminished in the past few years
column20: from 91 staff in 2009 to 82 staff in 2010 and currently 74 staff in 2012
column21:
the company did not make any dismissals. The decrease in the number of employees has been solely due to voluntary redundancies or natural wastage.

\r\n

There is a unitary work council (Rappresentanza sindacale unitaria
column22: RSU). This body is elected by all employees
column23: but representatives are usually elected through trade union lists. Therefore
column24: it includes features of both works councils (the broad active electorate) and trade union bodies (the almost exclusive inclusion of trade union representatives). In general
column25:
it can be associated with trade union bodies. The RSU was highly involved in the described restructuring process.

\r\n

The company is very embedded in the local community: 20 years ago
column26: 80% of the employees cycled to work. Nowadays
column27:
all employees live a maximum of 40 kilometres from the company. Also the owners of the company live nearby and are well rooted in the local community.

\r\n

The company does not have a written human resources strategy. Human resources management is administered internally by each head of sector
column28: who is responsible for all aspect of human resources and their development
column29: whereas other aspect of administration
column30: such as pay-rolls
column31:
are outsourced to an external consultant.

\r\n

The company has a large number of clients: around 1
column32: 000 active clients
column33: both from Italy and abroad. Foreign clients are mainly located in Europe
column34:
the US and Russia. The client base in Russia grew extensively during the last ten years. The company has also some clients in Asia and South Africa as well as some in North African countries.

\r\n

Distribution in Italy is carried out through hardware products wholesalers or producers of furniture. The same applies to foreign markets
column35:
where they either sell to furniture producers or they resell directly on foreign markets via local wholesalers.

\r\n

Since the economic crisis
column36: the Italian market for hardware products shrank dramatically
column37: however this was partially offset by a considerable expansion on foreign markets in the last years
column38: in particular in Russia
column39: France and Germany. In general
column40:
around 63 % of turnover derives from the Italian market while the rest from foreign markets.

Background to restructuring event

Due to the economic crisis
column41: turnover started to fall by 30–35% since 2008. However
column42: this fall was not immediate; indeed turnover fell by 27% in 2008–2009
column43: and decreased further in 2010 and 2011
column44: even if for 2011
column45:
the decrease was concentrated in the first quarter.

\r\n

Profits have diminished considerably. The market is much more exigent
column46: as customers demand perfection; furthermore
column47: most of the clients of the company no longer purchase to build up stock
column48: but rather order items already sold to their own customers. This implies an increase in the stock of the company with a longer rotation of this stock
column49: as well as very quick delivery times. Financially
column50: for the company this means an increase in costs and a reduction in profits. Moreover
column51: the intrinsic characteristics of the Italian labour market
column52: which do not allow companies to adjust employment levels quickly to market developments
column53:
lead to rigidities and profits reduction.

\r\n

The company was also largely affected by a strong speculation on the raw materials which are used in their production. This speculation could not be reflected in the prices
column54: as these had to be kept stable or in some cases reduced in order to make them more appealing to their customers
column55: who were also suffering from the economic crisis. Also repayment terms had to be extended and renegotiated
column56: while conversely
column57: access to credit
column58:
funding and financing were extremely limited.

\r\n

The company has also suffered a lot from competition from foreign countries with a cheaper labour force. As already discussed
column59: the company’s production is all made in Italy and based on a strong design element. The company launches about 35 new products per year and in order to develop these
column60: they study
column61: research and develop at least four times that many. This is a very long and costly process
column62:
however once produced and launched on the market the product and its industrial design can be immediately replicated by competitors. Most competition comes from China and Turkey.

To counteract the difficult developments of the economic and financial crisis as well as the rise of competitor countries at the end of 2008 company decided to implement a restructuring programme.

Restructuring process

Since the end of 2008
column63: turnover fell and costs became unsustainable. There was also a surplus of human resources compared to the level needed under the new conditions which could not be offset even by natural wastage
column64:
so the company started to consider which feasible options could be implemented to face the new deteriorated economic conditions. The company decided to implement a restructuring process via the use of social shock absorbers.

\r\n

In May 2009 the company introduced the ordinary wage guarantee fund (cassa integrazione ordinaria CIGO – see also Eurofound
column65: 2010). Under this arrangement
column66: on a rotation base the affected employees were working reduced hours
column67: receiving 80% of their normal salary. The CIGO affected both production sites and some offices. In the administration and in the trade divisions there was no necessity to implement short-time working
column68: as these offices operated already with a limited number of staff. The average number of non-worked hours is eight hours per week. At the beginning the company had opted for working one less hour per day
column69: however in order to guarantee continuity in the production cycle
column70: the company decided to concentrate the hours under the CIGO on two days
column71:
during which the affected staff worked on a rotation basis.

\r\n

Moreover
column72: the specific contract which regulates the conditions of employees of the company (contratto metalmeccanico) envisages a large number of paid hours for special leave. Thus at the beginning of the restructuring process
column73: those employees who had accumulated a considerable number of hours of paid special leave had been encouraged to make use of them during periods of reduced work. For the main productive site and the affected offices
column74: the CIGO lasted until the end of June 2012. At the end of the CIGO
column75: the company had to re-evaluate its conditions. Indeed
column76: as there was too many staff in proportion to the amount of work and turnover
column77: the company decided to implement a solidarity contract (contratto di solidarietà
column78: see also Eurofound
column79: 2010) for a number of its employees. Solidarity contract is a social shock absorber which provides for short-time working of equal measure for the whole workforce of a unit or division
column80: while employees benefit from income support of 80% of the lost wage. In this specific case
column81: the solidarity contract affected 51 employees who under this agreement reduced their working hours by 20%
column82:
while receiving 80% of the lost salary for the non-worked hours. Those employees not affected by the solidarity contract resumed working standard working hours.

\r\n

While restructuring in the main production site and some offices has been implemented through short-time working under the CIGO and more recently by the contratto di solidarietà
column83: restructuring of the smaller production site engaged in molding has been more difficult. In 2011
column84: as the decline in turnover was concentrated in plastic material products
column85: the second production unit was considered no longer profitable and the company was forced to assess its conditions and possible developments. At the beginning the company had considered the possibility of transferring the molding activity to the main production site. This would have resulted in a reduction of costs while safeguarding the affected staff. However
column86: after assessing the level of investments the company would have had to make in the main production site
column87: it became obvious that this was not feasible and economically viable. At this stage
column88: the company was left with the only option to outsource the molding activity and implement a procedure of extraordinary wage guarantee fund (cassa integrazione straordinaria CIGS) for the site which envisaged the stop of production (CIGS zero ore). Under this scheme employees work reduced hours or even no hours (complete stop of production in this case)
column89:
while receiving income support equal to 80% of their last wage.

\r\n

On this smaller production site
column90: which as the main site had been under CIGO since May 2009
column91: CIGS started in October 2011 and lasted until the end of September 2012. In October 2012
column92: with the end of the CIGS
column93: the employees of the second site have been dismissed under a mobility procedure. Under this procedure
column94: the dismissed employees are placed in special regional mobility lists
column95: which are special job placement registers compiled to promote the re-engagement of the dismissed employees into the labour market. Under a mobility procedure
column96: the employees also receive income support
column97:
if their former employer is eligible for CIGS.

\r\n

The restructuring process has required continuous organisational adjustments
column98: both in terms of tasks and roles. This implied a high degree of flexibility to the staff
column99: and also considerable costs to the company
column100: as in order to implement staff rotation
column101: most staff had to be re-trained. This process was the result of agreements with social partners
column102: and efforts have been channeled to ensure skills
column103: competences and professionalism were safeguarded
column104:
while at the same time ensuring that the least necessary number of CIGO were used.

Challenges and constraints of restructuring

The main challenges the company encountered related to access to capital
column105: financing and funding as well as bureaucracy.  Indeed
column106: SMEs’ limited size undermines their bargaining power with banks and financial institutions in accessing finance and credit. SMEs score higher than average failed loan requests or have to pay higher interest rates to compensate for the bank perceived risk. Either way
column107: credit and funding support dries up when most needed and this is highly significant as no investment or restructuring can be implemented without financing and credit. Moreover
column108: despite the restructuring being financed by the CIG (which is itself financed via a contribution that each enterprise pays
column109: in a sort of insurance mechanism)
column110: the procedure requires that the income support is anticipated by the company
column111: which will then be reimbursed by the Italian National Social Security Institute (INPS). This reimbursement
column112: however
column113:
can be paid up to six months after the implementation. This is an incredible incongruence because it results in a dramatic burden for companies which are already in difficulty.

\r\n

The employees were informed immediately via their trade union representatives
column114: as prescribed by Italian Law. Quite understandably
column115: at the beginning the employees were concerned
column116: also due to the fact that the majority of employees had been working in the company for a very long time and there had never been a need to implement such a restructuring process in the history of the company. However
column117: these worries and the uncertainty have slightly diminished during the ongoing process
column118: especially once it became clear that the reduction of hours worked concerned only a limited number of hours per employee (eight hours per week during CIGO) implying that there was not any prospect of temporary stoppage to the production or even closure. However
column119: the impact on the employees of the second production site
column120: which effectively stopped production
column121: has been much more dramatic
column122:
as their future outlook in the company seems quite negative.

\r\n

For the owners
column123: the decision to restructure was emotionally very difficult. The company is a family-run business
column124: which has been in the family for three generations. The owners are very bound to the company and the employees
column125: and even if the impact on wages has not been dramatic
column126: thanks to the supply of the CIG and of the solidarity contract
column127:
the decision to result to these instruments has been emotionally challenging.

Restructuring advice and support

The company has been supported in its restructuring process by the local offices of Confindustria (the Italian employers’ organisation for the industry sector)
column128: which provided advice and information especially on the social shock absorbers
column129: its procedures and the social dialogue with the other involved actors. The restructuring processes and the different options have been discussed with Confindustria which provided indispensable advice. The company has also been extensively supported by the external consultants that are also responsible for the outsourced administrative activities. The consultants provided detailed information on the different options of restructuring
column130: providing also legal requirements
column131:
and expected outcomes and different scenarios of the different restructuring options.

\r\n

The final decisions however are the sole result of the company decision and they are the result of the social dialogue.

\r\n

Social dialogue has been very fair
column132: and the main trade union representative has been extremely fair to the company as well as the employees. Employees did not directly participate in the social dialogue
column133:
but they did so through the trade unions and the RSU.

\r\n

The Ministry of Labour as well as the Public Employment Services has not been involved at all. The Ministry of Labour has been only provided with the detailed information on the financial outlook of the company at the time of applying for CIG and solidarity contract as prescribed by the Law.

\r\n

The company benefited of the economic support provided by the CIG and solidarity contract
column134:
which however are based on an assurance mechanism as they are financed companies. According to the company this support has proved vital for the survival of the company.

\r\n

However
column135: additional economic support to finance the restructuring in terms of costs for the training
column136:
and also costs toward the external consultants have been borne by the company.

The advice and support provided by Confindustria is free for all its members.

Outcomes of restructuring

The restructuring had a positive outcome as it enabled the company to face the decline in orders
column137:
turnover and profits due to the economic crisis.

\r\n

The Cassa
column138: in particular
column139: has proved to be indispensable in order to implement the necessary organisational adjustments
column140: while safeguarding employment levels. The company had not established a detailed restructuring plan which analysed the different steps and respective outcomes of the different phases of the restructuring process
column141: but it rather outlined the first phase of the restructuring
column142: while further steps were left for reassessment and renegotiation with social partners
column143: after the period of CIGO (July 2012). By then as staff was still not proportionate to the amount of work and turnover
column144: the company had to resort to the solidarity contract for 51 employees. This allowed an adjustment in terms of output and costs without jeopardising production
column145:
quality and employment levels. Those employees not affected by the solidarity contract have resumed working standard hours.

\r\n

The restructuring therefore achieved the intended outcomes
column146: as the company has been able to maintain the high quality standard of its products
column147:
while impacting as little as possible on employment.

\r\n

Nonetheless
column148: outsourcing the molding activity resulted in a loss of specific internal competences; regardless of this loss at products level
column149: competences
column150:
know-how and skills as well as quality have been guaranteed.

\r\n

The restructuring also impacted on the owners
column151: and not only in monetary terms
column152: but most for its emotional toll: indeed
column153: never in the history of the company had the owners had to implement any cost-cutting measure. However
column154: the owners firmly believe and stand behind the reasons for restructuring
column155: as after assessing all viable options
column156: they agreed that the specific restructuring implemented was the only feasible process which would have guaranteed the survival of the company. Notably
column157: by implementing short-time working for most of the employees in the offices and the main production site
column158: as well as deciding to stop production and outsource the activity performed in the second smaller production site
column159:
the company safeguarded the survival of the company and the job of at least 67 employees. This choice has been excruciating but essential.

\r\n

The company was not negatively affected by the restructuring event in terms of their network of customers and suppliers. Indeed
column160: given the economic contingencies
column161: restructuring has affected a massive number of firms
column162:
and for this reason the negative outcomes on the network of relations in this particular time has not been as negative as it could have been in more positive economic times.

\r\n

There have also been effects on staff
column163: as due to uncertainty some members of staff have decided to voluntarily leave the company. However
column164: the company believes there are positive outcomes ahead
column165: and it does not foresee any impediments
column166:
limits or constraint to the professional and occupational development of its staff.

\r\n

In the meantime
column167: the company is actively engaged in developing a strategy to expand its core business to other areas. For this reason the company also foresees an expansion in 2013
column168:
which will also require new employment opportunities.

\r\n

The restructuring process has not been formally evaluated
column169: neither internally or externally. However
column170: the company strongly argues that
column171: notwithstanding the associated difficulties
column172:
the restructuring process has been positive.

Commentary

The restructuring event was deemed positive by the company
column173: which has declared it would implement the exact same restructuring process if it could go back in time
column174: but it would implement it quicker. Indeed
column175:
the support of the CIG was deemed essential to implement the restructuring and to provide for the company survival.

\r\n

The company also declared that the support of Confindustria and the positive and fruitful social dialogue which resulted in the restructuring agreement
column176: have positively contributed to the successful outcome of the restructuring. The fair process of social dialogue has also encouraged a calm and polite environment within the company and in the relations with the management. Indeed while at the beginning affected employees were understandably worried about their uncertain prospects
column177:
with time they have understood and supported the reasons for restructuring

\r\n

The company identified access to credit and financing as the main challenge to restructuring and investment/innovation. Indeed
column178: no investment or restructuring can be implemented without funding

column181: funding and financing opportunities than their larger counterparts. This is even more dramatic during times of crisis
column182:
when funding opportunities are extremely limited.

\r\n

Also bureaucracy (both in terms of legislation and in terms of length of social dialogue) imposes a burden on companies needing to implement process of restructuring. In particular
column183:
the delay in INPS’ reimbursement of the income support imposes a damaging economic burden to companies already negatively affected by difficult economic conditions. .

The company argues that the main difference in SMEs’ restructuring

column1:
Golden Harvest, Malta~"Golden Harvest Company Ltd."~"

Maltese producer of baked goods Golden Harvest in 2008 relocated its operations out of a residential area to a new site in an industrial zone. The new bakery was larger
column2: and it better met the company’s needs for greater efficiency. To ensure a smooth transition of operations without disturbing productivity
column3: a migration plan was implemented and carried out over a 60-day period. Following the transition
column4: the company embarked on a restructuring of its internal management. Since the move
column5:
the company has seen a gradual increase in turnover and a rise in the number of full-time employees.

"~"

Organisational profile

The name Golden Harvest is synonymous in Malta with the manufacture of freshly baked bread
column6: pastry goods and cakes
column7: and ice-cream. The company traces its origin back to a modest traditional bakery set up in the small village of Floriana back in 1946. It did not take long for the reputation of this small bakery to spread beyond the confines of the small local community; and in a short time
column8: consumers were able to purchase its goods
column9: in particular its unconventional fancy bread
column10:
from various village shops across Malta.

\r\n

By 1949
column11: the company employed 20 workers and introduced new baked goods to its production lines. As its customer base continued to grow
column12: the next logical step was to shift its operations to a larger facility which would accommodate the needs of a growing business.  The new factory began to operate from the town of Gżira
column13:
now under the name of ‘Golden Harvest’.

\r\n

Between 1952 and 1958
column14: the company invested in more machinery and introduced the first spiral mixers to the local market. New silos and moving tunnel ovens which led to an automated line were introduced in 1964. This allowed for the introduction of new baked goods to its production line
column15: such as the popular French Slice and Slimex
column16:
appealing to the more weight-conscious consumer.

\r\n

The company continues to use the latest technology to offer Maltese consumers a wide variety of baked products. Golden Harvest also continues to ensure that time-honoured Maltese bakery and confectionary items remain on their production schedules using traditional recipes. The company also provides finished goods and pre-mixes to order and have been entrusted by companies and large fast-food outlets
column17: restaurants and hotels to produce their products under licence. Together with its traditional confectionary items
column18:
the company also sells frozen foods and seasonal items.

\r\n

A fundamental rule by which the company continues to abide is that whatever the situation
column19: there should be no compromise on quality standards. Golden Harvest strives to maintain high quality standards in its operations to consistently deliver the best products to its customers. This is achieved through its highly trained quality assurance staff
column20: who effectively monitor that all BRC (British Retailers Consortium) procedures are followed through each stage of production. This procedure incorporates a systematic
column21: preventative approach to food safety that addresses physical
column22:
chemical and biological hazards.

\r\n

Six decades down the line
column23: Golden Harvest has remained a family-run business which has reached its third generation all of whom are key members of the company’s management
column24:
as well as Board of Directors.

\r\n

Mark Aquilina was appointed Chief Executive Officer at Golden Harvest Ltd. in June 2011. As a member of the family and a firm believer in the continued success of the company
column25: Mr Aquilina was involved in the operations of the business at a relatively young age. Indeed
column26: He has been involved in the business for over 22 years and prior to his appointment as CEO of the company
column27: already served as a member of the Board of Directors. Throughout the years
column28:
Mr Aquilina has gathered a wealth of experience in the management and operations of the company which allows him to administer the day-to-day running of the business and set out projections for future growth.

\r\n

Renewed investment continues to be injected into the company
column29: producing on average 70
column30: 000 products each day. The company owns a fleet of 23 vehicles and delivers to 14 direct distribution branches and over 1
column31: 000 retail outlets daily across the Maltese islands. Its branch stores are independently run by store managers who oversee every aspect of the business. Notwithstanding
column32:
any restructuring which would impact the company’s business activities would need to be conferred with the Board of Directors for approval.

\r\n

As of spring 2012
column33: the company employs 143 full-time employees. The skills employed by the company include amongst others; accountants
column34:
delivery men and electronic operators.

\r\n

Almost 100% of the company’s production is produced for the local market
column35:
with only a fraction of its production line intended for export.

\r\n

Management strives to promote and maintain good industrial relations with its employees. In so doing
column36:
it promotes active measures such as staff training and development which helps stimulate further development and motivation on the job and consequently increase the average skill level of the company.

Background to restructuring event

In 2008
column37: Golden Harvest Ltd. moved into a new bakery in the industrial zone of San Ġwann. The inauguration of the new premises marked the successful completion of the company’s long-term plan to relocate out of its former plant in Gżira – which due to developments in building construction in the area throughout the years found itself located at the centre of what eventually became a residential area. The relocation also served to accommodate a larger
column38: more functional factory layout which would support the growing demands of the factory facilitating greater efficiency. The management also sought to ensure that the changes implemented in the new factory set-up
column39: such as equipment design and procedures
column40:
complied with HACCP (Hazard Analysis and Critical Control Point) certified standards.

\r\n

Following the establishment of a fully-fledged bakery plant
column41: the company also embarked on a restructuring of its internal management structure. The change embraced the appointment of Mark Aquilina as Chief Executive Officer and the assigning of other members of the family to key management posts.  The changes introduced to the management structure came about as part of a family succession planning exercise
column42: executed and agreed upon by the Board of Directors
column43:
composed mainly of family members.

Restructuring processes

The idea to relocate the operations of the factory to a new site outside of Gżira dates back to 1999. The construction of a new building
column44: to be designed and tailored for the specific operational and physical capacity of the company
column45:
was considered to be the single most viable option.

\r\n

Once the decision was taken by the Board of Directors to push forward with this project
column46: the company started to carry out the necessary research which would form the basis of what would be a solid Business Plan for the company’s restructuring process. The plan also included a feasibility study
column47: an architectural plan
column48:
engineers’ report and a design and layout for the new production line.

\r\n

The site which was to host the new factory was acquired through Malta Industrial Parks
column49: the corporation responsible for the administration and maintenance of industrial estates in Malta. The new factory was to be located approximately 5km away from the old factory site. By January 2007
column50: work on the new premises started to progress at a steady pace
column51: and in December 2008 the company inaugurated the opening of its fully-fledged plant in San Ġwann. The factory was built on the site of what was an old factory. The old building was subsequently demolished and became the site of the new Golden Harvest factory. The site was acquired through Malta Industrial Parks
column52:
an organisation created to manage industrial estates in Malta.

\r\n

The new plant represented an investment of over €20 million supported through equity and bank financing. Management claims that given the good standing which the company enjoys with its bank
column53:
no major difficulties were encountered during negotiations on the financing of the project.

\r\n

Employees and suppliers were informed in advance of the relocation to the new plant. In order to ensure a smooth transition of the plants’ operations without disturbing productivity
column54: a migration plan was implemented and carried out over a 60-day period. The new factory started to operate trial runs
column55: which required mainly production line workers to work extra shifts over the 60 day period
column56: until all employees completed the necessary training to be able to operate the new machinery. Specialised training on the new machinery was provided on-site by the supplier. Operation from the new plant continued to work in parallel with on-going work from the old plant until the full migration of its operations was complete. This was done in order not to disrupt productivity and supply for the local market.  Only small pieces of equipment were transferred to the new plant
column57:
with most machinery from the old plant sold to a foreign buyer. The old plant remains the property of Golden Harvest Ltd.; however it is currently not in operation.

\r\n

A different approach was adopted with some of the administrative staff of the company
column58: who was asked to translocate to the new premises at short notice
column59: claiming that not enough time was allowed for them to see to the shifting of most of their archives. Other than the mentioned hitch in relation to the short notification period applied to some members of staff
column60:
the overall experience of the restructuring process was viewed to be a positive one.

Challenges and constraints of restructuring

The inauguration of a new and more sophisticated factory marked another milestone achievement for Golden Harvest Ltd.

Like any other large-scale project
column61: the process had its fair share of challenges. The project involved a list of deliverables which needed to be met by the project team
column62: such as the gradual migration of employees to the new premises whilst at the same time providing them with the necessary training required in order to be able to operate the new machinery. In order to meet the projections set out in the Business Plan
column63:
the management engaged the services of an external management consultant to sit with the Board of Directors; a legal officer; financial and business consultants and a civil engineer.

Restructuring advice and support

The company attributes the success of the project to good planning
column64: which ultimately makes the implementation process easier. The ability to guarantee quantifiable results for a project in advance is a way of staving off any undesirable impact on the company’s operations
column65:
finance and employees.

\r\n

By engaging a team of experts which would assist in the planning and implementation of the project
column66: and developing a sound Business Plan for its undertaking
column67:
Golden Harvest Ltd. managed to avoid certain constraints which could have been detrimental to the successful outcome of the project. Management did not consider cost to be a real factor when evaluating the engagement of experts for this project.

\r\n

Golden Harvest Ltd. has also benefited from Government incentives such as interest rate subsidies which offer support to new investment projects undertaken by enterprises engaged in manufacturing. Other favourable incentives include Government subsidies on investment projects supporting renewable energy
column68:
which was an integral concept of the designs of the new factory premises.

Outcomes of restructuring

Golden Harvest has continued to register a growth in turnover
column69:
which is conducive to the continued investment injected into the company.

\r\n

Following the restructuring project
column70: Golden Harvest also experienced a gradual increase in the number of full-time employees. At the beginning of the restructuring process the number of full-time employees stood at 106. By spring 2012 the company expanded its operations
column71: and employs a workforce of 143 full-time employees. As part of the new operational arrangements which came about from relocation to the new premises
column72: the company also introduced changes to its human resource set up in order to enhance the value added of the company. These changes were mainly applied to key personnel performing production and administrative functions
column73: including sales
column74:
marketing and finance. Such changes would ensure that key functions and responsibilities were allocated to the right individuals according to their competence.

\r\n

The introduction of new cutting-edge technology for its machinery resulted in an increase in operational efficiency and an initial cut in employees’ overtime. However
column75: over the period 2010 and 2011
column76:
Golden Harvest continued to witness an expansion in its production line which came about as a response to accelerating growth in product demand. This led to the re-introduction of overtime shifts for its employees.

\r\n

The new bakery
column77: which is spread over 14
column78: 500 square metres of space
column79: is powered by 16
column80: 000 KVA transformers and houses a large cold room that can store up to 1
column81:
100 pallets and nine loading bays. The new space also incorporates two new production lines for loaf production and a bun line that provide 100% of additional capacity over the old plant. The building has also been designed to accommodate any future expansion of the company.

\r\n

Another outcome of the restructuring process is the improvement in cost structure. For Golden Harvest Ltd
column82:
the concept ‘going green’ translates into energy efficient technology which ensures environmental quality. This concept was a key element in the design of its sustainable high-end factory. The new structure was designed and built in close collaboration with an internationally renowned foreign bakery management consultancy firm which supervised the works from beginning to end.

\r\n

Design for environment is a concept which was integrated into the company’s business plans for the new factory. The bakery incorporates a photovoltaic system
column83: together with a solar water-heating system which supplies hot water throughout the building
column84: a modern waste separation system and a large water reservoir that has a capacity to store 96
column85: 000 gallons of rain water for every four inches of rainfall. The water is then purified through a reverse osmosis system and used for second class water. Moreover
column86: all oven burners use LPG gas
column87:
thereby reducing emissions and contributing towards a greener environment.

\r\n

Today
column88: the measures implemented by the company translate into a 20% drop in the factory’s energy uptake. A surge in the country’s utility rates has neutralised
column89: rather than cut down on the factory’s cost savings on energy. Notwithstanding
column90: had the company opted not to invest in green technology
column91:
the company would today have experienced a 20% increase in utility costs.

\r\n

Future plans for the company include increasing its production for export. The company is also investing in research and development
column92: seeking to extend the shelf life of its products and introduce a healthier product range on the market
column93: such as baked goods which have low gluten content. The company has also recently launched a Low Gi Multiseed Loaf containing a major source of fibre and is therefore ideal for healthy eaters
column94: dieters
column95:
vegetarians and type 2 diabetics who follow a low Gi diet. This product was developed by Bakels (UK) and is produced under license by Golden Harvest.

Commentary

The management at Golden Harvest Ltd. believe that the root of their success in the restructuring process lies in the time and energy invested in developing a well-structured plan – together with ambition
column96:
which is the driving force behind its achievements.

\r\n

Two significant decisions taken by the company include: the drafting and implementation of a Business Plan which clearly sets out the marketing
column97:
operational and financial plan in relation to the project. The plan also includes clearly defined targets and deliverables set out to be achieved by the company.

\r\n

By investing in a team of experts with distinct professional backgrounds
column98: Golden Harvest Ltd. increased its chances of project success
column99:
avoiding any pitfalls which could have resulted in a less desirable outcome.

\r\n

On a general note
column100: respondents remarked positively on the assistance available for helping SMEs and micro enterprises in Malta to invest in their economic growth. A shared perception was that larger companies tend to garner more interest and backing from Government due to their higher productivity and export share
column101:
and their sustenance of a larger workforce.

\r\n

Nevertheless
column102: it is felt that the importance given to larger companies does not significantly outweigh the collective strength and contribution of SMEs to the sustainability of the local economy. A shared perception which emerged during the interviews is the awareness of Government incentives which aim to assist and promote the growth and sustainability of SMEs on the islands. In particular
column103: respondents mentioned assistance offered to small businesses through Malta Enterprise
column104: such as the interest rate subsidy scheme. Other incentives include the promotion of investment in renewable energy
column105:
such as subsidies on the installation of solar water heaters and photovoltaic panels.

\r\n

Another observation made during the interviews was the need for more on-going dialogue and guidance relating to the assistance available to local SMEs
column106: in particular
column107:
access to finance.

column7: Company C

The group has a brief corporate charter

Before the split

The General Manager interviewed for the purpose of the present case study holds an IT diploma from a German technical university as well as a master’s degree in European business from a leading French business college. He has two years of international experience as a software engineer at IBM in the US. He joined Company A in 2006

on its creation. He and the two other partners at Company A have known and worked with each other for many years in the past. Background to restructuring event

The General Manager identifies several triggers to the restructuring event:

• willingness to separate two activities of different natures;

• the arrival of two new shareholders/partners

including the interviewed General Manager;

• some market opportunities in Luxembourg that were spotted by the management of Company A at the time

which was relatively easy to do due to the small size of the country.

Restructuring processes

This was decided and implemented by the three owners of the firm

The restructuring event was based on the company’s own funds. The company obtained a credit line from a bank but never activated it.

After the decision had been taken

Communication with the workforce was intense

At the time

Challenges and constraints of restructuring

The General Manager does not identify challenges the group specifically encountered during the restructuring process
column67: which
column68: according to him

Restructuring advice and support

The General Manager reports having used the services of one external expert

column73:
to assess the value of the company. One of the partners has a law degree and this person provided most of the legal input for the process.

Outcomes of restructuring

Overall
column74:
the outcome of the restructuring event is positive and group turnover steadily increased following the split.

As far as the other two owners are concerned

column79: with the restructuring event

for the first time they had to do a formal division of work. ime was needed for adjusting to this and for consolidating trust among the new directors.

The General Manager took over management functions that are very different from those he had in his previous job

As far as employees are concerned

The General Manager says that this is

related to the increasing revenues arising from the expanded activities of the companies rather than to the restructuring event itself.

Finally

\r\n

Today
column89: none of the eight employees initially employed by Company B remains within the group of companies. The General Manger explains that this high departure rate is essentially due to the fact that the companies used to be (and to some extent still are) small companies
column90:
employing young staff and that as these people mature professionally they tend to leave for new professional challenges.

Commentary

One advantage SMEs have over large firms in implementing change
column91: according to the General Manager
column92: is their agility. Large corporations implement change more slowly due to heavy reporting lines and complex decision-making procedures
column93: whereas things are more informal within SMEs
column94:
which he says is ‘priceless’.

\r\n

He notes that communication is currently more formal with respect to the new restructuring event
column95:
due to the fact that there are many more employees in the group than in the past.

\r\n

In relation to the new restructuring event
column96: the General Manager sees it positive that the group benefitted from subsidies granted by the Luxembourg government for R&D. Without these subsidies
column97: it would not have been possible for Company A to dedicate some staff to working full time on the development of the new product
column98:
including hiring new employees for that purpose. The subsidies also allowed them to develop the new product in a more structured way. An additional positive he sees is the active policy of the Luxembourg government to support intellectual property-related activities by exempting from taxes some of these activities. Company A is directly benefitting from this policy and the General Manager sees it as a positive for SMEs and innovation in general. In his view SMEs are the heart of innovation (they innovate while large groups buy innovative small companies).

\r\n

Finally
column99: the General Manager notes that most of the information in the present report is related to the continuous growth undergone by the group. The restructuring event described above is a means
column100: among others
column101:
that was used for facilitating and implementing this continuous growth.

Author

Cécile Musialski
column102:
Philippe & Partners.

Information sources

Interviews

General Manager and partner in Company A

Note:

The present case study is not based on any employee interview as no employee who worked in the group prior to the restructuring event remains within the group today.
