Meble Bugajski, Poland~"Meble Bugajski"~"

This Polish furniture producer has managed to succeed in the market by adapting flexibly to changing customer markets and tastes. By introducing new production methods and insourcing more and by strengthening domestic sales
column2: variations in international sales were more easily absorbed. However
column3:
30 employees lost their jobs.

"~"

Organisational profile

The Meble Bugajski company was established by Slawomir Bugajski in November 1991 in Wieloglowy near Nowy Sacz
column4: in the Malopolska Region. At the beginning of its operations
column5: the company’s owner and its only employee was involved in multi-sectoral trade
column6: including an international dimension. As a former sportsman
column7: a cyclist
column8: he had many contacts
column9: both in Poland and abroad
column10: which he used in his business. From the start of operations
column11:
the legal status of the company has remained unchanged and it continues to operate as a sole proprietorship.

\r\n

The owner holds secondary level education (vocational secondary school with matura
column12: the equivalent of the GCSE). He did not receive any technical or economics education nor did he have any previous work experience; however
column13:
he has taken part in professional development training courses.

\r\n

In February 1994
column14: Slawomir Bugajski decided to change the profile of his company from trade into trade and production. He had neither the experience nor the know-how concerning the furniture market and production but had noticed a significant demand for these types of products. Thus he became involved in the production of furniture. Initially he made furniture by himself in a basement of his parents’ house
column15: his only fixed assets being a truck and basic tools to make furniture. At the time
column16: he still did not employ any members of staff
column17: and he only used services of an accountant
column18: who was his friend and helped him to manage accounts. He dealt with supplies
column19: production
column20: distribution and sale of his products by himself
column21:
and delivered within a range of 200 km from the seat of his company. Direct contacts with buyers allowed him to match the production offer to the needs of his customers.

\r\n

All the furniture products are made from high-quality components
column22: which guarantee a professional look and high-quality usability for many years. Moreover
column23: well-qualified staff
column24: knowledge and long-term experience allows for constant development of products
column25: to fit the needs of customers perfectly.The Meble Bugajski company produces all types of upholstered furniture
column26: in the belief that it is able to offer customers a diverse range of comfortable suites
column27: including armchairs
column28: two to three person sofas
column29: and corners. It offer wide selection of fabrics
column30: leathers or alcantaras
column31: in a wide range of colours
column32: imported or ordered from best Polish companies. In addition
column33: it offers a wide range of additional options to choose from
column34:
which allows for customised furniture.

\r\n

At present (2012)
column35: the company employs 90 employees and this represents a decline in relation to 2006
column36: when it employed almost 120 employees. The number of staff in the individual years has ranged as follows: 2006: 120 employees; 2007: 98; 2008: 91; 2009: 94; 2010: 95; 2011: 93; and 2012: 90. Out of the current employees
column37: 65% are male while 35% are female. The age structure is as follows: 5% of females aged between 22 and 30 years
column38: the rest above 30 years; 10% of males aged between 22 and 30 years
column39: the rest above 30 years. The education structure is as follows: 5% higher
column40: 20% secondary
column41:
75% vocational.

\r\n

There are no trade union representatives in the company. There are no representatives of such bodies as council of employees or other formal structures of staff representatives. The owner does not have any formalised business development plans.

\r\n

The structure of gross sale has ranged as follows: 2006 – € 2
column53:
000.

Background to restructuring event

This company continues to operate in the same single location
column54: and no branches have been established. Since 1994
column55: the general profile of the company operations has not changed; however
column56: the buyers’ markets are different. In 1995
column57: the owner noticed increased demand for furniture
column58: both on the domestic market and the emerging Eastern buyers’ market. By 1997
column59: practically 85% of the products were exported to the former Soviet Union states (Russia
column60: Belarus
column61: Kazakhstan
column62: Ukraine and Lithuania). However since January 1998
column63: due to the crisis in Russia
column64: the Eastern market simply disappeared for Polish furniture manufacturers. They could not sell any furniture suites
column65: stopped receiving orders from sales agents and wholesalers. The company faced a risk of losing financial liquidity. During the first six months of 1998
column66: it had financial problems resulting from the lack of demand
column67: both abroad and in Poland. Problems with selling the already made products on the local market were due to the colours of the furniture made for the Eastern customers. Fortunately its quality and prices were acceptable on the local market
column68: which allowed to sell the finished stock without incurring major financial losses. That helped to avoid staff dismissals
column69:
although there was a surplus of labour force and production had to be suspended temporarily.

\r\n

As a result
column70: the entrepreneur decided to search for new buyers abroad. That involved foreign business trips to attend furniture trade fairs in Zagreb
column71: Ljubljana and Stockholm in order to learn about preferences and tastes of foreign customers. The company did not exhibit its products on these fairs
column72: its owner only spoke with the exhibitors about issues such as colours
column73: models
column74: quality and prices at which he could sell his products abroad. He tried to initiate commercial cooperation with the exhibiting local companies. In order to search for contacts
column75: he also used his acquaintances dating back to the times when he was a cyclist. His foreign colleagues from bicycle races facilitated his contacts with entrepreneurs they knew
column76:
and this type of personal recommendation was exceptionally useful for the small Polish business that did not have reputation and credibility among foreign businesses.

\r\n

Searching for new markets and adapting the product offer to their needs took over six months. During that time
column77: Mr Bugajski also started to cooperate with foreign buyers
column78: including a Swedish national
column79: owner of a business manufacturing and selling furniture on the local Swedish market. On his way back from a fair in Milan
column80: he passed Wieloglowy and became interested in Mr Bugajski’s company. Following a discussion
column81: the two entrepreneurs decided to start to cooperate in the field of furniture making by the company in Wieloglowy for the Swedish Partner. Sweden was not the only market with which the Polish entrepreneur started to cooperate. Initially he managed to initiate commercial contacts with enterprises from the Balkans (Slovenia
column82: Croatia
column83: Bosnia and Monte Negro)
column84: and then also from Slovakia and the Czech Republic. By 2004
column85: the company’s structure of sales was shaping in the following way: 90% of the production constituted export (Sweden
column86: Slovenia
column87: Croatia
column88: Bosnia
column89: Monte Negro
column90: Slovakia and the Czech Republic) which generated 80% of the revenues
column91: while the remaining 10% was sold on the local market
column92:
which generated 20% of the revenues. The difference in the revenue proportions in relation to the volume of production sold in Poland and abroad resulted from the differences and fluctuations of the currency exchange rates impacting foreign transactions.

\r\n

Since 2005
column93: the company changed its structure in terms of the target markets. Export activities were reduced to increase sale on the domestic and local market. In 2006
column94: at the beginning of the restructuring process
column95: almost 45% of the production was exported to the Scandinavian market
column96: Germany
column97: Switzerland and Croatia. The remaining 20% was sold on the local market and 35% on the national one. During that time
column98: sale of furniture was growing slowly
column99:
while the profit margin remained stable. Currently 60% is represented by export and 40% by the domestic sale.

\r\n

The decision to restructure addressed the need to reduce the costs of production and improve the quality of the goods in accordance with long-term plans targeting production of more exclusive products. It also resulted from an unexpected loss of a key importer – a client from Switzerland
column100:
which took place in 2006.

Restructuring processes

The first restructuring measures were implemented in 2006 and continued until 2008. The key actions involved employment restructuring (review
column101: appraisal of skills and staff dismissals) and extending production to manufacture furniture of a higher quality and basing it partly on insourcing of making furniture components (benches
column102:
woodworking joints) which before had been made by subcontractors.

\r\n

The production process was also changed by replacing the two-shift system with one-shift; also
column103: organisation of deliveries to the recipients was changed (reorganisation of storage of the finished furniture in a warehouse and the delivery system (just in time) to eliminate the costly process of storage and keeping finished furniture in the warehouse. The company made furniture following receipt of an order
column104: and then
column105: almost immediately
column106: it was loaded to trucks that delivered it to its recipients. As a result of introducing such a system
column107: the company’s own transport and delivery system was established
column108:
which enabled to maintain flexibility and independence of external carriers.

\r\n

The company developed and started to promote its own brand name
column109: ‘MB Design’
column110: trying to introduce it to the existing sales network in order to emphasise the more exclusive nature of its products. That decision resulted from a risk of perceiving the company as a ‘no name’ manufacturer
column111:
which would imply dependence on the current sale channels and network of stores. The new brand name was promoted in Poland and the Czech Republic in particular.

\r\n

The decision on the need for restructuring was made by the owner who also based it on opinions of the following six managerial staff members: director of production
column112: manager of production and foremen. Those decisions however were not formally recorded
column113: there was no schedule for them (although some general assumptions concerning time of their implementation were adopted
column114: which were then modified under the process of introducing changes). Employees and their representatives (none) were not included in the process of restructuring planning and implementation. Other restructuring-based measures were not taken into account either. Any changes and financial investments were delivered exclusively with funds provided by the owner
column115: and in case of purchase of vehicles for the transport and delivery department
column116:
leasing was applied.

Challenges and constraints of restructuring

The company’s employees were informed about the measures implemented by their immediate superiors at the beginning of the restructuring process. Further information was disseminated on an on-going basis. The response of employees was generally negative and distrustful as the process involved dismissing 30 employees.

There were difficulties in overcoming stereotypes related to work and production organisation as well as schedules and routine in the company
column117:
and overcoming the mental resistance of the staff.

Restructuring advice and support

The owner is of the opinion that professional assistance at the stage of preparing and planning restructuring of the company would have provided significant support for the planning and implementation process; however
column118: he did not receive any assistance. He did not have information on the means of obtaining such support from government institutions. Due to financial reasons
column119:
the company could not afford to obtain any support from commercial entities because they are too expensive.

Outcome of the restructuring

Restructuring followed in accordance with the assumptions adopted
column120: and its outcomes met the expectations planned. The company improved its situation and has maintained its status quo in its sector. It introduced its new own product
column121:
the ‘MB Design’ brand name in the form of leather-made furniture.

\r\n

In the course of the restructuring process
column122: around 30 employees with the lowest qualifications and competences were dismissed. These were blue-collar workers employed at the furniture production department
column123: who had basic vocational education and carried out the simplest physical activities involving packing and moving finished furniture to its storing space in the warehouse
column124:
and loading it into trucks. They were selected for dismissal by their immediate superiors and the dismissals had to be approved by the company owner himself. The staff reduction process was implemented successively and in stages in order to avoid the so called collective redundancies. Changing the two-shift system into a one-shift system and limiting overtime arising from the need to cut costs were accomplished by vacating a rented building in which one of the production process stages had been carried out.

\r\n

After a ten-month period
column125:
the best 25 employees of the company received a pay rise.

\r\n

The individual department managers changed work organisation by redefining and elaborating the scope of competence and responsibilities of employees of the departments of production
column126: transport and deliveries. A one-shift system was introduced in the production department
column127: which reduced the production volume
column128: while the company’s turnover remained at the same level as the company started to make MB Design furniture
column129: which extended the company’s product line. At that time
column130: 20% decline in the furniture sale was recorded while an 80% increase was recorded for MB Design. The structure of sale was as follows: 60% export
column131:
40% domestic market.

\r\n

The company decided to support the employees continuing their work for the company and delegated to other departments through internal training and practical courses providing skills to work at new posts. Staff requalification efforts were also supported.

\r\n

The response of the employees to the changes introduced was rather sceptical
column132: suspicious and distrustful in general
column133: on account of the staff dismissals. However
column134:
the company survived in the market and extended the scope of its operations by 30%. The fact that the staff working prior to the restructuring could stay and their salaries were raised is also of importance.

\r\n

In his current plans
column135: the owner envisages business development through construction of a new production facility
column136: increased production capacity
column137: further consistent promotion of the company’s own brand name
column138: MB Design
column139: establishing its own sale channels and networks in Poland
column140:
and entry to new store networks in the EU. Plans concerning the employees include vocational training and assistance to upgrade their qualifications.

Commentary

According to the owner
column141: restructuring processes in large and small enterprises differ. Large enterprises have the funds to use professional support in the course of restructuring. They also generate a stronger impact on government institutions to obtain their support. On the other hand
column142: medium-sized enterprises are more creative and faster in restructuring implementation. They demonstrate better flexibility during the process. SMEs hold significantly smaller human resources necessary for planning restructuring. They also lack funding necessary in the course of implementation of restructuring changes. The lack of trade unions is favourable
column143: as they delay the dynamics of restructuring. They lack formalised procedures
column144:
which make changes more difficult.

\r\n

The experience acquired by the owner during the restructuring process helped him to use a different approach to these measures now. Firstly
column145: he is of the opinion that he would take more care in the process of staff dismissals. He would treat the opinions of immediate superiors with lower priority
column146:
as they often follow their personal feelings (likes and dislikes).

\r\n

As regards public support
column147: the owner thinks that it should be more flexible in terms of changing fixed costs to help businesses with their tax obligations
column148:
for example by using temporary tax suspension or postponement for companies undergoing difficult process of restructuring.

\r\n

He is also of the opinion that he should spend more time in preparing and planning the restructuring. It is worth trying to consult other entrepreneurs and verify outcomes
column149:
results and introduce corrections on the on-going basis in the course of the implementation stage.

\r\n

The opinions of the owner were matched by those of the company production manager (47 years of age
column150: 15 years of service
column151: in large furniture-making facilities in particular). He was personally engaged in the company’s process of restructuring planning and implementation. In terms of his position
column152:
he was a superior of the staff covered by the restructuring measures (dismissals). He also proposed and justified dismissals of selected employees.

\r\n

He is of the opinion that the changes facilitated management of the other staff and introduced order in the scope of competence and responsibilities of the specific job positions. They also generated significant financial savings for the company
column153:
as the new work organisation increased efficiency.

\r\n

Employees of the company were informed of the restructuring planned; however
column154:
they were not involved in the decision on its implementation. Assistance offered to the employees by the company was limited to training to requalify the staff staying in the company.

\r\n

Employees’ reactions to restructuring were distrustful and negative. They expressed their anxiety and upset
column155: and did not get involved. To the employees staying at the company restructuring meant stability and keeping work
column156: as well as maintaining their current salary level
column157:
and perspective of pay rise.

\r\n

He does not think that the changes could be planned and implemented better. He said that
column158: according to the persons involved in the restructuring process
column159: the changes were optimum
column160: as they generated the outcomes planned. When comparing restructuring in SMEs and large enterprises
column161: he said that small enterprises lack experience and knowledge about restructuring. They also do not have funds. However
column162:
they can implement changes more dynamically and respond to changes in the environment faster due to their flexibility and the lack of bureaucracy.

Mermaid, Denmark~"Mermaid A/S"~"

A digital signage company in Denmark has expanded significantly over the last years by continously adding other companies with complementary products and markets across Scandinavia. After several waves of expansion
column2:
the next steps are about consolidation and rethinking the group structure.

"~"

Organisational profile

\r\n

Mermaid A/S is a total solution provider in digital signage with expertise in the development
column3: production
column4: and design of monitors and software. When the company started its activities in 2004
column5: it was mainly a hardware company selling monitors and screens for digital signage
column6:
but through acquisitions and product development the company can now offer complete solutions in the following areas:

• Monitors;

• Software platforms;

• Services (recurring business);

• Service-level agreements;

• Software upgrades;

• Administration contracts (customers outsourcing management of the platform);

• Content production.

Mermaid’s customers are companies with a need for dynamic signage: retailers
column7:
public transport and the public sector in general are the main customer segments.

\r\n

The development and acquisition of new products and services is part of a strategy where recurring business on the installed bases should generate an increasing share of revenue instead of through highly fluctuating hardware sales. Mermaid A/S expects to reach a milestone in 2012 where profit from recurring revenue will cover the fixed costs.

\r\n

Mermaid A/S was born out of a restructuring in 2004
column8: when the fast growing PC manufacturer Mermaid Technology A/S
column9: originally founded in 1997
column10:
more or less collapsed after changes in tax laws and competitive environment. The company closed and assets transferred to the new company Mermaid A/S.

\r\n

The re-born Mermaid sets out to be the leader in consolidation of the DDS market (Dynamic Digital Signage) in northern Europe – or even all of Europe - and Mermaid A/S now owns the companies mentioned in Table 1.

\r\n

Mermaid A/S is based in Glostrup
column11: Copenhagen
column12: and now has subsidiaries in Aarhus
column13: Denmark and in Stockholm
column14: Sweden and Oslo
column15:
Norway.

column23: the former owners of Norden Media Solutions – now Mermaid Technology AB – (17 %) and COO at Mermaid

Mads Henrik Hansen (2.42 %.). The remaining 35% of the shares are held by minor shareholders.

\r\n

Daily operations are managed by CEO Henrik Johnsen and COO Mads Henrik Hansen. The COO was originally the founder of the first acquisition Victor Soft. CEO Henrik Johnsen has an education in IT (EDB assistant
column25:
Datanom) from 1983 and a management career in different companies in the IT and electronics industry until he co-founded Mermaid Technology in 1997. COO Mads Henrik Hansen also has an education in IT (Datamatiker) and a Master in Management of Technology. He gained his former management experience from founding Victor Soft A/S at the age of 22.

\r\n

At the end of 2011
column26: the Mermaid group had about 60 employees – the large majority in Aarhus and Glostrup (Copenhagen)
column27:
Denmark – and an outsourced team of 12 freelance software developers in Pakistan. Employees are mainly men between 25 and 45 years old and mainly technical staff including 12–15 hardware or software engineers. Administrative staff includes sales people and a few business graduates. Staff are generally organised in trade unions.

\r\n

The company is international in the sense that it has operations in three countries and is looking for potential acquisitions in other European countries like Finland and Germany. Export sales outside Denmark
column28:
Norway and Sweden are about 15%.

\r\n

Mermaid A/S has had a fluctuating turnover due to the original hardware based business model (Table 2). However
column29:
the increased focus on recurring business is expected to stabilise turnover and especially improve earnings. An almost constant increase in gross margin ratio suggests that they have succeeded.

\r\n

Mermaid A/S’ activities are funded by 70% equity capital and 30% short term debt
column33:
and with external equity funding from First North they publish elaborate information for investors on their website at http://mermaid.dk/investors.

\r\n

Background to restructuring events

\r\n

The restructuring event described in this case study is a series of acquisitions made by Mermaid A/S from 2007 to 2011 with the first acquisition of Acrossmedia in 2007 described in most details. The reason for describing a series of acquisitions instead of just one event is that the whole acquisition process has been the key to building a complete product
column34:
service and technology platform that can make Mermaid A/S the European market leader. So it is actually a story about building a market leader in a new industry.

\r\n

To understand Mermaid today
column35: it is important to know a bit about the original Mermaid Technology that was founded in 1997 with the current CEO Henrik Johnsen as cofounder. Mermaid Technology made customised computers with logistics as the core of their business model
column36:
since the founders had a background in logistics.

\r\n

According to Henrik Johnsen
column37: the company became the fastest growing company in Denmark in 1998 and had grown to a turnover of DKK200–250 million (€27-34 mill.) and 150 employees in 1999. However
column38: a change in tax laws for home PCs for employees and the invasion of Dell computers on the market put a sudden stop to the success. After fighting hard for a few years out of moral obligation to the remaining employees and banks
column39:
the founders gave up Mermaid Technology and in 2004 Mr Johnsen founded Mermaid A/S with seven years of experience in managing rapid growth as well as rapid decline.

\r\n

The new Mermaid business was still mainly a hardware business manufacturing monitors for digital signage. After an early period with DVD players connected locally to the monitors
column40:
they soon realised that they needed software to manage the signage online. After searching abroad they found a local product in Denmark from Victor Soft and in 2005 they bought part of the company to acquire ownership of the software.

\r\n

After landing a large order from the retail chain Matas
column41: ambitions grew and at a European trade show in Paris in 2006 Mermaid realised that their products were miles ahead of competing offers. So they decided to go international and get equity capital from the First North marketplace in 2007. First North is an alternative market
column42: operated by the different exchanges within NASDAQ OMX. First North is an alternative to the regulated market
column43:
with less strict requirements and rules.

\r\n

In December 2007 they added another stone to the foundation when they acquired a major competitor
column44: Acrossmedia
column45:
who had content production as a core part of their business model. This made Mermaid the dominant player in digital signage in Denmark.

\r\n

Acquisitions were not just about growing in volume
column46: but also about adding products and competences to the palette. By adding software and content production they also created the foundation for a different business model
column47: where hardware sales were not the goal in itself
column48:
but rather a means to make recurring revenue on additional services.

Henrik Johnsen had obviously learned an important lesson about the vulnerability of a business model based on hardware sales in the first Mermaid Technology venture.

The acquisition of volume and additional products and competences continued in the other Scandinavian countries and can be illustrated by the timeline in Table 3:

According to company goals
column52:
the next acquisitions could very well be in 2012 in Finland or other countries in northern Europe.

\r\n

Restructuring processes

\r\n

The whole growth and acquisition process has not been planned as such
column53: but since hardware selling with relatively few large orders lead to a very fluctuating sales curve
column54: it was a part of the early strategy that the company wanted to add services to the installed base that could generate a more stable income stream. And to quote Henrik Johnsen
column55:
he is constantly thinking about ‘adding the next stone to the foundation’. Until now the new ‘stones’ have been picked for their ability to add new technologies and services to the total Mermaid solution package in combination with their ability to add new markets and customers to reach the goal of market domination in the Nordic countries – an ambition that was recently upgraded to market domination in Europe.

\r\n

Furthermore the introduction of stocks on the First North marketplace has obviously required an elaborate business plan and a clear strategy.

\r\n

Acquisitions are planned and decided in cooperation with the business partner and chairman of the board
column56:
Søren Svenningsen. The process typically starts with a decision to go into a certain market. Research is conducted about the market and companies in the market. Relevant companies are then contacted. The process before the actual acquisition is effectuated typically lasts half a year.

\r\n

It may sound like an aggressive strategy where Mermaid is chasing potential skills and customer bases to acquire
column57:
but during the interview Mr Johnsen seemed a bit surprised when he realised that three of the acquisitions actually contacted Mermaid first with the intention of selling.

\r\n

Even though the big master plan may not be very explicit
column58:
the company has gradually developed procedures for the acquisition process ranging from a checklist for potential acquisitions to the whole process of integrating different companies and cultures.

\r\n

People who are going to work together in the future will start working together in a project team that takes care of the integration process; to Henrik Johnsen it is important to make employees of the acquired company feel equal in the project group. During the integration process
column59: Mermaid A/S spends a lot of time convincing new staff why they have a future in the company and the project group is in constant dialogue over Skype throughout the process. Since acquisitions have been driven by the technology and skills in the acquired company
column60:
it is also important to keep the employees and their know-how.

\r\n

The support manager (customer support) who was originally working for Acrossmedia remembers a ‘100+100+100-plan’ for the process where the project manager made a plan with milestones and actions for three periods of a hundred days. According to the support manager this made it very clear what would happen.

\r\n

The support manager was completely taken aback when he got the information that Acrossmedia was being sold to Mermaid. At the information meeting he expected to hear something about a new order. At the time of the Swedish acquisition he knew a bit in advance
column61: but not about the Norwegian acquisitions. But he feels no need to know more about the acquisitions before they become a fact
column62:
and he hopes that more acquisitions will come in the near future since he would like to secure his job in Mermaid for many years.

\r\n

In January 2011
column63: after a long period of restructuring events
column64: the top management was split between Henrik Johnsen and co-owner Mads Henrik Hansen (original founder of Victor Soft)
column65:
who is now in charge of operations. In relation to acquisitions Henrik Johnsen now simply delegates a large block called ‘operations’ to Mads Henrik Hansen.

Challenges and constraints of restructuring

One of the challenges for Mermaid is that restructuring has not been a single event but a continuous series of events.

As a former elite handball player
column66: Henrik Johnsen is very focused on creating a hard-working and committed team with strong players in all positions. People need to agree to long workdays and accept that the reward will come later. The formula is simple: workdays from 7 to 18 hours and below average wages (working hours are not regulated by law
column67: but based on agreements with unions and local agreements in each company). This has not caused problems with acquisitions
column68:
since they are often in a weak financial position and used to below average wages. But the turnover in staff is low except for a few sales people who were tempted by considerably higher salary opportunities.

\r\n

However
column69: Mr Johnsen acknowledges that continuous acquisitions and working excessively can wear people out: ‘We don’t relax when we have reached a goal. Some people are getting worn out
column70: and we cannot get the same resources out of our staff that we could before. In the long run
column71: a company cannot be based on people working hard all the time’
column72:
he says.

This is a major reason why Mermaid is now establishing project teams for all major projects in the company. This means that there is a managed process for each project managed by a project group – in acquisition projects with representatives for both organisations. Before that everybody was involved in everything.

Being a larger organisation also means Mermaid can now establish specialist functions with more specialists so they are less dependent on individuals.

Even though Mr Johnsen is concerned about the extra workload for some employees
column73: it does not seem to worry the support manager. From his perspective
column74: the integration of new acquired companies appears to be more a gradual learning process than something that is turning their work upside down. For the support manager
column75:
the integration of a new acquisition has mainly involved learning about new hardware/software and learning a new language (Swedish) to be able to support new customers. Learning about software was in dialogue with the Swedish acquisition and language was learned through a language course. From his perspective the constant growth leads to increased responsibility and continual learning.

\r\n

Even though he finds inspiration in learning about new cultures
column76:
the support manager also emphasises the challenges of integrating different work styles and the difficulty in understanding the subtle details and especially dialects in a different language. Today Mermaid has employed a native Swede in the support function.

\r\n

Of course
column77: the addition of Swedish customers has increased the workload for the support department
column78: but the extra time has been taken from Danish customers. ‘We do what we have to do
column79: but we have to prioritise harder’
column80:
as he says.

\r\n

He also experienced how the willingness to cooperate in acquired companies is important when systems must be integrated
column81: particularly when there is a lot of tacit knowledge in the acquired company that must be passed over. The Swedish subsidiary might have felt that they were being downgraded
column82:
and since the Swedish developers had been laid off they were not able to train the supporters in their system. This was not a problem in Norway since they had a well structured support function and were able to help themselves.

\r\n

Since the support manager was originally employed in one of the first and biggest acquisitions
column83:
Acrossmedia he has also experienced challenges in acquisitions from the acquired company’s side. In the case of Acrossmedia the big challenge was the clash of cultures.

\r\n

Where Mermaid’s history and culture has its roots in production
column84: Acrossmedia was rooted in a partnership between marketing and multimedia skills. Where Acrossmedia was the archetypical creative company with table football as an integrated part of the workday and structure was a swearword
column85:
Mermaid was dominated by engineers and technicians with a more structured approach to business.

\r\n

For the creative staff it was a huge challenge to lose some of the benefits like flexible work hours and loose structure they had in Acrossmedia
column86:
but for people like the support staff it was a blessing to get more structure and better tools. The support manager felt that in the new culture the management was listening to him and took his problems more seriously.

\r\n

From the original staff at Acrossmedia one from the creative staff was laid off after the acquisition and three others decided to leave voluntarily.

\r\n

From the employee perspective it seems like the project organisation of acquisitions has been working well during the recent acquisitions. He attended three or four meetings where everything was planned. However
column87: the project of integrating Acrossmedia seemed to show the limitations of a small organisation. The 100+100+100-plan seemed like a great plan to the support manager
column88: but because people had their everyday operations as well
column89: they sometimes lost focus on the project plan and did not follow up on the planned milestones and actions. Some of the tasks from the first 100 days were passed on into the next 100 days
column90: and the plan for the last 100 days was never really made explicit to the support manager. In general
column91:
he felt the need to know exactly what to do and when – and somebody to ‘knock me in the head more often’ as he says. This has not been a problem in later acquisition projects though.

\r\n

However
column92: with future acquisitions Henrik Johnsen anticipates a more complicated process. Until now
column93: the acquisitions have mainly been about adding new competences. This basically means that all employees in the target company are still needed
column94: but the next acquisitions might very well bring along a more competitive agenda. ‘Now we have it all
column95: so with the next acquisition we have to consider who is holding the best competences’
column96: Henrik Johnsen says
column97:
since the purpose of new acquisitions will mainly be expansion into new markets.

\r\n

It may involve centralisation of functions in the mother company
column98: but if this involves cutting away functions in the Danish mother company there may be a loyalty issue with the original employees who have made sacrifices in the early days. This is still a hypothetical problem though
column99:
and not an issue where Mr Johnsen has experienced specific concerns among employees.

\r\n

Finally
column100: Henrik Johnsen also mentions the access to funding as a challenge
column101:
when you grow through acquisitions. Frequent acquisitions also mean that you regularly have to think about raising money.

\r\n

Restructuring advice and support

\r\n

The Trade Council under the Ministry of Foreign Affairs has conducted market research on new markets for Mermaid. This is a special offer
column102:
where SMEs can get market research in a market of their own choice at half the normal price.

\r\n

Apart from that
column103: Mermaid has not received public advice or support in connection with the acquisitions. However
column104: Mermaid participated in a spinoff-project under the regional business service centre Væksthus Hovedstadsregionen. The purpose of the project was to help a group of companies develop new spinoffs. During this project Mermaid developed a new spin-off project in media sales
column105:
where Mermaid A/S is selling ads on their installed hardware. The spin-off is now integrated as a new business area in the company (not a separate spin-off).

\r\n

Even though Mermaid was entitled to public funding for the project they said ‘no thanks’. Henrik Johnsen reasons that it would be indecent to ask for money when they got a profitable business out of it. If they had wasted their time participating in the project
column106:
they might have asked for the money.

The problem with a state fund is in this case that they are not risking their own money and that decisions are made by a small group of people with no money at stake themselves.

Outcomes of restructuring

The restructuring has required a lot of extra work
column107: but long hours and a good work ethic is part of the culture at Mermaid. Because of the low earnings
column108: wages remained unchanged in 2007–2009
column109:
but better earnings have led to small increases in wages in 2010–2011.

\r\n

Some acquired companies have paid lower wages since they have been struggling
column110: so there has been some harmonisation in wages there to match the general Mermaid level. But in general
column111:
Mermaid is not a leader when it comes to wages.

\r\n

An important part of the mainly intuitive evaluation process of potential acquisitions is the evaluation of the work ethic and whether there is a lavish or a thrifty culture. Cost awareness is an important part of the culture in Mermaid.

\r\n

The acquisitions have not caused layoffs in the mother company
column112: but layoffs of one or two employees have been necessary to improve profitability in some of the acquired companies and some time after the original Victor Soft and Acrossmedia were located at the same address in Aarhus
column113:
two people from the overlapping departments were laid off.

\r\n

Currently
column114: the Norwegian subsidiary is performing as planned and making a small profit
column115: but in 2010 the management was replaced as the subsidiary was not contributing to overall profitability. The Swedish subsidiary is still struggling to make a profit
column116:
but is expected to break even in 2012. Adding recurring revenue to their current installed bases is an important element in this.

\r\n

According to Henrik Johnsen
column117:
it is important for performance to create a sense of equality and mutual respect between colleagues in acquired companies and the mother company.

\r\n

Even though the financial crisis in 2008 stopped the order flow
column118: Mermaid A/S decided to keep the staff and did not lay off any employees because of the crisis. They expected the market to recover and they did not want to let highly skilled people go
column119:
who were too good and important for the future.

\r\n

This period of overcapacity drained the bottom line
column120:
but according to Henrik Johnsen it was important to keep his employees as long as possible.

\r\n

Commentary

\r\n

In Henrik Johnsen’s view
column121: the major difference between restructuring in SMEs and in large corporations is communication. In an SME the communication flow can be much more informal. On the other hand
column122:
you also need to be able to communicate everything and see each other as colleagues.

\r\n

He also thinks that negative restructuring is easier in SMEs. It is easier to ask people to accept a cut in salary – if they get something in return like ownership or bonus.

\r\n

As an owner-manager in an SME it is also easier to be honest with your staff and tell them exactly what the situation is. And since you have been in the boat all the way and have taken your turns
column123:
it is easier to ask people to do the same.

When it comes to disadvantages of being an SME in a restructuring process he points out the access to funding. It is hard to make a long-term investment strategy when you have to raise money continuously.

He also mentions the increasing workload on key employees who literally work day and night. Entrepreneurs need people with a work ethic like themselves.

From the employee perspective the support manager thinks that it is an advantage in an SME that you do not have to involve a lot of middle managers in the restructuring process. You do not have to convert as many people
column124: as he says. On the other hand he sees the lack of capital and resources to move the process forward as the main disadvantage. He also likes the way SMEs can easily bring people together to get to know each other and get the same information. However
column125:
he also finds it important that management is selective when they give information. He does not feel that he needs to know everything.

\r\n

Looking back on the process
column126: Mr Johnsen wishes that he had restructured the top management earlier. The restructuring has made delegating things easier for Henrik Johnsen. ‘If you have key employees you shouldn’t be afraid to give them a share of the company. Then you don’t waste your energy thinking “what if I lose him”’
column127:
Henrik Johnsen reflects.

\r\n

column1:
PAA Baths, Latvia~"PAA Baths Ltd."~"

PAA Baths is a leading Latvian manufacturer of high-quality bathtubs
column2: washbasins
column3: shower trays and bathroom furniture.  Restructuring was triggered by the economic downturn in 2008 when sales decreased by 70% and export levels reached only 40% of the previous year. The company managed to survive and thrive by refocusing its objectives
column4:
acquiring foreign investment capital that allowed it to expand its customer base and diversifying its product range while lowering costs and prices.

"~"

Organisational profile

РАА Ltd was founded in 1993 by three friends – a doctor
column5: a physicist and a carpenter – and is a 100% Latvian-based enterprise. The founders are still the owners of the company and all are active in the management of the firm. The idea behind the foundation of the company was to manufacture a bath using innovative materials
column6: previously used only in aeromechanics. The idea was to create an original
column7: high-quality acrylic bathtub that would be more durable
column8: attractive and practical than baths made from cast-iron. After months of persistent work
column9: encouraged by friends and blessed by good luck
column10: the founders created the first bathtub. In 1996 the technology of cast stone was introduced. At present PAA Baths uses three technologies: acrylic
column11: cast stone
column12: and glass fibre-polyester resin technology and is a leading Latvian manufacturer of bathtubs
column13: washbasins
column14:
shower trays and bathroom furniture for individual orders.

\r\n

The company occupies a unique niche among the wide range of other producers
column15: focusing on serving individual customer needs in product design
column16: size and color. PAA Baths specialises in exclusive production. The firm’s main customers are people interested in expensive
column17:
exclusive products. PAA Baths also offer products for ‘middle range’ customers.

\r\n

PAA Baths has an advantage over competitors
column18:
because the size of the firm gives an opportunity to be flexible (which means that the firm can easily change the variety and assortment of products it produces). Another important advantage is having a plant located near the headquarters of the firm. The company has owned the plant since 1999. This has allowed PAA to be less dependent of the changing situation and costs in a time of economic downturn: many other manufacturers renting their premises were tied to long term contracts based on the ‘high prices of good years’ and thus had limited options but to close their business due to high fixed costs.

\r\n

PAA started exporting to Lithuania and Ukraine in 1999. At present
column19: PAA Baths exports almost 40% of its production to eleven countries: Lithuania
column20: Estonia
column21: Switzerland
column22: Norway
column23: Sweden
column24: UK
column25: Poland
column26: France
column27: Ukraine
column28: Russia
column29: and Belarus. PAA uses two main strategies to enter foreign markets. Firstly
column30: PAA produces under their own brand name and export through different wholesale dealers
column31: sales representatives and joint ventures. Secondly
column32: the firm manufactures shower-trays that are sold under the client’s own brand name
column33:
too.

\r\n

The number of employees has not been not constant during last few years
column34:
due to the 2008–2009 crisis. The main figures are presented below:

  • Maximum number of employees at PAA (mid-2008) – in total 107
column35:
with around 70 at the manufacturing plant;\r\n
  • Minimum number of employees at PAA (mid-2009) – a\r\ntotal of 38
column36:
with 28 in the plant;\r\n
  • Number of employees at PAA at the end of 2011 –65\r\nin total
column37:
with around 50 in the plant;
  • Average age of employees: 30–45 years. In the factory there are also many very young workers.
  • Education: in the office 95% have higher education; in the factory mainly secondary education.
  • Gender: in the office 20% men
column38: 80% women; in the factory\r\n85% men
column39:
15% women.
  • There is no works council in the company.

    • Background to restructuring event

    The major challenges for PAA Bath came with the economic downturn in 2008. As a result of the crisis
column40: sales decreased by 70% and export levels reached only 40% of the previous year. This in turn influenced the company's income levels both on the Latvian market and abroad. Declining demand also led to reducing the number of employees
column41:
from 107 to 38.

\r\n

To overcome these problems
column42: the company decided to change several aspects inside the business. The two key decisions directly related to the restructuring are as follows: reduction of some production lines; and opening a new broad market in western Europe and eastern Asia with Premium-class products. The financial crisis forced PAA to retain only the best-selling products in its product portfolio. At the same time
column43: being focused mainly on high quality and high price segment customers
column44:
PAA was looking for new markets abroad with the intention to expand in this market niche.

\r\n

These two facts in turn implied a focus on even better production quality by PAA
column45: including implementing changes in the management process
column46: but even more importantly in the process of product design and manufacturing. Thus
column47: the main reason for the restructuring process was closely linked with the necessity for technological progress within the company to satisfy the wishes and requirements of potential customers. To do that
column48: new modern equipment had to be considered
column49: the production process optimised
column50:
as well as introducing new types of production that correspond to the high-tech trends in the world.

Restructuring processes

PAA started with an internal restructuring without having a formal restructuring plan
column51: as
column52: according to the company representatives
column53: in such a situation one should react very fast and there is no time for writing plans or other documents. The first decision of PAA was to implement changes with regard to the variety of goods sold. The company stopped the production of three different lines – upper segment products
column54: targeted at high income customers (SKY line)
column55: medium segment products (SUN line) and economy segment products
column56: mainly targeted at budget customers (SEE line) – and introduced a new catalogue which included only the best-selling items. All these decisions reflected changes in consumer preferences and required both understanding and support from employees. Thus
column57: from the very beginning of the restructuring process
column58: the company did their best to inform employees about the forthcoming changes
column59: using informal ways of communication
column60: such as face-to-face conversations with key people
column61: as well as through various meetings devoted to discussing the way changes would be implemented
column62: and information sent via e-mails
column63:
etc.

\r\n

The next decision related to restructuring within PAA Baths was to expand this catalogue with new products that would correspond to emerging customers’ needs. More specifically
column64: PAA increased production using cast stone materials. Cast stone was previously not widely used in the production of bathtubs
column65: yet the costs were lower than the cost of more commonly used materials. During the economic downturn
column66: people are more cautious in their spending
column67: thus by decreasing production costs at the same time as offering a good-quality product
column68:
PAA met the market demand.

\r\n

PAA created several new models: TRE
column69: TRE GRANDE
column70: UNO
column71: and GRANDE. Customers perceived these models to be more appealing and high grade (one of the characteristics of cast stone is to shine)
column72: yet they could be offered at a lower price. As a result
column73:
PAA managed to sell a substantial amount of this product line.

\r\n

As previously
column74: PAA continued to offer good-quality baths with an individual approach to each consumer when it came to choosing colour
column75: size and other features. In sum
column76: PAA aimed at providing customers with an exclusive product. With such a strategy
column77: it was only logical to make the next step and open new markets in western Europe and eastern Asia
column78:
focusing on the upper-class segment.

\r\n

It turned out that customers in these new markets were more interested in quality and design than price. Following this demand
column79: PAA created a new type of production with more fashion design and using more modern materials: the company started using solid surface materials and produced a new line of product. According to the export manager of PAA
column80: Mrs Lipsane: ‘We understood that if we offered the product that we have right now
column81: we would not be competitive and would sell nothing’.  Altogether
column82:
this aspect of the restructuring process that is often labeled as ‘business expansion’ took approximately one year to implement.

Challenges and constraints of restructuring

The main challenges facing PAA related to its operations in the high price and quality segment during the economic downturn. During the crisis customer income decreased. The material and forms for casting were very expensive; that is why the company needed a big turnover to produce new products. When sales were low
column83: however
column84: the company lacked money to buy a new batch of material
column85:
which made serving customers’ needs rather complicated.

\r\n

One of the most important points of restructuring was entering a new market. This was a good opportunity to explore the business
column86: but it implied a lot of risks. To reduce such risks the company had to allocate a person who was responsible for organisational issues
column87: knew the legislation and also the specifics of each market (such as extensive bribing in Post-Soviet countries: this person should know how to deal with such situations). Attracting new
column88: qualified person costs money
column89: and lack of money was indeed a challenge both for PAA
column90:
as well as many other companies in the market.

\r\n

The restructuring process in PAA Baths is ongoing today
column91: one of the reasons being the bankruptcy of one of the Latvian banks: Latvijas Krajbanka (Baltic News Network
column92: 2011). PAA was about to receive a transaction of €10
column93: 000 through Latvijas Krajbanka when the bank went bankrupt
column94: and therefore had major problems with cash: the transaction was made by a customer
column95: yet never reached PAA Baths due to the bankruptcy of the bank. What makes this even more complicated is that PAA had to pay most of this money to its suppliers
column96:
thus the whole process of manufacturing was influenced with this transaction.

\r\n

As acknowledged by the export manager of PAA Baths
column97: the most challenging issue about doing business is uncertainty: ‘…we cannot be sure what will happen tomorrow
column98: and no one is insured against failures’. That is why restructuring processes need planning
column99: but this plan can change depending on external factors like changing market conditions
column100: including changes in supply and demand
column101:
price fluctuations; the political situation at home and abroad; inflation; and the activities of the government.

Restructuring advice and support

The entry into the new market and all other changes in production had to be supported by the technological part of the venture. This issue was solved by participation in the annual competition ‘Prize for export and innovation – 2010’ (organised by the Ministry of Economy of Latvia and the State Agency ‘Latvian Investment and Development Agency’) where PAA Baths won first place in the category ‘Industrial Design’. PAA Baths used this special grant
column102: approximately €300
column104: to change its equipment. This in turn allowed the company to successfully implement the restructuring process
column105: that is
column106: start producing an absolutely new line of products that in turn led both to a more effective manufacturing process and an increase of the workforce. The new equipment (new machines) also allowed the company to produce more output including new types of baths. This is of particular importance since the business expansion aspect of restructuring depends on the production of new
column107: more prestigious varieties of baths
column108: intended to be sold to wealthier clients
column109:
enabling PAA to expand and set up new shops in western Europe and Hong Kong.

\r\n

Also
column110: the Latvian Investment and Development Agency provided the contact and also paid for the work of an American marketing expert
column111: who helps PAA baths. ‘I think that marketing makes up two thirds of our success
column112: therefore the assistance of this American marketing expert is very useful’
column113:
commented Ingura Lipsane. The American marketing expert introduced new features of marketing based on their experience in the USA; it allows the firm to carry out a very successful marketing strategy.

Outcomes of restructuring

One of the most important outcomes of restructuring of PAA was to increase the number of employees from 35 to 65. Indeed
column114: in order to keep up with the increased production that resulted from entering new markets and launching new products
column115: more workers were needed. The good news is that all this has also led to better performance in financial terms. Namely
column116:
the profit forecast for 2012 was higher than for previous years. Restructuring also increased the overall competitiveness of PAA: something that was crucial to simply stay in the market.

\r\n

The restructuring has led to the change in the firm’s main objectives. As explained by the export manager of PAA: ‘At the beginning (of the restructuring) the simple idea of survival in the very difficult market situation was the most important aim.’ Now it has brought a new direction into PAA’s export structure in order to expand in new directions and new (higher) market segments. In sum
column117: currently the key focus is on the continuous development and growth of the company
column118: rather than survival. Yet
column119:
even development plans include recovering from the losses that were made during the peak of the financial crisis.

\r\n

Attracting more foreign investors is another objective set by the company owners after the restructuring process. PAA is looking for investors that could support the purchase of modern equipment
column120: that
column121: in turn
column122: would increase the quality of products
column123:
reduce costs and increase the export share as well as sales in Latvia.

\r\n

As further emphasised by the export manager
column124: the current production still generates substantial cash inflow. Yet
column125: it is expected that soon sales might peak and might not continue to grow. Therefore
column126:
the company has developed the following future plans:

\r\n

Step 1: This step has already started and will continue until mid-2012. It includes creating a new product brand. This brand
column127: or collection to be more specific
column128: is targeted at customers that can pay a premium for the quality. High quality designer Massimo Farinatti has been invited to deal with design issues and thus make the offer as attractive as possible. Apart from developing the brand name and working on the design
column129:
PAA focuses also on improving the manufacturing process within this step.

Step 2: The second step started at the beginning of 2012. The key here is finding a strategic partner and launching a pilot project for strengthening presence in global markets (especially Asia: the company plans to start with Hong Kong). Further plans include western Europe.

Step 3: The third step is to create global brand awareness by participation in trade shows (ISH in Frankfurt; Milan). It is planned to have some results with regards to step 3 by 2013. The main goals are further expansion into global markets.

All these plans are mainly possible because of processes that have already happened. Another outcome of the restructuring process is the usage of new components in the production process. This allowed diversification of the product range
column130: expanding target markets and
column131: importantly
column132: reducing costs and thus also price. Altogether
column133: it led to an increase in the number of employees
column134: which
column135: in turn
column136: required improving human resource management systems within the company. This includes improving the work of the human resource department
column137:
mainly by fostering better communication between management of the company and employees as well as amongst firm employees themselves.

\r\n

All in all
column138: as a result of the restructuring process
column139: PAA Bath was able to make some significant changes that allowed the company to survive the period after the economic downturn in 2008. Even though the company lost a considerable amount of money during that time
column140: it still managed to survive and regain its reputation on both local and foreign markets. This was mainly possible by refocusing objectives
column141: an inflow of foreign investment that allowed searching for prospective clients in western Europe and eastern Asia
column142: and
column143: finally
column144:
through the diversification of the product range at the same time lowering costs and prices.

Commentary

PAA can be considered as quite a unique company. Founded by three friends from scratch
column145: during its best times the company has managed to reach turnover of approximately €4 million (2007). The competitive advantage of PAA compared to other players in the segment is the individual approach to each customer
column146: that is
column147: people can choose the size
column148:
model and color of the baths and other goods offered by PAA.

\r\n

The major reason for restructuring at PAA was the economic downturn. Even though crises are usually perceived negatively (and not without reason)
column149: this one pushed PAA to think in different directions in order to increase its competitiveness both in local markets and abroad. This was achieved by restructuring that
column150: in fact is far from over as the company is constantly facing new challenges
column151: namely
column152: changes in the production process
column153: improved sales and a marketing approach following new objectives
column154: and using new materials. These are all prerequisites to take further steps
column155:
as described above.
