column1:
Technofluid, Belgium~"Technofluid"~"

Company funds and two bank loans of €2 million each were used to fund restructuring by Technofluid
column2: a Belgian firm that originally sold pneumatic and hydraulic equipment. Changes in the company included a new business philosophy and human resource policy
column3: relocation and expansion into a new line of business
column4: photovoltaic solar panels
column5: as well as growing its original area of business. The restructuring spanned the years 2004–2009
column6:
involved regular consultation and ballots of staff and led to substantial growth in turnover.

"~"

Organisational profile

Technofluid S.A. is a company involved in the sale and distribution of wholesale machinery for industry
column7: specifically compressed air production
column8: pneumatic components
column9: instrumentation
column10: hydraulic components and vacuum pumps. In 2009 Technofluid launched a new product line the installation and maintenance of photovoltaic panels
column11: via another company
column12:
Technosun S.A.

\r\n

Technofluid’s and Technosun’s main premises are in the industrial zone of Awans
column13: close to the city of Liege
column14: in the Wallonia Region – the French-speaking part of Belgium. The company also has premises in Wetteren
column15: close to the city of Ghent
column16: Flemish Region
column17: the Dutch-speaking part of Belgium. Moreover
column18: Technofluid has a branch in a sister company
column19: Belgian Instrumentation Products BVBA/SPRL
column20: in Herentals
column21: close to Antwerp
column22:
employing five people.

\r\n

Technofluid was founded in 1968 by Henri Bouhy and his wife. One of their sons
column23:
Jean-Luc Bouhy joined the company in 1986 and became the general manager two years later due to the health problems of his father. Jean-Luc Bouhy is a qualified electromechanical civil engineer and also holds an MBA business degree Haute École de Commerce of Liege.

\r\n

The company is held by a family holding company
column24: Technohold S.A. There are no other firms in Technohold apart from Technofluid and Technosun. Employment figures given below are for both Technofluid and Technosun. The purpose of this corporate structure is to separate the management from the company
column25:
including to ‘professionalise’ it by separating it from family emotions.

\r\n

Until recently Technofluid had approximately 50 employees. With the launch of the photovoltaic panel activities
column26: the company hired approximately 30 additional staff. In 2012
column27: Technofluid /Technosun had 85 employees approximately
column28: including the management. The management is composed of 12 employees
column29: including Jean-Luc Bouhy and his two sons. Most of the workforce has a higher vocational diploma (graduat). Some workers have no diplomas
column30:
but the company has five engineers and a couple of additional employees with a university degree.

The company’s activities are mainly carried out on a local or national basis. The geographical split of the company’s activities is as follows:

  Traditional activities Photovoltaic panels
Local (within a 30-km radius) 20% 80%
National 79% 20%
International 1% 0%

Following the above-mentioned increase of personnel
column31:
Technofluid now meets the legal thresholds under which a company can be obliged to set up a union delegation (delegation syndicale). (Under Belgian law a company employing at least 50 people may be requested by one of the three official trade unions to set up a union delegation.) Social elections are currently (summer 2012) being organised within Technofluid.

\r\n

Since 2005
column32: the average turnover of Technofluid steadily grew from approximately €8 million to €10 million per year. In 2010 and 2011
column33:
turnover increased to €12 million and then to €23 million.

\r\n

The interviewed employee
column34: Anita Rouvrois
column35: has worked at Technofluid for over 30 years. She has a higher vocational diploma in office work and currently holds the position of Administrative Coordinator in the compressed-air department. In the past
column36:
she held a similar position in the pneumatic components department.

Background to restructuring event

The triggering event is a single and unplanned event
column37: namely a moment of insight that the general manager experienced at a seminar on management he attended in 2004. By ‘moment of insight’ it is meant that he understood in a new way what mattered to him in terms of management
column38: that is to run his business in a more ‘human’ way
column39:
with a clear mission statement and clear values shared by everyone and by taking into account the viewpoint of employees and promoting the well-being of everyone. He subsequently found the energy to work on it and implement it. The restructuring that took place within Technofluid is thus not linked to general tendencies on the market and can be traced back to a single moment.

\r\n

The development of photovoltaic panel activities is due to a fortuitous event. Technofluid’s management
column40: wanting a ‘green’ building as new premises
column41:
decided to purchase photovoltaic panels that would cover half of the surface of its roof. The vendor they contacted refused to carry out the job; Technofluid then decided it would do it itself.

\r\n

The general manager was well aware of photovoltaic panels in Belgium back then because he had investigated the sector on behalf of his brother (but not for Technofluid). Indeed
column42: the brother
column43: active in the compressed air dryer sector
column44: was at the time seeking product diversification
column45:
hence the knowledge of Mr Bouhy. The decision to move into photovoltaic could thus be taken quickly.

Restructuring processes

The restructuring event which took place at Technofluid is an internal restructuring
column46: consisting of implementing a new human resource and management policy
column47: which resulted in the development and the launch of a new product line
column48:
namely the installation and maintenance of photovoltaic panels. The restructuring event is thus furthermore a business expansion consisting in the offering of a new product line. It caused the creation of about 30 additional jobs and an increase of turnover of almost 100% in 2011 (from € 12 million in 2010 to € 23 million in 2011).

The restructuring event went on for several years and can be split into several milestones:

(i) Definition of a new course of action for managing the company:

  • 2004 – general manager’s insight during a management seminar.
  • 2004 – definition of the company’s corporate values
column49: by working groups
column50: including the staff. This results in the adoption of\r\na corporate charter containing 10 chapters
column51: on the company’s values such\r\nas ‘team spirit’
column52: ‘respect’
column53: \r\n‘responsibility’
column54: ‘honesty’
column55: ‘dialogue’
column56: \r\nprinciples regarding client management
column57:
and so on.
  • 2004–2006 – coaching sessions and advice for senior management from professionals and consultants.
  • 2006 – launching a human resource policy on the basis of the ‘Investors in People’ international methodology.

    • (ii) Relocation:

    • 2006 – submission of four projects on changes in the management of the company (new location of premises for example) to the vote of the board of directors
column58:
the employees and the suppliers. The project to move premises was rejected by the board of directors but this was followed by a massive vote by employees in favour of the project. It took two additional board meetings to obtain the final decision to relocate premises.
  • 2008 – overwhelming vote by employees in favour of the moving the company to new premises. The board endorses this decision
column59: which\r\nleads to relocation
column60:
still within the Liege Province.

(iii) Activity expansion:

  • 2009 – moving to the industrial zoned area of Awans
column61: which allows for two things
column62: (i) the development of new\r\nactivities requiring more space
column63:
such as large-scale compressed air operations; and (ii) the development of photovoltaic panel activities.

The restructuring event was not planned. Consequently
column64: there was no plan to implement and no record of implementation or adjustments. Moreover
column65:
no other options were considered than the ones mentioned above.

\r\n

The restructuring was funded by two loans from banks
column66:
of €2 million each. These loans financed the acquisition of two new premises and the remainder was funded with the company’s own funds. Mr Bouhy does not specify whether these loans were difficult to obtain or not.

\r\n

Early on
column67: employees were involved throughout the process via regular meetings and votes
column68: including a vote on whether or not to move premises. In total
column69: five staff ballots were organised. Additional meetings with specific teams or categories of employees were also set up. Since 2009
column70:
the management has organised a yearly plenary event where the results of the previous year are explained as well as the course of action for the following year.

\r\n

Ms Rouvrois confirms that employees were involved throughout the restructuring process
column71: as described above. No important decision was taken without prior consultation
column72: and sometimes a vote
column73: of employees. She sees this as positive as she feels employees are not ‘mis devant le fait accompli’ (confronted with already decided issues). She reports that some people gossiped extensively during the restructuring process. This generated fears and uncertainties among workers
column74: which were greatly reduced thanks to the open policy implemented by the management. For instance
column75:
the general manager set up meetings whose purpose was to talk openly about ongoing change. This reduced the amount of rumours.

Challenges and constraints of restructuring

The management faced some issues and challenges during the restructuring process. First
column76: a dispute arose between the general manager and two other directors
column77: a family member and the sales manager. The two directors were systematically opposed to the restructuring event and eventually left the company. The new corporate structure
column78: the creation of a family holding company to separate the family from the day-to-day management of the company
column79: is partly explained by this event. Second
column80:
the general manager suffered from health problems during 2006 and got help from health professionals as well as from management coaches and other professional consultants.

\r\n

Ms Rouvrois confirms that some workers were strongly opposed to the restructuring process but she feels that
column81: globally
column82: the restructuring event was perceived as positive by numerous employees. She certainly sees the restructuring event as positive
column83:
with figures and results ‘speaking for themselves’. She does not see how things could have gone better.

Restructuring advice and support

Financial support

Besides the loan mentioned above
column84:
Technofluid had access to public funds (notably from the Wallonia Region) for training on human resources and management techniques that were implemented throughout the restructuring process. Mr Bouhy explains that these resources were effective as he would probably not have gone through the whole process without this financial support. He does not report any serious difficulty in accessing these support resources at the time.

\r\n

However
column85: one improvement could be to cut down on the administrative burdens that he says could deter managers from using such funds. For instance
column86: Mr Bouhy had to go through a preliminary social audit that was certainly useful but lasted three days and cost him a lot of time
column87:
energy and money.

Non-financial support

Mr Bouhy benefited from numerous non-financial supports
column88:
such as:

  • consultancy services in human resources and management;
  • personal development coaches;
  • services from health professionals
column89:
including doctors;
  • moral support from family and friends.

    • The general manager paid for the first three types of supports mentioned above. He received public funds in support of the services for training on human resources and management techniques. He is satisfied with the price/value ratio of these services.

    Outcomes of restructuring

    The restructuring did not take place according to a pre-defined plan
column90: so it is not possible to say whether it resulted in the planned outcome for the workers and the company. The restructuring event is globally perceived as positive
column91:
taking into account the excellent results that followed it (increase of turnover and of employee numbers).

\r\n

Regarding employment effects
column92:
it should be noted that there was:

  • almost no negative numerical adjustments beside the laying-off of the two directors mentioned above;
  • no working time adjustments;
  • an abolition of the obligation for employees to ‘clock-in’;
  • slightly more significant pay increases than in the past;
  • substantial increases in staff training
column93: in the fields of\r\nICT
column94:
other skills and in personal and professional development. \r\n\r\n

The willingness of the general manager to give more independence and responsibility to employees (such as the removal of the clock-in obligation) should also be noted. At the structural level
column95: this has resulted in the creation of five main departments within the company
column96:
roughly corresponding to the main product categories offered. These departments have more autonomy than in the past. Reporting lines were made more flexible.

\r\n

The company’s management of course had to face employee reluctance
column97: including strong opposition at times
column98: but
column99: as a general rule
column100: the restructuring event was positively welcomed by most employees. A few people left the company
column101: notably at Ghent. The general manager explains these departures by the fact that changes were implemented quickly and within a short time frame. By this
column102: he does not mean that there was not enough time to deal with all the concerns of each employee
column103:
but simply that these people were reluctant to change whereas change occurred within a relatively short time frame.

\r\n

As far as the general manager is concerned personally
column104:
the restructuring event generated positive outcomes regarding his own assets and personal satisfaction.

\r\n

The general manager has plans for the future
column105: notably refining his human resources and management strategy. A human resource director was hired and is based in the Ghent premises. Moreover
column106: the general manager is currently working on his succession and the transfer of power. He also contemplates creating a new corporate structure
column107:
by splitting activities between different independent companies.

\r\n

Ms Rouvrois explained that she personally benefited from the restructuring. Before the restructuring event took place
column108: she was very stressed in her position as administrative coordinator for pneumatic components. She attributes the stress to the short and numerous deadlines she had to face. She explains she could not cope with work and had to work extra hours on a regular basis
column109:
which caused her fatigue and stress.

\r\n

In the context of the ‘human restructuring’ described above
column110: she understood that she too could improve her personal situation within the company so she worked on her problem and explained it to the management. Eventually
column111: she and the management found a solution. Her new position
column112: administrative coordinator for the compressed-air department
column113: causes her less stress as she now has fewer deadlines and works on a longer-term basis
column114:
which suits her personality better.

\r\n

Following the restructuring event
column115: she had access to training that was not available in the past
column116:
notably in ICT and technology.

\r\n

She explains that her relationship with other workers has not changed: it has always been very good. Her relationship with the management improved as the management is now more open to employees’ needs than in the past. She says the restructuring event created a more serene work atmosphere
column117:
in turn increasing productivity. She feels more focused on her work now and expects other colleagues are too. The team spirit has greatly improved.

Commentary

Mr Bouhy believes that large companies are less flexible than SMEs in implementing change. This is notably due to the presence of trade unions that are often reluctant to change. On the other hand
column118: large companies have more technical
column119:
human and/or financial resources for defining and implementing changes.

\r\n

If anything
column120:
Mr Bouhy would have done exactly the same thing 20 years earlier. He recommends administrative simplification for access to public support for SMEs. He views support for ‘investing in people’ as a necessity.

Ms Rouvrois underlines that job saving is more important for managers of SMEs than in larger companies and sees this as positive. She also believes that ‘investing in people’ is easier to implement in small companies than in larger ones.

Author

Cécile Musialski

column1:
Transamerico, Luxembourg~"Transamerico "~"

When the Luxembourg firm Transamerico was split into two firms after the sudden death of its founder
column2: all the decisions related to this had to be taken by his widow. However
column3: she extensively involved the staff
column4: who provided information
column5:
and actively participated by making calculations and providing analysis.

"~"

Organisational profile

Background information on the company

Transamerico is a company registered under Luxembourg law
column6: active in the transport and logistics sector (truck transportation). Transamerico S.A. was created in 1992 by Amérigo De Sousa Fernandes and his wife
column7: Danielle Weber. It started operations on the international freight market and from 1995 onwards it was also operating on the national Luxembourg market. Nowadays
column8: the company also has a vehicle hire business
column9:
mostly trucks and containers.

\r\n

In 2009
column10: following the sudden tragic death of Mr De Sousa
column11:
the company’s activities were split into two different companies:

  • Transamerico Sàrl
column12:
in charge of international\r\ntransport; \r\n
  • Transamerico & Fils S.A.
column13:
in charge of national transport.

The purpose of the split was to separate activities that suffered from international competition – mostly from central-eastern European countries following the 2004 enlargement of the EU – from those which were more profitable: the national activities. Transamerico Sàrl eventually went bankrupt (2010)
column14: so the focus of the family’s activities became national – representing a major reduction in scale
column15: given the small size of Luxembourg (2
column16:
600 sq km).

\r\n

At present
column17: 90% of the activities of Transamerico & Fils S.A. are located in Luxembourg
column18: while the remaining 10% are in the ‘Grande Région’: the area of Saarland
column19: Lorraine
column20: Luxembourg
column21: Rhineland-Palatinate and Wallonia situated between the Rhine
column22: the Moselle
column23:
the Saar and the Meuse rivers.

Transamerico & Fils S.A. currently (spring/summer 2012) employs 23 staff:

  • One manager
column24: who is also the sole owner following Mr\r\nSouza’s death
column25:
Ms Weber; \r\n
  • Two administrative staff: Daniel Marques
column26: Technical\r\nDirector
column27: and Yves Lefebvre
column28:
Operation Director;
  • One mechanic;
  • 19 truck drivers.

    • Ms Weber’s daughters provide support when needed. Transamerico & Fils S.A. qualifies as a company having to organise social elections
column29: so the company currently has one workers’ representative
column30:
Mr Lefebvre.

\r\n

No one at Transamerico holds a university degree. Ms Weber learnt her function ‘on-the-job’
column31: whereas Mr Marques and Lefebvre have a vocational diploma. Truck drivers generally do not hold any diploma or qualifications
column32:
apart from a licence to drive trucks.

\r\n

Since 2005
column33: the performance of the business has decreased. In the three years 2009 to 2011 the turnover of Transamerico & Fils S.A. was stable
column34: oscillating between €2 million and €2.5 million. In 2011
column35:
it was € 2.3 million.

\r\n

Mr Marques
column36: the employee interviewed for the purpose of the present case study
column37: holds a vocational diploma in accounting. He has also undergone a training programme diploma delivered by the Luxembourg Chamber of Commerce for people who want to start their own business. In addition
column38: he has had separate short-term training in transports and logistics. He joined Transamerico in 2007. Before this
column39: he worked as an accountancy clerk in a small tax company in the country. He is currently technical director of the firm. He thus not only deals with the company accounts but also works on diverse tasks
column40: such as the day-to-day management of the firm
column41: including financial analysis of the profitability of trucks and routes. He is not in charge of logistics
column42: maintenance or contacts with clients
column43:
which fall under the responsibility of Mr Lefebvre.

\r\n

The General Manager
column44: Ms Weber
column45: used to be only slightly involved in the company management
column46: which was conducted by her husband
column47: Mr De Souza. However
column48: following Mr De Souza’s death she took over the management of the firm. It took her some time to gather the information necessary to carry out her functions
column49: but thanks to the support of her employees
column50: she eventually gained a full picture of the company’s functioning and took the decision to split the company in two (see above)
column51:
including eventually to refocus activities on national markets.

Background to restructuring event

The event triggering the restructuring process was the sudden death of Mr De Souza
column52:
coupled with increasing competition from central-eastern European countries following the enlargement of the EU in 2004 and sharp increases in oil prices. Trucks that were sent abroad found it increasingly difficult to find a client or a consignment for the homeward trip.

\r\n

The European road freight transport industry used to be dominated by the major economies. However
column53: new Member States experienced substantial increases in their shares of the transport market following accession
column54: with Poland
column55: the Czech Republic
column56: Slovakia and Lithuania serving 40% of the European market following their accession in 2008. With its small size and location at the heart of Western Europe
column57:
Luxembourg has particularly suffered from new Member States’ expansion into the market.

\r\n

The death of Mr De Souza forced Ms Weber to take a deep look into the company’s accounts
column58: with the support of her office staff. The team eventually realised that international activities were getting increasingly worse and were threatening the viability of the whole company
column59:
whereas national activities were still profitable.

Restructuring processes

In order to protect the viable national activities
column60: it was thus decided to split the company’s activities into two separate companies/activities
column61:
with Transamerico Sàrl in charge of international activities and Transamerico & Fils S.A. in charge of local and national activities. The split was done with limited external support: advice from the accountant/auditor of the company and preparation of the legal documents by the law firm of the company. Employees working at the head office of the companies were of course informed of the split during the restructuring process due to their (physical) proximity to Ms Weber. Truck drivers were informed afterwards.

\r\n

The split turned out to be a positive way of managing things
column62: as Transamerico Sàrl eventually went bankrupt in 2010. Since then
column63: Transamerico & Fils S.A. is doing relatively well (constant annual turnover of €2 million to €2.5 million)
column64:
but Ms Weber acknowledges that times are hard and that prospects are not particularly good.

\r\n

Overall
column65: the restructuring process lasted approximately two years. The restructuring was unplanned and did not follow a formal implementation plan. Ms Weber took the final decisions but closely involved her office employees in the process – they actively participated in calculations
column66: analysis of the situation and similar tasks. She sometimes also consulted the truck drivers as well as the mechanic. The employees’ representative
column67: Mr Lefebvre
column68:
was consulted just like any other employee. It appears from this that the workforce was kept aware of the restructuring at all stages.

\r\n

The interviewer got the impression that Transamerico’s staff have formed close bonds
column69: like being part of a family. As Mr De Souza’s death was sudden and shocking
column70:
employees closed ranks in support of Ms Weber and her three children. Everyone was very supportive of her and she in turn acted generously.

Challenges and constraints of restructuring

Ms Weber does not report any specific difficulty
column71: apart from the fact that
column72: for the first six months that followed Mr De Souza’s death
column73: adjustments in daily management of the company were needed (there was difficulty in finding certain information
column74: for example
column75:
and time then was on making up for missing information) as no one in the company had the overview Mr De Souza had had over his business.

Restructuring advice and support

The restructuring was not subject to specific financial support
column76: internal or external. As far as non-financial support is concerned
column77:
Ms Weber benefited mostly from advice from auditors and accountants. These were the regular advisers of the company and Ms Weber did not look for additional external expertise in addition to that already available.

The restructuring was not funded by external resources and in fact the interviewer formed the impression that Transamerico’s management was not aware of any possibility of obtaining external funds.

Outcomes of restructuring

It is not possible to say that the restructuring went according to the initial plan as there was no real plan. The overall outcome of it is mixed. It is positive in that the split of the company in two allowed the viable national activities to be safeguarded. At the same time it is negative as the loss of international activities led to a major decrease in staff numbers
column78: sales and turnover.  However
column79: this last element is not really an outcome of the restructuring as it would have happened anyway
column80: that is
column81:
without the restructuring event properly speaking.

\r\n

As far as staff cuts are concerned
column82: it may be said that major job losses were avoided thanks to the restructuring as mostly voluntary departures and early retirements were necessary
column83:
according to Ms Weber. Only a few dismissals were necessary.

\r\n

Job retention was a major goal of Ms Weber
column84: who has always felt close to her workforce in the SME environment. Over the 2008–2010 period
column85:
one mechanic and 16 truck-drivers left the firm progressively on a voluntary basis. Ms Weber did not reduce salaries so the remaining employees the same income as before restructuring. No special action was taken to support the employees who left the company.

\r\n

Overall
column86: one may say that the general reaction of employees towards restructuring was good. As mentioned above
column87: Transamerico has a kind of ‘family’ atmosphere and everyone has been supportive of Ms Weber and her children
column88:
who really had to go overcome a family tragedy.

\r\n

Mr Marques explains that the first six months that followed Mr De Souza’s death were difficult
column89: as no one in the company had the knowledge that Mr De Souza had of his business. After a period of adjustment
column90: things started to stabilise and work got reorganised. Mr Marques says that the restructuring did not negatively affect the productivity of workers. On the contrary
column91:
employees were really motivated to support the family and Ms Weber.

\r\n

Personally
column92: Mr Marques benefited from the restructuring as he developed and acquired new skills and new functions
column93:
due to a diversification of tasks which would have not occurred without the restructuring event. This increased his self-confidence. He moreover benefited from the experience of the expert auditors and accountants who advised the company during restructuring. Mr Marques believes that all employees were treated fairly during the process.

Commentary

Ms Weber has no particular lessons to draw from the restructuring. She felt she did what she thought was appropriate to do
column94:
with the support of her close employees. This was confirmed by Mr Marques.

Author

Cécile Musialski

Philippe & Partners

Information sources

The present report is based on interviews with Ms Weber and Mr Marques
column96:
as well as on a press article on the circumstances of Mr De Souza’s death.

The restructuring process at Portuguese company Polisport Plásticos was designed primarily to improve the processes and methods of production. The main focus was on developing the skills of employees and technological capabilities
column3: aimed at the involvement of all in the constant innovation process
column4: the sustained decisions and the openness to change
column5:
and afterwards in the innovative capability of the firm.

"~"

Organisational profile

\r\n

Polisport is an international and legally independent company
column6: based in the northern region of Portugal. The company is 100% owned by Polisport SGPS
column7: a holding that is devoted to transforming the industry of plastics for bicycles and motorcycles (NACE 30920) and has a financial capital of €1 million. The group consists of two companies
column8: Polisport and Polinter which operate in the market for bicycle and motor accessories. Both firms are based in the town of Carregosa
column9: in the municipality of Oliveira de Azeméis
column10: and divided into three production units totalling 19
column11: 000 m<sup>2</sup> of covered area
column12: with 160 employees. This case study is about the firm Polisport
column13: with 110 employees in 2012.The company does not have a works council. The main clients are manufacturers of bicycles
column14: motors and motorcycles. The board members include the president of the board of directors (Pedro Araújo)
column15: a member of the board of directors (Maria Araújo) and a representative (Avelino Antão). The company structure is divided into the financial
column16: production/operations
column17: commercial
column18: human resources
column19: purchasing
column20: marketing
column21: IT
column22:
quality and logistics departments.

\r\n

From the very beginning
column23: the company grew by setting high goals and raising them every time. The technologies and production processes applied are: injection moulding
column24: simple injection overlapped extrusion
column25:
blow moulding and thermoforming (moulding vacuum).

\r\n

In 1982
column26: Polisport was created in the form of a society under the name Pedro & Paulo Araújo Plásticos
column27: Lda. and started the production of plastic mudguards. After two years
column29: they went to the first international exhibition that took place in Cologne
column30: Germany. In that year
column31: Polisport started moving beyond Portugal
column32: exporting to the Spanish market. Until 1985
column33:
Polisport devoted itself primarily to the production of plastic components for motorcycles.

\r\n

With the opening of new markets and Portugal joining the EU
column34: Polisport needed to diversify its product range
column35: initiating the production of components for bicycles. In 1989
column36:
Polisport starts its own moulds production.

\r\n

In 2012
column37:
Polisport exported to about 50 countries.

\r\n

In 1998
column38:
the company established the application of the Quality Management System according to NP EN ISO 9002.

\r\n

In 1999
column39: Polisport became a listed company and one year later launched a new set of innovative products and technologies
column40: namely
column41: the DGP technology (Durable Gloss Polypropylene) and the first baby seat for cars. In 2005
column42: the firm decided to create a Research
column43: Technology and Development (RT&D) department. In addition
column44: it also created the Logistics and Marketing departments
column45:
to support the investment in new products and innovative production methods.

\r\n

The RT&D department started to produce innovative outcomes for Polisport that won it the first IMDA Award from the Inmold Decoration Association for Best Injection Mould Part in 2008
column47: the company received two IMDA Awards from the Inmold Decoration Association for Best Injection Mould Part and Best IMD Durable Product. Additionally
column48: Polisport was awarded with an Honourable Mention from COTEC
column49: Portugal‘s national innovation system for companies
column50:
for being one of the most innovative Portuguese SMEs.

\r\n

In 2010
column51: Polisport was recognised as the most innovative Portuguese company by receiving the award of PME Innovation COTEC-BPI and won the Portuguese SME Excellence award. One year after
column52:
the company won two IF Design Awards: product design for Guppy bicycle baby seat and material design for Corky bicycle water bottle.

\r\n

The company has three major own brands – Driver
column53: Polisport and Premier – spread over the five continents. Totally focused on the two wheel business
column54:
Polisport works for both the bicycle and motorbike industry specialising in plastics.

\r\n

The main products for the motorbike market are replica plastics for off-road bikes (enduro
column55: motocross and supermoto) but also headlights
column56: hand protectors
column57:
body protections and other accessories.

\r\n

In the bicycle market
column58: Polisport is the leading European producer of baby-seats
column59: setting the standards for the industry. The range of products also includes mudguards
column60: water bottles
column61:
helmets and other accessories.

\r\n

Background to restructuring event

\r\n

The performance of this SME before the restructuring event was characterised by decreasing sales and turnover. In addition
column62:
they needed to extend the scope of their R&D activities oriented towards internationalisation.

\r\n

The main motivation for the restructuring was based on a fall in turnover
column63: which was mainly caused by the use of non-effective production processes
column64:
the need to diversify for destination markets to sell their final products and the need to reinforce the internal R&D capacity and improve the quality of the portfolio of goods and services.

\r\n

The focus on innovation and development has emerged as a strategic priority
column65: with the emergence of new products
column66: new ideas
column67: new materials
column68: new tools and new processes
column69:
which have led to an increase in the volume of business.

\r\n

Before the restructuring process
column70: Polisport had an ineffective production structure characterised by a lack of technologies to be applied to the injection moulding of thermoplastics with multiple colours
column71:
which was a demand from established clients in international markets

\r\n

Restructuring process

\r\n

The restructuring process was based on a specific restructuring plan targeted at improving the processes and methods of production. It consisted of two main actions: (i) legal restructuring of the company and (ii) the creation of a research
column72:
technology and development department.

\r\n

The change in the legal form enabled the company to acquire an increased bargaining capacity to restructure the RT&D capacity of the company and improve its capacity to innovate. The company was listed on the national stock exchange which created several challenges in terms of accountability of the society and also public dissemination of indicators of the company´s financial performance. This strengthened the company´s capacity for negotiating with banks
column73: in order to access the needed external finance to promote the international expansion of the company and the reorganisation of corporate R&D activities. Secondly
column74: in 2005 the management team created the department of Research
column75:
Technology and Development focusing on innovative activities in terms of R&D.

\r\n

From 99 employees
column76: Polisport has increased its number of employees to 110 and introduced a series of technological innovations in the production processes
column77: such as injection molding
column78: simple injection overlapped extrusion/blow molding and thermoforming (molding vacuum)
column79: the Plastic Decor Plus which allows the decoration of the entire surface of the plastic parts with greater protection and durability
column80: the Inmold Plastic Decals
column81: which enables inmold sticker on the plastic part during injection
column82: the Double Injection
column83:
consisting of two different materials used in the same product and the Durable Gloss Polypropylene.

\r\n

Several changes were introduced at the level of the formal structure of the company
column84: especially at the corporate governance level
column85: by establishing several leaders (some in-house and some new recruitments) for the areas of logistics
column86: production
column87: marketing
column88: sales
column89: human resources
column90: quality
column91: trading and information systems. The company also created several new areas
column92: such as the Research
column93: Technology and Development department
column94:
and through this the need for strengthening the logistics and marketing department also increased.

\r\n

To address this set of R&D challenges (the need to develop a new set of innovative and more effective production processes and technologies) that was part of the restructuring process
column95: the company implemented an open innovation strategy
column96: by fostering R&D cooperation activities with several scientific stakeholders (spin-offs
column97: academies
column98: R&D laboratories
column99: other firms)
column100: identified through collaborative arrangements made possible by joint projects and funding opportunities
column101: licensing patents in the field and opening up to international circuits to explore other innovative channels. In order to get the internal collaborators (workers in the RT&D department) involved in the restructuring process
column102: the firm increased the set of innovation activities
